headline: Kazu Miura and the Never-Ending Soccer Career
abstract: Still going at age 51, the former Japan star represents the possibilities of aging productively in a country with an average life expectancy of 83.8 years.
lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — A typhoon approached. Rain arrived by kickoff. Everyone in the sparse crowd seemed to be wearing a poncho or holding an umbrella.

headline: Overlooked No More: Minnie Mae Freeman Penney, Nebraska’s ‘Fearless Maid’
abstract: In one of America’s deadliest blizzards, a schoolteacher used quick thinking and resourcefulness to save more than a dozen students.
lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we’re adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

headline: F.B.I. Arrests Utah Man in Ricin Scare at Pentagon
abstract: William Clyde Allen III is suspected of sending two envelopes found to contain castor beans, the raw material for ricin.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. on Wednesday arrested a Navy veteran suspected of sending two envelopes to the Pentagon this week that contained raw materials for the deadly poison ricin. The man, William Clyde Allen III, was detained at a home in Logan, Utah.

headline: Is Happy the Elephant Lonely? Free Her, the Bronx Zoo Is Urged
abstract: An animal rights group that seeks to give animals legal rights is suing the Bronx Zoo, saying it should move Happy to an elephant sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: Happy the Asian elephant has been living at the Bronx Zoo for more than 40 years.

headline: Planning to Vote in the November Election? Why Most Americans Probably Won’t
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: This year’s midterms carry enormous political stakes, but if history is any guide, the vast majority of eligible voters will stay home on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, W.Va. — Lula Hill voted in just about every election once she became old enough in 1952. Her coal mining family of registered Democrats believed that elections were like church services: You didn’t skip them.

headline: Oh No, Trump Is Buzzing!
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Repeat three times: This is just a warning.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday we had a Presidential Alert test. Did you hear it? Your cellphone probably started beeping madly. It was just a run-through to make sure you’d get the warning if some terrible disaster was headed your way.

headline: Geoff Emerick, 72, Dies; Recorded the Beatles in Their Prime
abstract: A Grammy Award-winning engineer, he played a key role in the making of “Revolver,” “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” and other important albums.
lead_paragraph: Geoff Emerick, a sound engineer who recorded, among others, the Beatles, helping to shape the band’s ever-evolving music on pivotal albums like “Revolver” and “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” died on Tuesday. He was 72.

headline: The Trump Circus
keywords: ['Identification Devices', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'News and News Media', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The president has latched onto his supporters, and they onto him, in a symbiotic last-ditch shot at survival.
lead_paragraph: It is a scene that has become all too common, and dare I say dangerously close to becoming mundane: Donald Trump said something outrageous at one of his political rallies and his supporters, those hopelessly beguiled by the bully, cheered.

headline: The Top 10 Trends From Fashion Month
abstract: The most famous faces of the ’90s returned to the runways, bike shorts are here to stay — and the beach was every designer’s favorite destination.
lead_paragraph: There was a refreshing shift on the runways this season, and it had little to do with the clothes and everything to do with the casting. While plenty of new faces graced the catwalks as usual, the real surprise was the reappearance of some of the greatest models of the ’90s. Yasmin Le Bon walked at Calvin Klein, Stella Tennant and Georgina Grenville starred at Ferragamo, and Shalom Harlow — who hasn’t set foot on the runway in years — closed Versace (in a floral lace gown and a cloud of her natural ringlets). These women added to the shows a kind of diversity that has been lacking: a range of ages. They also lent strength to the collections, thanks in part to their walks: the powerful, showstopping strides of the original supermodels. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST, style director, women’s, T magazine

headline: The Times Photographers Who Captured the Kavanaugh Hearings
abstract: Erin Schaff’s photos of Christine Blasey Ford, Brett Kavanaugh and Jeff Flake drew attention for their perspective. (She’s used to being the only woman in the room.)
lead_paragraph: Last week, the photographer Erin Schaff received a high-profile assignment from her editor at The New York Times: to shoot the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing in which Christine Blasey Ford would testify that the Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh had sexually assaulted her when they were in high school. Judge Kavanaugh would also testify, emphatically denying the allegation. The night before the hearings, a photographer with The Associated Press told Ms. Schaff, “This is going to be the biggest thing you’ve ever shot.”

headline: David P. Schippers, 88, House Counsel in Clinton Impeachment, Dies
abstract: A Chicago lawyer and a lifelong Democrat, he worked for the Republicans at the behest of his friend Henry Hyde, the House Judiciary Committee chairman.
lead_paragraph: David P. Schippers Jr., who served as chief investigative counsel for the House Judiciary Committee during the impeachment of President Bill Clinton in 1998, died on Friday at his home in Grayslake, Ill. He was 88.

headline: No Exit: Refugees Trapped in a Squalid Greek Camp
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: Camp Moria, on the Greek island of Lesbos, is a visible reminder of Europe’s hardening stance toward migrants.
lead_paragraph: It may seem paradoxical that while the number of migrants arriving in Europe has fallen by 90 percent from its 2015 peak, the refugee camp on the Greek island of Lesbos has grown into an unspeakable hell, where asylum seekers are driven to madness and suicide. Sadly, the horror of Camp Moria described by Patrick Kingsley of The Times this week is the price of the actions that have stemmed the flow of refugees.

headline: South Carolina Shooting Kills One Officer and Wounds 6 Others
abstract: The episode in Florence, S.C., was punctuated by evacuations in a tactical vehicle and a protracted standoff between a barricaded suspect and the authorities.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Seven law enforcement officers were shot — at least one of them fatally — in an extraordinary barrage of firepower after the authorities sought to serve a search warrant in South Carolina on Wednesday, officials said, transforming a residential subdivision into a tragic battleground.

headline: An Icon or Insensitive Relic? Prospector Pete Is on Its Way Out
abstract: For Native American students and activists at Cal State Long Beach, the removal of the campus statue is long overdue.
lead_paragraph: Towering over the courtyard at California State University, Long Beach, is the barrel-chested statue of Prospector Pete, the epitome of the rugged 49ers who came to the state looking for gold and land.

headline: With a Transformed Judiciary in Sight, McConnell ‘Will Not Be Intimidated’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: But Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, knows he may take the blame from President Trump and conservatives if the Senate does not confirm Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell had just arrived at Reagan Washington National Airport on Monday afternoon to resume the battle over the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh when he was met by an unwelcoming committee — a group of women who angrily confronted him.

headline: Protesters Ask McConnell: ‘Do You Always Turn Your Back on Women Like This?’
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', '#MeToo Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell was followed and questioned by a group of women about sexual assault victims at Reagan Washington National Airport on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell was followed and questioned by a group of women about sexual assault victims at Reagan Washington National Airport on Monday.

headline: Stranded for Months at Malaysia Airport, a Syrian Refugee Is Arrested
abstract: Since March, Hassan al-Kontar has been camped out in the terminal at Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia.
lead_paragraph: For seven months, Hassan al-Kontar, a Syrian refugee, has been posting videos to social media documenting his life stranded at the Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia.

headline: The Forgotten Lessons of Black Hawk Down
abstract: The disaster in Somalia offered America a glimpse of the future of warfare. No one listened.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-five years ago this week, a Somali warlord named Mohammed Farah Aidid offered the American military a glimpse of its future. But neither policymakers back in Washington nor commanders in the field were attuned to what he had on offer.

headline: In Risky Shift, Trump and G.O.P. Directly Assail Christine Blasey Ford
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', '#MeToo Movement']
abstract: After weeks of not directly attacking Christine Blasey Ford, the president and his Republican allies have embarked on a more aggressive effort to challenge her credibility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than two weeks he held back. Against all his instincts, President Trump for the most part resisted directly attacking the woman whose sexual assault allegation has jeopardized his Supreme Court nomination. The accuser was to be treated with kid gloves, like “a Fabergé egg,” as one adviser put it.

headline: Teenagers Were Moved Off Rikers for Safety. Their Brawls Came, Too.
keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Gangs', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Twenty correction officers were hurt on Wednesday during a fight between rival gang members who were moved from Rikers Island to Horizon Juvenile Center.
lead_paragraph: When the city moved its youngest inmates from Rikers Island to a juvenile detention center last week, the goal was to shield them from the violence of the adult jail and place them in an age-appropriate setting, as required under a new state law.

headline: Supreme Court Battle Lines
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', '#MeToo Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A vigil was held in Brooklyn on Wednesday to protest Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Americans are forming seemingly irreconcilable camps around the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to a seat on the Supreme Court. Christine Blasey Ford, a California research psychologist, testified in searing detail before the Senate Judiciary Committee last week that Judge Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her when they were teenagers. Judge Kavanaugh angrily and emotionally denied her accusations, and President Trump, at a rally in Mississippi Tuesday evening, mocked Dr. Blasey for gaps in her memory of the episode. The nomination has become a touchstone of the #MeToo movement, a vivid reminder of the deep chasm between men’s and women’s lived experience of sex and power. Many opponents of Judge Kavanaugh’s confirmation have taken to the streets to express their anger and solidarity, including, as shown, on Wednesday in Brooklyn.

headline: Review: Wrestling With a Master in ‘On Beckett’
abstract: Bill Irwin blurs the lines between clown and dramatic actor in an insightful anatomy of the works of Samuel Beckett.
lead_paragraph: When Bill Irwin talks about how the language of Samuel Beckett “has gone viral,” he becomes a walking, writhing index of a contagion’s symptoms. This is a grave and incurable condition in which the human body is at war with itself, its mind and the inescapable forces of gravity.

headline: Profundity
abstract: Joon Pahk just wants to teach the world to sign.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE —  Joon Pahk returns after a three-year absence from the Times puzzle with a deeply philosophical, trenchant grid that will move you to tears, or at least to call your loved ones and reconnect, because life is just so, so short …

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Toughest Corner in the Bronx
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 4, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “There were a lot of things being said about my mother that day, a lot of it bad stuff and depressing. But the best one was ‘Hey, Canha, your mother’s meatballs aren’t that good.’ ”

headline: Corrections: October 4, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, October 4, 2018.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Pence Speech to String Together a Narrative of Chinese Aggression
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Vice President Mike Pence, in a speech on Thursday, is expected to say that “China wants a different American president,” according to excerpts from the speech released Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence will signal a far tougher American line on China on Thursday, delivering a speech in which he is expected to accuse the Chinese of aggressive moves against American warships, of predatory behavior against their neighbors, and of a sophisticated influence campaign to tilt the midterms and 2020 elections against President Trump.

headline: A Tragedy in the Tattoo Parlor
abstract: The story of Freddy Negrete and his sons.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Now that pop stars routinely fly their favorite ink masters around the world for personal appointments and stockbrokers plunk down thousands of dollars to get the Wall Street bull etched on their arms, it can be easy to forget the days when tattoos were still considered outlaw art.

headline: Red Ball
abstract: What story could this image tell?

headline: Yankees Blast Away Nerves, and the A’s, for a Wild-Card Win
abstract: Aaron Judge’s first-inning homer set the tone, and Luis Severino steadied the Yankees early as they cruised past the A’s and into a showdown with the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees have had two months, ever since they were swept at Fenway Park in early August, to come to terms with a reality that could have left their palms quite sweaty: that their World Series ambitions would begin with nine innings of unpredictable, win-or-go-home baseball.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Dheepan’ and ‘Deadpool’
abstract: Jacques Audiard’s Palme d’Or-winning immigration tale is on Hulu. And “Deadpool” airs on FX.
lead_paragraph: Jacques Audiard’s Palme d’Or-winning emigration tale is on Hulu. And “Deadpool” is on FX.

headline: Why Is Eastern Germany So Far Right?
abstract: Almost 30 years after reunification, the former Communist region is now home to right-wing extremism.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — On. Oct. 3, Germans celebrated Reunification Day, the moment when, 28 years ago, the former East and West Germany became one nation again. And yet this year, instead of celebrating our unity, there is a growing sense of estrangement. East and west are drifting apart again.

headline: Indonesia, Brett Kavanaugh, Iran: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Judge Blocks Trump Administration From Ending Some Immigrant Protections
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The decision temporarily relieves more than 300,000 immigrants from El Salvador, Haiti, Nicaragua and Sudan from the threat of deportation.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in San Francisco blocked the Trump administration from ending special protections for immigrants from four countries devastated by war and natural disaster, temporarily relieving more than 300,000 people from the threat of deportation.

headline: Fuzzy Thinking: Artist-Designed Rugs
abstract: You might think an artist named Christopher Wool was destined to design rugs, but what about the rest of his peers?
lead_paragraph: As the line between art and design becomes increasingly blurry, one type of product is emerging as fertile turf for cross-disciplinary collaboration: rugs by artists.

headline: Advice for Renovating Your Home
abstract: On wheelchair-friendly ovens, four-poster beds, new rooms for soaking tubs and dramatic wallpaper.
lead_paragraph: This column is part of a series for the Design special report of The New York Times. Readers are invited to send questions to designadvice@nytimes.com.

headline: Trends in Design and Home Furnishings
abstract: From lava lights to vinyl wallpaper to role that lights in the dark, a look at what’s making news now.
lead_paragraph: When a news release announced that kitchen rugs were the latest home design trend, some were skeptical. After all, it’s hard enough keeping kitchen floors clean without an add-on that harbors pet hair and cooking splatters.

headline: He Suspects Mr. Moose in the Forest With Incisors
abstract: A forensic ecologist reads the landscape for clues about what grew or grazed on it centuries ago.
lead_paragraph: The tendrils of Tom Wessels’ white beard quiver when he grows animated while prowling forests and meadows. He does this for a living. Throughout his native New England, Mr. Wessels, an ecologist, tells current stewards of the land how previous users corralled livestock, hauled rocks out of plows’ way and harvested timber and crops. He estimates the dates of insect infestations on saplings that have recovered, and hurricanes that toppled tree trunks now carpeted in ferns.

headline: A Design Tour From Your Armchair
abstract: For those with lingering wanderlust this fall, six coffee table books offer adventurous design from around the world.
lead_paragraph: By October, fallen leaves and unforgiving work schedules can make summer seem like a sun-soaked fantasy. For those with lingering wanderlust, there’s no need to putter farther than your living room. These six coffee table books put adventurous design from global destinations right into your lap.

headline: The Boswell of Beverly Hills: A Historian of Homes
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: David Silverman has created an unlikely career as the author of books about the homes of the famous in Los Angeles
lead_paragraph: David Silverman had discovered a gold nugget. It came in the form of party notes kept by Edie Goetz, the late Hollywood socialite and hostess. There in the handwriting of the daughter of Louis B. Mayer were the names of famous guests (Mr. and Mrs. James Stewart; Miss Olivia de Havilland), the food served (suckling pig; potage Saint-Germain) and the movies screened (on Jan. 15, 1983, “Gandhi”) at dinner parties dating back to the 1940s.

headline: In Williamsburg, Designing for Work-Life Balance
abstract: In 2005, the artist Tara Donovan bought a garage in Brooklyn. She has lived there ever since, making a few tweaks along the way.
lead_paragraph: Polished-brass pendants dangle in the walnut-paneled sunken lounge. Low-slung sectional sofas flaunt plum-colored upholstery. A flame in a cone-shaped metal fireplace ignites with a turn of a knob.

headline: Word + Quiz: vitiate
abstract: This word has appeared in seven articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: On Politics: Republicans Condemn Trump’s Mockery of Kavanaugh Accuser
abstract: Three senators who could decide Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court confirmation denounced President Trump’s taunts against a woman who accused the judge of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: France Lifts the Lid on Its Algeria War
keywords: ['Algerian War (1954-62)', 'Torture', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: More than half a century later, a French president has acknowledged his country’s responsibility for the brutality of a colonial war.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On June 11, 1957, at 11 p.m., French soldiers burst into Maurice Audin’s apartment in Algiers. Mr. Audin, a 25-year-old mathematician, just had time to tell his wife, Josette, “Take care of the children” before being marched down the staircase by two paratroopers.

headline: Learning With: ‘The Confidence Gap for Girls: 5 Tips for Parents of Tween and Teen Girls’
abstract: Why should girls this age have in their lives a “regular helping of risk, and the failure that comes with it”?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Six Malaysian Firefighters Drown While Searching for Boy in Pond
abstract: Heavy rain drove strong currents through an old mining site, leading to one of the worst disasters ever for the country’s rescue services.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The firefighters rushed to the disused mine outside Malaysia’s capital in a steady rain Wednesday evening, searching for a teenager who had slipped into a pond. The rescue effort quickly turned into one of the worst disasters the country’s emergency services have ever experienced, with six firefighters drowning in the dark, rushing waters, officials said Thursday.

headline: Should Ex-Felons Have the Right to Vote?
abstract: How important is the right to vote to a democracy? How does the ability to vote affect individuals and communities?
lead_paragraph: Most states restrict the voting rights of former felons to some degree, and an estimated six million people nationwide are barred from voting because of felony convictions.

headline: Dreamlike Photos of Sweden’s Dark Winter
abstract: When Lars Tunbjork accepted an assignment to create his own portrait of winter in Sweden, he attempted to confront the emotional darkness he associated with it.
lead_paragraph: Lars Tunbjork always dreaded winter’s arrival in Sweden.

headline: The ‘Flight of the Conchords’ Special That Almost Wasn’t
abstract: The musical comedians Bret McKenzie and Jemaine Clement discuss preparing for their HBO special and how it was nearly derailed by an 11th-hour injury.
lead_paragraph: How hard could it be to get Flight of the Conchords together for a single show? After all, this comedic folk-rock band consists entirely of Jemaine Clement and Bret McKenzie, longtime friends from their college days at New Zealand’s Victoria University of Wellington, who hoped their satirical songs and deadpan banter would someday propel them far beyond the bar scene.

headline: The Only Hollywood Abuser I Want to Hear From Is a Horse
abstract: In a TV season filled with very special #MeToo episodes, a few standout shows like “BoJack Horseman” commit to telling a bigger story.
lead_paragraph: The reckoning has come for BoJack Horseman. Netflix’s washed-up Hollywood star has recklessly abused his power for four seasons: harassing his ghostwriter, goading his sober co-star into a bender that kills her, coming on to a friend’s teenage daughter.

headline: Review: ‘Private Life,’ a Piquant Look at a Couple’s Campaign to Conceive
abstract: Kathryn Hahn and Paul Giamatti star in Tamara Jenkins’s perfect new comedy.
lead_paragraph: Rachel is a writer whose new novel is about to be published. Her husband, Richard, used to run an experimental theater and now, without undue sourness, runs an artisanal pickle company. The couple live in a cluttered, cozy apartment on an East Village block not yet overrun by money. They are literate, witty people (played by Kathryn Hahn and Paul Giamatti) who might rather be smart than nice but are generally pretty nice anyway, even to each other. Their mutual prickliness is a sign of long intimacy, as if they were two cut-to-match pieces of sandpaper. Over the years of their relationship — he’s 47, she’s about a half-decade younger — neither one has been too badly scraped up or smoothed out by the other.

headline: My Human Doctor
abstract: Medical school teaches us to examine, to research, to treat. We don’t learn to err and recover.
lead_paragraph: The needles go under the skin, into a layer of fat. Three times per week, for over a decade, Shirley had taken one of the pre-filled syringes from her refrigerator and injected her thighs. Then I met her.

headline: Trump Tax Law Is Back to Haunt House Republicans in Key Races
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (2017)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Suburbs']
abstract: The House vote making the tax law permanent, including the SALT cap, has given Democrats a hot-button issue for close races around the country.
lead_paragraph: When President Trump’s tax law passed last year, Republicans in many high-tax districts faced a revolt over a key provision — a $10,000 cap on the federal deduction for state and local taxes, known as SALT.

headline: New Sentences: From ‘American Vandal’
abstract: Investigating the behavior of teenagers has become a much more pressing activity than this TV show anticipated.
lead_paragraph: — From “#2,” the second episode of the second season of “American Vandal” (Netflix, Sept. 14, 2018), written by Dan Lagana.

headline: 36 Hours in Nashville
abstract: Flourishing art and food scenes, and musical venues that celebrate new voices are just a few of the reasons to visit this ever-evolving city.
lead_paragraph: Nashville has undergone a number of iterations in recent decades, from its longstanding position as the “home of country music” to its boozier, fun cousin “Nashvegas” to its most recent as home to one of the fastest-growing foreign-born populations in the United States (not to mention the country’s No. 1 destination for bachelorette parties). Tourism aside, Nashville lures those wanting the cultural heft of larger cities on the coasts without the price tag. Behind the swell of newcomers are the expected bonuses: flourishing restaurant and art scenes, and a new crop of gleaming hotels that have brought with them performance spaces and rooftop bars.

headline: Seven Chef-Led Food Tours That Explore Cuisine and Culture at the Same Time
abstract: There are few better ways to learn about the culture of your destination than to explore its cuisine, and these new food tours, led by accomplished chefs, will help you embrace both.
lead_paragraph: Food tourism is on the rise, prompting tour companies and cruise lines to cater to traveling food lovers with culinary experiences led by working chefs — on land and at sea.

headline: Estranged in America: Both Sides Feel Lost and Left Out
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Nearly half of Democrats say they feel this way, slightly more than Republicans.
lead_paragraph: In the 2016 election, Donald J. Trump tapped into a sentiment strongly held by white working-class voters that America had changed so much around them that they felt estranged in their own country.

headline: How I Trained My Husband to Be a Dad
abstract: It required two things that don’t come naturally to me: acting helpless and asking for help.
lead_paragraph: Nick was trying to cut a piece of squid with a butter knife in his right hand as he rocked our baby to sleep with his left while seated in a self-consciously hip tapas joint during a recent family vacation in Spain.

headline: A White Mob Once Destroyed a Black Neighborhood in Tulsa. The City Wants to Find the Graves.
abstract: The city’s mayor said he would reopen the investigation into the aftermath of the attack, which destroyed black-owned businesses and left hundreds of people dead.
lead_paragraph: A white mob rampaged through a wealthy black business district in Tulsa, Okla., in 1921, in a spate of violence that destroyed more than 1,200 homes and left up to 300 people dead.

headline: Ben Fountain Takes a Tour Through Our Current Existential Crisis
abstract: In his new book, “Beautiful Country Burn Again,” the author of “Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk” turns to the state of our politics in the age of Trump.
lead_paragraph: BEAUTIFUL COUNTRY BURN AGAINDemocracy, Rebellion, and RevolutionBy Ben Fountain433 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

headline: Mia Love, Sole Black Republican Woman in Congress, Fights for Her Seat
abstract: Ben McAdams supporters see him riding a blue wave into Washington, but Ms. Love and her supporters are not convinced.
lead_paragraph: MILLCREEK, Utah — Ben McAdams, a candidate for Congress, was speed-walking along the highway shoulder in his business suit, safety and common sense be damned.

headline: In Italy, ‘Al Dente’ Is Prized. In Taiwan, It’s All About Food That’s ‘Q.’
abstract: In Taiwan, “Q” texture refers to cuisine that is “springy, soft, elastic,” usually found in foods with some kind of starch like noodles or tapioca pearls.
lead_paragraph: NEW TAIPEI CITY, Taiwan — As dusk falls at Lehua Night Market, the fluorescent lights flicker on and the hungry customers start trickling in, anxious for a taste of the local delicacies that give this island its reputation as one of Asia’s finest culinary capitals.

headline: Andre Dubus III: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of the novel “Gone So Long” is moved by compassion in literature: “The sense that the writer is not poking fun at his or her characters, but instead is genuinely curious about their lives.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of the novel “Gone So Long” is moved by compassion in literature: “The sense that the writer is not poking fun at his or her characters, but instead is genuinely curious about their lives.”

headline: ‘God Was on Vacation’: A Visit With a Long-Lost Cousin in Romania Is a Holocaust Lesson
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Iancu Zuckerman is 95 and the host of a classical music show in Bucharest. But in 1941 he was marched through the streets of Iasi, a center of anti-Semitism. The specters are still there.
lead_paragraph: I had thought I was the last male Zuckerman in our family. Zuckerman is a fairly common Jewish name (see Pinchas, the Philip Roth character, my orthopedic surgeon), but my own family for the last few generations has produced an abundance of daughters, whose children inherited their fathers’ last names.

headline: Macron, With Popularity Slumping, Tries Tax Cuts for France’s Working Class
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Taxation', 'Income Inequality', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: As polls numbers drop, President Emmanuel Macron promises benefits for middle- and low-income earners and tells investors he won’t halt economic reforms.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As President Emmanuel Macron presses ahead with the most business-friendly overhaul of the French labor market in decades, his popularity with many of his countrymen has gone into a tailspin. Consumer confidence is falling. A nascent recovery is cooling off. Unemployment has been stuck above 9 percent for months.

headline: Yuki Kawauchi Is Distance Running’s Elite Oddball
abstract: Kawauchi, the Boston Marathon winner, is known as Citizen Runner and combines racing with a government job. He is about to compete in his ninth marathon of the year. Most top runners do two.
lead_paragraph: KUKI, Japan — Even from two blocks away the stride was familiar — muscular, insistent, arms low and wide — and the runner could be only one person, Yuki Kawauchi, improbable winner of the 2018 Boston Marathon, hamburger connoisseur and fastest man in a panda costume.

headline: Driven by South’s Past, Black Women Seek Votes and a New Future
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Voting and Voters', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Mobilized by the nation’s divisions on race and Donald Trump’s presidency, black women are using networks forged in segregation to turn out voters this fall.
lead_paragraph: AMERICUS, Ga. — Lorena Barnum Sabbs thought the past really was past. Born 67 years ago in a segregated hospital, she was arrested when she was 11 for trying to integrate the local movie theater and locked in a stockade for several days without beds, working toilets or running water. Later, as one of the first black girls to attend the formerly whites-only high school, she ventured to the bathroom only in groups for fear of attacks.

headline: They Moved to Queens, and Brought the Neighbors With Them
abstract: It took years, and a special friendship, to find the ideal two-family home in Ridgewood.
lead_paragraph: Shaylin Clay and Wyatt Wolfram were both in the class of 2009 at Syracuse University, but they didn’t meet until after graduation, through mutual friends.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Doesn’t Think We Need the New Presidential Alert System
abstract: Kimmel said, “I already get terrifying presidential alerts on my phone — they’re called the news. They come every day.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', '#MeToo Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How the agency’s findings could affect the confirmation vote on the Supreme Court nominee, and why the tone of the controversy has shifted.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: New York Today: A Dispatch From New Jersey
abstract: Thursday: A key battleground in the midterm elections, and an exhibition of courtroom art.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this still-summery Thursday.

headline: For Once, I’m Grateful for Trump
abstract: In the president, one big bully stands up to others.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since Donald Trump entered the political fray, I find myself grateful that he’s in it. I’m reluctant to admit it and astonished to say it, especially since the president mocked Christine Blasey Ford in his ugly and gratuitous way at a rally on Tuesday. Perhaps it’s worth unpacking this admission for those who might be equally astonished to read it.

headline: Machiavelli Would Have Loved This Year’s Midterms
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Trump may not be on the ballot, but he will be on everyone’s mind.
lead_paragraph: The stakes — already sky-high — for both the Trump administration and the Democratic Party in the coming congressional elections have been raised even higher by the struggle over the Supreme Court nomination of Brett Kavanaugh.

headline: How to Make Trump-Style Wealth Pay Its Fair Share
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: Congress has a variety of tools for blocking tax cheats. It should use them.
lead_paragraph: We always knew President Trump was being misleading when he portrayed himself as a self-made man. But until Tuesday’s bombshell Times story, we did not know the breathtaking scale of the deception, or the extent to which his wealth was built on tax evasion.

headline: For Naomi Watts, Art Is Like a Tattoo. She Explains How.
abstract: As a trophy of success, art endures, while an extravagant dress could fray and a piece of jewelry may be lost, Ms. Watts says.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Watts — whose work includes such varied films as “King Kong,” “The Ring” and “Diana” — will be the first to tell you she is no big-league collector. She also does not buy in bulk, having purchased just 20 pieces since 2011. And while she once spent nearly $100,000 on a painting, even that is inexpensive compared with the multimillions circulating at the highest levels of the collecting world.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Meet Our 2018 Conference Speakers
abstract: Sundar Pichai, Mary Barra, Peter Thiel, and Lloyd Blankfein are among the lineup for our seventh annual conference in November.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. Want this by email? Sign up here.

headline: Heavyweights on the Undercard: Get Ready for Yankees-Red Sox
abstract: The storied rivals will play the first division series between 100-win teams.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a first-round playoff series quite like this. A division series matchup between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox is like an undercard with Ali and Frazier. They are heavyweights with a history.

headline: Rufus Wainwright’s First Opera Was ‘a Nightmare.’ He’s Trying Again.
abstract: “Hadrian,” opening on Oct. 13 in Toronto and about a gay relationship in ancient Rome, benefited from the criticism of “Prima Donna.”
lead_paragraph: VERBIER, Switzerland — Rufus Wainwright’s eyes filled with tears. He stood quietly, one hand marking time, as the rich voice of the baritone Thomas Hampson filled a rehearsal room looking out onto snow-capped mountain peaks here.

headline: Review: ‘Shine’ Puts the Focus on Salsa Dancing in Spanish Harlem
abstract: The movie focuses on two estranged brothers who are at odds, until they head out on the dance floor.
lead_paragraph: A big heart and a blunt plot run through “Shine,” a movie whose story is there mostly just to usher in a dance sequence or an earnest speech.

headline: Review: ‘Trouble’ in Vermont, as Two Siblings Fight for Land
abstract: Anjelica Huston and Bill Pullman play feuding siblings in this dull comedy.
lead_paragraph: A great many indignities are heaped on Bill Pullman’s character, Ben, in “Trouble,” including pneumonia, a collapsed lung and a bullet to the chest. This last is delivered by his sister, Maggie (Anjelica Huston), though she’s not the only relative who wishes him ill: another tries to smother him with a pillow. Family, it seems, is not Ben’s forte.

headline: Review: In ‘Wobble Palace,’ a Relationship Hangs by a Stringy Toupee
abstract: The movie is a sendup of broke-artist types that shimmers with abashed affection.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t often that a hairstyle becomes the conduit for a film’s soul. In “Wobble Palace,” a comedy that centers on the trials of try-hard millennials, Eugene (Eugene Kotlyarenko) and Jane (Dasha Nekrasova) are a couple in the death throes of their relationship. They see other people, but they haven’t broken up because neither wants to move out of the apartment they share in downtown Los Angeles — an art-freak crash pad with AstroTurf carpets and curtains printed to look like a crowded Windows desktop, complete with the ubiquitous grassy knoll.

headline: Review: ‘A Crooked Somebody’ Finds a Con Man Caught Up in His Own Plan
abstract: This thriller follows an opportunistic psychic who furthers his career with the help of a murderer.
lead_paragraph: Often uncomfortable and all the better for it, “A Crooked Somebody” doesn’t mind watching its characters squirm a little. That’s tough for them but good for us in this highly enjoyable thriller.

headline: Review: In ‘Await Further Instructions,’ a Family Home Becomes a Battleground
abstract: A British family turns on itself when a mysterious substance seals its home in this genuinely upsetting horror-sci-fi hybrid.
lead_paragraph: Toxic patriarchy and all-access paranoia flourish in “Await Further Instructions,” Johnny Kevorkian’s genuinely upsetting, supremely British horror-sci-fi hybrid.

headline: Review: In ‘Viking Destiny,’ a Warrior Princess Reclaims Her Throne
abstract: This low-budget Nordic caper is about a Viking princess and her stolen throne.
lead_paragraph: See Terence Stamp declaim from beneath a mothy blanket, then disappear in a puff of smoke! See a metal-caged severed head swing from a chain like a gruesome tea ball! These dubious pleasures and more await in “Viking Destiny,” a bit of low-budget Nordic nonsense that only makes you appreciate the visual finesse and rowdy discipline of the History channel’s “Vikings.” Pillaging done right is nothing to sniff at.

headline: Review: ‘Above and Beyond,’ a Heartening Salute to NASA
abstract: Rory Kennedy’s new documentary is an informative chronicle of American achievements in space.
lead_paragraph: The director Rory Kennedy has a personal connection to the subject of her latest documentary. “Above and Beyond: NASA’s Journey to Tomorrow” is a 60th-anniversary celebration of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration — NASA, that is. While the agency was founded during the Eisenhower administration, it was President John F. Kennedy, Ms. Kennedy’s uncle (the filmmaker is the daughter of Robert and Ethel Kennedy), who defined NASA’s mission for the better part of a generation by instructing it to set its sights on a manned mission to Earth’s moon.

headline: Review: Against the Odds, ‘Studio 54’ Sheds Light on the Club
abstract: The documentary is at its best when focused on Ian Schrager, one of the founders, who hasn’t shared his side of the story in such depth before.
lead_paragraph: Does the world really need another cinematic retrospective on New York night life in the late 1970s? Depends on whom you ask. I went in to “Studio 54,” a new documentary directed by Matt Tyrnauer, thinking definitely not.

headline: Review: In ‘Bayou Caviar,’ the Main Course Is a Cold-Blooded Noir
abstract: A Russian gangster, a blackmail scheme and some hungry alligators in the directorial debut of Cuba Gooding Jr.
lead_paragraph: The title “Bayou Caviar” refers to the preferred body disposal method of a Russian gangster (Richard Dreyfuss) in New Orleans, where it’s easy to keep alligators who love a fleshy snack. That disgusting conceit provides a fitting central image for the movie, a cold-blooded noir in which the overarching question is which chumps will become chum, literal or metaphorical.

headline: Review: In ‘Wajib,’ a Father and Son Trek Through Nazareth
abstract: The writer-director Annemarie Jacir adds quiet warmth to the story of a strained but loving relationship in a Christian Palestinian community.
lead_paragraph: There’s a quiet warmth that runs like a current through “Wajib,” a new film from the Palestinian director and writer Annemarie Jacir. The title is Arabic for “duty,” and here the obligation is shared by father and son. Abu Shadi, an aging divorcee living in a Christian Palestinian community in Nazareth, is driving around his neighborhood and its outskirts all day at the beginning of the Christmas season — he’s got “Jingle Bells” as his phone’s ringtone — hand-delivering invitations to his daughter’s wedding. With him is his son, Shadi, an architect who now makes his home in Rome.

headline: The A’s Tried Baseball’s Hot New Tactic, but the Yankees Foiled It
abstract: Bringing in an “opener” to briefly start the game did not work for Oakland.
lead_paragraph: In the quiet aftermath of a lopsided defeat, Billy Beane stood in the tunnel outside the visitors clubhouse at Yankee Stadium and defended his team’s use of the so-called opener — a concept that Beane thinks is only going to expand in baseball.

headline: Barry Jenkins’s Films of Love, Pain and Black Male Vulnerability
abstract: The “Moonlight” director brings his intuitive approach to an adaptation of James Baldwin’s “If Beale Street Could Talk.”
lead_paragraph: The “Moonlight” director brings his intuitive approach to an adaptation of James Baldwin’s “If Beale Street Could Talk.”

headline: What Makes ‘The Good Place’ So Good?
abstract: NBC gave Michael Schur total freedom. So the TV impresario made a sitcom that’s also a profound work of philosophy.
lead_paragraph: NBC gave Michael Schur total freedom. So the TV impresario made a sitcom that’s also a profound work of philosophy.

headline: Ghosts of the Past, Embalmed in White Plaster
abstract: Rachel Whiteread has spent decades making sculptures out of empty spaces. A retrospective at the National Gallery of Art is a model of her commitment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some artists have careers that take juddering turns, with early works giving no hint of later, sudden shifts in style: El Greco or Turner, Frank Stella or Philip Guston. Then there are artists — and it’s no vice — who stay the course. They find a style or principle early on, and, like Voltaire’s Candide, they cultivate their garden, over decades. They devote themselves to a single color, like Robert Ryman and white, or a single subject, like On Kawara and dates, and in the studio each day they make artworks that are always in concert but never the same.

abstract: The challenge of closing larger transactions argues in favor of pursuing smaller acquisitions.

abstract: What are the biggest signs that a community’s children will remain poor?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: Chinese Oil Company Official Talked Arms Deals and Evading Iran Sanctions, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The head of the Chinese company’s nonprofit arm discussed using its connections to help sell weapons to Chad, Qatar and Libya, according to federal prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The mysterious Chinese oil company known as CEFC China raised eyebrows wherever it went. Its executives hinted at deep connections within Beijing’s halls of power as well as with China’s powerful military. Then, last year, prosecutors in the United States arrested one of its top executives, accusing him of bribery in an effort to secure oil rights in Chad and Uganda. Now, they say, he also explored businesses beyond oil: brokering arms deals in other countries and looking for ways to dodge American sanctions on Iran.

headline: Danske Bank Faces U.S. Inquiry Over Money Laundering
keywords: ['Money Laundering', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The Danish lender said it is cooperating with a Department of Justice criminal investigation into flows of money at its branch in Estonia.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Danske Bank, which last month acknowledged failing to prevent suspected money laundering at its Estonian branch, has now drawn the attention of United States authorities.

headline: Teenagers in The Times: September 2018
abstract: Our roundup of the news stories and features about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the September edition of Teenagers in The Times, a roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. During the school year, we publish a new edition on the first Thursday of each month. It might be especially useful for students participating in our new challenge, Show Us Your Generation: A Photo Contest for Teenagers. (And, educators, we have a related question for you: Teachers, Do You Think This Generation Is Misunderstood? Your answers could be featured in print in the special Learning section coming in early November.)

headline: What’s Housework Worth? $1.6 Trillion a Year in U.K., Officials Calculate
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Britain’s statistics agency considers unpaid domestic labor a huge hidden slice of the economy, with transport and child care its largest elements.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Household chores like washing dishes and taking care of children have long been undervalued, feminists and others argue.

keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Jellyfish', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Social Media', 'Physics']

lead_paragraph: Sometimes it seems as if we’re living under a constant barrage of heavy news. But it isn’t all bad out there. This feature is meant to send you into the weekend with a smile, or at least a lighter heart. Want to get The Week in Good News by email? Sign up here.

headline: Kavanaugh Vote on Friday Will Be a Showdown in the Senate
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Two Republican senators, Jeff Flake and Susan Collins, signaled satisfaction with the F.B.I. investigation, while a swing-vote Democrat, Heidi Heitkamp, came out against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Oct. 5, 2018: Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh cleared a major hurdle Friday morning in his quest for the Supreme Court, as the Senate voted narrowly to cut off debate on his nomination and move to a final vote as early as Saturday. Read the latest, here.

keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Doping (Sports)', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: American and European officials said Russian military intelligence officers were responsible for a string of attacks and attempted hacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Western allies accused Russian intelligence officers on Thursday of launching cyberattacks against organizations around the globe that challenged Russian wrongdoing, exposed Kremlin disinformation campaigns or took on President Vladimir V. Putin.

abstract: Many Americans will cast their ballots in voting booths on Nov. 6. But for some, voting begins far earlier. The dates below list the early voting dates for each of the states that allow it.

lead_paragraph: Through Oct 20. Postmasters, 54 Franklin Street, Manhattan; 212-727-3323; postmastersart.com.

abstract: The district, which includes the exceptionally wealthy Hamptons, many middle-class communities and some rural farm towns, twice voted narrowly for Barack Obama, but for Donald J. Trump by 12 points in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The district, which includes the exceptionally wealthy Hamptons, many middle-class communities and some rural farm towns, twice voted narrowly for Barack Obama, but for Donald J. Trump by 12 points in 2016.

headline: ‘Cent’anni!’ A Century of Sicilian Loaves in the Bronx
abstract: Madonia Bakery has been making semolina bread for 100 years. The biscotti, a more recent addition, was added in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Joanne Labadia knew enough to call ahead for the pretzels.

headline: U.S. Women Begin World Cup Qualifying Tournament With 6-0 Win
abstract: The top three teams in the Concacaf championship that begins Thursday will qualify for next year’s Women’s World Cup in France.
lead_paragraph: The United States is the defending Women’s World Cup champion and the No. 1-ranked team in the world. But it is not guaranteed a place in next year’s Cup, and though the scenario is unlikely, it could theoretically be eliminated from the tournament months before it begins if things go badly in a regional qualifying tournament over the next two weeks.

headline: Film Club: ‘Long Live Benjamin’
abstract: Can humans and animals be friends?
lead_paragraph: “Long Live Benjamin” is a 10-minute film that touches on themes of unconditional love, the relationship between people and wild animals, and what it means to be human. It is the first episode in a six-part documentary about the artist Allen Hirsch and how he came to care for a capuchin monkey he called Benjamin. The Op-Doc won the 2018 Emmy for New Approaches: Arts, Lifestyle and Culture.

headline: Kayaking Is a Workout. And in Jamaica Bay, There are Ospreys
abstract: At this 18,000 acre wetland estuary near the Rockaway Peninsula, the New York State Parks Department sponsors daily kayaking activities for free.
lead_paragraph: Urban kayakers are easy to spot along the Hudson River, watched over by skyscrapers and nonstop traffic of Manhattan. But for those who really want to get away from the city — while staying in the city — to do some paddling, there’s Jamaica Bay, Queens.

headline: Our Favorite Photos From the Paris Shows
abstract: Highlights from the past week, including Chanel’s indoor beach and Dior’s dancers, as captured by T’s photographers.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the past week, including Chanel’s indoor beach and Dior’s dancers, as captured by T’s photographers.

headline: Daily Baby Aspirin May Lower Ovarian Cancer Risk
abstract: A standard aspirin did not lower ovarian cancer risk.
lead_paragraph: Taking low-dose aspirin is a daily routine for many people because it may lower the risk for heart attacks and strokes, and some research has tied it to a lower risk of colorectal cancer. Now a new study in JAMA Oncology suggests it may lower the risk for ovarian cancer as well.

headline: Take a Hike With Fall’s Hottest Boots
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Hiking boots are going off the trails and veering into fashion’s lane.
lead_paragraph: The utilitarian hiking boot, once relegated to the racks of sporting goods stores, has gotten a fashion makeover. Brands like Gucci and Prada have taken the outdoorsy staple and given it a cosmopolitan shine using high-tech materials and runway-ready details. Here are six boots that can go effortlessly from town to country.

headline: T’s Best Photos From Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Elegance and softness were the defining notes at the Spring 2019 shows in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Elegance and softness were the defining notes at the Spring 2019 shows in Paris. At Miu Miu, models traipsed down a grand curving staircase and onto the catwalk in slouchy sequined tanks and silk slips adorned with rosettes. Sarah Burton’s collection for Alexander McQueen, inspired in part by the shape of a Victorian wedding dress, was heavy on mega-ruffles and tiny waists belted in black leather. And, on the final morning of the Paris shows, Chanel installed a beach in the Grand Palais, where models frolicked in straw hats and silk chiffon dresses in the sand and sea grasses. Click through the slide show to see highlights from these shows and more.

headline: Why Investors in European I.P.O.s are Currently Grabbing Bargains
abstract: Companies rushing to list while stock market valuations are high and Britain remains in the European Union are having to price offerings modestly.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Simona Halep Tries to Heal Before the WTA Final
abstract: She won the French Open, she’s ranked No. 1, but a herniated disk has intruded. She discusses the injury and her mental approach to the game.
lead_paragraph: It has been a career-defining year for Simona Halep. The 27-year-old has enjoyed her top-ranked perch since winning her first Grand Slam at the French Open in June, but all that is under threat. Battling a bad back and a four-game losing streak, Halep of Romania is racing to heal in time for the WTA Finals in Singapore, Oct. 21-28, to defend her No. 1 ranking. This conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: A Short Novel of Love, War and Comrades in Arms Contains the World in a Foxhole
abstract: Elliot Ackerman’s “Waiting for Eden” keeps an eye on a wounded veteran from the perspective of his dead best friend.
lead_paragraph: WAITING FOR EDEN By Elliot Ackerman 173 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

headline: Hillary Clinton Is Coming to Broadway. As a Character in a Play.
abstract: Lucas Hnath’s “Hillary and Clinton” will be the first play with Mrs. Clinton as a protagonist to reach Broadway.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Lucas Hnath made his Broadway debut last year with a drama starring Laurie Metcalf in an imagined sequel for one of the most famous women in theater history, Nora Helmer of Ibsen’s “A Doll’s House.”

headline: MacArthur Foundation Announces 25 New ‘Genius’ Fellowships
abstract: This year’s MacArthur fellows, who each win $625,000 awards, include writers, scientists, artists, a human rights lawyer and a journalist.
lead_paragraph: There was laundry to be done for Okwui Okpokwasili, a choreographer and performer, as she walked out of her Brooklyn home early last month toward a laundromat. She was getting ready to fly to Berlin that night and, adding to her irritation, she kept missing calls from an unidentified number.

headline: MacArthur ‘Genius’ Grant Winners for 2018: The Full List
abstract: The newest group of 25 MacArthur Fellows has been announced. The honor comes with an award of $625,000.
lead_paragraph: The MacArthur fellowships, awarded annually by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation for exceptional “originality, insight and potential,” come with a no-strings-attached award of $625,000, distributed over five years. Below are the 2018 fellows.

headline: Review: In ‘Venom,’ Tom Hardy as a Weirder-Than-Usual, Not-Quite Superhero
abstract: The film, which focuses on a popular Marvel character, feels like a body-horror movie played for slapstick.
lead_paragraph: It would be irresponsible of me to recommend that you get to the theater late if you go see “Venom,” a new movie adapted from a Marvel comic book about a kind of divided-self superantihero. By missing the first scene you will be bereft of some ostensibly essential plot material concerning a rocket crash, alien organisms fetched from the East Malaysia scene of said crash, one such alien organism taking over a variety of human bodies, and so on.

headline: Joe Ide Adds More Breathless Action to the Mix in ‘Wrecked’
abstract: In the third novel in Ide’s IQ series, the detective Isaiah Quintabe is entangled in a case involving a missing woman and a menacing group of ex-Abu Ghraib military personnel.
lead_paragraph: Joe Ide opens “Wrecked,” the third book in his blazing IQ series, with the novelist’s equivalent of a stun gun. He presents the jokey, bored sadism of a group of ex-Abu Ghraib military personnel as they casually torment some poor sap in California. They nickname him “Sneaky Pete,” and he’s almost a footnote in this prologue — until the thugs mention his real name.

headline: Hey, My Tween Daughters Heard That
abstract: A reader wonders whether the content of a snooped-on phone call can be confronted.
lead_paragraph: Because of distance, my tween daughters and I visit my parents once a year. The first few days are festive. My sister, who lives three miles away with her family, calls the attention to us “unfair” and “obnoxious.” During our last visit, she left my parents’ house exasperated. Later, she phoned my mom, and my daughters secretly listened in on the extension. My sister trash-talked me, and my mother replied neutrally: “Uh huh, uh huh.” I know the eavesdropping was wrong, but I’d like to tell my mom how hurtful and abetting her behavior was. Any thoughts?

headline: Most Passing Yards: It’s an N.F.L. Record Made to Be Broken, Again and Again
abstract: Drew Brees should pass Peyton Manning on the all-time yardage list Monday night. But that record probably won’t last long in today’s pass-happy N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: The year is 2027. Late in the third quarter of Detroit’s game in London, Matthew Stafford, in his 19th consecutive season quarterbacking the Lions, whips the ball toward a teammate darting across the middle. The receiver catches it in stride, eluding a defender reaching for the flag dangling from his hip, for a 20-yard gain, and the Lions race onto the field to mob Stafford.

headline: M.L.B. Playoffs 2018: Our Picks to Win the Division Series
abstract: Baseball is hard to predict, but we’re going to do it anyway. Here’s how the final eight teams stack up.
lead_paragraph: It took an extra day of the regular season, plus the usual wild-card games, but Major League Baseball’s division series have finally arrived. The National League is up first, on Thursday, with two Game 1s, but the most compelling matchups will be in the American League.

headline: Lindsey Graham Welcomed Trump’s China Tariffs, Then Helped Companies Avoid Them
keywords: ['Customs (Tariff)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The South Carolina senator urged the administration to exclude imports used by companies from his state from a list of products subject to tariffs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has been one of the biggest proponents of President Trump’s crackdown on China, welcoming tariffs on Chinese imports while conceding that they will raise costs for American businesses and consumers.

headline: New Life for a 1902 Manual About Color
abstract: Emily Noyes Vanderpoel was an artist and historian who filled her book with color studies that are surprisingly contemporary.
lead_paragraph: In 1902, Emily Noyes Vanderpoel, a 59-year-old artist, historian and collector of exotic artifacts, published a book called “Color Problems.”

headline: How Do You Take a Picture of a Black Hole? With a Telescope as Big as the Earth
keywords: ['Event Horizon Telescope', 'Sagittarius A*', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Telescopes and Observatories', 'Black Holes (Space)', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'Milky Way Galaxy']
abstract: A planet-spanning virtual observatory, years in the making, could change how we think about space, time and the nature of reality. Will it work?
lead_paragraph: We live 26,000 light-years from the center of the Milky Way. That’s a rounding error by cosmological standards, but still — it’s far. When the light now reaching Earth from the galactic center first took flight, people were crossing the Bering Strait land bridge, hunting woolly mammoths along the way.

headline: The Famed Brooklyn Heights Promenade May Close for Years. Here’s Why.
abstract: Here’s why replacing a crumbling stretch of the expressway that includes the Brooklyn Promenade will be the city’s hardest, costliest transportation project.
lead_paragraph: It is 1,825 feet of unparalleled views of Manhattan and New York Harbor that is known around the world and has captivated generations of visitors and inspired tributes in films and TV shows.

headline: Brett Kavanaugh and ‘Boys Club’ Code
abstract: From Las Vegas to Georgetown Prep, variations of “what happens here stays here” are common. But where does this phrase come from and what does it really mean?
lead_paragraph: From Las Vegas to Georgetown Prep, variations of “what happens here stays here” are common. But where does this phrase come from and what does it really mean?

headline: After the Braves Let the Kid Play, Ronald Acuña Jr. Soared
abstract: Ronald Acuña Jr.’s youthful exuberance and power hitting have helped rejuvenate the Braves.
lead_paragraph: It may be hard to remember that Ronald Acuna Jr., the Atlanta Braves’ slugging sensation and a front-runner to win this year’s National League Rookie of the Year Award, was not even ranked among the team’s top prospects just a few years ago.

headline: A Composer Follows His Masterpiece by Aiming for the Cosmos
abstract: Andrew Norman’s symphony-length “Sustain” will have its high-profile premiere in a concert to open the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s centennial season.
lead_paragraph: “What you’re hearing,” the composer Andrew Norman said in the middle of an interview earlier this week, “are some prerehearsal jitters on my part.”

headline: ‘The Hills’ Gets Mischa Barton and More: Your Thursday Pop Culture Cheat Sheet
abstract: What you need to know from today’s TV, music and movie news.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

headline: The Kavanaugh Report: Reactions From Senators on the Right and Left
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Lawmakers reviewed the F.B.I.’s findings from an inquiry into Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s background. Here’s what senators from each side of the aisle had to say about it.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Thursday received a single copy of the F.B.I.’s findings from a reopened background investigation into Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, a nominee for the Supreme Court.

headline: Deep in Human DNA, a Gift From the Neanderthals
abstract: Long ago, Neanderthals probably infected modern humans with viruses, perhaps even an ancient form of H.I.V. But our extinct relatives also gave us genetic defenses.
lead_paragraph: People of Asian and European descent — almost anyone with origins outside of Africa — have inherited a sliver of DNA from some unusual ancestors: the Neanderthals.

headline: Anime’s Teen Boys and the Women Who Voice Them
abstract: The actresses behind Luffy, Naruto and Boruto say female voices make sense for these characters, though fans are often shocked to learn of their involvement.
lead_paragraph: If you’re under 30, Monkey D. Luffy, the zany captain of the Straw Hat Pirates, in the Japanese manga and TV show “One Piece,” and the ninja leader Naruto and his adolescent son, Boruto, from a different series, probably rank among your favorite animated characters. If you’re over 30, they’re the stars of the biggest franchises you’ve never heard of.

headline: Jason Van Dyke Killed Laquan McDonald in 2014. Now Chicago Awaits a Verdict.
abstract: A Chicago jury must decide the fate of Jason Van Dyke in the killing of Laquan McDonald in a case has become a proxy for questions about police accountability.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Three years ago, grainy video of a white police officer shooting a black teenager 16 times upended this city. The police superintendent was forced out, the prosecutor lost her election, and Mayor Rahm Emanuel has since announced he is not seeking re-election. Chicagoans were furious and a Justice Department investigation confirmed their anger, finding far-reaching failures by the police, including rampant excessive force aimed at African-Americans and Latinos.

headline: The Sommelier Finds Room to Breathe
abstract: The stresses and demands of restaurant work eventually compel many, like Patrick Cappiello, to seek out other careers in wine.
lead_paragraph: SEBASTOPOL, Calif. — Over the last 15 years, Patrick Cappiello has been one of New York’s most accomplished sommeliers. Now, like so many of the country’s top wine servers, he has largely put that job behind him.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: “Women almost never become art monsters,” Jenny Offill wrote in her 2014 novel “Dept. of Speculation” (one of the Book Review’s favorite novels that year), “because art monsters only concern themselves with art, never mundane things.”

headline: Review: In This Entertaining ‘Bacchae,’ Dionysus Is a Nasty Woman
abstract: Anne Bogart directs a flashy production that puts ancient anxieties about women and power front and center.
lead_paragraph: The women of Thebes are dancing. The women are rioting. They are breast-feeding wolf cubs and disemboweling cows and using snakes as belts. Just because you’re possessed by a fierce and devouring god doesn’t mean you can’t be fashion-forward.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Turkish Company for Trade With North Korea
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The sanctions on a Turkish company intend to be a tough signal to Pyongyang ahead of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s visit to North Korea this weekend.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States imposed sanctions on Thursday against a Turkish company and two of its officers for doing business with North Korea, sending a tough signal to Pyongyang ahead of Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s expected visit there this weekend.

headline: Viruses Spread by Insects to Crops Sound Scary. The Military Calls It Food Security.
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Viruses', 'Drought', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Insects']
abstract: Critics warn that a Defense Department-funded food security project that is still in the lab could set off a “biological arms race.”
lead_paragraph: Within the Defense Department, one agency’s recent project sounds futuristic: millions of insects carrying viruses descend upon crops and then genetically modify them to withstand droughts, floods and foreign attacks, ensuring a permanently secure food supply.

headline: 4 Stars, 4 Distinct Eras: Which Version of ‘A Star Is Born’ Does It Best?
abstract: The newest version, starring Bradley Cooper and Lady Gaga, hits theaters this weekend. But how does it stack up against the others? Here’s a scorecard.
lead_paragraph: In the latest imagining of “A Star Is Born,” which debuts this weekend, the actor Sam Elliott waxes poetic on the structural limitations of music. Within every octave, he says, are 12 notes, the same story told again and again: “All that the artist can offer the world is how they see those 12 notes.” It’s a wistful and winking nod to the challenge Bradley Cooper faced for his directorial debut, in which he and Lady Gaga reprise two already beloved roles: What can Cooper’s version — a remake of a remake of a remake — bring to audiences that feels fresh and compelling?

headline: Should Women Show Their Rage?
abstract: Readers discuss using fury as a political weapon and sharing stories of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: As Afghanistan Frays, Blackwater Founder Erik Prince Is Everywhere
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Mercenaries and Private Military Contractors', 'Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Some Afghan officials say Mr. Prince is trying to influence presidential elections to pave the way for his plan to privatize the war for President Trump.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A new crop of senior American officials in Afghanistan has been racing to contain a dual crisis on the battlefield and in a potentially explosive election dispute. But it is a different American figure — the mercenary executive Erik D. Prince — who has been the talk of Kabul these days.

headline: Spellbound by Harry Potter and the Museum of Magic
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Harry Potter (Fictional Character)', 'Art', 'Museums', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: At the New-York Historical Society, a glimpse of the folkloric, cultural and scientific influences on the magic of the popular series.
lead_paragraph: A crumpled piece of paper hanging on the far wall had me mesmerized. It was a sketch of a dark-haired boy with round glasses surrounded by his sour-faced relatives. The page is covered in wrinkles and stained with what looks like coffee. But there he is, the Boy Who Lived, drawn lovingly by J.K. Rowling herself, a full six years before the first Harry Potter book was published.

headline: Stanford’s Endowment Grew 11.3% Last Year, Beating Harvard but Not Yale
abstract: The third-largest university endowment in the world was valued at $26.5 billion at the end of August, officials said.

headline: N.F.L. Week 5 Picks: Can the Jaguars Slow Down Patrick Mahomes?
abstract: The N.F.L.’s best defense gets a crack at Kansas City, the Rams are heavy favorites in Seattle and the Eagles try to get back on track.
lead_paragraph: Passing, passing and more passing. The N.F.L. is on a record-setting pace for points, mostly because enough teams have fully embraced that the game has gone vertical. Far from making games uncompetitive, it has resulted in an average margin of victory of 9.9 points, which, according to the league, would be the lowest such mark since 1932 were it to continue.

headline: I Was in the Elevator With Jeff Flake. Senators, Don’t Look Away From Me.
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Lawmakers can’t claim to respect sexual assault survivors and then ignore them.
lead_paragraph: When I ran from Senator Jeff Flake’s office door to the elevator last Friday and put my arm in to stop it from closing, I wasn’t thinking about what would come next. I had no idea what I was about to say. But when he would not look at me, or the woman standing next to me baring her soul, I felt only fury.

headline: Are You a Visual or an Auditory Learner? It Doesn’t Matter
abstract: One mental strategy may be much better suited than another to a particular task.
lead_paragraph: You must read this article to understand it, but many people feel reading is not how they learn best. They would rather listen to an explanation or view a diagram. Researchers have formalized those intuitions into theories of learning styles. These theories are influential enough that many states (including New York) require future teachers to know them and to know how they might be used in the classroom.

headline: Warrington Colescott, Who Etched With a Satirical Edge, Dies at 97
abstract: In his etchings, Mr. Colescott, a renowned printmaker, made biting and witty commentaries on history, politics, civil rights and, satisfyingly, the I.R.S.
lead_paragraph: Warrington Colescott, an innovative printmaker who deftly navigated the intersection between tragedy and high comedy with biting etchings about civil rights, history, politics and the Internal Revenue Service (which audited him), died on Sept. 10 at his farmhouse in Hollandale, Wis., southwest of Madison. He was 97.

A disjointed string of terminals. One of every four flights delayed. Aggravatingly long security lines. Brutal slogs through traffic just to reach the airport.

headline: C. Payne Lucas, Leader in Aid to Africa, Is Dead at 85
abstract: Mr. Lucas helped found Africare and, with help from African-Americans, built it into a leading nonprofit promoting economic development.
lead_paragraph: “My friends thought I was crazy,” C. Payne Lucas recalled of his efforts in the early 1970s to start a nonprofit organization in the United States to provide aid in Africa. “People used to say: ‘C. Payne, this is a stupid idea. You aren’t going to get black Americans to give you any money. They’re too tied up trying to get things accomplished here.’ ”

lead_paragraph: Peggy Sue Gerron Rackham, who became part of Buddy Holly’s circle of friends as a teenager and long reveled in having her name used as the title of one of his biggest hits, died on Monday in Lubbock, Tex. She was 78.

headline: In ’80s Comedies, Boys Had It Made. Girls Were the Joke.
keywords: ['Movies', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Teen movies like “Porky’s” reveled in the dynamic of Dr. Christine Blasey Ford’s worst memory: “The uproarious laughter between the two, and their having fun at my expense.”
lead_paragraph: The top movie of 1982, by a wide margin, was “E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial,” Steven Spielberg’s fantasy about a group of boys who try to get an alien back to outer space. Below it, at No. 5, was “Porky’s,” about a group of boys who try to have a lot of sex. It coasted on the pre-J.F.K.-assassination nostalgia that made huge hits of “American Graffiti,” a decade earlier, and “Animal House,” five years after that. But “Porky’s” wasn’t innocent, or for that matter, nostalgic. All that the boys long for is girls — to talk to, sure, but mostly to peep at, ogle and harass.

headline: Pets Shed Constantly. Here’s How to Keep Up.
abstract: Because pets are always shedding, the tireless robot vacuum is the best vacuum for pet hair — but a great dust mop works well, too.
lead_paragraph: If you are a pet owner, it’s likely you know this: pets shed constantly. A typical house cat can shed up to 75,000 hairs a day. If you are a typical human, you probably also know that you lack  the time and the will to keep up with that kind of cleaning. As a result, pet hair builds up on floors and rugs, which can go from annoying to disgusting in a matter of days.

Kavanaugh as central to salvaging the Republican Party’s fortunes in the midterm elections, and hope to use the fervent liberal opposition to his nomination to the Supreme Court as a graphic example of the threat posed by a Democratic return to power in Congress.

headline: Seven Ways to Teach the Midterms With The New York Times
abstract: To help educators prepare for the final month before the midterm elections, we have collected ideas submitted by teachers and added some of our own to create this list.

headline: Wasted Ballots? A Lesson Exploring Why More Young People Don’t Vote, and What Students Can Do About It
abstract: In this lesson plan, we ask students to think about: Why do so many young people don’t vote? And what can we do, as a society, to get more youth to the polls?
lead_paragraph: All fall, news sources have been reporting that the pace of new voter registrations among young people is accelerating. After the Parkland school shooting — and with heated emotions for and against President Trump — perhaps young Americans will show up at the polls in record numbers. But in 2014, in the last midterm elections, fewer than one in five 18-29 year olds voted. Four years before that, the number was only slightly better: fewer than one in four. Will this year be notably different?

headline: A Supreme Violation
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', '#MeToo Movement', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Republicans want to ram Kavanaugh through no matter how many women object.
lead_paragraph: In the end, it didn’t really matter how many women begged them not to do this, how many times women said slow down, stop, please, no. As of this writing, it seems inevitable that Republicans in the Senate are going to shove Brett Kavanaugh down our throats. According to polls, a majority of American women believe that Christine Blasey Ford told the truth when she said Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her. But the United States Senate is run by Republican men, and thanks to them, Kavanaugh will most likely soon be on the Supreme Court, deciding, among other things, how much control women will be permitted over our own bodies.

headline: Hoaxers Slip Breastaurants and Dog-Park Sex Into Journals
