lead_paragraph: One paper, published in a journal called Sex Roles, said that the author had conducted a two-year study involving “thematic analysis of table dialogue” to uncover the mystery of why heterosexual men like to eat at Hooters.

headline: Singing, Chanting and Rage on Capitol Hill as Kavanaugh Vote Nears
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government', '#MeToo Movement', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: On a steamy day in the capital, several thousand protesters, most of them female, made a late stand against the nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It started almost plaintively. “Why aren’t you brave enough to talk to us?” a protester demanded of Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, as he waited for an elevator in a Senate office building on Thursday.

headline: Hunted for Months, Reputed Mobster Is Gunned Down at McDonald’s
abstract: A law enforcement official described a mafia-style assassination: a shooting as an S.U.V. waited at a drive-through window.
lead_paragraph: For months, Sylvester Zottola has been pursued by someone who wanted him dead. On Thursday evening, as night fell outside a McDonald’s on Webster Avenue in the Bronx, it appears that someone caught up with him.

headline: When Your Friend Is Your Rapist
abstract: Readers responded to a writer’s disclosure of sexual assault at the hands of someone she later dated.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of Christine Blasey Ford’s testimony about her sexual assault, Mara Gay, a member of The Times’s editorial board, wrote  about bumping into the man she says raped her more than a decade ago. She wrote that she never felt compelled to share her story before because she considered it “unremarkable,” so common, and “so many women have been through worse.” But after hearing Dr. Blasey’s testimony, Ms. Gay wrote, “I wanted to tell it and be free.”

(The show plays in repertory through Jan. 19 and will be broadcast in movie theaters via National Theater Live on Dec. 6.)

headline: 40 Years of Hip-Hop Photos
abstract: Decades after photographers captured the hip-hop scene that emerged in the South Bronx, contact sheets offer a valuable peek into how artists on both sides of the camera worked.
lead_paragraph: The art of making something from nothing has always been at the heart of hip-hop culture. D.J.s in South Bronx parks created a global youth culture with just records and a sound system. And in that analog world, photographers fittingly documented the emerging scene on film. Decades later, those contact sheets are a visual primary text that offer a valuable peek into how artists on both sides of the camera worked.

headline: Maja Hoffmann Fights to Build Her Cultural Capital in Arles, France
abstract: Imagining her city transformed by art, a “rainmaker” takes on a role once reserved for planners.
lead_paragraph: ARLES, France — It was 90 degrees at 10 p.m. as the lights dimmed on a stage under the exposed trusses of a 19th-century foundry. All was silent but for the humming of cicadas, all was still apart from the sultry breeze, and all was dark, except for the green flashing lights on the giant construction crane hovering overhead.

abstract: Sometimes I find myself resenting my brother for never having been born.
lead_paragraph: The year I turned 16, I asked my mother why I did not have siblings. Having immigrated to North America a decade earlier, my family had long since been freed from China’s one-child policy. Nearly all my high school classmates had siblings, and I wanted to know why my family had chosen differently.

headline: The Literati: Tolstoy’s Last Chapter
abstract: An illustrated retelling of the Russian novelist’s troubled marriage, and final breaths.
lead_paragraph: When Count Leo Tolstoy, 34, proposes marriage to 18-year-old Sonya Behr in 1862, he is not much of a catch. Although the heir to a vast estate with hundreds of serfs, he has lost much of his fortune through gambling. And, since visiting a dentist takes up time better spent at roulette, he has also lost most of his teeth.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘Windfall,’ ‘The Ruined House’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: WINDFALL: How the New Energy Abundance Upends Global Politics and Strengthens America’s Power, by Meghan L. O’Sullivan. (Simon & Schuster, $18.) The rise of cheap gas and fracking has shifted the balances of power worldwide, O’Sullivan, a Harvard professor, writes. The revolution has allowed the United States to be more self-sufficient, helped stabilize Europe’s economy and blunted Russia’s efforts to become a superpower.

headline: His Novel Describes the Dark Side of Internet Fame. Hank Green Knows Something About That.
abstract: In “An Absolutely Remarkable Thing,” which debuts on the list at No. 1, a YouTube video transforms its creator into an overnight media sensation.
lead_paragraph: In Hank Green’s debut novel, “An Absolutely Remarkable Thing” — which debuts on the fiction list at No. 1 — 23-year-old April May, coming home from work late one night in New York City, stumbles upon an enormous metal sculpture planted on the sidewalk, “a 10-foot-tall Transformer wearing a suit of samurai armor, its huge barrel chest lifted up to the sky.” She and a friend shoot a video of it, which they upload to YouTube, and go to bed. By the next morning, the video has gone viral, transforming April into an internet celebrity.

headline: The Way We Look Now, According to Mary Beard
abstract: The classicist and author of ‘How Do We Look’ explains what Instagram’s most popular photos reveal about our likes (and dislikes).
lead_paragraph: In her new book, “How Do We Look: The Body, the Divine and the Question of Civilization,” Mary Beard, a professor of classics at Cambridge University, turns her eye to the history of art. The slim volume, published in September by Liveright, focuses on the relationship between viewers and images, beginning with sculptures from ancient Greece and China and ending in a mosque in modern day Istanbul.

headline: Content for Humans About the Content of Humans
abstract: Spotify and Ancestry team up for that saliva sample sound.
lead_paragraph: The pitch for home DNA testing could not be more succinct: know thyself, for a fee.

headline: The Best New Fantasy Novels
abstract: Amal El-Mohtar looks at four books that immerse readers in richly imagined otherworlds.
lead_paragraph: Moving from one season into another isn’t unlike traveling to different countries: As landscapes and weather patterns shift, so do our habits and thought processes. Now that autumn is upon us, I want to look at four wonderfully immersive otherworlds that circle around ideas of magically controlled environments and the free wills that resist them.

headline: A Graphic Nonfiction Account of Hitler’s Would-Be Assassin
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: In “The Faithful Spy,” John Hendrix makes the life story of Dietrich Bonhoeffer, a leader of the Dutch resistance against the Nazis, into both a thriller and a tale of valiant faith.
lead_paragraph: For a man accursed by history, Adolf Hitler led a grimly charmed life. He survived several well-planned assassination attempts through sheer luck. The theologian Dietrich Bonhoeffer, a double agent claiming to spy for Hitler’s Reich, was actually involved in the resistance movement that planned a few of these plots. John Hendrix’s graphic biography, THE FAITHFUL SPY: Dietrich Bonhoeffer and the Plot to Kill Hitler (Amulet, 176 pp., $16.99; ages 10 and up), intertwines two stories: the insidious rise of Hitler with his creed of hatred and Bonhoeffer’s development as an ethical thinker who believed that radical action was necessary, but that killing was a sin. Hendrix writes, “the conspirators needed to find a place where God would forgive them for plotting an assassination.”

headline: Does Coenzyme Q10 Reduce Statin-Related Muscle Aches?

lead_paragraph: Q. Does coenzyme Q10 help to reduce muscular issues and other negative side effects associated with statins? And if so, should doctors give this information to patients when statins are prescribed?

keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Productivity']

headline: The Scene of the Crime: Four Mysteries in Ominous Locales
abstract: Marilyn Stasio’s column takes readers to backwater towns in Minnesota and Oklahoma and the murky Victorian-era Thames. Also a not-very-sunny California.
lead_paragraph: As far as I’m concerned, Joe Ide can’t write them fast enough. His unorthodox hero, Isaiah (IQ) Quintabe, happily met again in WRECKED (Mulholland, $27), is a brainy private eye from Los Angeles who helps his neighbors deal with the usual neighborhood problems: “store thefts, break-ins, lost children, wife-beaters, bullies and con men.” For his services, he’s usually paid in casseroles, cookies and home repairs; Louella Barnes even settled her bill by knitting him a reindeer sweater. But that sort of trade-off looks to change when a painter named Grace Monarova walks into his life, along with the prospect of bona fide, negotiable cash in order to find her mother. But the money seems less important than what else might be on offer: the sort of serious love interest that was missing from his first two cases.

headline: The Ugly Beauty of Cindy Sherman’s Instagram Selfies

headline: Why the Wilder Storms? It’s a ‘Loaded Dice’ Problem
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Floods', 'Rain', 'Drought', 'Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Typhoon Mangkhut (2018)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Reservoirs', 'Levees and Dams']
abstract: Global warming is bringing an era of wilder, more dangerous rains. The good news is that we’re getting better at evacuating flood zones. The bad news is everything else.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rainfall lashed Japan in July. A cloudburst in August submerged entire villages in south India. In September, Hurricane Florence burst dams and lagoons, with coal ash and pig waste spilling into the waterways of North Carolina. On the other side of the planet, a typhoon walloped the Philippines and ravaged the country’s staple crop, rice.

lead_paragraph: By the time T.J. was about 2½-years-old, it was clear to his mother that he was already behind. His twin brother was speaking in full sentences. T.J. couldn’t say a word.

headline: How Jennifer Jones Austin, Poverty Relief Advocate, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Ms. Jones Austin, who lives in her childhood home, attends Bethany Baptist Church, where her father was a pastor, and enjoys a home-cooked dinner.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Jones Austin is the chief executive officer of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, an organization that works with 170 groups in New York to reduce poverty. She is also a leukemia survivor, whose recent memoir, “Consider It Pure Joy,” chronicles her quest for a bone marrow donor. Ms. Jones Austin, 50, lives in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, with her husband, Shawn, 52, an insurance executive, and their son, Channing, 17. Their 21-year-old daughter, Kennedy, is a student at Wellesley College. Ms. Jones Austin and her husband bought her childhood home from her mother and father, the Rev. William A. Jones, who worked with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1960s.

headline: Why Did Leonardo Draw These Weird Faces?
abstract: Some scholars see doodles, and others an artist trying to understand the range of human emotion. The faces are the focus of a new exhibit in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: HAARLEM, the Netherlands — Most people associate Leonardo da Vinci with his visions of beauty: the “Mona Lisa,” for instance, or his perfectly proportioned “Vitruvian Man.” But if we had been alive at any time from the 16th century to the 19th century, we would most likely have associated the Italian Renaissance master with bulbous noses, protruding foreheads and sunken chins.

abstract: It certainly knows how to conduct cyberattacks that disrupt political processes.
lead_paragraph: President Trump recently accused the Chinese of interfering in American politics ahead of the midterm elections. “They do not want me or us to win because I am the first president to ever challenge China on trade,” he said, addressing the United Nations Security Council. He provided no evidence, and appeared to be complaining mostly about retaliatory tariffs by the Chinese government, which may hurt constituencies that support him, and an advertorial touting U.S.-China trade in an Iowa newspaper.

headline: A Young Activist’s Advice: Vote, Shave Your Head and Cry Whenever You Need To
keywords: ['Parkland, Fla, Shooting (2018)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Gun Control', 'Crying']
abstract: Some people say, “I don’t pay attention to politics.” Others don’t have a choice.
lead_paragraph: I don’t remember exactly when I found out Carmen Schentrup was dead. Carmen and I became friends in middle school. We had science together. I got my period one day and didn’t have a pad, and Carmen gave me one — what a queen. We rode the bus together every day after school. She would vent about her a cappella club, and we would compare the TV shows we were watching. At her birthday parties everyone would eat pizza and watch a movie in the Schentrups’ living room, and then after the movie we would all just talk — about school, politics, life. I still have one of her party invitations taped up on my mirror.

headline: The Indian Government’s Astonishing Hunger for Citizen Data
keywords: ['Identification Devices', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Income Tax', 'Biometrics', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The country’s highest court has curtailed the uses of the national identification program, but fears about the misuse of information collected from a billion people remain.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — India’s Supreme Court has placed strict limits on Aadhaar, the government’s sweeping biometrics-based national identity program, but questions about the imposition of technological solutions and privacy remain.

headline: At City Ballet, Learning From Dancers Who Learned From Balanchine
abstract: Patricia McBride, Edward Villella and Mimi Paul have been invited to coach the roles that were made for them by George Balanchine.
lead_paragraph: She stomped to accentuate rhythms. She sang out the notes. She counted, inserting the word “and” in all sorts of unfamiliar places to emphasize new accents. And though she is in need of a hip replacement, Patricia McBride moved like the wind.

headline: I Thought Men Might Do Better Than This
keywords: ['#MeToo Movement', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: From Harvey Weinstein to Brett Kavanaugh in one exhausting year.
lead_paragraph: I watch a lot of “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.” Many women I know do too. I’ve seen nearly every episode from 19 seasons, most of them several times. I will watch a dozen episodes of the show back to back, no matter how many times I’ve seen them. At times, it troubles me, my ongoing willingness to consume this show and the disturbing story lines about sexual assault and the terrible ways of the world, but there is something so very satisfying about watching it. The victims don’t always find justice, but they are, more often than not, believed by the S.V.U. detectives. Their stories are heard and respected. Justice may be elusive, but on the show, it exists within the realm of possibility.

headline: Pence’s China Speech Seen as Portent of ‘New Cold War’
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations']
abstract: China could respond to Vice President Mike Pence’s tough speech by spending more on its military or withdrawing support for sanctions against North Korea.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Vice President Mike Pence’s accusations in a stinging speech Thursday warning of a tougher approach toward Beijing may have been familiar to China’s leaders. But until now, such remarks were delivered in private, in fairly decorous terms, and rarely threatened direct action.

headline: Former South Korean President Gets 15 Years in Prison for Corruption
abstract: Lee Myung-bak, who was president from 2008 to 2013, was accused of embezzlement and receiving bribes. He said he would appeal the conviction.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Lee Myung-bak, a former president of South Korea, was sentenced on Friday to 15 years in prison for bribery and embezzlement, becoming the second South Korean leader convicted in recent months in a crackdown on corruption.

headline: In the Yankees-Red Sox Rivalry, History’s Echoes Are Everywhere

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When the first pitch is thrown on Friday night at Fenway Park, Yankees Manager Aaron Boone will be stationed at his usual perch, along the top step at the near end of the third-base dugout. Just off his left shoulder, hanging on the railing, will be his bench coach, Josh Bard.

headline: A Father’s Photo Reignites the Conversation About Diaper Changing Stations
abstract: Donte Palmer posted a photo online showing how he changes his son’s diaper in public restrooms without changing stations. Messages of support flooded in from fathers around the world.

abstract: With “Homeland” about to end, he’s released his first new albums in more than a decade, with a young pop-minded producer pushing him to take risks.
lead_paragraph: “You know how people stand around and sing show tunes at parties?” Mandy Patinkin asked recently. “I hate it. Can’t stand doing it.” He noted, unnecessarily, “You can see the irony” in that confession — coming from a performer whose fire-and-honey voice made him one of the biggest musical theater stars of his generation in shows like “Evita” and “Sunday in the Park with George.”

headline: Taking the A Train to the Middle Ages
abstract: The Medieval Festival in Fort Tryon Park is quite a scene: jugglers, jousting knights and New Yorkers thirsting for mead.
lead_paragraph: The life of a New York clown takes many roads. For John Grimaldi, last Saturday it meant stilt-walking on the Metropolitan Opera stage, in Franco Zeffirelli’s production of “La Bohème.” A day later he was juggling and singing in medieval garb in Upper Manhattan.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: Sept. 28-Oct. 4
abstract: Sixty-two security force members, one American soldier and 37 civilians were killed during the past week.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in September, the Times bureau in Kabul mobilized all of its stringers and Afghan reporters to record every attack on the Afghan security forces that they could find, as a daily chronicle of the war. In this week’s edition, we are adding reports of civilian casualties.

headline: Checking In on the Alaïa Experiment
abstract: Think you can identify clothes from 1985 and 1990 today? Think again. Sometimes, fashion really is timeless.

Asked what it is that he likes about Studio 54, a shockingly relaxed and smiling Jackson says, “I like the atmosphere — the feeling, the excitement.

headline: For a German Chef, Hospital Food Is the Ultimate Challenge
abstract: Patrick Wodni was cooking for a Michelin-starred restaurant in Berlin but wanted to do something “useful.” Now, he aims to revolutionize institutional menus.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With the effortless skill of a chef of a Michelin-starred restaurant, Patrick Wodni quickly assembled the ingredients he would need for the day’s lunch special, an onion tart. But this time, instead of putting them into his favorite stainless steel mixing bowl, he poured the sour cream, eggs, cumin, fenugreek, red pepper and turmeric into an industrial-size vat and mixed it with both hands.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Cook for just for yourself, and make Anita Lo’s terrific recipe for cauliflower chaat, or go bigger and make new recipes from David Tanis and Alison Roman.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Our Tejal Rao is on the road right now, driving west to become our first California restaurant critic. But she’s still filing stories! Her latest is a look at an emergent genre of cooking that I read about a lot in letters sent to my email inbox: cooking for one. For her report, Tejal spent time talking with the chef Anita Lo, whose “Solo: A Modern Cookbook for a Party of One” will be published this month, and returned to the office with Lo’s terrific recipe for cauliflower chaat (above). Try that the next time you’re alone at dinner.

A comedian and a devilishly gifted impressionist, she scampers from Angela Merkel to Jerry Hall, Brigitte Macron to a shoplifting, poop-flinging Judi Dench.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Woman with No Sense of Smell
abstract: If her husband cooks, is she obligated to have one?
lead_paragraph: Alex writes: My partner, Jocelyn, was born without a sense of smell. She has never even mentioned it to a doctor. I don’t know if it’s treatable, but as an avid cook, I would love to be able to share the smells of what I am making. Please order Jocelyn to go to a professional and see if something can be done!

headline: Poem: Picture of a Soul
abstract: Selected by Rita Dove.
lead_paragraph: If, as Wallace Stevens claimed, “the poet is the priest of the invisible,” Elizabeth Spires may well be its high priestess. In just 59 words and 15 lines, she evokes that most stubbornly upheld, philosophically contested aspect of human consciousness: the soul. Why should my introduction presume to explain further and risk toppling this delicately poised lyric with superfluous discourse? Read it through, slowly — once, twice — then look up and let go of the breath you didn’t realize you’d been holding. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: China’s Small Farms Are Fading. The World May Benefit.
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Rural Areas', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Land Use Policies', 'Family Business']
abstract: Traditional plots of land are slowly becoming parts of bigger operations, eroding a way of life but enriching local residents and helping more Chinese people move into the modern world.
lead_paragraph: SHANHUI, China — This village doesn’t change quickly. The ebb and flow of the planting and harvesting seasons still govern the lives of its 3,000 residents. Some rise at 3 a.m. to cook homemade tofu, a Shanhui specialty, over a coal-burning stove. Most homes remain topped by traditional Chinese tiled roofs, here crowned by carved dragon’s heads, as is local custom.

headline: Review: Puccini’s American Opera Needs a New American Vision
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s 1991 staging of “La Fanciulla del West,” which opened on Thursday evening, has cinematic polish but hollow realism.

That scene is a pivotal moment for the heroine, Minnie, as she gambles her lover’s life on a game of poker with the town sheriff. In the pit, jittery 16th notes in the basses ratchet up tension.

headline: Surprising Truths About Trade Deficits
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The economist N. Gregory Mankiw presents some conclusions about trade that most economists accept but, upon first hearing, are not at all obvious.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has put trade policy at the center of his agenda. A case in point is the revised trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, announced on Monday. Yet it is hard to be sanguine about this accomplishment, in part because the changes are so modest but mostly because the president’s overall approach to international trade is so confused.

headline: A Tube of DNA? Not Pretty, but That’s Life.
abstract: Extracting and purifying DNA is routine now, but the results are not particularly aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: Q. If I had a test tube of pure DNA, what would it look like?

headline: McGregor vs. Nurmagomedov: Notorious Is Back
abstract: After two years away, Conor McGregor jumps right into a bout against the U.F.C. lightweight champion, Khabib Nurmagomedov.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two years, Conor McGregor, still the biggest star in mixed martial arts, is finally returning to the octagon. No warm-ups for McGregor: He jumps right into a bout against the U.F.C. lightweight champion, Khabib Nurmagomedov, in Las Vegas.

headline: Dave Anderson’s Columns: An Introduction to a Legend’s Voice
abstract: Dave Anderson, who died on Thursday at 89, covered the entire landscape of sports for The New York Times over nearly three decades. Here is a sampling of some of his more memorable pieces.

headline: Time to Install Subway Gates
abstract: An injury control researcher at N.Y.U. suggests a way to deter platform jumpers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hidden Stories of Chinese Migration and Culture Found in Giant Genetic Study
abstract: Scientists reported an assortment of findings resulting from a sweeping and novel analysis of data from the prenatal tests of 141,431 participants.
lead_paragraph: Lamb stew, hearty and fragrant, cooked until meat falls off the bone and served alongside thick, chewy noodles — this is the type of food that cuts through northern China’s winter chill.

headline: The Playlist: Sharon Van Etten Comes Back Strong, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Halsey, Van Morrison, Alessia Cara and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Review: William Forsythe Brings Baroque Dance and B-Boy Moves Together
abstract: “A Quiet Evening of Dance” is a program of the choreographer’s new and newish works that begins in silence and builds to a brilliant finale.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Making dance without music is nothing new: Choreographers as varied as Mary Wigman, Jerome Robbins, Twyla Tharp and Emanuel Gat have created works in which the only sounds are the dancers’ breath and footfalls. Yet William Forsythe, still one of our most pioneering dance makers at 68, believes there’s a contemporary virtue to quietness in the current political and media climate. In “A Quiet Evening of Dance,” a program of new and newish material by Mr. Forsythe that runs at Sadler’s Wells through Saturday, two of Mr. Forsythe’s works are performed entirely in silence, and all five are choreographed with an intimacy that demands a very special kind of attention.

headline: Denis Mukwege: A Sense of Calm Amid the Grinding Work of Saving Lives
abstract: A gynecologist in a war zone, the Nobel Peace Prize winner made a specialty of treating women who had been raped with extreme violence.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Gettleman was the East Africa bureau chief of The New York Times from 2006 to 2017.

headline: A Local Response to Climate Change
abstract: A landscape architect offers suggestions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Lil Wayne Became One of Hip-Hop’s Most Durable Stars
abstract: Tracing the rapper’s evolution from a teen in New Orleans to his long-awaited album “Tha Carter V.”
lead_paragraph: Next week Lil Wayne’s “Tha Carter V” is projected to debut at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, a validation of the intensity of Lil Wayne’s fandom, especially given that this album has been in a sort of legal purgatory for around four years. Lil Wayne persisted, and his fans held on.

headline: Mike Sorrentino, of ‘Jersey Shore’ Gets Prison Sentence: Your Week in Pop Culture
abstract: What you need to know from today’s TV, music and movie news.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.
