keywords: ['Birds', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: A hotel cleaner keeps the lobby in good shape. He also cares for the birds in there.
lead_paragraph: Errol Lindsay, 50, is a cleaner at Newport Beachside Hotel and Resort in Miami Beach, Fla.

headline: How a Seafloor Blob Became Mexico’s ‘Black Gold’
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Biodiversity']
abstract: A frenzy for sea cucumbers, driven by demand in Asia, has brought their populations near collapse in the waters off the Yucatán Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: RÍO LAGARTOS, Mexico — It is not a glamorous creature.

headline: Review: Despair Rips at the Seams of Beth Gill’s New Dance
abstract: In “Pitkin Grove,” at the Joyce Theater, her focus on form persists, but she has carved out more space for feeling to creep in, or blast through.
lead_paragraph: Writing about the choreographer Beth Gill, critics have often described her work as “meticulous.” Every choice — the placement of an arm, the manner of taking off a sweater — seems exactingly considered. That might be why, so often, her dances unfurl with a sense of inevitability; she has tuned in to what has to happen next.

headline: Activists Fighting Sexual Violence Receive Nobel Prize
abstract: Nadia Murad, a survivor of sexual violence by the Islamic State, and Dr. Denis Mukwege, a gynecological surgeon who founded a hospital in the Democratic Republic of Congo, were awarded the 2018 Nobel Peace Prize for their campaigns against the use of rape as a weapon of war.
lead_paragraph: Nadia Murad, a survivor of sexual violence by the Islamic State, and Dr. Denis Mukwege, a gynecological surgeon who founded a hospital in the Democratic Republic of Congo, were awarded the 2018 Nobel Peace Prize for their campaigns against the use of rape as a weapon of war.

headline: Family of Junior Seau Settles Case Against N.F.L.
abstract: The family of Seau, who was found to have C.T.E., reached a settlement with the league for an undisclosed sum, their lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: The family of Junior Seau, the Hall of Fame linebacker who committed suicide and was found to have a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, has reached a settlement with the N.F.L., ending a six-year legal standoff.

headline: Melania Trump Raises Eyebrows in Africa With Another White Hat
keywords: ['First Ladies (US)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Safaris', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The first lady drew criticism after she appeared on a safari grassland wearing a pith helmet — a common symbol of European colonial rule.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A half a world away from the spectacle of Washington, Melania Trump still managed to create one of her own during a Kenyan safari on Friday, riding out into the grassland wearing a crisp white pith helmet — a common symbol of European colonial rule.

headline: Review: The Doctor Regenerates, and So Does ‘Doctor Who’
abstract: Jodie Whittaker takes over the lead when this science-fiction institution starts a new season on BBC America, but the changes go way beyond gender.
lead_paragraph: Everything you read about Sunday’s season premiere of “Doctor Who” on BBC America will focus on the new Doctor, played by Jodie Whittaker, the first woman in the show’s five-decade succession of stars. (Like the previous 12, she’s British and white.) A woman as the Doctor is a big deal in the traditionally patriarchal, often rabidly insular world of science fiction.

headline: Kate Atkinson on ‘Transcription’
abstract: Atkinson discusses her new novel about a young woman caught up in spy work during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: Why Some Italian-Americans Still Fiercely Defend Columbus Day
keywords: ['Columbus Day', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Italian-Americans', 'Indigenous People', 'Exploration and Explorers']
abstract: A growing number of cities are replacing Columbus Day with Indigenous People’s Day, but Italian-Americans say that erases their history.
lead_paragraph: As cities across the country increasingly reject Columbus Day, choosing instead to celebrate Indigenous People’s Day, some Italian-Americans have sent a clear message: Their holiday isn’t going down without a fight.

headline: Slow Progress for Asians in Hollywood
abstract: A reader recounts the history of Asian actors in film and the theater.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Can We Discuss Your Anonymous Feedback?
abstract: An annual employee survey is advertised as strictly confidential. But an incident suggests that this isn’t always true. How should an employee respond when the privacy ground rules seem murky?
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: ‘Justice for Laquan!’ Demonstrators Chant, as Chicago Officer Is Convicted of Murder
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: For some residents, the trial of Officer Jason Van Dyke in the killing of Laquan McDonald became a proxy for years of anger over police mistreatment of black Chicagoans.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For three years, Chicago was racked by the political, legal and emotional impact of a chilling video that lasted only seconds: A black teenager could be seen collapsing onto a street as a white police officer shot him over and over, 16 times in the end.

headline: Opera on the High Line: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: A choral work on the elevated park, a dance set to Bach and a rising conductor were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: [Read all of our classical music coverage here.]

headline: Taming the Groundcherry: With Crispr, a Fussy Fruit Inches Toward the Supermarket
keywords: ['Fruit', 'Crispr (DNA)', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Tomatoes', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: You may have never eaten a groundcherry, but with common gene-editing techniques it and other fruits may be more easily domesticated.
lead_paragraph: The groundcherry might look at first like a purely ornamental plant. A member of the genus Physalis, it bears papery, heart-shaped husks that resemble Chinese lanterns. (The plant popularly known as the Chinese lantern is a close cousin.) Within each groundcherry casing is a small, tart, edible fruit, similar in appearance to a cherry tomato, that is sometimes sold at farmer’s markets.

headline: Cleveland Judge Refuses to Send Low-Level Defendants to Jail After Inmate Deaths
abstract: Judge Michael L. Nelson Sr. of Cleveland Municipal Court said a spate of six inmate deaths in four months showed that local jails were unsafe.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Cleveland is refusing to send people accused of low-level crimes into the county jail system, citing safety concerns after six inmate deaths in four months.

headline: Where Babe Ruth Still Draws Fans (and Liquor, Cigars and Hot Dogs)
abstract: Ruth’s grave has always been a pilgrimage spot for Yankees fans — especially during the playoffs, and especially against the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: HAWTHORNE, N.Y. — Michael Tavaniere, 80, walked up a grassy slope in Gate of Heaven Cemetery and approached a granite monument depicting Jesus blessing a little boy in a baseball uniform. “Ruth” was written in large capital letters along the bottom.

headline: Tears, Fury or Action: How Do You Express Anger?
abstract: Readers discussed their struggles expressing rage and suggest turning anger into action.
lead_paragraph: “Feelings of anger are a signal that something in my life is very wrong and needs to be changed,” wrote LD Buck in a comment on Rebecca Traister’s Opinion essay, “Fury Is a Political Weapon, and Women Need to Wield It.” In the article, Ms. Traister discussed the different ways in which men and women are encouraged to express their anger — or not — and how those differences were on display when Dr. Christine Blasey Ford and Judge Brett Kavanaugh testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee last week. Today, it seemed all but certain that Judge Kavanaugh would be confirmed to the Supreme Court by the Senate.

headline: Kerry James Marshall Paints for Chicago. His Mural Should Stay There.
abstract: The proposed auction of the artist’s 1995 painting “Knowledge and Wonder,” held by the Chicago Public Library, is a dreadful idea.
lead_paragraph: The painter Kerry James Marshall was born in Alabama, but he is defined by Chicago: the city he moved to in 1987, and whose private salons and public housing projects have inspired an art of rare ambition. His excellent retrospective “Mastry,” which opened at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago in 2016 and traveled to New York and Los Angeles, introduced huge new audiences to his grand tableaus of black American life, steeped in art history and defined by the coal-black paint he uses in place of African-American skin tones.

headline: A Virginia Coal Town Finds a New Natural Resource: Serpentine Roads for Motorcycling
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Scenic Route 16, with a twisting 32-mile stretch, is being branded for tourism as the “Back of the Dragon.”
lead_paragraph: By 1999, when Larry Davidson ended his 27-year military career and moved back to the Virginia mining town where his parents lived, the coal industry was dying, and the town of Tazewell with it. The businesses that thrived on coal — belt manufacturers, lathing companies, welding companies — had gradually disappeared. The once-affluent Main Street was blighted with empty storefronts. “You could not even buy a soft drink on Main Street, and that is a fact,” said Todd Day, Tazewell’s city manager. “Not even from a drink machine.”

headline: Find Jamal Khashoggi
abstract: Saudi Arabia must do everything in its power to help locate the missing Washington Post journalist.
lead_paragraph: In his first column for The Washington Post a year ago, the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi explained why he and others who had dared criticize the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, had been forced to go into self-imposed exile: “We are not opposed to our government and care deeply about Saudi Arabia. It is the only home we know or want. Yet we are the enemy.”

headline: Vladimir Radunsky, 64, Dies; Protean Children’s Book Illustrator
abstract: Mr. Radunsky harnessed a multitude of artistic styles for different narrative effects in books about subjects including Albert Einstein and a rapping dog.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Radunsky, an illustrator who used an abundance of artistic styles to create captivating children’s books about subjects including Albert Einstein, a rapping dog and a towering stalk of asparagus, died on Sept. 11 at a hospital near his home in Rome. He was 64.

headline: The Eight Biggest Beauty Trends From Fashion Month
abstract: Here, the boldest looks from the spring 2019 shows.
lead_paragraph: As seen on the spring 2019 runways, beauty is what you make of it — whether you choose to chop your bangs, layer on glitter or experiment with abstract eyeliner. Here, the boldest looks from the recent shows.

headline: House Democrat Promises Kavanaugh Investigation if Party Wins Control
abstract: Representative Jerrold Nadler, who is in line to be the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said he was prepared to look into accusations of sexual misconduct and perjury.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats will open an investigation into accusations of sexual misconduct and perjury against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh if they win control of the House in November, Representative Jerrold Nadler, the New York Democrat in line to be the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said on Friday.

headline: Awaiting a Final ‘Yes’ on Kavanaugh
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers express dismay at the process and events that brought us to this point.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: When Interference Occurs Before the Ball Is Snapped
abstract: The N.F.L.’s reliance on wireless communication between coordinators and players is littered with the potential for disruption.
lead_paragraph: Josh McCown knows the stomach-plunging feeling of approaching the huddle, anticipating a play call to come in through the two orange earphones inside his helmet, and hearing … nothing.

headline: As Kavanaugh Moves to Final Vote, Still No Resolution on Hill Harassment Legislation
abstract: Lawmakers have yet to finalize their own overhaul rules to handle discrimination and harassment on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Senate has wrestled in recent days with sexual misconduct allegations against Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, an uncomfortable reality lingered over Capitol Hill: Lawmakers have yet to complete their own promised overhaul of sexual discrimination and harassment rules for Congress.

headline: The Voices in José Mourinho’s Head
abstract: The Premier League’s vast punditocracy has had plenty to say about José Mourinho. But some criticism hits too close to home.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — For once, José Mourinho bit his tongue. Ordinarily, he is not the type to let criticism slide, or to refrain from offering a rebuttal. But last Tuesday night, he resisted. “I’m not interested,” he said. His air was that of a man whose appetite for battle has been, at last, exhausted.

headline: The Last Americans Fighting in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A rare look at the front lines where Special Forces battle the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: MOHMAND VALLEY, Afghanistan — When I spent time with the 12 men of the Operational Detachment Alpha team in July, they had been fighting an Islamic State affiliate, the Islamic State in Khorasan, for four months. The team was based at Combat Outpost Blackfish, a farm compound at the mouth of the bucolic Mohmand Valley that they had named after the killer whale.

headline: Indian Cooks Embrace the Instant Pot
abstract: The electric pressure cooker is well suited for many Indian dishes, and a slew of new cookbooks are seizing on its popularity.
lead_paragraph: When the cookbook author and food editor Chandra Ram was a child visiting relatives in India, the sounds coming from the kitchen would make her jump.

headline: New Jersey Transit Riders Get Glimpse of How Their Commute Could Get Worse
abstract: A derailment briefly closed down train service under the Hudson River, the type of disruption that transit advocates warn could cripple the Northeast if the tunnel closed for extensive repairs.
lead_paragraph: For riders of the country’s second-busiest railroad, the past few weeks have been a maddening drumbeat of delays and canceled trains. On Thursday, a “minor slow-speed” derailment in Manhattan near the Hudson River tunnel left thousands of commuters stranded.

headline: A Daughter’s Wedding Adds to the Drama Around the Senate’s Kavanaugh Vote
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Senator Steve Daines, Republican of Montana, probably won’t be needed to confirm Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh, but he’s ready to leave his daughter’s Big Sky wedding if necessary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sending their regrets to the senator, the wedding guests scrawled an explanation of the conflict preventing them from attending: “Same day as our female cattle sale.”

headline: Gwen Jorgensen Tries to Solve the Marathon
abstract: The world’s top female triathlete was sick of swimming every day. Now she wants to win a marathon gold medal in Tokyo. A husband who takes care of the baby should help.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Gwen Jorgensen, the world’s top female triathlete, had a baby, quit her sport and decided to become a runner.

headline: On Wall Street, the Bond Market Sets the Tone
abstract: The rise in yields is a double-edged sword. It reflects optimism about the economy, but also gives traders reasons to worry.
lead_paragraph: The bond market dominated the conversation on Wall Street this week as yields on benchmark Treasury bonds, which help determine interest rates for borrowers ranging from first-time home buyers to international corporations, steadily rose to seven-year highs.

headline: T Suggests: Detroit’s Hall of Mirrors, the Freedom of Bare Feet and More
abstract: A roundup of things our editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: When Beth Bugdaycay left her job as the C.E.O. of the ready-to-wear label Rebecca Taylor four years ago, she did so partly in order to collaborate with her husband, the real estate developer Murat Bugdaycay. In 2015, the couple launched Foundrae, a New York-based jewelry company whose eclectic, mystical pendants, chains and charms are adorned with silver and diamond-accented glyphs — including stars, arrows and pyramids — that Beth culls from across history and cultures. Her hope, she says, is that her pieces will ripen into “modern heirlooms.” Fittingly, the latest collection from Foundrae, a range of practical objects — lighters, matchbooks, pen knives and an incense holder — is based on the designer’s actual family heirlooms.

headline: On Politics With Lisa Lerer: Inside Murkowski’s Vote on Kavanaugh
abstract: Why a senator from Alaska broke from her party; photos from a crazy day on Capitol Hill; and Hillary’s Broadway debut.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Kavanaugh, Jobs, Nobel Peace Prize: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Brooklyn Heights Is Fighting Robert Moses Again
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Eminent Domain', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: The need for massive repairs on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway raises a fundamental question: Aren’t city planners supposed to plan ahead?
lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, I received an email asking me to participate in a survey that sought to gauge community interest in a swimming pool, to be built not far from my home in Brooklyn Heights. Would I use such a pool? How often? Would I bring children? Would I like it if there were yoga too?

headline: The Dutch Reach: A No-Tech Way to Save Bicyclists’ Lives
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Drivers Education']
abstract: This simple change in the way you get out of your car can save lives — of cyclists, drivers and passengers. Here’s how to do it, and why it’s so effective.
lead_paragraph: If Michael Charney has his way, more Americans would adopt a simple method to prevent “doorings,” a type of collision when a driver or passenger in a parked car opens a door into the path of a cyclist.

headline: Read Susan Collins’s Speech Declaring Support for Brett Kavanaugh
abstract: Senator Susan Collins of Maine, a key Republican vote, said “my fervent hope is that Brett Kavanaugh will work to lessen the divisions in the Supreme Court.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, announced her support on Friday for Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s Supreme Court nomination. With Ms. Collins’s key vote, Judge Kavanaugh is all but certain to be confirmed to the Supreme Court.

headline: Cuomo Accepts the Working Families Ballot Line, Ending Feud. For Now.
abstract: A bet by the Working Families Party on Cynthia Nixon didn’t work out. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo won big. The party then had to ask him to take its line, grudgingly.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — After a defiant rejection, a retaliatory strike, a big-time gamble, a big-time loss and a political walk of shame, the Working Families Party and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo arrived at a muted truce Friday, as the governor opted to take the party’s line in the November election.

headline: Richard Kaplan, Acclaimed Documentarian, Is Dead at 93
abstract: His films included an Oscar-winning study of Eleanor Roosevelt and a portrait of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that one critic called a “genuine spiritual epic.”
lead_paragraph: Richard Kaplan, who directed an Oscar-winning documentary about Eleanor Roosevelt and oversaw production of an acclaimed portrait of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. two years after his assassination, died on Sept. 29 in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: The Trade Deal is Done, but Wounds Remain: The Canada Letter
keywords: ['North American Free Trade Agreement', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: This week we review our coverage and the aftermath of North America’s new trade deal, and take a look at Quebec’s new government.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was some week: Canada cut a major trade pact and Quebecers had a memorable vote.

headline: ‘A Major Turning Point’: Chicagoans Weigh In on the Van Dyke Verdict
abstract: After the Chicago police officer Jason Van Dyke was found guilty of second-degree murder in the death of Laquan McDonald, Chicagoans told us what the verdict means for them and their city.
lead_paragraph: A jury found Jason Van Dyke, the Chicago police officer who shot and killed Laquan McDonald, a black teenager, guilty of second-degree murder on Friday. The verdict came three years after the release of a dashboard-camera video that shows Officer Van Dyke firing 16 shots at Laquan.

headline: Church Manual to Prevent Sex Abuse Sets Off Outrage of Its Own
abstract: The Chilean Catholic Church withdrew and apologized for a manual that gave examples of inappropriate behavior but failed to actually call them sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — The manual, published by the Archbishop’s office of Santiago, Chile, said that it was inappropriate to “pat the buttocks or touch the genital area or chest” of minors.

headline: Ford, an Automaker at a Crossroads, Seeks Cuts and Partners
abstract: With its stock at its lowest point since 2009, the company plans to trim its salaried work force and is exploring an alliance with Volkswagen.
lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — When Ford Motor was celebrating the 100th anniversary of its Rouge industrial complex last week, its chairman, William C. Ford Jr., offered an optimistic outlook for the years ahead.

headline: Sydney Goldstein, Maestro of Public Conversation, Dies at 73
abstract: She founded City Arts & Lectures, which showcases conversation as entertainment and is broadcast on more than 100 public radio stations nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Sydney Goldstein, a San Francisco impresario who helped pioneer the art of showcasing conversation as a cultural offering, died on Sept. 25 in Los Angeles. She was 73.

headline: William Helfand, a Collector Intrigued by Quackery, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Helfand’s collection of posters and prints for dubious medical cures was formidable. It is now spread among assorted museums.
lead_paragraph: William H. Helfand, whose vast collection of prints, posters and similar memorabilia documented the peddling of spurious pills, potions and other medical treatments across the centuries in the United States and beyond, died on Tuesday in Branford, Conn. He was 92.

headline: Susan Collins, Standing Alone, Makes Her Case for Kavanaugh
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', '#MeToo Movement']
abstract: The Republican senator from Maine delivered a 45-minute, point-by-point civics lesson of a speech to explain her support for President Trump’s nominee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Susan Collins was on her own.

headline: HPV Vaccine Expanded for People Ages 27 to 45
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the use of Gardasil 9, a vaccine against nine strains of the human papillomavirus for older age groups.
lead_paragraph: The HPV vaccine, which prevents cervical cancer and other malignancies, is now approved for men and women from 27 to 45-years-old, the Food and Drug Administration said on Friday.

headline: Robert Pinsky: Patriotism for an Age of Unreason
abstract: When things are headed in the wrong direction, it’s good to remember who truly loves their country.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you read something when you are young that stays with you forever. In the 1960s, when I was barely out of my teens, that happened to me with Paul Goodman’s “Growing up Absurd.”

headline: The High Court Brought Low
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: Don’t let Donald Trump and Brett Kavanaugh have the last word about American justice.
lead_paragraph: So what now?

headline: The Myth of the Lazy Nonvoter
abstract: Most Americans want to vote. Many states make it nearly impossible.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans want to vote. Many states make it nearly impossible.

headline: After Lots of Bluster, Trump Has a Week to Brag About
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: But in Mr. Trump’s scorched-earth presidency, the victories — whether the success of Judge Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination or the trade deal with Canada and Mexico — are divisive and come at a cost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He promised so much success that everyone would be tired of all the winning. But after 20 months that proved more arduous than President Trump once imagined, this may be the best week of his presidency so far.

headline: Bitter Tenor of Senate Reflects a Nation at Odds With Itself
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', '#MeToo Movement', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The battle over the confirmation of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh has exposed a climate of partisan distrust rivaled by few other moments in the recent past.
lead_paragraph: As he helped speed Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s embattled nomination toward a vote this week, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the Republican chairman of the Judiciary Committee, declared that the Senate was approaching “rock bottom” and needed to right itself.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Collins and Manchin Say They’ll Back Him for Court
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 6, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “Certain fundamental legal principles about due process, presumption of innocence do bear on my thinking and I cannot abandon them. We will be ill-served in the long run if we abandon the presumption of innocence.”

headline: What It All Meant
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', '#MeToo Movement', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination was about so much more than Brett Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: Well, on the positive side, we probably won’t have to spend the autumn watching the leaves turn and listening to people talk about Brett Kavanaugh.

headline: F.B.I. Review of Kavanaugh Was Limited From the Start
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President Trump, reacting to critics, said the F.B.I. should have a free hand to investigate. But the White House counsel told him that was a bad idea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An exasperated President Trump picked up the phone to call the White House counsel, Donald F. McGahn II, last Sunday. Tell the F.B.I. they can investigate anything, he told Mr. McGahn, because we need the critics to stop.

headline: An Insidious and Contagious American Presidency
abstract: Trump believes that judges should be agents of those who appoint them. That would be the end of the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: Insidious is the man. Insidious is his pollution of the F.B.I., whose former director, James Comey, he fired after Comey refused to show “loyalty.” Loyalty in this instance meant willingness to shelve, at Trump’s demand, an investigation into dealings between his first national security adviser, Michael Flynn, and Russia.

headline: Of Demagogues and Pedagogues
abstract: Colombia demonstrates the value of the political center.
lead_paragraph: Last week I interviewed Colombian President Iván Duque, who took office in August and calls himself a man of the “extreme center.” In an era of rising populism, I asked, how should politicians make the case for reviving or strengthening centrist-style politics?

headline: Alex Cora Manages the Red Sox and Inspires Boston’s Puerto Ricans
abstract: Cora, 42, is the team’s first Latino manager, and in his first year at the helm he led the Sox to a franchise record 108 regular-season wins.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Over the winter, the Boston Red Sox handed Alex Cora, a native of Puerto Rico and a former player, the reins of a talented team with realistic World Series aspirations. It was a first not just for him — he had never been a major league manager — but also for this storied franchise. None of the previous 46 managers in its 118-year history were Latino, or members of any other minority group.

headline: Make Rent
abstract: Lewis Dean Hyatt is here to shred your Saturday solve average.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE —  I have been flattened by whatever flu or cold is going around, so forgive me for being brief and/or obtuse this weekend.  I thought I’d be able to power through thanks to zinc and a few walks in the sun, but whatever germs are doing this should be working for big pharma because I’m frankly grateful to be going through one of those day/night packs of  over-the-counter stuff.

headline: Corrections: October 6, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 6, 2018.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Red Sox Pounce. The Yankees Peck. The Red Sox Win.
abstract: The first part of the game was pure bliss for Boston: a quick 5-0 lead. The last part of the game was pure anguish as the Yankees drew closer and closer.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Narratives, when they are weighted with history, are not easily rewritten.

headline: On Politics: This Week’s Biggest Stories
abstract: From Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s all-but-assured confirmation to revelations about President Trump’s wealth, here are some of this week’s biggest stories in American politics.
lead_paragraph: From Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s all-but-assured confirmation to revelations about President Trump’s wealth, here are some of this week’s biggest stories in American politics. (And some links if you wish to read further.)

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: Flight of the Conchords and ‘A Prayer Before Dawn’
abstract: Flight of the Conchords gets a comedy special on HBO. And “A Prayer Before Dawn” comes to Amazon Prime.
lead_paragraph: Get ready for “Business Time”: Flight of the Conchords gets a comedy special on HBO. And “A Prayer Before Dawn” comes to Amazon Prime.

headline: 8-Year-Old Girl Pulls Pre-Viking Sword From Lake in Sweden
abstract: Saga Vanacek recovered a sword lost for more than a thousand years, and kept the find secret for months while archaeologists surveyed the site.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — At the height of a sweltering summer, Saga Vanecek went paddling in a southern Swedish lake. And in the shallow waters, reduced by a long heat wave, she came across something astonishing.

headline: Bosnia’s Election Exacerbates Old Divisions, to Russia’s Satisfaction
abstract: Sunday’s election has highlighted many of ingrained problems: corruption, high unemployment, rising nativism, public disillusionment and foreign meddling.
lead_paragraph: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina — Just before Bosnia’s presidential elections on Sunday, the separatist Serb leader Milorad Dodik made sure to pay a public visit to one of his most important backers: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Montserrat Caballé, Opera Star With ‘Ethereal’ Voice, Is Dead at 85
abstract: One of the 20th century’s most renowned sopranos, the Spanish-born Ms. Caballé inspired delirious adulation on both sides of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Montserrat Caballé, the Spanish soprano widely counted among the last of the old-time prima donnas for the transcendent purity of her voice, the sweeping breadth of her repertory and the delirious adulation of her fans, died on Saturday in Barcelona. She was 85.

headline: The Endangered Beer Hall Adds to Germany’s Cultural Debate
abstract: One village’s effort to save their local pub, by selling shares to residents, highlights the steady disappearance of traditional venues as Germany grows older and more diverse.
lead_paragraph: HANDORF-LANGENBERG, Germany — When 87-year-old Hubert Frilling died quietly in his sleep a year ago, the village beer hall he owned and ran for more than 60 years, “Zum Schanko,” looked set to die with him.

headline: The Trump Trade Strategy Is Coming Into Focus. That Doesn’t Necessarily Mean It Will Work.
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Taking an aggressive stance with traditional allies now seems to be just a warm-up for the main event: isolating China.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has been closely watching the Trump administration’s strategy for remaking global trade might have reasonably believed at times that it had no strategy for remaking global trade.

headline: ‘Vice,’ ‘The Mule’ and More: The Week’s Best and Worst Trailers
abstract: Christian Bale looks convincing as Dick Cheney, Clint Eastwood’s drug runner looks promising, but Taron Egerton’s ‘Robin Hood’ is feeling more pointless.
lead_paragraph: Trailers for several much-anticipated movies dropped this week. Here’s a roundup of the best and worst, ranked from most to least promising.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: Trump and the myth of the self-made man. Lady Gaga is still shape shifting. What makes ‘The Good Place’ so good? What’s a postpartum doula? And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. There are provisions to pick up and there is baseball to watch. Maybe this is the weekend to make your famous chili or bake some cookies. No matter what you’re doing, make some time to read some great journalism.

headline: U.S. General Considered Nuclear Response in Vietnam War, Cables Show
keywords: ['Vietnam War', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Books and Literature', 'United States International Relations', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: In 1968, a top American military commander wanted to move nuclear weapons to South Vietnam to prevent defeat in a key battle. President Johnson refused.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of the darkest moments of the Vietnam War, the top American military commander in Saigon activated a plan in 1968 to move nuclear weapons to South Vietnam until he was overruled by President Lyndon B. Johnson, according to recently declassified documents cited in a new history of wartime presidential decisions.

headline: An Ancient Ant-Bacteria Partnership to Protect Fungus
abstract: Amber specimens indicate that fungus-farming ants have been cooperating with antimicrobial bacteria for tens of millions of years.
lead_paragraph: The dawn of agriculture did not rise with Neolithic humans in Mesopotamia. Or in China. Or in the Levant. No, it bloomed in the rain forests of South America some 60 million years ago. And the first farmers were humble ants.

headline: Why Count All the Squirrels in Central Park? Why the Heck Not
abstract: The team behind the park’s census of Eastern grays say an accurate tally is possible despite the critters’, well, squirrelish ways.
lead_paragraph: Attention, urban rodent fans.

headline: Imagine Burning Man Without the Tech Crowd
abstract: At the Oregon Country Fair, a three-day summer festival in Veneta, Ore., “people in society that can’t do what they want to do can do it here.”
lead_paragraph: Just past the entrance of the Oregon Country Fair, a three-day summer festival held in Veneta, Ore., elaborately costumed fairgoers — half-clothed dragons, fairies and clowns — crowded narrow alleys. A family of stilt walkers playing violins and dressed in Renaissance garb nearly careened into passers-by. At “Fair,” improv abounds and those without scheduled acts make stages out of shady groves.

headline: Cameroon on Brink of Civil War as English Speakers Recount ‘Unbearable’ Horrors
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Elections', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'English Language', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A crackdown on separatists has emptied cities amid accounts of soldiers burning homes and shooting civilians. Despite the chaos, the country holds an election Sunday.
lead_paragraph: BUEA, Cameroon — A soldier’s crumpled corpse at a traffic circle. Young men gunned down in their living room while partying. A teenage boy killed by a stray bullet while watching television. Outbursts of gunfire so frequent that children call them “frying popcorn.”

headline: Around the World in a Day With Carmen Electra
abstract: Carmen Electra, a shining vision of American success, keeps totally making it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Carmen Electra, the Prince protégé who fled Paisley Park for Hollywood, married and divorced Dennis Rodman, and launched her acting career in a tiny red “Baywatch” regulation swimsuit, recently did one of the riskiest things she’s ever done, professionally speaking.

headline: Who Is Neri Oxman?
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Bees', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Design', 'Synthetic Biology', 'Bacteria', '3-D Devices and Effects']
abstract: A star of M.I.T.’s Media Lab working in “material ecology,” she has intrigued Björk, Brad Pitt and the Cooper Hewitt.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — One hot day in early September, Neri Oxman, a tenured professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Media Lab, was on her way to lunch when it hit her. “‘Form follows pheromones!’” she remembered exclaiming. “I was thinking, as I was devouring my meatball sandwich, about how we could use robotic arms to spit out pheromones guiding bees to template honeycombs in the absence of queens. The robots, you see, could master the hive.”

headline: A Place I Could Call My Own
abstract: On growing up in the Bronx, and never truly leaving it.
lead_paragraph: When I was born, my mother and father lived on the first floor of a six-story building in the Bronx that looked just like all the other buildings compressed on my block, and all the other buildings stretching to infinity outside. I shared a small room with my parents, my thin bed pushed into the corner and my window facing a brick wall. I was close enough to hear their fights at night. Close enough to jump into their bed when I was disturbed by a bad dream.

headline: Ireland Bill Aims to Crack Down on Excessive Drinking With Health Warning Labels
abstract: Legislation passed by the lower house of Parliament orders sweeping restrictions on how alcohol is sold and advertised.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland will impose tobacco-style health warning labels on alcohol as part of a sweeping package of restrictions intended to tackle what a World Health Organization survey ranks as one of the world’s worst rates of binge drinking.

headline: Miniature Horses Are Welcome on Alaska Airlines (But No Snakes, Please)
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Horses', 'Disabilities']
abstract: The airline has clarified its policy about which service animals are allowed on board. Mini horses, welcome to the club.
lead_paragraph: In the 30 years he’s worked at Alaska Airlines, Ray Prentice has never actually heard of a miniature horse boarding one of its flights.

headline: In Home Run Era, Red Sox’ J.D. Martinez Is More Than ‘Just Dingers’
abstract: With a .330 average to go with his 43 home runs, Martinez, Boston’s star off-season acquisition, has become a complete hitter.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The nickname is both irresistible and inaccurate. J. D. Martinez hits so many home runs his initials might as well stand for Just Dingers. It’s a cute line, fun to say. It also misses the essence of the complete hitter who elevated the Boston Red Sox to the best record in baseball this season.

headline: Their Long-Distance Relationship Kept Getting Shorter
abstract: The couple had many mutual friends, but didn’t meet until after they connected through OkCupid.
lead_paragraph: Reeba Susamma Monachan and Keshav Sethi Attrey were married Oct. 6 at Belk Chapel on the campus of Queens University in Charlotte, N.C. Dr. Janice Odom, who was ordained by the Alliance of Baptists at Pullen Memorial Baptist Church in Raleigh, N.C., performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Father George Philipose, vicar of the Christian Orthodox Church, taking part. Earlier in the day, the couple took part in a Sikh ceremony at the Gurdwara Sahib Charlotte in North Carolina. Gyani Satnam Singh Ji, a Sikh priest and a friend of the couple, performed the ceremony.

headline: Fact-Checking the President: Has He Saved or Sabotaged Obamacare?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: President Trump boasts that he has “mostly obliterated Obamacare.” His health secretary is taking credit for making the law work better than ever. Who’s right?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as President Trump boasts that he has “eliminated the core of Obamacare,” his health secretary is taking credit for making the law work better than ever.

headline: My Co-Op Building Is Going Smoke-Free, But I Don’t Want to Quit
abstract: If you don’t want to sell your apartment or be evicted, you probably can’t use it the way you always have.
lead_paragraph: Q: The Manhattan co-op where I have lived for 20 years will become a smoke-free building in January. I am a 76-year-old smoker. It’s a bad habit that I picked up in college, but I still enjoy it. I don’t think I should be forced to sell my apartment or move because the rules changed. I understand that a new policy could affect new owners, but shouldn’t there be an exception for longtime residents? Do I have any right to challenge this?

headline: Banksy Painting Self-Destructs After Fetching $1.4 Million at Sotheby’s
abstract: The British street artist Banksy appeared to pull off one of his most spectacular pranks on Friday night, with a frame that shredded his “Girl With Balloon” after it sold.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British street artist Banksy pulled off one of his most spectacular pranks on Friday night, when one of his trademark paintings appeared to self-destruct at Sotheby’s in London after selling for $1.4 million at auction.

headline: 10 Recipes Readers Love
abstract: Spicy spaghetti with caramelized onions, old-fashioned beef stew, and more to cook this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, make 5-minute hummus (above), Julia Moskin’s chicken francese or any of the top dishes of the week. Click the “10 Most Popular Recipes” collection below for more recipes.

headline: ‘We Just Didn’t Buy It’: Jury Was Unswayed by Officer’s Story in Laquan McDonald Case
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Jury System', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Jurors who convicted Officer Jason Van Dyke of second-degree murder said they believed dashboard camera video footage over his tearful testimony.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Officer Jason Van Dyke asked 12 jurors to trust his memory, not a widely circulated dashboard camera video, to know what really happened the night he shot Laquan McDonald 16 times.

headline: As Tokyo Fish Market Closes, Sellers and Customers Honor an Era of Grime
abstract: Tsukiji, thought to be the world’s largest seafood market, is relocating. On its last day, few welcomed the prospect of an air-conditioned future.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It’s going to be tough to replace 83 years’ worth of grime.

headline: What the ‘Grievance Studies’ Hoax Really Shows
abstract: The problem is not the subject matter. It’s that these scholars are marginalized in overly specialized fields.
lead_paragraph: Another culture war, another hoax inflicted on left-wing academics.

headline: Confirming Kavanaugh: A Triumph for Conservatives, but a Blow to the Court’s Image
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Supreme Court will move further to the right than it has been in many decades, with two distinct blocs that reflect the deep polarization of the American public and political system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Trump and for Senate Republicans, confirming Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh as a Supreme Court justice was a hard-won political victory. But for the conservative legal movement, it is a signal triumph, the culmination of a decades-long project that began in the Reagan era with the heady goal of capturing a solid majority on the nation’s highest court.

headline: Brazil’s Presidential Race: Who’s Ahead and What to Expect
keywords: ['Elections', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: A far-right candidate who was a marginal political figure as recently as a year ago has emerged as the front-runner in Brazil’s presidential election on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — There has been no lack of drama in the lead-up to Brazil’s presidential election on Sunday. One candidate was jailed, another was stabbed and a week before the voting, women organized nationwide protests against the front-runner.

headline: A Year of Reckoning
abstract: To move forward, we have to excavate the past.
lead_paragraph: One year ago, on Oct. 5, 2017, when we stood with our editors and pressed the “publish” button on Harvey Weinstein’s secrets, we were unsure what would happen next.

headline: Variety: Split Decisions
abstract: I’m always of two minds when solving these Fred Piscop puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — So I think I need to be in a particular mood for Split Decisions, which is unlike all the other variety offerings we have in that there’s so much deduction involved and that requires a certain type of patience from me. I absolutely never solve them quickly, I’ll tell you that.

headline: The Laquan McDonald Case: a Turning Point or an Aberration?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: In this week’s Race/Related newsletter, Officer Jason Van Dyke is found guilty, the Texas governor’s race, and more controversy at Ole Miss.
lead_paragraph: Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox. ¶

headline: In Disaster’s Grip, Again and Again, on Indonesian Island
keywords: ['Earthquakes', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The earthquake and tsunami that devastated Indonesia’s Sulawesi Island struck a place where every kind of catastrophe — natural and man-made — has piled on, and help is far away.
lead_paragraph: SIGI, Indonesia — The sun was setting on the mosque in Sigi, and Randi Renaldi, 7, knelt and reached his fingers out in supplication. Then the ground beneath him juddered and swayed.

headline: ‘This Moment Turned Out to Be Fleeting’
keywords: ['#MeToo Movement', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Men and Boys', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Nine reflections on #MeToo, one year on.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, the #MeToo movement spawned hundreds of articles reflecting on where all this is headed. Some reveled in an unexpected revolution — in late October, Margaret Renkl celebrated “the raw power of #MeToo.” Some fretted about its potential to sprawl: In January, Bari Weiss wrote that a story about Aziz Ansari’s behavior in his personal life, not his workplace, “trivializes what #MeToo first stood for.” Still others used the moment to train a lens on the Bible, advice columns and Bill Clinton.

headline: What They’re Saying About Kavanaugh on the Senate Floor
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: A series of Democrats and a couple of Republicans made remarks through Friday night and into Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate is expected to vote Saturday afternoon to send Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court in a momentous victory for President Trump and Senate Republicans, after a grueling confirmation battle that roiled the nation.

headline: How Every Senator Voted on Kavanaugh’s Confirmation
abstract: The Senate voted 50-48 on Saturday to confirm the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: The Senate voted 50-48 on Saturday to confirm the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh.

headline: What Has Actually Changed in a Year
keywords: ['#MeToo Movement', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Women and Girls', 'Strikes', 'Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Discrimination', 'Workplace Environment', 'Minimum Wage', 'Organized Labor', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Tips and Tipping']
abstract: It’s worth recognizing the progress brought about by the #MeToo movement.
lead_paragraph: It’s worth recognizing the progress brought about by the #MeToo movement.

headline: Afghanistan Signs Major Mining Deals Despite Legal Concerns
abstract: Civil society groups say the government breached the law by awarding contracts to a consortium that included a businessman who was a cabinet minister.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government on Friday signed two contracts for the exploration of copper and gold deposits in the north, in a bid to move away from the country’s dependence on foreign aid by tapping its mineral wealth.

headline: Hackers, Good and Bad
abstract: A reader suggests that some of the good guys may in fact be bad guys when it serves their purpose.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Susan Collins Is the Worst Kind of Maverick
abstract: She votes with the most right-wing members of her party, even while attempting to occupy some imaginary moral high ground.
lead_paragraph: Belgrade Lakes, Me. — My wife and I gathered around the television on Friday to listen to our senior senator, Susan Collins, announce her final decision on the nomination of Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.

headline: Kavanaugh Is Sworn In After Close Confirmation Vote in Senate
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: His elevation locked in a solid conservative majority on the Supreme Court and capped a rancorous battle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh was confirmed to the Supreme Court on Saturday by one of the slimmest margins in American history, locking in a solid conservative majority on the court and capping a rancorous battle that began as a debate over judicial ideology and concluded with a national reckoning over sexual misconduct.

headline: Does Melania Trump Ever Tell the President to Put Away His Phone? ‘Yes!’
abstract: In front of the Great Sphinx in Egypt, Mrs. Trump took questions on Brett Kavanaugh, the president’s remarks about Africa and his Twitter habits.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — No one can say Melania Trump, the first lady, doesn’t understand the power of an image.

headline: The Pope and the Accusers
abstract: Can Francis change the church while stonewalling on sex abuse?
lead_paragraph: Let me ask you to do the impossible, tear your mind away from the Kavanaugh affair for a moment, and cast your eyes from the new Rome to the old one — from the American Empire’s judicial wars to the similar mix of scandal, polarization, and intrigue in the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Deputies Made Jokes About a Veteran Thrashing in His Cell Before He Died
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Bryan Perry, an Iraq War veteran, was in jail suffering from an apparent drug overdose in 2016. In a cellphone video, deputies can be heard laughing at him.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, a man died of an apparent drug overdose after being held at the Clackamas County Jail in Oregon City, Ore.

headline: Lindsey Graham Is the Saddest Story in Washington
abstract: His fight for Brett Kavanaugh completed his transformation into Donald Trump’s slobbering manservant.
lead_paragraph: The battle over Brett Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court was an especially ugly episode of a reality-show presidency that degrades almost everyone swept up in it, and many characters stagger away from it looking worse than ever.

headline: Stopping Climate Change Is Hopeless. Let’s Do It.
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power']
abstract: It begins with how we live our lives every moment of every day.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the world’s leading climate scientists are expected to release a report on how to protect civilization by limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, or 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit. Given the rise already in the global temperature average, this critical goal is 50 percent more stringent than the current target of 2 degrees Celsius, which many scientists were already skeptical we could meet. So we’re going to have to really want it, and even then it will be tough.

headline: Justice Delayed, With a Life on the Line
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Capital Punishment', 'Criminal Justice', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown is still reviewing a murder case that advanced DNA testing could settle.
lead_paragraph: Imagine being framed for a horrific crime: the fatal stabbing of a married couple and two children. You then spend 35 years in prison awaiting execution for that quadruple murder.

headline: I'm Just a Middle-Aged House Dad Addicted to Pot
abstract: Cannabis should be legal, just as alcohol should be legal. But marijuana addiction exists, and it almost wrecked my life.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — My name is Neal, and I’m a marijuana addict.

headline: Why Is Behavioral Economics So Popular?
abstract: The recent vogue for this academic field is in part a triumph of marketing.
lead_paragraph: Behavioral economics seems to have captured the popular imagination. Authors like Michael Lewis write about it in best sellers like “The Undoing Project,” while pioneers of the field like Daniel Kahneman popularize it in books like “Thinking, Fast and Slow.” Its lexicon of “nudging,” “framing bias” and “the endowment effect” has become part of the vernacular of business, finance and policymaking. Even “Crazy Rich Asians,” the summer’s blockbuster romantic comedy, features an explicit nod to “loss aversion,” a key concept in the field.

headline: Pope Orders New Inquiry Into Abuse Accusations Against McCarrick
abstract: The Vatican said that it would study its archives to see how Archbishop Theodore McCarrick was able to climb the church hierarchy despite years of allegations.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis has ordered a deeper investigation into the accusations of sexual misconduct against Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick, the Vatican said Saturday, including a “thorough study” of archival documents to determine how he climbed the church hierarchy despite allegations he had slept with seminarians and young priests.

headline: Con Man Claimed to ‘Cure’ Childless Women. Blackmail Followed, Then Bodies.
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Honor Killings', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Superstitions']
abstract: Rasool Landay lured Afghan women into having sex with him to treat their infertility. He then filmed the encounters and extorted money. Officials fear some of the women may been killed by relatives.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — For years, Rasool Landay went from place to place in northern Afghanistan, offering a very specialized and in-demand service: treatment for women unable to have children.

headline: The Prison ‘Old-Timers’ Who Gave Me Life
abstract: Aging inmates, some serving life sentences, helped me turn my life around. They could do even more good on the outside.
lead_paragraph: I can speak for both myself and my older brother, Darryl, when I say that March 8, 2000, was the most regrettable day of our lives. On that day, I accompanied Darryl to an encounter with a gang member who, days earlier, had sexually assaulted Darryl’s wife. We were both armed. Rather than report the assault, we set out for a confrontation. Within seconds, the situation escalated and Darryl fired several shots in a struggle for the gun, wounding the gang member and himself. Darryl and I survived. The gang member did not.

headline: Naomi Osaka, a New Governor and Me
abstract: Is Japan becoming more welcoming to mixed-race people?
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Just over 40 years ago, when my family moved from California to Tokyo, the fact that my mother was Japanese did not stop schoolchildren from pointing at me and yelling “Gaijin!” — the Japanese word for foreigner — as I walked down the street.

headline: Full Video: Senate Delivers Final Vote on Kavanaugh
abstract: After a highly contentious nomination process, senators delivered the final vote on the confirmation of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: After a highly contentious nomination process, senators delivered the final vote on the confirmation of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court.

headline: Medicaid’s Work Requirement
abstract: A Medicaid special-needs health plan takes issue with Arkansas’ move.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 50 Die After Accident and Fire in Democratic Republic of Congo
abstract: The fire broke out just as local residents had reached the scene to gather leaking fuel.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — At least 50 people were killed and more than 100 suffered burns in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Saturday when a tanker truck collided with a bus and caught fire, officials said.

headline: A Sometimes-Shaky Boston Bullpen Is a Steady Source of Anxiety
abstract: The Red Sox relievers were shaky this season and no more impressive in the team’s Game 1 victory on Friday night. In Game 2, they were a lot better, for a while.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Red Sox set a club record by winning 108 games in the regular season. They put an end to any serious talk of a divisional pennant race in early August and demonstrated a cohesive approach under their new manager, Alex Cora, that had not been seen in Boston for several years.

headline: Did Facebook Learn Anything From the Cambridge Analytica Debacle?
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Media']
abstract: An even bigger data breach suggests it didn’t.
lead_paragraph: It’s been barely six months since Mark Zuckerberg appeared before Congress and promised lawmakers and the American public that he and Facebook, the company he founded and leads today, would do better. “This episode has clearly hurt us,” Mr. Zuckerberg said. “We have to do a lot of work about building trust back.”

headline: Women, What Is Your Reaction to Kavanaugh’s Confirmation?
abstract: We are eager to understand how women are viewing this moment.
lead_paragraph: The battle over Judge Brett M. Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court has been one of the most bitter, emotional and galvanizing political events of our time. Now that the decision is made, we’d like to hear from women — of all political persuasions — how you feel about it.

headline: With ‘Fishy’ Jet Deal, India’s Opposition Finally Lands a Blow on Modi
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The Congress Party has found a new spring in its step by hounding Prime Minister Narendra Modi over the purchase of fighter jets from France, a deal that it says raises questions of corruption.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India swept into office four years ago vowing to crush corruption. Some of his most momentous acts since taking office, like wiping out nearly 90 percent of India’s currency virtually overnight, have been to clean up the country’s endemic graft.

headline: ‘I Voted’ Stickers for 2018
abstract: You have a month to get them ready.
lead_paragraph: The midterm elections are a month away! On Nov. 6, citizens across America will head to the polls, hoping to change their country for the better and/or to politically humiliate someone they didn’t realize was alive until a year and a half ago.

Kavanaugh sat in the anteroom of Room 216 in the Hart Senate Office Building, a sterile, living-room-like space with a couch and a couple of armchairs and a large television on the wall. His chances of joining the Supreme Court seemed to be vanishing. “Disaster,” read the text message from one Republican.

headline: A Day of Broad Smiles and Raised Thumbs for Trump

headline: Cory Booker Criticizes Trump in Iowa, Where Presidential Hopefuls Flock
abstract: Mr. Booker, of New Jersey, is one of several potential Democratic presidential candidates who is crisscrossing the country, getting themselves in front of voters.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey did not announce he was running for president on Saturday. Nor did he say he was thinking about it. But on a demoralizing day for Democrats, he came to this bellwether state and sounded a lot like someone who wanted to lead the Democratic Party in its quest to oust President Trump from the White House.

abstract: Curators enlisted a drone to survey damage to the Fuentidueña apse, which dates to the 12th century, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Cloisters in Northern Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Filed away at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are documents with photographs showing the condition of the objects in the Met’s collection, and not just the Van Goghs and the Vermeers. The Met has tiny objects like a 3,000-year-old seal from a Mesopotamian cylinder that is 1⅛ inches tall and a miniature cotton tunic from South America.

headline: North Korea Agrees to Allow Inspectors Into Nuclear Testing Site, Pompeo Says
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also said that during his fourth trip to Pyongyang he had discussed a new meeting between President Trump and the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that in his meeting with Kim Jong-un on Sunday, the leader of North Korea had agreed to allow inspectors into a key nuclear testing site that the North has claimed it blew up, a down payment on the country’s commitment to denuclearize the country.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’: How to Write the Perfect Con

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’: How to Cook Up the Perfect Con
abstract: For four seasons, the writers of “Saul” have slowly been transforming Jimmy McGill into the slimy Saul Goodman. In this video, they broke down a pivotal scene before the season finale.
lead_paragraph: What compels otherwise decent people to choose a path of destruction? And what are the stories they fashion to live with the consequences? These questions drove AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” in which a high school teacher transforms himself into a ruthless drug lord, as they have that show’s prequel series, “Better Call Saul,” about a good-hearted lawyer with a slippery past (Bob Odenkirk) whose fate, as we know, leads to perdition.
