headline: Behind Enemy Lines: The Red Sox Fan at Yankee Stadium
abstract: Smile a lot at the natives and monitor their beer intake. If someone begins to growl, back off, smiling. Maybe know where the security man stands.
lead_paragraph: As tribal baseball war had returned to the Bronx on a milky misty Monday night, I figured I’d play anthropologist and find that most outlandish of homo sapiens risk takers, the Red Sox fan in Yankee Stadium.

headline: In Year of the Homer, a Single Is the Dodgers’ Biggest Hit
abstract: Los Angeles advances to meet Milwaukee, helped by a David Freese pinch hit.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Los Angeles Dodgers needed a change to their offensive disposition Monday in the National League division series with the Atlanta Braves.

headline: Review: In ‘Liyana,’ Swaziland Orphans Turn Hardship Into a Folk Tale
abstract: The film follows a group of orphans as they take part in a storytelling workshop.
lead_paragraph: By addressing strife in Africa in a roundabout way, “Liyana” breaks free of the heaviness that can weigh down an issue-based documentary. The movie, directed by Aaron and Amanda Kopp, follows a group of orphans at a home in Swaziland as they take part in a storytelling workshop.

headline: Review: In His Last Years, Oscar Wilde Is Far From ‘The Happy Prince’
abstract: Written and directed by Rupert Everett, who also stars, the film opens as Wilde is released from prison after serving two years for gross indecency.
lead_paragraph: A mopey yet gorgeous-looking wallow in the final years of the literary giant Oscar Wilde, “The Happy Prince” staggers around Europe with one eye on the grave and the other on the kinds of sorry mischief an unrepentant hedonist like Wilde could get up to.

headline: The Unknowable Fallout of China’s Trade War Nuclear Option
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Economy']
abstract: China holds more than a trillion dollars in United States debt, and an escalating trade war could tempt it to wield that debt in a way that has long been unthinkable.
lead_paragraph: It is often called the nuclear option.

headline: Janet Jackson, Stevie Nicks and Def Leppard Nominated for Rock & Roll Hall of Fame
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Halls of Fame']
abstract: The 15 acts eligible for the class of 2019 also include Radiohead, Rage Against the Machine, the Cure and Devo.
lead_paragraph: Folk, new wave, hip-hop, R&B, rap-rock, heavy metal and good old-fashioned rock ’n’ roll are among the many genres (and subgenres) represented by the latest shortlist of nominees for induction into the ever-broadening Rock & Roll Hall of Fame.

headline: Voter Suppression Is No Excuse
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities']
abstract: Yes, it’s an outrage. But it is not the main reason that voter turnout is so low.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: Turkish Officials Say Khashoggi Was Killed on Order of Saudi Leadership
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'News and News Media', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Security officials have concluded that the Saudi dissident was killed within two hours of his arrival at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul, and his body dismembered.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Top Turkish security officials have concluded that the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi was assassinated in the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul on orders from the highest levels of the royal court, a senior official said Tuesday.

headline: A Paste That Brings the Heat
abstract: Quibos Pepper Original Hot Pepper Paste is based on achar, a fiery relish of green mango and chiles.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a new hot pepper condiment that does not disappear in a splash. It has a chunky texture, making it suitable to serve alongside grilled meats or fish, or to be mixed with soft butter and spread on lamb chops. It’s Caribbean, but based on a relish found in India and Indonesia called achar. The ingredients are mostly green mango and high-octane chiles, seasoned generously with cumin.

headline: The Not-So-Sweet Side of Sugar
abstract: The violent history of sugar is the subject of a talk at the Brooklyn Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: James Walvin, a professor emeritus of history at the University of York in England, will discuss his book “Sugar: The World Corrupted, From Slavery to Obesity,” at the Brooklyn Historical Society. He promises not to sweeten the very fraught story of this culinary staple.

headline: A Little Purple Bag Brings Back Memories
abstract: Crown Royal’s newest release, a 13-year-old Blenders’ Mash, includes the well-known sack.
lead_paragraph: I remember Crown Royal whisky from my childhood. My father drank it and would give me the purple fabric sacks it came in, which I would use to store small toys, doll clothing and the like. A new edition of the Canadian whisky, the 13-year-old blenders’ mash, brought back memories. It is one of the limited-edition blends that are available annually in the company’s Noble Collection, introduced in 2016. The 90-proof spirit is ultrasmooth, with hints of dried fruit and honey. Crown Royal was first created in 1939 to honor a visit to Canada by King George VI and Queen Elizabeth. It was packaged in the bags to make the presentation to the king and queen more regal, and they ended up keeping it.

headline: Morgenstern’s Opens a New Flagship
keywords: ['Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The store, two really, offers composed desserts along with 88 flavors of ice cream.
lead_paragraph: You need a good amount of space to offer 88 flavors of ice cream, as Nicholas Morgenstern does at Morgenstern’s Finest Ice Cream. Having outgrown his Rivington Street headquarters, he has now taken over a stretch of storefronts in Greenwich Village for his new flagship, which opens Friday. Most of the gleaming white space is devoted to the dipping shop, where there are a few booths and outdoor seating. There is also a kitchen area with a counter seating eight, for composed desserts like sundaes, pie à la mode and slices of cake. A separate store, a few steps away, sells pints, ice cream cakes and merchandise like T-shirts.

headline: A Food Hall in Ma Bell’s Shadow
abstract: It’s off the beaten path, but the Bell Market at Bell Works has plenty of food offerings in a striking setting.
lead_paragraph: To Shop

headline: Nothing but Gnocchi
abstract: Patavini, an Italian manufacturer, brings its tender potato dumplings to New York.
lead_paragraph: Patavini, a company in Padua, Italy, manufactures tender potato gnocchi, to sell wholesale, in myriad flavors. Luca Marco Giraldin, an owner, has now opened a retail outpost in New York. Porcini, pumpkin, spinach, buckwheat with cumin, squid ink, Cajun pepper, truffle and beetroot are a few of the savory options at this elegant little shop. Sweet tiramisù and pistachio are also available. Stuffed gnocchi have fillings like mortadella with pistachio. All are sold to take away. A window in the rear of the store provides a view of the chefs heating gnocchi and sauce for eating at tables outside or on the run. Fancy Italian packaged foods, including sauces, are displayed on shelves.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Chinese Food (Cuisine)', 'Noodles']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.

headline: Iran Widens an Already Huge Rift Between Europe and U.S.
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Since President Trump announced that he would pull out of the Iran nuclear deal, European leaders are actively working to help Tehran get around new sanctions.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Of all the issues dividing Europe and the Trump administration, Iran has become the sharpest, with the Europeans actively working against United States policy, placing them in league with Russia, China and Iran.

headline: California Today: Readers Weigh In on the Dirtiest Block in San Francisco
abstract: Tuesday: Reaction to our article about a dirty block of Hyde Street, a landmark report on climate change, and a study that says your dog isn’t really as smart as you think.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Review: The Ages of A.R. Gurney in the Wistful ‘Final Follies’
abstract: This bill of short comedies, early and late, allows fans of Gurney to chart the evolution of theater’s foremost chronicler of a waning caste.
lead_paragraph: The last comedy completed by A. R. Gurney, who died last year, begins as so many early chapters of adult lives do — with a job interview. But the candidate in the affectingly titled “Final Follies,” at the Cherry Lane Theater, is scraping against middle age and would seem to have no viable set of skills for the 21st century.

headline: 24 Hours Inside the Christian Marclay Installation ‘The Clock’
abstract: At Tate Modern in London, Holly Williams watched a full day and night of the video installation so you don’t have to.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Christian Marclay’s video installation “The Clock” is functional: The 24-hour montage of film and TV clips featuring clocks and watches actually tells the time.

headline: How Will Google Play Its New Product Announcements on the Back of a Data Scandal?
abstract: Google is dealing with the disclosure that it exposed personal data of up to 500,000 users, but will hope its new products can take investors’s minds off the debacle.

headline: Nikki Haley to Resign as Trump’s Ambassador to the U.N.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Ms. Haley, one of the few high-profile women in the Trump administration, said she would leave at the end of the year because she wanted a break after two years in a rigorous job.
lead_paragraph: President Trump’s ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki R. Haley, said on Tuesday that she would resign at the end of the year, marking the departure of one of the few high-profile women in the Trump administration.

headline: The Long Journey of the Aleppo Pepper
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Peppers', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Chefs', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Chili Peppers']
abstract: The signature Syrian spice, caught up in conflict, became scarce in the United States just as its popularity boomed. But importers and vendors are finding new ways to get it.
lead_paragraph: Early in the seven-year-old Syrian civil war, American imports of Syria’s signature dried, ground Aleppo chiles dropped drastically.

headline: First He Built a Set of Stairs. Then He Built Somewhere for Them to Lead.
abstract: One extraordinary (and totally nonessential) space. This month: a British expat’s tower in Tangier.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t decide to move to Tangier so much as I just dribbled into it,” says Jonathan Dawson, an affable 67-year-old Englishman who has divided his time over the last two decades between Morocco and Spain. In 1992, as a self-proclaimed “hack reporter” for the Daily Mail in London, he was sent to Tangier to write a story on the houses of British expats, including the writer Annie Lambton, the artist Marguerite McBey and the interior decorator David Herbert, whom Ian Fleming, according to some sources, used to call the “Queen Mother of Tangier.” Charmed by his hosts and the glorious weather, Dawson decided to stay a while. “I found a dog with a broken leg, then I realized I needed a place for the dog to stay, so I rented a flat,” he says. Before he knew it, “a while” had turned into 25 years.

headline: Why German Trucks May Become a Target for Activist Investors
abstract: German vehicle manufacturers rarely take a lead in corporate governance, but Volkswagen and Daimler may be forced to when separating out their truck businesses.

headline: Are You Overwashing Your Face?
abstract: How to choose the right face wash in a sea of cleansers.
lead_paragraph: Face cleansing used to be the most boring part of a skin-care regimen. Want bells and whistles? Better to look to the pricey moisturizer that comes in a faceted faux-crystal jar. Need targeted skin-care solutions? Look to potent serums and masks for results.

headline: Justice Kavanaugh’s Law Clerks Are All Women, a First for the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Brett M. Kavanaugh’s hiring of four women law clerks means that more than half of the Supreme Court’s law clerks will be women for the first time in American history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, confirmed to the Supreme Court amid fiery accusations of sexual misconduct against women, arrived Tuesday for his first day on the bench with an unprecedented all-female class of law clerks.

headline: To Help Young Women in Prison, Try Dignity
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Women and Girls', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: A program in Connecticut lets older inmates counsel their younger counterparts in how to prevent prison bars from becoming a revolving door in their lives.
lead_paragraph: NIANTIC, Conn. — Despite their names, state “departments of correction” in the United States aren’t known for correcting much. More than seven of every 10 prisoners, according to some studies, are arrested again less than four years after they are released. And while recent years have seen the beginning of a national decline in the number of male prisoners, the situation has not improved much for women, who remain incarcerated at stubbornly high levels.

headline: Give Tenants Lawyers
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: Eviction is a nationwide epidemic, and people faced with losing everything need representation.
lead_paragraph: The numbers in a report released this year by Princeton University’s Eviction Lab confirmed what housing advocates and public-interest housing law scholars have always known: Evictions from rental housing are a national epidemic. Over two million United States families were forced from their homes in 2017, in big and small cities alike. In some states, like Virginia, which has five of the top 10 cities on the list of cities with most evictions, the number of renters who have faced eviction is jarring.

headline: Watching Khabib Nurmagomedov’s Victory in Dagestan
abstract: Nearly 7,000 miles from Las Vegas, fans, government officials and even the fighter’s father gathered in the capital city to watch their local hero retain his belt.
lead_paragraph: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — Twelve hours before Khabib Nurmagomedov choked out Conor McGregor to retain his U.F.C. lightweight title in Las Vegas, children nearly 7,000 miles away were beating a punching bag that hung under a sign that read “Knock the chicken’s teeth out!” The bag, attached to a lifelike model of an octagon cage inhabited by likenesses of Nurmagomedov and McGregor, was part of the pre-fight festivities in Makhachkala, the capital of Dagestan.

headline: Abroad in America: Why You Should Care About the Governors’ Races
abstract: In this newsletter, Sarah Lyall takes international readers to meet the candidates in Macon, Ga., and explains the details of election procedure.
lead_paragraph: It’s Tuesday in America, and the midterm elections are exactly four weeks away. After last week’s distasteful partisan horror show ended with now-Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh’s elevation to the Supreme Court, the question everyone’s asking is how this unseemly episode will affect the forthcoming elections. Mainly, we’re wondering who it might most galvanize to turn up at the polls.

headline: After a Long Wait, India’s #MeToo Movement Suddenly Takes Off
abstract: To the surprise of many in the country, an eruption of sexual harassment allegations against men in entertainment and journalism has had quick results.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — After a year of fits and starts, India’s #MeToo movement has leapt forward over the past week, getting concrete action in two of the country’s most powerful industries: entertainment and the news media.

headline: Plastic Purses, Collected by a Former Editor of The New Yorker
abstract: Robert Gottlieb has amassed over 400 pieces on road trips around the United States, from caramel-colored purses to pearly Lucite minaudières.
lead_paragraph: What began as occasional junk-store trawling in the late 1970s eventually turned into a decades-long infatuation for Robert Gottlieb, the writer and former editor of The New Yorker and the publishing house Alfred A. Knopf. The 87-year-old, who nurtured the literary careers of everyone from John Cheever and Toni Morrison to Nora Ephron and Bill Clinton, collects midcentury plastic handbags — caramel-colored purses, pearly Lucite minaudières — a style that flourished during the post-World War II plastics boom. He has amassed over 400 pieces on road trips around the United States, storing them in a dedicated closet in his Manhattan townhouse. “I never went on real vacations. Instead, I’d drive — and drive and drive — across Iowa, Indiana or somewhere in the South, visiting flea markets. Seeing these places broke down a lot of my ignorance of the country. I stopped collecting about 15 years ago. But if I come across an exceptional one in person, I’ll pick it up,” says Gottlieb, whose latest book of reviews and essays, “Near-Death Experiences” (FSG), came out in June.

headline: New Pixel Phones and Other Gadgets Keep Google in the Hardware Hunt
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Tablet Computers', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Computer Monitors', 'Smartphones', 'Speakers (Audio)', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Laptop Computers']
abstract: Though sales of its devices have been slow, the search giant unveiled the Pixel 3, a smart speaker with a built-in screen and a tablet that doubles as a PC.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — For much of the last decade, Apple and Samsung have dominated sales of smartphones. So why would anyone bother trying to sell a new phone?

headline: Trump Claims Trade Victories but Businesses Struggle Under His Approach
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Politics and Government', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'Aluminum', 'Steel and Iron', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Farmers, automakers and other businesses are feeling pain from the president’s steel and aluminum tariffs, which remain in place despite a revised North American Free Trade Agreement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump has spent the past week praising his new trade agreement with Canada and Mexico as a win for farmers, saying the pact will send cash pouring into the United States and enrich America’s agriculture and industrial workers.

headline: A New Biography of a Brilliant Playwright Who Died Too Young
abstract: “Looking for Lorraine,” by Imani Perry, is an admiring account of the life of the influential playwright, activist and intellectual Lorraine Hansberry.
lead_paragraph: LOOKING FOR LORRAINE The Radiant and Radical Life of Lorraine Hansberry By Imani Perry 236 pp. Beacon Press. $26.95

headline: Inexpensive Improvements for Any Bathroom (Even if You Rent)
abstract: Clever storage, new linens and smarter organization can improve even the smallest spaces.
lead_paragraph: An ugly bathroom is like an unwelcome houseguest — loud, messy, and difficult to get rid of. Renovations range from dauntingly expensive (for owners) to downright impossible (for renters). But there are a few easy ways to improve any bathroom with little effort and not much outlay.

headline: On Bessies Night, Casting a Wide Net Over New York Dance
abstract: Bessie awards went to artists including Simone Forti, Sara Mearns and Germaine Acogny.
lead_paragraph: A life in dance offers few material rewards, especially for noncommercial artists working outside of major companies. Audiences are small and engagements short; two years of rehearsals might end in three nights of performance. And money? Not a motivator. As the choreographer Merce Cunningham once said of dancing, “It gives you nothing back,” only “that single fleeting moment when you feel alive.”

headline: ‘We Have to Skype’: A Two-Choreographer Support System
abstract: Tere O’Connor and Lucy Guerin talk about their decades-long dialogue about dance-making and their latest projects.
lead_paragraph: When a choreographer is in the middle of creating a new dance, there’s an inevitable freak-out moment. When it happens to Tere O’Connor, Lucy Guerin usually receives an urgent email: “We have to Skype.”

headline: Binoculars With a Side of Quenelles
abstract: Danny Meyer’s latest project, Manhatta, is a French restaurant on the 60th floor of a downtown skyscraper.
lead_paragraph: Danny Meyer’s latest project, Manhatta, is a French restaurant on the 60th floor of a downtown skyscraper.

headline: At Danny Meyer’s Manhatta, Only the View Tries to Dazzle
abstract: This new French restaurant on the 60th floor of a financial district skyscraper strikes a surprisingly modest tone.
lead_paragraph: Shrinking modesty is not the normal attitude for restaurants with a view. The Rainbow Room had Art Deco razzmatazz and its revolving dance floor; Windows on the World, before terrorists destroyed it, served cocktails in a room named the Greatest Bar on Earth. Manhatta, which recently opened on the 60th floor of an International Style tower downtown, doesn’t follow their lead. It is the least show-offy skyscraper restaurant you’ve ever seen.

headline: Ottawa: The City of Makers
abstract: Chocolatiers, brewers and farmers find inspiration in a city teeming with creativity.
lead_paragraph: Chocolatiers, brewers and farmers find inspiration in a city teeming with creativity.

lead_paragraph: Seven months after taking a leave of absence following sexual harassment allegations, the prominent architect Richard Meier is stepping down from the leadership of his firm, the office announced on Tuesday.

headline: Need a Handbag or a Tie to Land Your First Job? Borrow One With a Library Card
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Ties (Apparel)']
abstract: A new program at the New York Public Library lets job-seekers — particularly teenagers and young adults — check out accessories to wear to interviews.
lead_paragraph: On the second floor of the New York Public Library’s Riverside branch last week, a handful of high school students were eager to hear Michelle Lee, a young adult librarian there, discuss tricks for finding employment.

headline: Forget the Wall: Pati Jinich Wants to Build a Culinary Bridge to Mexico
abstract: The cookbook author and PBS chef, who started out in the diplomatic world, aspires to help Americans appreciate her native cuisine.
lead_paragraph: TAKOMA PARK, Md. — When you walk into a Taco Bell with Pati Jinich, the brainy and buoyant Mexican cooking authority, shame walks in with you. It feels like buying a pack of cigarettes in front of a friend who thought you had quit, or getting caught watching cat videos.

headline: Elvis Costello, Carole King and a Song 20 Years in the Making
abstract: The two musicians reunite to discuss songwriting, a frightening accident and the long-delayed track “Burnt Sugar Is So Bitter.”
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, Elvis Costello and Carole King kept running into each other at a Japanese restaurant in Manhattan. “It was the lure of the sea urchin,” Costello said. And the meals paid off: Over the course of several omakase dinners, the musicians developed a friendship that led to a writing collaboration — but not before they went through a harrowing experience.

abstract: Readers share advice about letting go of perfectionism.

abstract: The American Jewish Committee faults those who say Islam is not a religion.

headline: At Zauo, Diners Can Catch Their Own Dinners
abstract: Masa Takayama updates his TriBeCa space, an Instagram-focused pasta restaurant and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: It’s catch-and-relish, not catch-and-release, at this new Japanese import. Customers can opt for baited hooks to snag rainbow trout, salmon trout, fluke, shrimp, flounder, farmed striped bass, rockfish, lobster or abalone swimming in the pools. Or a staff member can lend a hand. (Prices are $16 to $125 if they do the fishing, and $12 to $110 if you fish.) The chefs then prepare the seafood to order, salt-grilled, simmered in soy sauce, sashimi or tempura. Whimsically instructive menu cards provide guidance. The restaurant, which has 13 locations in Japan, was introduced there in 1993 by a company called Harbor House: The New York restaurant is its first branch outside that country. Takuya Takahashi, whose father was the founder, is president of the New York branch. A narrow but soaring space, the restaurant has a fish tank opposite the bar on the ground floor, and two more tanks on a loftlike second floor. The hull of an immense, hand-built polished wooden boat hangs from the ceiling. In addition to the freshly caught seafood, the menu offers a vast array of Japanese standbys, mostly seafood, including salads, sushi, hand rolls and rice and noodle dishes. (Opens Monday)

headline: Britain’s ‘New Puritans’: Youth Drinking Falls Dramatically
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Youth', 'Social Media', 'Age, Chronological', 'Marijuana', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: Underage drinking has dropped sharply among European youths, and the biggest drop is in Britain, land of the pint of ale. No one is sure why, though some point to social media.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Xenia Clegg Littler and her friends were underage, their idea of fun was shopping, walking in parks and eating ice cream, not doing shots or chugging beer. She never had a drink until she was 18, the legal age in Britain and now, at 19, she has as little interest in alcohol as ever.

headline: A Dire Warning on Climate Change
abstract: Readers urge government officials to heed the warning and call on the public to be more energy-efficient.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘All American’ Can’t Quite Find the End Zone
abstract: The new CW football drama has plenty of potential but little excitement and even less authenticity.
lead_paragraph: A hybrid of “The O.C.” and “Friday Night Lights” should be a bonanza of teen-show riches, of high stakes and fancy parties and big crunchy tackle sounds, of father figures and shy romances. Two different characters say “Welcome to Beverly Hills” in one episode — this, too, should be teen-show manna.

headline: Beto O’Rourke May Benefit From an Unlikely Support Group: White Evangelical Women
abstract: In the Texas race, any small shift among evangelical voters could be a significant loss for Senator Ted Cruz — and a signal to Democrats.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — After church on a recent Sunday, Emily Mooney smiled as she told her girlfriends about her public act of rebellion. She had slapped a “Beto for Senate’’ sticker on her S.U.V. and driven it to her family’s evangelical church.

headline: Review: Looking Anew at a Norwegian Massacre in ‘22 July’
abstract: The director Paul Greengrass tries to make sense of a 2011 mass murder by a right-wing extremist who railed against women, Islam and Marxism.
lead_paragraph: “The civil war has started.” This is what the Norwegian mass murderer Anders Behring Breivik announced to the interviewers interrogating him on July 22, 2011. Earlier that day, Breivik had parked a van crammed with about 2,000 pounds of explosives in front of a 17-story government building in central Oslo housing both the prime minister’s office and the Ministry of Justice. The bomb exploded, killing eight, while he was driving the 19 miles to a summer camp on Utoya Island run by the Labor Party. There, he slaughtered 69 additional people, most of them teenagers.

They’re waiting for monkeys, apes or birds to scan the foliage, eat the ripe fruit and either spit or defecate seeds far from their sources, spreading their next generation to a new location.

headline: Electric Bikes Are About to Go Mainstream
abstract: New York’s restrictions on electric bikes have loosened. E-bike sharing is poised to expand. Here’s what to expect before you head out for a ride.
lead_paragraph: On any given day, as many as 50,000 bicycle delivery workers sweep through the streets of New York, and according to their advocates, more than half of them are on e-bikes. The electric-assist bicycle (or e-bike) has become a vital tool in this arduous job, where a worker’s shift can last up to 10 hours, six days a week. Until very recently, however, e-bikes were actually illegal to operate in the city, often leading to stiff fines and penalties for the delivery people.

headline: The Lives of the 20 Limo Crash Victims
abstract: The people killed in the crash were friends and relatives — including four sisters from one family and newlyweds — who were on their way to celebrate a 30th birthday.
lead_paragraph: The limousine accident in Schoharie, N.Y., on Saturday took 20 lives almost instantly. It devastated families, killing siblings and leaving young children without parents. The victims were friends and relatives — including four sisters from one family, and two brothers from another — who were traveling to a brewery in Cooperstown, N.Y., to celebrate a 30th birthday.

headline: Donald Trump Versus the Jungle
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s fantasy is that the U.S. can ignore the global forces of nature.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump spoke at the United Nations on Sept. 25 and provoked guffaws from the diplomats in the audience for his boasting, Trump insisted that they were not laughing at him, they were laughing with him. I wasn’t there so I can’t say what they were actually doing on the outside. But on the inside, I’m pretty sure I know: They were crying.

headline: What the Primaries Say About the Future of Democrats
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare']
abstract: The progressive movement is energized, but there is not much evidence that it is taking over the party.

These Democratic Socialists, this version goes, were “conquering” the Democratic Party.

headline: A Stolen Stradivarius Is Recovered, and Lent to a Student

It remained lost for 35 years.

headline: Strengthening to Category 4, Hurricane Michael Aims at Florida

headline: Italy’s Government Is Looking East. Or Is it Heading There?

headline: Against the Red Sox, the Yankees Simply Don’t Measure Up

Since neither the traditional left or right blocs won a majority, the Sweden Democrats, with roots in the neo-Nazi movement, hold the balance of power.

headline: Why Is Israel Scared of This Young American?

headline: Looking at Protestant Loyalist Life in Post-Conflict Belfast
abstract: Years after the Good Friday peace accords, Mariusz Smiejek took his camera on both sides of the walls that divide Protestants and Catholics in Belfast, gradually focusing on Protestant Loyalists.
lead_paragraph: Mariusz Smiejek’s first long-term photo story wasn’t exactly a simple one. Rather than play it safe, he dived into the lives of Protestant Loyalists in Belfast, Northern Ireland, where signs of the past Troubles lingered. They did so even after the Good Friday peace accords ushered in a new era 20 years ago between those who favored being part of the United Kingdom and those who were allied with the Republican cause for one Ireland.

headline: This Broadway Season, the Play’s Really the Thing
abstract: In a turnabout no one expected, New York’s most prominent stages are rich with drama, most of it new and most of it American.
lead_paragraph: The blockbusterization of Broadway is taking a breather.

headline: ‘The Ferryman’ Shows a Dark Irish Chapter Through a Personal Lens
abstract: It took persuading, but Jez Butterworth wrote his new play for his partner, Laura Donnelly, both to honor her history and give her a great part.
lead_paragraph: Police checkpoints in the street. Helicopters overhead around the clock. The necessity, in certain parts of town, to give a fake last name if anyone asked, because her real last name would tip them off that she was Roman Catholic.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Declares That Earth Is Going Out of Business
abstract: After hearing about a foreboding report from U.N. climate scientists, Mr. Kimmel ran a mock going-out-of-business ad for the entire planet.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: How to Grieve for Online Friends You Had Never Met in Person
keywords: ['Grief (Emotion)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Social Media', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: We often use technology to form meaningful relationships with virtual strangers. But what happens when the person on the other side of the screen dies?
lead_paragraph: Last November, Kristi Pahr felt both shock and denial after learning that her online friend of over four years, Amy, had died suddenly. She says she still cries remembering those initial days of grief. Amy, she said, “was a better, more ‘real’ friend to me than most people I know in person.”

headline: Should Celebrities Weigh In on Politics?
abstract: Do famous figures have a duty to their fans to serve as an escape from reality? Or do they have the right to speak about their personal beliefs and opinions?
lead_paragraph: How do you feel about celebrities who are outspoken about their political views? Do you think famous people should voice their opinions about politics, or stay out of them? Why?

headline: A Suicidal Nanny, an Underground Industry and 3 Babies Stabbed
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Child Care', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: An attack at a Queens maternity center shined a light on “birth tourism,” private, unregulated nurseries that cater to both Chinese tourists and New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: Dark circles formed like warning signs beneath Yu Fen Wang’s eyes as she worked 12-hour graveyard shifts in a Queens maternity center that operated on the margins of legality. Her family said she had grown gaunt, could not sleep and told her husband she no longer wanted to live.

headline: For Doctors, Delving Deeper as a Way to Avoid Burnout
abstract: As the practice of medicine shifts, physicians should follow their curiosity to continue to find meaning in their work.
lead_paragraph: The anatomy laboratory was always freezing. This was our first course as medical students, and we had split ourselves into groups — four students to every cluster. Each of us carried a copy of “Netter’s Anatomy”; by the end of three months in the lab, the volume would become chemically yellowed by formaldehyde, and to leaf through the tawny, crackling pages would be to feel your fingers becoming slowly embalmed. Our group had three men — me, S. and B. — and a woman, G. We “shared” a 60-something female cadaver whose name we knew by only her initials: M.C. She had died, we were told, of metastatic breast cancer. Eventually, as we dissected her body, we would find misshapen deposits of that cancer in her brain, liver and bones.

headline: Vigorous Exercise, Even a Trek Up Everest, May Be Safe During Pregnancy
keywords: ['Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Exercise', 'Babies and Infants', 'Mountaineering', 'ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY']
abstract: New research undercuts widely held beliefs about strenuous physical training and pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Female athletes seem to be able to exercise safely and intensively both before and during pregnancy without increasing their risk for birth-related complications, even if they are trekking up Mount Everest, according to two eye-opening new studies.

headline: Democrats Are Ignoring One Key Voting Group: Veterans
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Democrats have a rare opportunity to gain a foothold against the Republican Party. If they come up short, it may be in part because of a failure to pursue veterans.
lead_paragraph: With control of Congress at stake in next month’s midterm elections, Democrats have a rare opportunity to gain a foothold against President Trump’s Republican Party. But if they come up short, it may be in part because of a failure to pursue a key group of voters. It’s a constituency that makes up 13 percent of the voting population, enjoys high voter turnout and is especially concentrated in some decisive swing states. That group is military veterans — and in the battle for their votes, the Democratic Party lags far behind the Republicans.

headline: A Future Where Everything Becomes a Computer Is as Creepy as You Feared
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Home Appliances', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Privacy', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: Amazon and other tech giants have made devices connected to the internet increasingly prevalent. Now is the time to be freaking out about the dangers.
lead_paragraph: More than 40 years ago, Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft with a vision for putting a personal computer on every desk.

headline: A New Biography Presents Gandhi, Warts and All

lead_paragraph: GANDHI The Years That Changed the World, 1914-1948 By Ramachandra Guha Illustrated. 1,083 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

headline: The Democrats Have an Immigration Problem
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Family separations, multibillion-dollar border-wall schemes, unleashed ICE officers —the Trump presidency has taught the Democrats what they stand against.  Now they have to figure out what they stand for.
lead_paragraph: In early June, the Washington office of Representative Pramila Jayapal began to hear rumors about the women. They had crossed into Texas, where Border Patrol officers promptly arrested them. But now the women were somewhere around Seattle, the city Jayapal represents.

headline: Trump Nominee Draws Scrutiny for Ties to Ukrainian Energy Interests
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Consultants', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The case, involving the president’s choice for a top post at the Department of Homeland Security, is the latest to shed light on foreign influence on American politics and government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As tanks, artillery and combat troops streamed from Russia into Ukraine in 2014, the United States government dispatched a multiagency team of technical experts to Kiev to help the fragile government there shore up its energy supply for the coming winter.

headline: Downturn Looms as Leadership Test for California, World’s 5th Largest Economy
abstract: California faces concerns about its economic stability and a possible recession just as Gov. Jerry Brown heads out the door.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It has the highest concentration of billionaires in the country. It exports more  computers than any other state. It is the nation’s largest producer of agriculture products by far: More than $6 billion in dairy products alone last year.

headline: A Cake Fit for Julia Child
abstract: Paying homage to a mentor’s insistent unfussiness.
lead_paragraph: Early into the first meal I had with Julia Child, she asked me if I’d ever seen the “Saturday Night Live” episode in which Dan Aykroyd imitated her. “I’m sure I’m the only person in the world who hasn’t,” I told her, and then, in a flash, she stood up, her six-footish frame looming over our small table, and re-enacted the best moments of the skit in full trill, saving her most dramatic voice for the famous last line: “Save the liver!” Julia was a master of many things, and as she proved that night, one of them was the art of making a newcomer feel comfortable.

headline: In Lexington, Selfies With American Pharoah, Then ‘Bourbon and Branch’
abstract: October is also racing season at Keeneland in Kentucky’s Bluegrass country, where farm visits, locavore restaurants and revived bourbon distilleries beckon.
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Derby, held annually at Churchill Downs in Louisville, outdraws other American horse races, from the Belmont Stakes in Elmont, N.Y., to the Santa Anita Derby, in Arcadia, Calif. But thoroughbred lovers champion Keeneland Race Course in Lexington, 70 miles east, as the intimate alternative with the hospitable practice of welcoming fans behind the scenes, from morning training sessions to the backside barns.

headline: Amy McGrath Is Avoiding Attack Ads. Can a Congressional Candidate Win Without Them?
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. McGrath, a Democrat challenging a Kentucky House member, is turning her competitive contest into a lab to test the conventional wisdom that negative ads work.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Heather Trump is certain of one thing about the midterm election: She cannot wait until it is over. She will no longer have to hear the negative campaign ads that have become the inescapable white noise in her life.

headline: Trapped by the ‘Walmart of Heroin’
abstract: A Philadelphia neighborhood is the largest open-air narcotics market for heroin on the East Coast. Addicts come from all over, and many never leave.
lead_paragraph: The first time Mark shot up “Philly dope” was in the summer of 2017, with his girlfriend, Sarah. They had been on their way from Massachusetts to South Carolina, hoping to get clean there and find someplace cheap to live. The plan was to detox slowly on the way. In New Jersey, they needed to buy more drugs, just enough to make it to Myrtle Beach. Mark got out his phone and Googled “really bad drug areas.” A neighborhood in Philadelphia came up: Kensington.

headline: Five Places to Go in Lincoln, Neb.
abstract: The Nebraska capital’s downtown used to be considered rather sleepy. But with new watering holes and shops percolating, it’s become a pride of the plains.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 1920s, Nebraska’s capital had a marketing slogan: “Lincoln — A City Worthy of a Noble Name.” Today, that motto seems to hold up perhaps more than ever, especially in the creative-meets-collegiate downtown in this tidy metropolis of 280,364 residents, which is home to the University of Nebraska and a growing immigrant population (now nearly nine percent of city dwellers). The increasingly buzzy downtown is luring visitors with recently-opened shops and watering holes. And, be sure not to miss the 1932 Art Deco capitol building, with its mosaics by muralist Hildreth Meiere and 14th-floor views of the Great Plains.

headline: Bavarian Millennials Embrace Tradition (Dirndls, Lederhosen and All)
abstract: Not so long ago, the 19th-century peasant garb was considered the uniform of older, more conservative folk. Now it is all the rage with millennials.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Hip-hop blared from oversize speakers. Half-finished beer glasses teetered precariously along the bar, and a scrum of teenage bodies writhed on the dimly lit dance floor. It was a regular night out in hip urban Munich.

headline: A Playwright’s LSD Trip Becomes a Psychedelic Journey
abstract: The British playwright Leo Butler believes that taking acid can have beneficial effects. His new play explores how he thinks it can help.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — Half a century after Timothy Leary urged the world to “Turn on, tune in, drop out,” there’s a surge of interest in lysergic acid diethylamide, or LSD. The psychedelic drug was outlawed in Britain in the 1960s and the United States later followed suit, but a new wave of scientists, authors and artists are now intent on changing our perceptions.

headline: What ‘Justice’ Really Means
abstract: The word has taken a beating in the past few weeks. But what role does it truly play in our lives?
lead_paragraph: It’s a staple of common sense that we don’t let judges try their own cases. Yet if we are to gain self-knowledge, we all must do just that: We must judge ourselves to know ourselves. While we typically think of justice as a virtue of social arrangements or political institutions, the United States has recently bore witness to this virtue in its first-person aspect — self-regarding justice — while watching the confirmation hearings of a Supreme Court Justice.

headline: Colson Whitehead’s Next Novel Tackles Life Under Jim Crow
abstract: In “The Nickel Boys,” the author of the award-winning “Underground Railroad” explores the dark history of a segregated Florida reform school
lead_paragraph: After he published his surreal epic, “The Underground Railroad,” in the summer of 2016, Colson Whitehead was set to write a crime novel set in Harlem. But he couldn’t stop thinking about a story that haunted him, about the abuses — beatings, torture, neglect, suspicious deaths — that took place at the Arthur G. Dozier School for Boys, a reform school in the Florida panhandle that operated for more than a century.

headline: House Hunting in … Australia
abstract: After years of steady growth, housing prices around Melbourne have flattened out, due in part to tighter restrictions on foreign buyers.
lead_paragraph: This four-bedroom, two-bathroom ranch house is on a gated, 1.2-acre lot on a quiet country lane in Lower Plenty, an affluent suburb 13 miles northeast of Melbourne, Australia, the capital of the state of Victoria. The 4,047-square-foot home — built in the 1930s as a farmhouse before being expanded in 2000 and then renovated in 2012 — has 14-foot ceilings and Tasmanian oak floors throughout, as well as “spectacular views to one of Melbourne’s highest peaks, Mt. Dandenong,” said Aaron Yeats, a director and auctioneer with Jellis Craig North East, which has the listing.

headline: 25 Years Later, Norway Files Charges in Shooting of ‘Satanic Verses’ Publisher
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Norwegian authorities refused to identify the suspects or discuss the evidence. They filed charges two days before a deadline that would have forced them to drop the case.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — William Nygaard, publisher of the Norwegian edition of Salman Rushdie’s novel “The Satanic Verses,” was shot three times and left for dead outside his home in a quiet suburb of Oslo on the morning of Oct. 11, 1993.

headline: Can Poland’s Faded Brutalist Architecture Be Redeemed?
abstract: Long derided as relics of an oppressive regime, the country’s Communist-era buildings are being given a second look, and a new life.
lead_paragraph: THE BUILDING SITS there like an abandoned ship. Broad, squat and jarring, the Unitra Telpod, a former electronic equipment factory in the Polish city of Krakow, is a depressing sight. Less than two decades ago, the building hummed with activity, and its rectilinear facade, all concrete and glass and steel, dominated the landscape, imposing itself on Krakow’s far more elegant medieval core. Now the offices are closed, shattered glass litters a dusty courtyard and the steel is rusted. It still retains a certain dignity, even majesty, but of a distinctly faded sort.

headline: In Tokyo, a Couple Proving That Good Craftsmanship Knows No Boundaries
abstract: She’s a Swedish accessories designer. He’s the founder of a street wear brand. Sophia and Masafumi Watanabe have opposing design sensibilities, but are creatively intertwined.
lead_paragraph: “IT IS THREADS, hundreds of tiny threads, which sew people together through the years,” the French actress Simone Signoret once said of marriage, and for Sophia and Masafumi Watanabe, this is especially true. Masafumi is the founder of the popular Japanese street wear brand Bedwin and the Heartbreakers; his wife is the creator of Sophia 203, a Jaipur-based line of embroidered accessories. The couple has been together for eight years and married for nearly four. They live with their 1- and 4-year-old children in a modest, sparsely furnished three-bedroom apartment in central Tokyo’s expat-heavy Moto-Azabu district, traveling every other weekend to their beach house in Hayama, a quiet seaside getaway an hour outside of Tokyo where the Japanese imperial family has long maintained a home. “My husband makes street wear, and I do something handcrafted,” Sophia says. “He’s got a big clothing line and I have a small business, but despite that, we really do influence each other.”

headline: ‘Sisters’ Isn’t ‘Psycho,’ but It’s a Lacerating Spin on Hitchcock
abstract: Newly restored, “Sisters,” by Brian De Palma, remade Alfred Hitchcock’s “Psycho” as a thriller for the disillusioned 1970s.
lead_paragraph: The 1973 slasher film “Sisters,” digitally restored and playing at the Quad Cinema, as well as streaming on services like FilmStruck, was Brian De Palma’s first homage to Alfred Hitchcock. Shamelessly lurid, it’s also his best.

headline: Lena Dunham and Jenni Konner Go ‘Camping’
abstract: The creators of the new HBO series talk about battling snakes on set, the end of the their creative partnership and the pressure of following up “Girls.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The outdoors, even the fake outdoors, may not seem like the place you’d expect to find Lena Dunham and Jenni Konner, otherwise known as the duo behind the Brooklyn-chic millennial comedy “Girls.”

headline: ‘Crazy Ex-Girlfriend’ Plans ‘Our Version of a Happy Ending’
abstract: As the CW musical comedy prepares for its final season, the creators Rachel Bloom and Aline Brosh McKenna discuss rom-com tropes, mental illness and saying goodbye to West Covina.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A lively “let’s put on a show” energy pervades the production complex that houses “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend.” It’s appropriate, because the CW comedy’s characters, who use a varied array of tunes to describe their emotional plights, now and then unleash song-and-dance numbers that pay tribute to Hollywood’s golden age of big-screen musicals.

headline: Business Is Boo-ing! The World of Extreme Haunts
abstract: Americans are paying to scare themselves witless, and not just on Halloween.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday night, ten anxious individuals were blindfolded and taken to a secret location in the desert, 40 minutes outside of Los Angeles. They were told that they would each be playing the part of a futuristic criminal who had been lobotomized and summoned to help investigators identify two bodies discovered on the grounds.

headline: Peter Rice, Fox’s Un-Hollywood TV Boss, Is Getting More Say Over What You Watch
abstract: Like his father before him, Mr. Rice was a Rupert Murdoch loyalist. With Disney acquiring 21st Century Fox, he is about to start a new chapter.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood executives are not so different from the stars they employ. They want to be seen in the right booths at the right restaurants. They work the room at the after-parties on awards nights. And they would rather die than drop a spot on The Hollywood Reporter’s annual power list.

headline: Bombay Fritatta!
abstract: Make Nik Sharma’s recipe, full of spices and studded with feta, for dinner tonight.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m way down east in Maine, Bar Harbor, Mt. Desert Island, leaf-peeping the reds and yellows with one of my kids, steaming on a working boat through Frenchman Bay to Egg Rock Light and a half-dozen seals banana-loafing on the rocks while guillemots red-foot it into the water at speed, their tuxedos sleek. Those seals get the fish. We had local pork and brown rice for dinner, under glittering stars. We’re feeling fine. It’s sweater weather at last.

headline: 120 Years of European History, in 3 Disorienting Hours
abstract: The composer and artist Heiner Goebbels has brought musicians, dancers and clips from the day’s news together in a new work performed in a disused rail station in Manchester, England.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — In a dank, disused railway station, TV news clips were playing on a huge screen: a pig farm in Arizona; young men in Islamic dress on a street in Iran, their white robes streaked with blood; a car rally on a dirt track somewhere. It wasn’t clear what connected these disparate moments, part of a three-hour multimedia performance orchestrated by the German composer and artist Heiner Goebbels — or if anything linked them at all.

headline: National Book Foundation Announces Finalists for 69th Annual Award
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Lauren Groff, Rebecca Makkai and Sarah Smarsh are among the 25 shortlisted books in five categories.
lead_paragraph: The National Book Foundation announced the finalists for the 69th annual National Book Awards on Wednesday, with a stylistically and thematically diverse group of 25 finalists in five categories — fiction, nonfiction, poetry, young people’s literature and translated literature.

headline: How the New ‘A Star Is Born’ Complicates an Old View of Womanhood
abstract: The relationship between Ally and Jackson echoes the original and other remakes, while modernizing their dynamic for current sensibilities.
lead_paragraph: In the 1937 film “A Star Is Born,” Esther Blodgett (Janet Gaynor) has a dream: to leave small-town life in North Dakota and become a movie star. It won’t be easy, as she — and we — are reminded time and again. “For every dream of yours you make come true, you’ll pay the price in heartbreak,” her gruff but supportive grandmother tells her plainly.

headline: U.K. Appoints Minister for Suicide Prevention
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Months after appointing its first minister for loneliness, Britain named the health minister to the new role as part of a push to tackle mental health issues.

headline: CVS Health and Aetna $69 Billion Merger Is Approved With Conditions
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']

lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s approval of the $69 billion merger between CVS Health and Aetna on Wednesday caps a wave of consolidation among giant health care players that could leave American consumers with less control over their medical care and prescription drugs.

keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)']

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)']

lead_paragraph: Volkswagen is taking another crack at becoming a major force in the American auto market, now that it appears to have put the worst of its emissions-cheating scandal behind it.

headline: Inside Brandon Truaxe’s Meltdown at Deciem
abstract: “He is destroying what could have been a very successful company,” said the former C.F.O.
lead_paragraph: In the last two years, The Ordinary has become one of the hottest brands in skin care, selling no-fuss products at a fraction of the prices of its competitors, to the obsessive delight of young consumers.

headline: Evacuate? Or Stay Put? Here’s Where to Find Shelter From Hurricane Michael
abstract: Alabama, Florida and Georgia have all opened shelters for residents in the path of Hurricane Michael. But officials cautioned it may be best for some to shelter in place.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Michael battered the Florida Panhandle on Wednesday, officials scrambled to open evacuation centers in three states.

headline: It’s Her Job to Get More People to Act Like You Right Now
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'News and News Media', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Social Media', 'Headphones and Headsets']

lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Millie Tran, a global growth editor for The Times, discussed the tech she’s using.

headline: A Tortured Choice for Immigrants: Your Health or Your Green Card?
abstract: A doctor explains how a new rule proposed by the Trump administration would force vulnerable people to make impossible decisions.
lead_paragraph: Scrolling down the list of my primary care patients, I wondered who might be affected. A pregnant woman from Cameroon. An elderly woman with brittle bones from the Dominican Republic. A man with cancer from Ecuador. The Trump administration’s proposal to deny green card status to people who use services like food assistance and Medicaid threaten several of my patients with a harrowing choice: their health, or their immigration status.

headline: Hurricane Michael Slams Into Florida
abstract: Wind and rain roared through the region, flooding homes and sending debris flying at dangerous speeds.
lead_paragraph: Wind and rain roared through the region, flooding homes and sending debris flying at dangerous speeds.

lead_paragraph: THE WITCH ELM By Tana French 509 pp. Viking Press. $28.

headline: The Time to Buy Those Holiday Travel Tickets? Now
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: Going home for the holidays can be expensive and stressful, but with the right timing and these maneuvers, it doesn’t always have to be.
lead_paragraph: For many, traveling during the Thanksgiving and Christmas holiday season is a necessary evil. It’s the most wonderful time of the year (if you believe the song), but getting home for the holidays can easily be an expensive and stressful journey.

headline: Limo Firm’s Operator Is Charged in Fatal Upstate New York Crash
abstract: Nauman Hussain faces a charge of criminally negligent homicide. The crash was the worst transportation-related accident in the nation in recent years, killing 20.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Almost immediately after a limousine crashed in upstate New York and killed 20 people, investigators bore down on the limousine company, which had a record of repeated safety violations. On Wednesday, they made their first move against the company, arresting its operator outside Albany and charging him with criminally negligent homicide.

headline: Ambrose Akinmusire’s Trumpet Takes a Back Seat to His Pen on ‘Origami Harvest’
abstract: His new album, a collaboration highlighting the Mivos Quartet and the rapper Kool A.D., makes a powerful statement about race, anxiety and injustice.
lead_paragraph: Ambrose Akinmusire, 36, may be the most distinctive, elusive and ultimately satisfying trumpeter of his generation. With a prickly, attenuated tone, he plays in little diving gestures, often wrapping his phrases around a crooked peg. When moving up a scale, he sometimes skips across an unexpected interval, as if he’s just built you a bust and left off the nose.

headline: Lessons in a Water Bottle
abstract: Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, calls for funding sustainability coordinators in the public schools.

keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Forensic Science', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Turkish officials say 15 Saudis, including an autopsy expert, killed a Saudi dissident inside the consulate in Istanbul and dismembered his body.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — A Turkish newspaper close to the government has published a list of 15 men it says formed a hit squad of Saudi government agents the Turks suspect of killing and dismembering a prominent critic inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.

headline: Reducing Fatal Crashes
abstract: The limo accident that took 20 lives in upstate New York raises two issues that a reader says should be addressed.

headline: Review: ‘First Man’ Takes a Giant Leap for Man, a Smaller Step for Movies
abstract: Damien Chazelle’s sweeping and intimate yet underwhelming film revisits the first lunar landing, with Ryan Gosling as Neil Armstrong.
lead_paragraph: In July of 1969, as the world’s attention was fixed on the spectacle of the first lunar landing, news broadcasts would sometimes flash back to a speech given by President John F. Kennedy earlier in the decade. In effect writing the check that Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins would cash a half-dozen years after his death, Kennedy vowed to send astronauts to the moon not because it is easy, but because it is hard.

headline: Marie Runyon, a Liberal Firebrand Into Her 90s, Dies at 103
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Evictions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Her long fight as a tenant against eviction by Columbia University led to decades of protests for peace and racial justice and even arrests.
lead_paragraph: Marie Runyon, a relentless liberal firebrand on many fronts who waged a Forty Years’ War on behalf of fellow tenants facing eviction by Columbia University, died on Sunday in the off-campus Upper Manhattan apartment where she had lived since 1954. She was 103.

headline: The White House Approved a Climate Report (and What That Even Means)
abstract: Also, two economists win the Nobel in economic science for their work on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Hurricane Michael Has Shut Down Travel on the Florida Panhandle
abstract: With the storm making landfall, all area airports are closed and many local roads are shut down as well.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Michael made landfall on  Wednesday, travel in the Florida panhandle had come to a halt.

headline: Women Are Directing More TV Shows, but Minorities Aren’t, Report Says
abstract: Pressure on Hollywood is resulting in gains for women, but not for people of color, a new report from the Directors Guild of America finds.
lead_paragraph: Pressure on Hollywood to be more inclusive is resulting in far better overall gains for female television directors than for nonwhite professionals.

headline: Yael Alkalay, on the Farm
abstract: The founder of the beauty brand Red Flower hand-picks the items that she mixes into her products.
lead_paragraph: The founder of the beauty brand Red Flower hand-picks the items that she mixes into her products.

headline: Ingredient Hunting With a Holistic Skin-Care Expert
abstract: Once a year, Yael Alkalay of the brand Red Flower heads to the southern coast of Massachusetts to get her hands dirty and dream up new elixirs.
lead_paragraph: Yael Alkalay is standing in the woods with a pile of plant clippings at her Wellington-shod feet. Her rescue dog, Salty, has broken free of his leash and is eagerly sniffing at the dirt. They’re in a wild field near Buzzards Bay on the southern coast of Massachusetts, where Alkalay has decamped for the season from her home base in New York City. Here among the rose hips, raspberries and hibiscus that grow throughout this area of New England, she’s spending a late-summer morning researching ingredients for her holistic beauty line, Red Flower.

headline: Cardi B on a Bike and More: Your Wednesday Pop Culture Cheat Sheet
abstract: What you need to know from today’s TV, music and movie news.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

headline: How to Delete Facebook and Instagram From Your Life Forever
abstract: Lost faith in Facebook and Instagram after data leakages, breaches and too much noise? Here’s a guide to breaking up with the social network and its photo-sharing app for good.
lead_paragraph: You may have decided enough is enough: It’s time to delete Facebook.

headline: Hurricane Michael: How to Prepare and Stay Safe
abstract: Officials said it was too late for Florida Panhandle residents to evacuate their homes and advised them to shelter in place. Here are some tips if you’re in the path of the storm.
lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Michael neared landfall Wednesday on the Florida Gulf Coast, the state’s governor, Rick Scott, told Panhandle residents that evacuation was no longer an option and that it was time to settle in.

headline: After Hints of a Presidential Run, Bloomberg Switches to Democrat
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Michael Bloomberg has rejoined the party he abandoned to launch his political career in 2001, when he became the Republican mayor of New York City.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the Democrat-turned-Republican-turned-independent, says he is returning to his roots: He has re-registered as a Democrat — an initial but essential step toward a possible run for president in 2020 as a Democrat.

headline: An Epic Blaze Propels Susan Orlean’s ‘The Library Book’
abstract: Orlean’s latest, inspired by the mystery of a fire that destroyed and damaged more than a million books in Los Angeles, is also a tribute to public libraries.
lead_paragraph: When writing about the books of Susan Orlean, it’s hard not to feel like the neurotic Charlie Kaufman character in the film “Adaptation,” sweating in front of his typewriter as he tries to work on a screen adaptation of Orlean’s “The Orchid Thief.” He worries that her book is too sprawling and bountiful to cram into a contrived Hollywood plot, and he ends up just thinking about the banana nut muffin he wants to eat. Orlean’s work in general has that elusive quality to it: exquisitely written, consistently entertaining and irreducible to anything so obvious and pedestrian as a theme.

headline: This Is What Gentrification in Brooklyn Sounds Like
abstract: “Place,” a meditation on social and personal change, was made by the composer Ted Hearne, the poet Saul Williams and the director Patricia McGregor.
lead_paragraph: “I just got off the train coming here, and hadn’t seen it before,” the director Patricia McGregor said, her voice rising with incredulity. “I was like: There’s an Apple store?”

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Pennsylvania’s 1st District, Fitzpatrick vs. Wallace
abstract: After the redrawing of the Pennsylvania congressional map in February, the new First District preserves the core of Pennsylvania’s Eighth and keeps Bucks County intact. But it now adds more Democratic territory from central Montgomery County, so going by 2016 results, it’s now a Clinton-leaning district instead of a Trump-leaning one.
lead_paragraph: After the redrawing of the Pennsylvania congressional map in February, the new First District preserves the core of Pennsylvania’s Eighth and keeps Bucks County intact. But it now adds more Democratic territory from central Montgomery County, so going by 2016 results, it’s now a Clinton-leaning district instead of a Trump-leaning one.

abstract: A reader criticizes the first lady for her emphasis on clothes.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, Christopher A. Wray, defended the bureau’s handling of an abbreviated background check into Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, telling lawmakers on Wednesday that agents acted properly amid criticism that they should have more thoroughly investigated sexual assault allegations against him.

headline: The Guy in the Painting? You Saw Him Foraging at the Junk Shop
abstract: Michael Rips once won a blind auction battle for a painting. It turns out the other bidder was a friend — the artist who had created the piece.
lead_paragraph: The storied Chelsea Hotel was filled with artists and beat poets when Michael Rips and his wife, Sheila Berger, an artist, moved in 24 years ago. “This had been Charles James’s apartment and atelier,” Mr. Rips, executive director of the Art Students League, said, referring to the eccentric designer said to be one of the models for the couturier in the film “Phantom Thread.”

headline: New U.S. Weapons Systems Are a Hackers’ Bonanza, Investigators Find
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Authorized hackers needed only hours to break into weapons systems the Pentagon is acquiring, and in many cases teams developing the systems were oblivious to the hacking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Authorized hackers were quickly able to seize control of weapons systems being acquired by the American military in a test of the Pentagon’s digital vulnerabilities, according to a new and blistering government review.

headline: Phyllis Kind, Art Dealer Who Took In Outsiders, Dies at 85
abstract: In New York and Chicago galleries she expanded the narrative of 20th-century art to include artists known as the Hairy Who and then as the Chicago Imagists.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Kind, a combative, visionary art dealer whose championing of a group of young artists called the Chicago Imagists as well as major outsider artists helped expand the narrative of 20th-century art, died on Sept. 28 in San Francisco. She was 85.

headline: How to Look Up Medical Information Online
abstract: Stick to the first page of results. Tell your doctor if you come across something that scares you.
lead_paragraph: “Would you take health advice from a stranger on the street? If you wouldn’t, then don’t go to an online forum either,” says Anthony M. Cocco, a doctor at St. Vincent’s Hospital in Melbourne, and the lead author on a recent scientific study about the search habits of people before they show up in an E.R. Stick to vetted, well-sourced information, like that found on hospital or university websites. “The deeper you go, the poorer quality information you’ll find,” says Cocco, who suggests sticking to the first page of results.

headline: He’s Running for Congress. It Doesn’t Hurt That His Opponent Is Out on Bail.
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A conversation with Nate McMurray, whose long-shot bid for the House picked up steam after his opponent, Representative Chris Collins, was indicted.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t often that a congressional candidate goes from relative obscurity to national prominence, with no effort or money expended.

headline: Stocks Plunge, as Fresh Tensions With China Batter Tech Shares
keywords: ["Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'Nasdaq Composite Index']
abstract: A slide in technology shares dragged down major stock indexes on Wall Street as investors continued to digest rising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Stocks suffered their steepest drop in eight months on Wednesday, as rising interest rates gnawed at investors and as previously high-flying technology shares tumbled in the face of growing tensions with China.

headline: Acute Flaccid Myelitis Cases in Children Are Investigated in at Least 5 States
abstract: Nearly half a dozen states have reported that they are investigating cases of the condition, which causes limb paralysis and severe muscle weakness.
lead_paragraph: Health authorities in the United States said this week that they were investigating an unusual spike in cases of a rare condition that causes limb paralysis and severe muscle weakness in children.

headline: At Immigration Argument, Justice Kavanaugh Takes Hard Line
abstract: A Supreme Court argument on immigration detention appeared to reveal a gap between President Trump’s two appointees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Supreme Court argument on Wednesday over the detention of immigrants during deportation proceedings seemed to expose a divide between President Trump’s two appointees, Justices Neil M. Gorsuch and Brett M. Kavanaugh.

headline: The Moon Eclipsed the Sun. Then the Bees Stopped Buzzing.
abstract: Researchers worked with a small army of elementary school children to collect audio recordings of bees as they visited flowers along the path of last summer’s total eclipse.
lead_paragraph: Last year’s Great American Eclipse drew hundreds of millions of eyes to the sky. But while people across the country “oohed” and “aahed” at the phenomenon, it appears the bees went silent.

headline: Is 10 Corso Como a Fish Out of Water?
abstract: At the South Street Seaport outpost of the pioneering Italian concept shop, clothes are only part of a rich life.
lead_paragraph: The Seaport district is one of those parts of New York so overrun with tourists that it ceases to maintain even the faintest vestige of the umbilical cord that once connected it to the city’s spirit. You know, like SoHo.

headline: Chinese Officer Is Extradited to U.S. to Face Charges of Economic Espionage
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Extradition']
abstract: The Chinese intelligence official was arrested in Belgium and brought to the United States, an escalation of the Trump administration’s effort to crack down on Chinese spying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Chinese intelligence official was arrested in Belgium and extradited to the United States to face espionage charges, Justice Department officials said on Wednesday, a major escalation of the Trump administration’s effort to crack down on Chinese spying.

headline: A Damaging Bid to Censor Applications at Harvard
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Asian-Americans', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION']
abstract: If a lawsuit over affirmative action is successful, would-be college students may have to hide their race.
lead_paragraph: Imagine this scenario: An admissions officer sits down to read a stack of applications, but they’re heavily redacted because the college must censor all references to an applicant’s race.

headline: What We Saw at New York Bridal Fashion Week
abstract: A quick look at some of the latest collections from top bridal designers.
lead_paragraph: Bridal fashion designers, both seasoned veterans and newcomers, showcased Fall and Winter 2019 collections during Bridal Fashion Week, which was Oct. 4-7 in New York. This year, Ines Di Santo, Vera Wang and Inbal Dror departed from last season’s princess-inspired collections and embraced bold, intricately designed gowns that were as much art as bridal wear. On display were dramatic gowns with colorful floral details, bright shimmering embroidery and sultry, sheer paneled dresses. Here are some highlights of what we saw.

headline: New This Week, Under $250
abstract: Five fresh releases to get you excited about fashion again.
lead_paragraph: Call it a fashion hangover. With the spring 2019 runway shows behind us, it’s easy to fall into a bit of a funk. After all, how many times can a fashion hound hash over Hedi Slimane’s debut at Celine, or that set at Chanel?

headline: Khashoggi, the Philippines, Chinese Espionage: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
