headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Make up a chili, or roast chicken, or a riff on tuna poke: It’s really the best tuna salad there is.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I wrote about fishing for The New York Times Magazine this week, an “Eat” column devoted to the joys of East Coast tuna poke. Of course there’s a recipe to go with the words (above). It’s my cover-band rendition of the classic Hawaiian dish and, if you can jig up a bonito off Point Judith or buy some top-drawer yellowfin tuna at the fishmonger, you can make it yourself and see. It is really the best tuna salad there is.

headline: For the Women of One Oaxacan Village, Pottery Is a Way of Life
abstract: There are some traditions that are universal. Here, we highlight a single craft — and how it’s being adapted, rethought and remade for the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: POTTERY — THE ACT of turning earth into clay and transforming its properties with fire — is one of humankind’s earliest inventions. Throughout history, certain techniques and styles have been particularly coveted, including Japanese raku ware, Turkish Iznik pottery, Persian earthenware, Italian majolica, Dutch delftware and Native American pottery. The secret of Chinese porcelain making, the pursuit of which involved spying, reverse engineering, imprisonment and alchemy, was a holy grail for centuries, eluding the Ottomans, Koreans, Japanese and Europeans.

headline: She Lost Her Father, Her Health and All She Held Dear. At Least She Found Perspective.
abstract: Alethea Black’s memoir, “You’ve Been So Lucky Already,” traces her journey from grief to religious faith.
lead_paragraph: YOU’VE BEEN SO LUCKY ALREADY By Alethea Black 188 pp. Little A. $24.95.

headline: People, Places and Things to Know: Feminist Art That’s Also Furniture, Patterned Bags and More
abstract: T’s cultural compendium of what’s new.
lead_paragraph: In the early ’90s, while she was living in Paris, the Korean artist Seulgi Lee received a gift from a friend — a blanket quilted using the nubi method, a traditional Korean technique characterized by distinctive, tightly spaced rows of stitches. She was instantly drawn to the blanket’s bright colors and parallel lines of thread, which reminded her of a rice field. After years of failing to track down similar pieces, she decided to make her own, working closely with artisans from Tongyeong, South Korea. In 2017, she produced a collection of richly colored cashmere nubi for Hermès. On November 15, Seoul’s Gallery Hyundai will unveil her newest works: silk canvases hand sewn with color-blocked geometric forms inspired by such droll Korean proverbs as “eat the rice cake lying down” and “even a straw sandal has its pair.” The show will also feature a selection of woven sculptures she created with a cooperative of female basket makers in the remote Oaxacan village of Santa María Ixcatlán. Though the town’s indigenous language is all but lost, Lee says, its residents still know how to weave palm leaves. “We were inventing new shapes and naming them,” she said, “to allow an ancient language to resurface.” — MERRELL HAMBLETON

headline: Did Hell Freeze Over? My Republican Dad Is Voting for a Democrat
abstract: He’s casting his ballot for Jon Tester, who is less of a cookie-cutter Democrat and more of a Bull Moose wild card, “a Montanan who understands Montana.”
lead_paragraph: BOZEMAN, Mont. — Montana has the highest suicide rate in the United States. For starters, there’s the random geographical bad luck that the altitude of the state’s six most populous cities exceeds 3,000 feet, the elevation at which blood oxygen levels go down and suicide stats go way up. Along with seven Indian reservations and agriculture being a leading industry — farmers and natives are more likely to end their own lives than other Americans — veterans make up about 10 percent of the state’s population. According to the new Veterans Affairs secretary, Robert Wilkie, every day, 22 American vets kill themselves.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: The final season of “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend” is here, along with a wild experimental TV opera. Meanwhile, Monty Python has finally come to Netflix.
lead_paragraph: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions on what to watch.

headline: Saving Sears From Potential Bankruptcy Should Have Started Six Years Ago
abstract: The company’s chief executive, Eddie Lampert, had plenty of chances to turn the company around. It may now be too late.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Hope All but Gone, Keeping Vigil for the Missing in the Indonesian Earthquake
abstract: The government has ended the search for bodies, and desperate family members are not ready. “If God could give me just one,” one man said, “it would be enough.”
lead_paragraph: PALU, Indonesia — Two weeks after the earthquake and tsunami that devastated his neighborhood, Anjas Firmansyah is still desperate to see his wife and son.

headline: Princess Eugenie Marries, and Britons Gripe About the Tax Bill
abstract: Excitement for the Windsor Castle wedding paled in comparison to the frenzy that accompanied Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s ceremony five months earlier.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — What a difference a royal wedding makes.

headline: The Bold Sensibility of Pierre Hardy
abstract: The designer, who launched his label in 1999, is known for his spare, graphic and utilitarian accessories. Here, he shares his many inspirations with T.
lead_paragraph: “I wasn’t even remotely interested in fashion,” the accessories designer Pierre Hardy says of his Parisian childhood. “My mother was a ballet instructor and my father taught athletics, so the only kind of clothing that caught my attention was super sporty, like high-tech ski suits.” Hardy, too, was passionate about dance as well as drawing, disciplines he pursued even as he worked toward a teaching degree in plastic arts from the École Normale Supérieure Paris-Saclay in Cachan. After graduation, he joined a modern dance troupe and drew illustrations for European fashion magazines such as Vanity Fair Italia and Vogue Hommes. In 1987, he took a position styling shoes at Christian Dior, and so began his distinguished career in fashion. Hermès was next to notice Hardy’s talents, naming him creative director of its men’s and women’s shoes in 1990 — and, later, of its haute joaillerie. In 1999, he started his own label, known for its color-blocked saddlebags and men’s sneakers. Soon after, Nicolas Ghesquière, then the designer of Balenciaga, asked him to oversee women’s shoes for the brand — a decade-long collaboration that resulted in some of Hardy’s most beloved designs, including his futuristic Lego sandal and platform Oxfords with Formica-tiled heels.

headline: A Mother’s Pain, a Daughter’s Addiction
abstract: In “If You Love Me,” Maureen Cavanagh chronicles her family’s journey through her daughter Katie’s heroin addiction.
lead_paragraph: IF YOU LOVE ME A Mother’s Journey Through Her Daughter’s Opioid Addiction By Maureen Cavanagh 208 pp. Henry Holt & Company. $26.

headline: Abroad in America: What Really Happens at a Trump Rally?
abstract: President Trump loves rallies! He loves the adoration of the crowds who attend his rallies!
lead_paragraph: Hello! This week I’m in Erie, Pa., where I’ve just been to one of the more arresting spectacles of the 2018 election calendar: a campaign rally featuring President Trump.

headline: Subscribe to the 'On Politics’ Newsletter
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: ‘On Politics With Lisa Lerer’ is a daily newsletter cutting through the noise and bringing you the people, issues and ideas shaping our world.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to On Politics, a daily newsletter by Lisa Lerer that brings you the people, issues and ideas shaping our world.

headline: Lamb Even Haters Can Love
abstract: Alison Roman on the meaty, savory and not at all lamby cut that changed her mind.
lead_paragraph: For years, I convinced myself that I didn’t care for lamb. I found that I could only ever describe it as “lamby,” which is not exactly a compliment. But now, the way I am constantly trying to persuade people to cook more lamb, you would think I was secretly working for the American Lamb Board. (I am not.)

headline: Hong Kong Bars Another Democracy Supporter From Running for Office
abstract: Lau Siu-lai, a college lecturer, won a seat in the city’s legislature in 2016, but was disqualified for the way she took her oath of office.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong government on Friday disqualified a democracy advocate from running for a seat on the local legislature, the latest in a series of moves that have undermined the political power of the opposition camp in the semiautonomous Chinese city.

headline: Young Adult Books That Plunge Into the Ecstasies, and Agonies, of Teenage Life
abstract: New novels about road trips, summer jobs and first love as well as darker realities: mental illness, body issues, the threat of gun violence.
lead_paragraph: “Given the right circumstances, any person could kill someone. Even you.” That thought-provoking statement comes early in Ellen Hopkins’s PEOPLE KILL PEOPLE (Simon & Schuster, 428 pp., $19.99; ages 14 and up), which explores the stories of six teenagers whose lives have been changed by gun violence. Among them are Silas and Ashlyn, who find purpose in a youth white supremacist group; Cami, a teenage mom secretly selling marijuana to make extra cash; and Daniel, couch-surfing after his mother’s deportation. One, we’re informed, will die at the hands of someone with a gun.

headline: How Asian Social Media Transformed a Quiet U.K. Walking Spot
abstract: “When we search for London on social media, it’s the first thing we see,” said one South Korean who visited the Seven Sisters cliffs, two hours south of London.
lead_paragraph: EAST SUSSEX, England — To an online travel site popular with younger Chinese travelers, the cliffs about two hours’ drive south of London are a “windy paradise.” In June, a South Korean actress shared a picture of herself at the cliffs, along with a video in which she stands uncomfortably close to the vertiginous edge. And the stars of a Korean reality television show visited them in a spring episode.

headline: Another Old Croton Aqueduct Gatehouse Enters the Commercial Age
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'AQUEDUCTS']
abstract: The Department of Parks and Recreation, which has jurisdiction over 1894 landmark, is seeking a business to revitalize it.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon a handful of restaurateurs and other interested parties showed up at the mystery building in the Morningside Heights neighborhood of Manhattan. Made of granite blocks and topped by a slate-shingled roof with trees growing out of the gutters, the single-story structure has sat empty for decades on the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and West 119th Street, near Columbia University.

headline: To Cope With Loss, a Pianist Mined the Music of Life Itself
abstract: Igor Levit discusses his album “Life,” which he recorded in the aftermath of his best friend’s death, ahead of his recital at Zankel Hall next week.
lead_paragraph: After a streak of ambitious recordings, the pianist Igor Levit didn’t have plans for his next album.

headline: Review: In ‘Place,’ a Composer Questions His Comfort, and Power
abstract: Ted Hearne’s collaborative new work at the Brooklyn Academy of Music puts a personal spin on gentrification, privilege and inequality.
lead_paragraph: The drive for redemption has inspired much of Western music. But what might redemption mean to a contemporary American composer sensitized to social injustice?

headline: How Noorain Khan, of the Ford Foundation, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: She calls her mother “10,000 times a day,” focuses on her volunteer efforts, and is “totally obsessed” with barre class at Physique 57.
lead_paragraph: Noorain Khan, a program officer at the Ford Foundation, makes grants that involve, among other things, economic, racial, and gender justice. On Sunday, she “loves creating community.” She carves out time for volunteer efforts and get-togethers with friends and family, sometimes conducting the latter over boxes of Popsicles in a nearby park. Ms. Khan, 34, lives with her husband, K. Sabeel Rahman, who is the new president of the progressive think tank Demos and an associate professor of law at Brooklyn Law School, in an apartment in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: How the Comedian Phoebe Robinson Acquired a Not-So-Ancient Sculpture
abstract: The “2 Dope Queens” co-host reflects on moving in with her boyfriend and purchasing an appropriately grown-up decorative object.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, Emily Spivack, the author of “Worn Stories,” interviews creative types about their most prized possessions. Here, the comedian and actress Phoebe Robinson describes the bust that sits in her home office. Robinson is the creator and co-host of the “2 Dope Queens” podcast and author of two books, including the forthcoming “Everything’s Trash, But It’s Okay.”

headline: Roasted Squid, by Way of Mexico
abstract: Layered with small potatoes and poblano chiles, and served with a tomatillo salsa, squid becomes the centerpiece of a worthy fall lunch.
lead_paragraph: All I know is I went to the fishmonger, who had some beautiful small squid, and suddenly an urge came over me: I had to take them home and give them a Mexican twist.

headline: What 9 Hypebeasts Wore to Hypefest
abstract: The festival was a two-day celebration of all things street wear.
lead_paragraph: It was a multicolored sea of collectible sneakers, limited-edition sweatshirts and white-hot brands, including Off-White, Billionaire Boys Club and Supreme. Last weekend, more than 10,000 streetwear aficionados made their way to the Brooklyn Navy Yard for the first-ever Hypefest. Organized by Hypebeast, the online fashion bible and boutique, it was a two-day celebration of all things street wear. Needless to say, attendees wore their A game.

headline: Nicole Maines on Becoming TV’s First Transgender Superhero
abstract: The actress and activist joins “Supergirl” this season, which begins Sunday, as Dreamer.
lead_paragraph: “Supergirl” will be gaining a new ally — TV’s first transgender superhero — when her series returns on Sunday. That night viewers will meet Nia Nal, who is a reporter in training working alongside Kara Danvers (Melissa Benoist), the civilian guise of the title hero. As the season progresses, Nia will be revealed to be the superheroine Dreamer. The character will be played by Nicole Maines, an actress and activist who is also transgender.

headline: Review: ‘Camping’ Is a Long, Uncomfortable Trip
abstract: HBO’s cringe comedy about a weekend getaway run by a control freak has some insight, but it’s more harsh than funny.
lead_paragraph: When we first see Kathryn (Jennifer Garner), she’s leaping into the air in slow-motion, against a backdrop of nature and blue sky. It’s a performance: She’s having her husband Walt (David Tennant) snap her picture for her Instagram account (which is “cresting 11,000 followers”). She rushes over to see the images, her happy face flickering off and her eyebrows pitching a tent of anxiety. “Did you like it?” she asks. “It’s kicky, right?”

headline: Beto O’Rourke’s War Chest Bothers Some Democrats as He Struggles Against Ted Cruz
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Mr. Cruz, the Texas Republican senator, held an eight-point lead in a new Times poll over Mr. O’Rourke, his Democratic challenger, in one of the most closely watched Senate races this year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Beto O’Rourke’s blockbuster fund-raising in his race to unseat Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is colliding with a widening deficit in polls, bringing long-simmering tensions into public view between Democrats who believe Mr. O’Rourke should share his bounty with better-positioned candidates and others who say his only obligation is to maximize his own chances.

headline: Watch This Blob of Cells Become an Embryo in High-Resolution
abstract: Researchers developed a new microscope that traces embryonic cell movement in real time, sketching a virtual map of how organ systems develop.
lead_paragraph: When the video above starts, this wiggling, glowing blue blob seen under a new high-resolution microscope doesn’t look like much. But in just 26 seconds you and I can watch the blob’s tiny cells multiply, interact and organize into the first organ systems of a living mouse embryo.

headline: Mercedes Ruehl Takes Weekly Strolls With Her Acting Students
abstract: The actress, who stars in the Broadway revival of “Torch Song,” is an acting teacher and mentor.
lead_paragraph: “Do you want to ask me about acting?” Mercedes Ruehl said, holding her water bottle. “I also take questions on faith and morals.”

headline: ‘We Need Answers’: Hurricane Michael Leaves Florida Residents Desperate for Aid
abstract: “When is anybody coming to do something?” one woman asked as Panhandle residents began searching for basic necessities.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA CITY, Fla. — It was two days after Hurricane Michael, and Eddie Foster was pushing his mother in a wheelchair down a thoroughly smashed street, his face creased with a concentrated dose of the frustration and fear that has afflicted much of the Florida Panhandle since the brutal storm turned its coast to rubble.

headline: Get It Done
abstract: When the days are full and you’re dead tired, make braised chicken thighs with greens and olives, BLT tacos, or green shakshuka.

My daughter is turning 1 this week, so I’m deep in yellow-cake recipes and buttercream, contemplating sprinkles and candles and round cake vs. sheet. (Round is so classic, no?)

lead_paragraph: Before mixed martial arts broke into the mainstream, led by Ronda Rousey and Conor McGregor, it still had a core of fanatical followers. And among those early adopters there was no more revered figure than the heavyweight Fedor Emelianenko. Yet he never fought in the Ultimate Fighting Championship.

lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — For months, the government of Nepal has struggled to contain public anger over a rise in sexual assaults in this small Himalayan nation — up 60 percent over the past five years, officials say.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Manipulative Parental Generosity
abstract: When mom and dad pay for plane tickets, are they controlling you?
lead_paragraph: Lauren writes: I am 24 and live in Boston. My father and mother live in San Diego. I am very lucky to have parents who support my coming home for the holidays by buying my plane tickets. But I believe that it is unreasonable for my dad to ask me eight months in advance for my flight preferences.

headline: Why Rent Control Is a Lightning Rod
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Referendums', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Affordable Housing', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Proposition 10 in California has put a new focus on an old question: whether rent control tends to ease or compound a shortage of affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: A supply of housing sufficient to meet urban needs in California will not be built for decades, if ever, and right now building doesn’t seem to be helping much. Many of the newer rental buildings carry high-end prices, while stock of affordable housing is actually falling.

headline: California Tenants Take Rent Control Fight to the Ballot Box
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Referendums', 'Landlords', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: An initiative to loosen state restraints on local rent restrictions is the focus of a political battle being fought with tens of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — From pulpits across Los Angeles, Pastor Kelvin Sauls has spent the past few months delivering sermons on the spiritual benefits of fasting. The food in the sermon is rent, and landlords need less of it. “My role is to bring a moral perspective to what we are dealing with around the housing crisis,” Pastor Sauls explained.

headline: Tiny Nanoparticles to Treat a Huge Problem: Snakebites
keywords: ['Nanotechnology', 'Snakes', 'Tissue (Human)', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Snakes kill or cripple 500,000 people a year, but antivenins are costly and rare in poor countries. Now scientists are testing injectable nanoparticles that neutralize venom.
lead_paragraph: An Epi-Pen to treat a snakebite?

headline: Facebook Hack Included Search History and Location Data of Millions
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The company said Friday that a network breach was smaller than originally thought: 30 million profiles. But the hackers stole detailed information.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said Friday that an attack on its computer systems that was announced two weeks ago had affected 30 million users, about 20 million fewer than it estimated earlier.

headline: Who Are the ‘Titans’?
abstract: The new live-action series “Titans,” on DC Universe, is the latest iteration for this group of former sidekicks first branded as the Teen Titans in 1965.
lead_paragraph: The live-action superhero series “Titans” debuted on the DC Universe streaming service today, with Robin, the onetime sidekick of Batman, destined to meet Beast Boy, Raven, Starfire and other heroes to form a team. “Titans” is the first original scripted show for the service. It will be joined by “Harley Quinn,” “Swamp Thing” and other series next year.

headline: Why Our Beliefs Don’t Predict Much About the Economy
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Two new studies show how changing beliefs about the financial future can destabilize the economy, perhaps even for decades.
lead_paragraph: The more we learn about how people really think, the more we must rethink economic theory.

headline: Review: ‘Split’ Is Naked and Clothed, Formal and Savage
abstract: The choreographer Lucy Guerin’s duet “Split,” at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, is nearly a thriller.
lead_paragraph: One dancer is clothed. The other isn’t. They do the same precise motions, locked into the same rhythm, an endlessly looping drum track. The stage floor is outlined in tape, and after 20 minutes, they split it in half with more tape, restricting themselves to one side. Ten minutes later, they split it again — and again after five more minutes, and so forth, as time and area keep diminishing by half until there isn’t room for two.

headline: Turning Loss Into Piano Greatness: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: Igor Levit's new album, composer news and the San Francisco Symphony were among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Happy Friday! We have some essential listening for your weekend: “Life,” the new album from the pianist Igor Levit. It’s sprawling, dense and inspiring.

headline: Jeff Koons’s Tulips Find a Home: A Central Garden in the City of Light
abstract: Despite repeated controversies, the monumental sculpture will end up in the gardens of the Petit Palais in Paris, near the Champs-Élysées.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For two years, Jeff Koons sought an appropriate place here for his monumental gift to Paris, “Bouquet of Tulips.” In three hours on Thursday, he found a garden, which may provide the end to a saga that has agitated France’s cultural circles since November 2016.

headline: How the Humble Bean Went Global
abstract: Introduced to Europe from the Americas, the common bean was cultivated into a staggering number of varieties.
lead_paragraph: Q. Are there more varieties of beans than there used to be?

lead_paragraph: The most intriguing part of Howard Marks’s new book about market cycles has nothing to do with the cycles themselves.

headline: The Week’s 5 Best and Worst Trailers (Sorry, ‘Pet Sematary’)
abstract: “House of Cards” tops our list for its riveting clip, followed by “Glass” from M. Night Shyamalan, “Ben Is Back” and “The Best of Enemies.”
lead_paragraph: The most exciting trailer released this week wasn’t for a movie. It was a teaser for the much-anticipated, post-Kevin Spacey farewell season of Netflix’s “House of Cards.” Still, there were several promotional clips for films that also generated discussion online, both positive and negative. Here are the highest-profile, ranked from most to least enticing.

headline: Why You May Be Your Own Worst Enemy as an Investor

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross has shifted his explanation for adding a citizenship question to the 2020 census, saying he now recalls discussing it with Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump’s former chief strategist, according to court documents filed Thursday.

headline: With Market Hot, Landlords Slam the Door on Section 8 Tenants
keywords: ['Section 8 (Housing)', 'Vouchers', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Affordable Housing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Many landlords are now refusing to accept vouchers when they can get higher rents, without the bureaucratic red tape, on the open market.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — One morning last year, Michele Carter woke up to find an eviction notice slipped under her apartment door. She had to move, she was later told, to make way for the renovation of her high-rise and the higher-paying tenants it would bring.

headline: Index Fund Investors’ Simpler Approach May Enrich Returns
keywords: ['Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Foreign Investments', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Fund investors often earn less than they could because emotions get in the way. People who use index funds seem to make fewer and better choices.
lead_paragraph: People who put their money into index funds seem to make fewer decisions than other investors. And that leads to better performance.

headline: For the Astros and the Red Sox, a Playoffs Reunion
abstract: Red Sox Manager Alex Cora, a coach on the Astros’ 2017 World Series champions, isn’t the only link between the teams as they meet in the playoffs for the second year in a row.
lead_paragraph: When the Boston Red Sox searched for a new manager last fall, they did not have to look far. The Houston Astros, who had just beaten them in the playoffs, had a bench coach who was just the right fit. Alex Cora was young, bright, charismatic — and he already owned a Red Sox championship ring from 2007, when he was a backup infielder. He got the job.

headline: Chicago Officer Is Cleared in Fatal Shooting of 15-Year-Old in Back of the Head
abstract: An independent civilian body found Officer Brandon R. Ternand “credible and persuasive” in saying that he feared for his life before shooting the teenager, Dakota Bright.

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives

lead_paragraph: The winter shopping list of Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman grew longer on Friday when the team learned that shortstop Didi Gregorius needed Tommy John surgery on his throwing arm.

headline: Faulty Work by Gas Company Caused Massachusetts Explosions, Officials Say
abstract: A crew contracted by Columbia Gas mishandled high-pressure gas as it replaced old pipes, according to a preliminary report by the National Transportation Safety Board.
lead_paragraph: A faulty plan to replace aging gas pipes caused sudden explosions and fires in three towns north of Boston last month that killed one person and drove thousands from their homes, the National Transportation Safety Board said Thursday.

lead_paragraph: Political persuasion is rarely friendly, and there will be lots more yelling, blaming, placard-waving and marching before we get to the November midterm elections. But I hope there will be some fervent singing as well — maybe even some of what used to be called protest songs.

headline: Fight Breaks Out Near Republican Club After Visit by Gavin McInnes, Police Say

headline: Brazil Enthralls With an Art Show of Afro-Atlantic History
abstract: With more than 200 artists, the São Paulo exhibition is a hemispheric treasure chest about resistance to racism. Its timing is apt.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — It’s worth going a distance for greatness. And great is what the exhibition “Histórias Afro-Atlânticas” (“Afro-Atlantic Histories”) is. With 450 works by more than 200 artists spread over two museums, it’s a hemispheric treasure chest, a redrafting of known narratives, and piece for piece one of the most enthralling shows I’ve seen in years, with one visual detonation after another.

headline: Neil deGrasse Tyson on How Space Scientists Have Long Been an ‘Accessory to War’
abstract: Tyson’s new book shows how the technologies that advanced our knowledge of the universe were designed with military advantage in mind.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2003, as the United States launched its invasion of Iraq, the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson was attending the annual conference of the Space Foundation, in Colorado Springs. The conference brings together professionals from various fields who share an interest in space — scientists, commercial satellite makers, as well as government and military officials — and as the invasion got underway, some of the attendees drifted to a television screen to watch the spectacle unfolding live on CNN.

headline: Joseph Tydings, Ex-Democratic Senator and Nixon Target, Dies at 90

headline: Mapping Out Where Noir Lives in the City of Angels

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Cold War Era']

headline: Nursery Cry
abstract: Kevin G. Der comes at us with a screaming tough Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE —  Kevin G. Der has established himself as a technical master of weekend puzzles (if you’re new to them and like a challenge, check out his previous Saturday production). He is particularly good at unexpected clues (that puzzle had NATO clued as “Turkey club?” in case you forgot) and surprise debuts (today has several entries I can’t believe are new, including CHEAT DAY).

headline: Feeling Like a Teenager
abstract: Amanda Chung and Karl Ni begin our solving week in a most refreshing way.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Fairy tales can come true, it can happen to you, if you regularly solve crossword puzzles. Well, maybe not fairy tales, but you’ll definitely get better at solving. And you will be entertained.

headline: At Ohio Rally, Trump Delivers Trademark Mix of Exaggerations and Vague Assertions

headline: A Brewers Reliever Bests a Dodgers Ace, With a Homer, in an N.L.C.S. Game 1 Win
abstract: Brandon Woodruff became the third relief pitcher in major league history to hit a home run in a postseason game as Milwaukee beat the Dodgers.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Brandon Woodruff’s usual job is to put baseballs over the plate at more than 90 miles per hour, not smash them over a fence.

headline: Brandon Woodruff and Postseason Home Runs Out of Nowhere
abstract: With his unlikely blast, the Brewers reliever joined obscure players like Tom Lawless, Jim Mason and Kurt Bevacqua, as well as greats like Ozzie Smith and Kirk Gibson.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — When a left-handed-hitting reliever launches a playoff home run off a left-handed pitcher bound for the Hall of Fame — well, let’s just say you don’t see that much in October. Yet it really did happen in the third inning on Friday at Miller Park, in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series, when the Brewers’ Brandon Woodruff connected off the Dodgers’ Clayton Kershaw.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads

headline: U.N.C. Chancellor Apologizes for History of Slavery at Chapel Hill
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']

headline: Lenny Bruce Is Still Talking Dirty and Influencing People
keywords: ['Theater', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: The influential “sick humor” comic, who died of a drug overdose in 1966, is having a resurgence in pop culture.
lead_paragraph: Ronnie Marmo didn’t set out to make a political play when he wrote and starred in “I’m Not a Comedian … I’m Lenny Bruce.” Instead, the actor wanted to depict the complicated style of the counterculture comedian and satirist, who died over 50 years ago. But many have read Mr. Marmo’s performance as a commentary on the Trump era.

abstract: A week after the justice’s controversial swearing-in, the African-American activists I study offer a lesson to those who are in despair: Failure is part of the process.

headline: Can My Landlord Evict Me From My Rent-Stabilized Apartment?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords']
abstract: Under some circumstances, a landlord can attempt to reclaim such an apartment for personal use.
lead_paragraph: Q: My domestic partner and I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a West Village building that converted to a co-op years ago under a noneviction plan. In February, my landlord sold my apartment to a new owner who has been harassing us for the past six months. He says he is not going to renew our lease when it expires at the end of October because he wants to take possession of it. My partner and I are both over 62 and one of us is disabled. I feel the landlord has no grounds to remove us, but what should we do? It doesn’t seem right that we should have to hire an attorney when the law seems so clear.

Naturally, its most glorious scene is the moon landing: the moment he takes that final, hesitant leap and we see his white boot press into the fine lunar soil before we gently pan over Earth, suspended in the vast blackness of space.

headline: Jim Taylor, Hall of Fame Fullback for the Green Bay Packers, Dies at 83

lead_paragraph: Jim Taylor, the bruising fullback who played on four N.F.L. championship teams with the Green Bay Packers of the 1960s and became the first star in Coach Vince Lombardi’s dynasty to be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame, died on Saturday. He was 83.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Davos in the Desert,’ a Saudi Prince’s Glittering Showcase, Is Stained by a Grisly Accusation

headline: Game Hunting
abstract: No animals were harmed in the making of this Ross Trudeau puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I love the topography of today’s grid: The long central staircase and the L-hooks everywhere make it very kinetic. There’s an interesting arrangement of long fill, too, which makes up for the slightly sparse theme entries. I like a Sunday grid like this once in a while; it worked like a giant Saturday. Even though my solving time was pretty average, forgoing some of the small fry in the grid made it feel like a quicker trip, somehow, which is not a jab at Ross Trudeau — it’s more a commentary on this time of year, when there’s this odd quickening before we settle down for the winter. Anyone else?

He had a two-run homer, and the Dodgers, who at times have looked overmatched by the Brewers in this National League Championship Series, had a 4-3 lead in the eighth inning that would hold up for a victory in Game 2.

headline: Review: Remembering the Way It Was (Not) in ‘The Things That Were There’
abstract: David Greenspan’s tone poem of a play, at the Bushwick Starr, considers time, death, family and the ways in which we recall our dead.
lead_paragraph: Though it never, predictably enough, says a word, the lovingly polished wooden dining table in David Greenspan’s “The Things That Were There” is as eloquent as any of its characters. The mere sight of this basic piece of furniture, which occupies center stage at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn, almost moved me to tears before Mr. Greenspan’s brief but ponderous play even started.

abstract: We want to hear your memories of watching the first man step onto the moon.

A new film, “First Man,” tells the story of the moon landing — the danger and the triumph — from Armstrong’s perspective.

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: ‘Sight’ Balances Grief, Freud and Parenthood
abstract: Jessie Greengrass discusses her first novel, about a woman remembering her mother and grandmother as she decides whether to have children herself.
lead_paragraph: This has been a year rich in books about the struggles and joys, the frustrations and rewards, of being a mother — a raft of stories comprising what Parul Sehgal, one of The Times’s book critics, called “radiantly specific dispatches from almost every corner of motherhood.” The British writer Jessie Greengrass’s first novel, “Sight,” can be fit into that group but offers its own distinct philosophical and lyrical pleasures. It is told by an unnamed narrator who recounts struggling with the decision of whether to have children with her partner, Johannes. (In real life, Ms. Greengrass has two young children.) Told in patient, psychologically complex prose, “Sight” combines the narrator’s thoughts about her own mother, who died several years earlier, and her remembrances of her grandmother, a psychoanalyst, with her relevant digressions about scientific history. (Real-life figures contemplated in the book include Sigmund Freud; Wilhelm Röntgen, who discovered X-rays; and John Hunter, an 18th-century surgeon and anatomist.) The narrator’s thoughts about having children undergirds the story, but the novel is also concerned with the nature of grief, selfhood and memory. Below, Ms. Greengrass talks about the early history of psychoanalysis, writing a novel while starting her own family and more.

headline: Jeff Hawkins Is Finally Ready to Explain His Brain Research

ANTHONY, Idaho — Belinda Luna, the librarian in this outpost in Idaho farm country, still shakes when she remembers a visit one day a little more than a year ago to an Immigration and Customs Enforcement office in Idaho Falls. An immigration official informed her husband, right in front of her and their children, that he was being deported to Mexico.

headline: Review: Rufus Wainwright’s ‘Hadrian’ Is a Step Forward, but Still Frustrating

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Even Rufus Wainwright now concedes that “Prima Donna,” his first opera, which received mixed to negative reviews at its 2009 premiere, was dramatically bland. But if the experience was a “nightmare” on many levels, as he said in a recent interview, he has tried to channel what he learned from it into his second opera, “Hadrian,” which had its premiere on Saturday here at the Canadian Opera Company in an elaborate, colorfully costumed production directed by Peter Hinton.

abstract: Hurricane Michael wrecked every other beachfront house on the block, but one came through the storm nearly pristine, as if protected by grace. How did it survive?

They picked gleaming paints from a palette of shore colors, chose salt-tolerant species to plant in the beach dunes and christened their creation the Sand Palace of Mexico Beach.

headline: ‘The Deuce’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Dirty Money

lead_paragraph: Two episodes ago, I wrote about the difficulties of being a “good guy” in the world of “The Deuce,” focusing mostly on Vinnie, whose eagerness to please all parties was putting him a morally perilous spot. In that instance, his failure to raise a fuss over Bobby’s negligence in the death of an underage parlor girl disappointed Abby, but it’s a pattern of behavior dating back to the first episode of the show, when he witnessed C.C. beating “Ashley” (now Dorothy) and could be counted on for his silence. Decency is a luxury that he cannot afford, especially on the mob’s payroll, so the best he can do is choose the best of an endless series of compromised options.

headline: David Price Finally Leads Red Sox to a Postseason Victory. Sort Of.

He gave up four runs in fewer than five innings, handed back a lead that his Boston Red Sox teammates had given him in the first inning and was removed from Game 2 of the American League Championship Series against the Houston Astros after he had allowed two batters to reach base in the top of the fifth.

headline: Ma guerre avec la guerre d’Algérie
keywords: ['Algerian War (1954-62)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: La France reconnait enfin ses crimes. Mais qu’est-ce-que cela veut dire pour moi, un algérien en Algérie aujourd’hui?
lead_paragraph: ORAN, Algérie — Je suis né huit ans après la proclamation de l’indépendance de l’Algérie en 1962. Je n’ai pas connu la guerre, mais elle a été présente dans mon imaginaire. Par la voie de mes parents et proches et de leurs discussions, et par la voie de l’Etat: l’école, la télévision, les fêtes officielles et les discours politiques. Tout ce que j’entendis alors a créé en moi, comme dans l’esprit de beaucoup de personnes de mon âge, une saturation qui provoqua le rejet.

headline: What to Do When Your Colonizer Apologizes
keywords: ['Algerian War (1954-62)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: France finally recognizes its crimes. What does that mean for me, an Algerian in Algeria, today?
lead_paragraph: ORAN, Algeria — I was born eight years after the 1962 Algerian declaration of independence. I didn’t experience the war, but it was present in my imagination, through my parents, their friends and their discussions, and through the state: in school, on television, on national holidays and in official speeches. As for many people my age, everything I heard brought on saturation and then rejection.

abstract: The newly opened Grand Junction-Moab trail, a 155-mile route linked by a network of backcountry huts, and accessible only two months a year, offers an almost irresistible challenge for bikers.
lead_paragraph: The granite cliffs of Unaweep Canyon, in the western area of Colorado, just south of Grand Junction and about 265 miles from Denver, are said to be some of the oldest exposed rocks in the state — roughly 1.5 billion years old, or a third of the earth’s recorded history.

headline: How an Unlikely Family History Website Transformed Cold Case Investigations
keywords: ['Genealogy', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Forensic Science', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Sex Crimes', 'Serial Murders', 'Privacy']
abstract: Fifteen murder and sexual assault cases have been solved since April with a single genealogy website. This is how GEDmatch went from a casual side project to a revolutionary tool.
lead_paragraph: LAKE WORTH, FLA. — On Halloween night in 1996, a man in a skeleton mask knocked on the door of a house in Martinez, Calif., handcuffed the woman who greeted him and raped her. Two weeks later, he called the dental office where she worked. Investigators tried to track him down through phone records, but got nowhere. They obtained traces of his semen, but there was no match for his DNA in any criminal database.

lead_paragraph: A MONONYM IS possessed of a certain celebrity: Prince, Madonna, Iman. No surname needed, thank you very much. Just a couple of syllables and the whole of the mononym’s grandeur flashes across our consciousness.

headline: George R. R. Martin, Fantasy’s Reigning King
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Television', 'Myths and Mythical Creatures', 'Science Fiction']
abstract: The author of “A Game of Thrones” has expanded the realms of genre fiction and prestige television — and forever changed how we engage with an imagined universe.
lead_paragraph: GEORGE R. R. MARTIN is in his element. Pen in hand, wearing his signature wool flat cap, he’s seated in a corner of the cavernous San Jose McEnery Convention Center, site of this year’s Worldcon — the World Science Fiction Convention, held annually since 1946. A long line snaking around stanchions inches forward. A hundred people, maybe more. A member of the convention staff stands near the table, explaining ground rules: one book at a time. If you want multiple books signed, you must go to the back of the line.

headline: Viggo Mortensen, the Unlikely Leading Man
abstract: The accomplished actor has made his career by defining himself as everything a movie star isn’t.
lead_paragraph: IN THE INFORMAL taxonomy of Hollywood’s leading men, there are several obvious types. There is Brad Pitt: too lean and too chiseled to ignore, rangy and funny but emotionally aloof. He doesn’t understand you, but then again, as with all beautiful people, you don’t need him to. There is the spiritual descendant of Jack Nicholson, Leonardo DiCaprio, that boyish, Peter Pan type who still happens, however incongruously, to be in possession of an old soul. There’s Matthew McConaughey and Keanu Reeves — dreaming, or maybe just out to lunch. There are the jerks: Ben Affleck, Tobey Maguire. The preppies: Jude Law, Christian Bale. The guys who can make you laugh, even when you’re annoyed at them: Will Smith, George Clooney. There’s the men you’d want to carry you from a burning building, flames licking at their heels: Denzel Washington, Bruce Willis. The meat and potatoes: solid and reliable, like Matt Damon and Russell Crowe.

headline: How Carrie Mae Weems Rewrote the Rules of Image-Making
abstract: Perhaps our best contemporary photographer, she creates work that insists on the worth of black women — both in art and in life.
lead_paragraph: ON CARRIE MAE WEEMS’S deck in Syracuse, N.Y., locusts are buzzing about the space like doomsday portents, emerging from the ground after 17 years only to drown boozily in our cups of rosé. It’s a warm day in late June, and a summer languor — or maybe it’s a news-cycle-induced torpor — is in the air, but Weems, perhaps our greatest living photographer, is juggling so many projects that when we were emailing to work out the interview logistics, she warned me, “We’ll need all your skills on this.” She is simultaneously working on a trio of shows: a retrospective at Boston College’s McMullen Museum of Art this fall, an installation for Cornell University and a group show she’s curating, “Darker Matter,” which will include a new series of her own, at the Park Avenue Armory around 2020 — a follow-up to the creative think tank of artists, musicians and writers she organized at the venue last winter titled “The Shape of Things.”

headline: Bruce Nauman’s Work Through the Years
abstract: For over 50 years, he’s made art about art itself, inventing his own visual language along the way.
lead_paragraph: For over 50 years, he’s made art about art itself, inventing his own visual language along the way.

headline: In Photos: Gucci by Alessandro Michele
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Photography']
abstract: With a vision as inclusive as it is imaginative, the creative director has ushered in a new way of dressing for one’s self.
lead_paragraph: With a vision as inclusive as it is imaginative, the creative director has ushered in a new way of dressing for one’s self.

headline: Alessandro Michele, Fashion’s Modern Mastermind
abstract: In just three years, Gucci’s creative director has shifted the industry’s course, altering the way the world sees value, gender and even identity.
lead_paragraph: ON A BRIGHT May day, Alessandro Michele and I stand side by side at the same picture window gazing at the same patch of Lower Manhattan, but we don’t have the same view. Where I see a riot of buildings born of utility and bereft of any unifying aesthetic, he sees a story, a timeline, a testament. While I want to tidy it up somehow, he wants to let it be and breathe. To me, it’s a mess — an exciting one, but still. To him, it’s a mosaic.

headline: Bruce Nauman, the Artist’s Artist
abstract: In the past half-century, he has created masterpieces in nearly every medium and, in the process, pushed the limits of what art can — and should — do.
lead_paragraph: THOUGH THE ARTIST Bruce Nauman’s home and studio are just outside of Santa Fe, N.M. — a few miles from grapefruit margaritas, enchiladas with red-and-green chile sauce (“Christmas style”), stores selling miniature adobe huts, innumerable yoga studios, innumerable galleries of local artists — the distance feels greater. To enter into Nauman’s world is to leave much of what one feels to be familiar, to suddenly feel all of it is trivial and inessential and to regret that at some point one has to return to it. His house is so unassuming as to be indescribable, his studio not much more than a giant shed. There is a field for a few tranquil horses, a shelter full of bales of hay. It was a dry year, he said in his clipped, hoarse, somewhat unlocatable Western accent, and water-stressed rattlesnakes stayed close to home. Just the other day, he found one on the steps to the studio.

headline: How to Fix Fake News
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Philosophy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: Technology has given rise to an age of misinformation. But philosophy, and a closer look at our own social behavior, could help eliminate it.
lead_paragraph: Technology spawned the problem of fake news, and it’s tempting to think that technology can solve it, that we only need to find the right algorithm and code the problem away. But this approach ignores valuable lessons from epistemology, the branch of philosophy concerned with how we acquire knowledge.

The avatar of this new nationalism is Donald Trump, who urged the world in his United Nations speech last month “to reject the ideology of globalism and accept the ideology of patriotism.”

lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s for crisp-cooked spiced lamb chops with fennel and cucumber (above), and it’s made with little loin chops, thin-cut, fairly lean. They have a less pronounced funkiness than their fattier cousins the rib chops, or the meat of the shoulder, belly and leg.

lead_paragraph: The N.F.L.’s new emphasis on enforcing the roughing-the-passer rules has certainly affected many games this season. But on Sunday night, the rule played a crucial role not because of a game-changing penalty, but because of a player who wanted to avoid one.

headline: Infosys Built Its Global Machine With Indian Workers. Can It Adjust to Trump’s ‘Hire American’?
abstract: Doing significantly more work in the United States, as the company is being pressured to do, would require an overhaul of its business model and corporate culture.
lead_paragraph: When Infosys, a big Indian technology outsourcing company, opened a new office in Indianapolis this year, executives hailed it as a step along a new path.

headline: Review: A ‘Lost Highway’ Suite Refracts David Lynch
abstract: Olga Neuwirth’s instrumental work, drawn from her 2003 opera, shows off the impressive capabilities of the experimental art center Empac.
lead_paragraph: TROY, N.Y. — It’s a little off the New York City radar, but one of the country’s most invigorating hubs for performance and what’s fashionably called “time-based” visual art has been operating here for a decade now.

headline: Finding Lost Apples and Reviving a Beloved Cider
abstract: George Washington was among the many fans of Newark cider, a long-missing treat now being recreated by a former ad man on a mission.
lead_paragraph: ASBURY, N.J. — Ironbound Hard Cider may seem an odd name for the business Charles Rosen has built here on 108 acres in central New Jersey. The farm, where a new taproom offers pastoral views of the still-ripening fruit, doesn’t appear to share much with the Ironbound, an industrial neighborhood 50 miles to the east in Newark.

headline: Barbara Kingsolver’s New Novel Moves Between the Distant Past and the Troubled Present
abstract: “Unsheltered” threads the story of a present-day family struggling in New Jersey with that of a 19th-century science teacher who had lived on the same property.
lead_paragraph: “If you want a piece of property to go downhill,” Madeleine Blais wrote in a memoir titled “To the New Owners” (2017), “just leave it in the care of a bunch of word people.”

headline: Ecuadorean Food, From Coast to Highlands
abstract: The menu at Rincón Melania includes Ecuador’s national dish: encebollado, whose warmth softens the harder edges of the world.
lead_paragraph: The menu at Rincón Melania includes Ecuador’s national dish: encebollado, whose warmth softens the harder edges of the world.

headline: A Menu That Roams Ecuador From Queens
abstract: At Rincón Melania, an airy, modern restaurant run by a family with roots in the Cañari tribe, every meal begins with tostado, a snack of roasted corn.
lead_paragraph: The kernels are as dark as brass, with hard shells and glossy vellum skins. They’re still warm from the pan, when the moisture inside the shells turned to steam and made the corn swell and pop. But there’s no outward sign of the tumult, no spilling of guts. It’s popcorn, minus the explosion into fluff — a worthwhile trade-off, sacrificing lightness for meatiness and crunch.

headline: Review: A Put-Upon Nanny Erupts in Todd Solondz’s ‘Emma and Max’
abstract: This strident satire from the filmmaker behind “Happiness” and “Wiener-Dog” is perfectly staged — and all too obvious.
lead_paragraph: Watching scenery being changed is not, as a general rule, what you go to the theater for. But this basic necessity of stagecraft takes on such emotional weight in “Emma and Max,” written and directed by the filmmaker Todd Solondz in his theatrical debut, that it becomes the production’s most moving element, in far more than a literal sense.

headline: Pete Davidson and Ariana Grande Split Up: Your Monday Pop Culture Cheat Sheet
abstract: What you need to know from today’s TV, music and movie news.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

headline: ‘Shocking and Abhorrent’ Abuse Rampant in U.K. Parliament, Report Says
abstract: An inquiry into sexual harassment in the House of Commons describes a “master and servant” culture, with lawmakers accorded an “almost godlike status.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A scathing new report on Britain’s House of Commons released on Monday describes a culture of bullying, abuse and sexual harassment “as embedded as it is shocking,” where complaints of mistreatment are typically muffled by “deference, subservience, acquiescence and silence.”

headline: A ‘Sugar Date’ Gone Sour
abstract: In the fuzzy space between jobs and relationships, there’s a lot that can go wrong.
lead_paragraph: Chandler Fowles knew it wouldn’t be simple to move from Mystic, Conn., to New York City last year. But staying put held little appeal. Her degree in art history and fine arts from Eastern Connecticut State University wasn’t helping her land any job worth sticking around for. She was coming out of a tough breakup. She and her mother weren’t speaking at all after a particularly bad argument.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Arizona Senate, McSally vs. Sinema
abstract: Whoever wins this election will make history as the first female senator from Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Whoever wins this election will make history as the first female senator from Arizona.

abstract: Songs from the movie, including the rising hit “Shallow,” were bought and streamed enough to top the Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Cooper, Willie Nelson’s son and a real pop star masquerading as a fake pop star are among the musicians celebrating a chart-topping album this week.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Florida’s 27th District, Salazar vs. Shalala
abstract: This traditionally Republican district, which includes wealthy communities like Miami Beach, Key Biscayne and Coral Gables as well as Little Havana in Miami, has been trending Democratic in recent years.
lead_paragraph: This traditionally Republican district, which includes wealthy communities like Miami Beach, Key Biscayne and Coral Gables as well as Little Havana in Miami, has been trending Democratic in recent years.

headline: When Sears Was Everywhere: Espionage, Politics and Fine Art
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Art', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Bankruptcies']
abstract: Over its long history, the retailer has had an influence in some unexpected places.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time — because it feels as if it has been around forever — Sears was a central player in American life.

abstract: A journalist’s traumatic story of epilepsy and his struggle to have it treated seriously, and properly, in his college years.
lead_paragraph: A MIND UNRAVELED A Memoir By Kurt Eichenwald 416 pp. Ballantine. $28.

headline: Invisible Irish Border Carries the Scars of a Fractured Past
abstract: The frontier between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland has become a major sticking point in talks about Britain’s exit from the European Union.
lead_paragraph: PETTIGO, Ireland — Along the winding open border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, Cuilcagh Mountain trail rises into a steep wooden stairway that comes to a halt at a lookout deck.

headline: U.S. Credit Card Giants Flout India’s New Law on Personal Data
keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Data Storage', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Protectionism (Trade)']
abstract: As India develops new rules governing the data of its residents, global firms are the first target. Companies say they need more time to comply.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When the clock struck midnight in Delhi at the end of Monday, Visa, Mastercard and American Express were suddenly in violation of the law every time an Indian swiped a credit or debit card.

keywords: ['Turtles and Tortoises', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Plastics', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: An organization on the coast of Kenya tries to persuade local residents to help return the trapped reptiles to the ocean, rather than sell their meat and shells for a living.
lead_paragraph: WATAMU, Kenya — The young hawksbill turtle was accidentally caught in a net in the Indian Ocean off Kenya’s coast.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The disappearance of a Saudi dissident journalist has put Steven Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, in an increasingly tenuous position as he prepares to attend an investment conference in Riyadh next week.

headline: The Lawsuit Against Harvard
abstract: A reader objects to the depiction of the Asian-American plaintiffs as pawns.

headline: She Founded Me Too. Now She Wants to Move Past the Trauma.
abstract: One year after #MeToo upended Hollywood and politics, Tarana Burke talks about the movement’s future, the #HimToo backlash and advice for survivors.
lead_paragraph: When the activist Tarana Burke started the original “Me Too” movement more than a decade ago on MySpace, she never imagined what a force it would become. Then on Oct. 15, 2017, the actress Alyssa Milano shared on Twitter a friend’s suggestion that “women who have been sexually harassed or assaulted” write “Me too” in the wake of the Harvey Weinstein revelations earlier that month. The #MeToo hashtag instantly went viral. And Burke was thrust into the global spotlight.

headline: The Midterm Elections: What Are Your Issues?
abstract: We’re asking readers, “What are the top one or two issues that will affect your vote, and why?”
lead_paragraph: Beyond the heat and the noise, substantive issues are at stake as the midterm elections near. What are the top one or two issues that will affect your vote, and why?

headline: How Sears Was the Amazon of Its Day
abstract: It was a technological wonder — until the retail landscape changed and new innovation, and greedy owners, arrived.
lead_paragraph: The orders poured in from everywhere — 105,000 a day at one point — so much so that the company became an economic force. It could make or break suppliers by promoting their products. It could dictate terms on manufacturing. Its headquarters city boomed as this tech-driven retailer built huge warehouses and factories and attracted other businesses and rivals. State and local governments complained that the company was harming small-town retailers.

headline: Think Tim Jones’s Cosmic R&B Is Weird? Wait Until You Meet His Dummy
abstract: A new reissue shines a light on Jones, known as Preacherman, an obscure musician who has spent four decades fashioning his own instruments and philosophy.
lead_paragraph: James Brown was famously known as “the hardest working man in show business,” but Tim Jones seems deserving of at least an honorable mention.

headline: The Japanese Man Who Saved 6,000 Jews With His Handwriting
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: What the astonishing Chiune Sugihara teaches us about moral heroism.
lead_paragraph: NAGOYA, Japan — “Even a hunter cannot kill a bird that flies to him for refuge.” This Samurai maxim inspired one gifted and courageous man to save thousands of people in defiance of his government and at the cost of his career. On Friday I came to Nagoya at the invitation of the Japanese government to speak in honor of his memory.

headline: Budget Deficit Jumps Nearly 17% in 2018
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Plunging corporate tax revenues from the Trump tax cuts helped push the annual deficit to $779 billion. It is on track to reach $1 trillion by 2020.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal budget deficit swelled to $779 billion in fiscal year 2018, the Treasury Department said on Monday, driven in large part by a sharp decline in corporate tax revenues after the Trump tax cuts took effect.

headline: Trump Rule Would Compel Drug Makers to Disclose Prices in TV Commercials
abstract: The plan sets the stage for a battle with the pharmaceutical industry, which announced earlier that it would not show prices but would direct viewers to company websites that featured the information.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over vehement objections by drug companies, the Trump administration proposed on Monday a new federal regulation that would require them to disclose the list prices of prescription drugs in their television advertisements.

headline: Gear to Help Your Baby (and You) Sleep Better
abstract: New babies — and new parents — often have trouble getting enough sleep. Wirecutter shares products and real-world lessons that can help.
lead_paragraph: Having a baby means relearning one of the basic tasks of survival: how to sleep. There’s no magic product that will work for every family, but Wirecutter’s parenting team has consulted pediatricians and sleep experts and tested dozens of products in a quest for a better night’s rest. Here’s what may actually work.

headline: Does Harvard Admissions Discriminate? The Lawsuit on Affirmative Action, Explained
abstract: The case, concerning allegations that Harvard unfairly restricts the number of Asian-Americans it accepts, could have a broad impact on how schools choose their incoming classes.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Harvard University’s admissions practices are on trial in Federal District Court in Boston, in a lawsuit that could have a broad impact on the way colleges choose their incoming classes.

abstract: With the midterm elections approaching, we tracked the war chests of candidates in the tightest House races.
lead_paragraph: With the midterm elections approaching, we tracked the war chests of candidates in the tightest House races.

headline: Abortion Debate in Australia Has a New Element: Women in Power
abstract: The Parliament in the Australian state of Queensland, which has achieved a striking level of representation for women, is considering scrapping a century-old abortion law.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — Activists in the Australian state of Queensland have tried for decades to scrap a criminal code from 1899 that makes having an abortion an offense punishable with prison time, and for decades their efforts have failed.

headline: Trump Falsely Claims E.U. Was Formed to ‘Take Advantage’ of U.S. on Trade
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The European Union was created to end strife and promote economic prosperity — with the support, not opposition, of the United States.
lead_paragraph: — President Trump, in an interview with “60 Minutes” broadcast on Sunday

headline: Did Minnesota’s Eighth District Really Swing by Almost 20 Points?
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: An apparent drastic shift toward the Republican candidate highlights the challenges of polling generally, and of polling in certain states particularly.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota’s Eighth District is one of a handful of Democratic-held House seats where Republicans have a realistic shot to win in the midterms in three weeks. The incumbent, Rick Nolan, is retiring, and he won by only one percentage point in 2016 in a district President Trump carried by 15.

headline: Culinary Tales From the Hudson Valley
abstract: A new book from the chef Richard Erickson and his wife, Mary Anne Erickson, includes recipes from their Blue Mountain Bistro-to-Go.
lead_paragraph: Richard Erickson, a chef, and his wife, Mary Anne Erickson — the owners of Blue Mountain Bistro-to-Go, a prepared food shop in Kingston, N.Y. — have published a cookbook. Despite the title “Feel Good Food,” the book is not plugged into the ubiquitous “wellness” trend. It’s simply a solid collection of reliable recipes closely tied to the Hudson Valley agricultural region, with profiles of farms and farmers. The book also reflects Mr. Erickson’s travels and experience. Mr. Erickson is from Missouri; he and his wife moved in the early 1990s to Woodstock, N.Y., where they opened Blue Mountain Bistro in 1993, now closed. The recipes for dishes like tomato-fennel soup, mushroom-leek bread pudding, spiced lamb keftas and coq au vin are seasonal, sometimes with Middle Eastern flavors, and suit both everyday and special occasions.

headline: Add Art to an Opulent Dinner
abstract: A new line of serving ware from the Whitney Museum relies on the designs of Sol LeWitt.
lead_paragraph: A line of dinnerware designed by the artist Sol LeWitt and made to his specifications in Deruta, Italy, is a stunning addition to the Whitney Museum store. Serving pieces include this flat, 12-inch sharply patterned plate, for hors d’oeuvres, cheese and desserts like tarts and cakes. It’s worthy of display when not in use. There are other designs for plates, bowls and even sets.

headline: Chelsea’s Baking Shop Finds a New Home
abstract: The daughters of the founder of the New York Cake Academy have moved the bakeware shop and baking school to a larger space.
lead_paragraph: The closing of the New York Cake Academy, the venerable baking supply house and cooking school this year, has a very happy ending. Lisa Mansour and Jenny Kashanian, the daughters of the founder, Joan Mansour, have moved the establishment into a larger space just a block away. The new store has a cafe in the front, where dessert confections made in-house are served, something that was never possible in the smaller shop. The glassed-in cooking school can handle twice as many students and now has ovens, so baking, not just confectionery, can be taught. And in the rear are racks upon racks filled with every baking and decorating implement imaginable.

headline: Keith Ellison’s Campaign Overshadowed by Ex-Girlfriend’s Allegations
keywords: ['Elections, Attorneys General', 'Dating and Relationships', '#MeToo Movement', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Domestic Violence', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Karen Monahan has accused Mr. Ellison of emotional and physical abuse. The claims loom in a race that has become close.
lead_paragraph: When Keith Ellison started his bid to become Minnesota’s next attorney general, he had formidable advantages.

headline: Helping Refugees, One Dish at a Time
abstract: The founder of Emma’s Torch and the restaurant’s culinary director will discuss the nonprofit’s mission to train refugees for food service jobs at a talk at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: Emma’s Torch — named for Emma Lazarus, whose poem is inscribed on the base of the Statue of Liberty — is a Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, restaurant that’s also a nonprofit training facility to help refugees and survivors of human trafficking qualify for jobs in the hospitality field. Kerry Brodie, the founder and executive director, and Alexander Harris, the culinary director, will discuss it with food historian Francine Segan at the 92nd Street Y. Food will be served.

headline: Carl Icahn Returns to Haunt Dell
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The billionaire investor said he intended to fight Dell’s bid to buy out investors in a tracking stock. That has echoes of his last fight with the company.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Amid Brexit Impasse, Theresa May Says Deal Is ‘Achievable’
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: With negotiations over Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union stymied, the British prime minister is trying to put a summit meeting back on track.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a significant setback in talks over Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday insisted that an agreement was still “achievable” as she tried to prevent a crucial meeting with her European counterparts this week from turning a diplomatic deadlock into a crisis.

headline: For Relaxing Times, Japanese Gin and Vodka
abstract: Suntory, outside Kyoto, releases its gin and vodka to an American audience.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Japanese spirits, one thinks of whiskey and soju, not gin and vodka. But now those “white spirits,” notably gin, have seeped into the American market. Recently, Suntory — the Japanese distiller that has been in business near Kyoto since 1899 — started shipping its newest gin and vodka to the United States. The vodka, which is fairly neutral but traced with sweetness, is distilled from rice. The gin, which is floral and citrusy, is flavored with six Japanese botanicals, including yuzu peel and sencha tea. Though the herbs and spices typically used for gin, like juniper and coriander, are also added, they are subtle; the gin is not the London dry style.

headline: Belgium Elects Nation’s First Black Mayor, a Congolese Immigrant
abstract: Almost six decades after Belgium’s rule ended in Congo, a land it brutalized for decades, an overwhelmingly white borough elected a man who was born in that colony.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Belgian voters elected the first black mayor in their nation’s history on Sunday — a man originally from the huge swath of central Africa that Belgium brutalized for generations, in one of the harshest of the European colonial regimes.

headline: Sears Plan to Get Out of Bankruptcy Has a Familiar Ring
abstract: The retailer says it will do more of what it has been doing in recent years: closing stores and borrowing more money from its controlling shareholder.
lead_paragraph: In its bankruptcy filing on Monday, Sears argued that, given enough time and less debt, it would be able to reverse the decades-long decline of its retail business.

headline: Will Meghan Markle’s Royal Baby Have American Citizenship?
abstract: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle have a dual-nationality marriage. Their expected baby will be British. But will he or she also be American?
lead_paragraph: For many Americans, the news on Monday morning that Meghan Markle was expecting a royal baby came as a welcome injection of delight into the depressing drumbeat of politics and animosity that normally fills the nation’s news feeds.

headline: Herbert D. Kleber, Pioneer in Addiction Treatment, Dies at 84
abstract: A professional detour to the federal prison hospital in Lexington, Ky., known as the “narcotics farm,” would set the course of his life’s work.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from completing his medical residency at Yale-New Haven Hospital in 1964, Dr. Herbert Kleber fulfilled his military obligation by volunteering for the United States Public Health Service. He expected to do research at the National Institutes of Health. But to his dismay he was assigned instead to the Public Health Service Prison Hospital at Lexington, Ky.

headline: Why Is Trump Still Backing Saudi Arabia in Yemen?
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The president wants you to believe that the U.S. gets “massive amounts” of money for backing the kingdom. That’s fake news.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of journalist Jamal Khashoggi’s disappearance, a group of bipartisan senators demanded answers about why the United States is still backing the Saudi-led war in Yemen. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont said the U.S. should “get out” of the war entirely if the kingdom is involved with the journalist’s disappearance. President Trump said the U.S. gets “massive amounts” of money selling arms to Riyadh. That’s fake news.

headline: Mary Midgley, 99, Moral Philosopher for the General Reader, Is Dead
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Philosophy', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Biology and Biochemistry']
abstract: Writing into her 90s — her last book was published last month — Dr. Midgley challenged with wit and verve the primacy of science as arbiter of reality.
lead_paragraph: Mary Midgley, a leading British moral philosopher who became an accessible, persistent and sometimes witty critic of the view that modern science should be the sole arbiter of reality, died on Oct. 10 in Jesmond, Newcastle Upon Tyne, less than three weeks after her last book was published. She was 99.

headline: Irving Like, 93, Dies; Foe of Power Plant and Friend of Fire Island
abstract: Mr. Like, an environmental lawyer, waged a long and ultimately successful fight against the Shoreham nuclear generator on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Irving Like, an environmental lawyer whose unflinching crusade over a quarter century permanently shuttered the Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island, died on Oct. 3 at a hospital in West Islip, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: On Politics With Lisa Lerer: Doing What She Can
abstract: How one 92-year-old woman is trying to shape the midterms; analyzing the president’s interview on “60 Minutes”; and Elizabeth Warren’s DNA test.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

abstract: Some 31 studies by Dr. Piero Anversa contain fabricated or falsified data, officials concluded. Dr. Anversa popularized the idea of stem cell treatment for damaged hearts.
lead_paragraph: A prominent heart researcher formerly at Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston fabricated or falsified data in 31 published studies that should be retracted, officials at the institutions have concluded.

headline: Alfred Hubay, Met Opera’s Box Office Prognosticator, Dies at 93
abstract: In a lifetime of working at the Met, he developed an ability to project ticket sales with uncanny accuracy.
lead_paragraph: Alfred Hubay, who rose from usher to house and box office manager at the Metropolitan Opera and along the way developed an ability to predict with uncanny accuracy what ticket sales would be for individual shows and entire seasons, died on Oct. 3 in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Argentina Will Leave You Speechless
abstract: From the white salt desert of Jujuy Province to the tremendous power of Iguazú Falls to the thriving diversity of Buenos Aires, discover the transformative experience of Argentina.
lead_paragraph: From the white salt desert of Jujuy Province to the tremendous power of Iguazú Falls to the thriving diversity of Buenos Aires, discover the transformative experience of Argentina.

headline: Paul G. Allen, Microsoft’s Co-Founder, Is Dead at 65
abstract: Mr. Allen and Bill Gates started the company in 1975, helping to usher in the personal computing revolution. He died after a recurrence of cancer.
lead_paragraph: Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft who helped usher in the personal computing revolution and then channeled his enormous fortune into transforming Seattle into a cultural destination, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 65.

headline: Russia Takes Further Step Toward Major Schism in Orthodox Church
abstract: The Russian Orthodox Church moved to sever ties with the Constantinople Patriarchate to protest moves to form an independent church in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Russian Orthodox Church on Monday moved to sever all ties with the Constantinople Patriarchate, the Orthodox mother church, to protest its moves toward creating an independent church in Ukraine.

abstract: Climate policy is the ultimate example of Trumpian corruption.
