lead_paragraph: On 106 acres in Fishlake National Forest in Richfield, Utah, a 13-million-pound giant has been looming for thousands of years. But few people have ever heard of him.

headline: Review: Sex, Lies and Vindication in a Most Timely ‘Measure for Measure’
abstract: The heroine’s impossible position could hardly be more sympathetic or central than in this Pushkin Theater Moscow/Cheek by Jowl staging.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the more repellent bargains in Shakespeare: a young woman’s virginity in exchange for her brother’s life. To our modern minds, it seems like such a no-brainer. Of course Isabella should sacrifice herself. Who would refuse that deal, ugly though it is?

headline: Felix Smith, Who Piloted Covert Flights Over Asia, Is Dead at 100
abstract: Recruited by Lt. Gen. Claire Chennault, Captain Smith flew over China, Vietnam and Laos on stealth Cold War missions for the American government.
lead_paragraph: Felix Smith, a swashbuckling pilot for a Chinese Nationalist airline that flew covert missions over Asia for the American government during the early days of the Cold War, died on Oct. 3 in Milwaukee. He was 100.

headline: A Big New Biography Treats Frederick Douglass as Man, Not Myth
abstract: David W. Blight’s “Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom” is an ambitious and empathetic biography of a major American life.
lead_paragraph: Time has a way of sanding off the rough edges of historical memory, turning even the most convulsive, contentious lives into opportunities for national triumphalism and self-congratulation. With “Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom,” the historian David W. Blight wants to enrich our understanding of an American in full who, for more than half his life, wasn’t even legally recognized as such. Now that Douglass is enshrined on his pedestal, shorn of what made him “thoroughly and beautifully human,” Blight notes how the “old fugitive slave” has been “adopted by all elements in the political spectrum,” eager to claim him as their own.

headline: How One Journalist’s Death Provoked a Backlash That Thousands Dead in Yemen Did Not
abstract: The sudden turn against Saudi Arabia reveals uncomfortable realities of alliance politics, group psychology and the perception of morality.
lead_paragraph: If you had to pick a year in the past decade when the contradictions of the American-Saudi relationship seemed likeliest to explode into crisis, 2018 would not be the obvious choice.

headline: In Virginia House Race, Anonymous Attack Ads Pop Up on Facebook
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Political Advertising', 'Online Advertising', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Media']
abstract: The ads, with language and imagery not typically found in even the roughest campaigns, were purchased by a critic of Jennifer Wexton, a Democrat trying to unseat the Republican incumbent.
lead_paragraph: A competitive race in Virginia’s 10th Congressional District has an alarming new element: anonymous attack ads on Facebook.

headline: ‘Halloween’ 1978: The Times Finally Reviews a Horror Classic
abstract: We didn’t review “Halloween” in 1978 because of a newspaper strike. Forty years later, our critic takes a new look at John Carpenter’s masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: When “Halloween” was released in October 1978, The New York Times didn’t review it. But it wasn’t out of snobbery. Printing press workers were on strike, and nothing was being published (not even the news of a new pope). Vincent Canby, the chief film critic then, did circle back to the movie the next year, but we’ve never given this horror classic a proper review. So, with a new “Halloween” due Friday, we asked Jason Zinoman to rectify a 40-year oversight.

headline: Review: ‘Mid90s’ Skates Back to a Less Innocent Time
abstract: This period-specific coming-of-age story was written and directed by Jonah Hill.
lead_paragraph: No matter how old you were, where you lived or how many T-shirts and mixtapes you owned, it’s unlikely that you remember the mid-1990s as well — as obsessively, as nostalgically, as literally — as “Mid90s” does. Written and directed by Jonah Hill, this film wants to be less a period piece than a time capsule, an immersion in the sights and sound of a pop-cultural moment.

headline: Fed Plans to Continue Raising Rates, Despite Trump’s Ire
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Federal Reserve released minutes of its last meeting that suggest it is on track to continue raising rates, perhaps to a level that would act as a mild brake on the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s official account of its latest policy meeting, published Wednesday, does not mention any discussion of President Trump’s demands that the Fed should stop raising interest rates.

headline: Why Many Native Americans Are Angry With Elizabeth Warren
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'Cherokee Indians', 'Genealogy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: The anger is about what it means to be Native American, and who gets to decide.
lead_paragraph: If Senator Elizabeth Warren thought that releasing her DNA test results showing Native American ancestry would neutralize a Republican line of attack, she was wrong.

headline: Push It: 5 Style Challenges
abstract: Shop a little more creatively this fall.
lead_paragraph: The shows are over, the trends declared: For spring 2019, we’re talking crochet, tie-dye, bike shorts galore. But beyond the obvious themes from the collections, there were plenty of smaller moments that served up sartorial inspiration, thanks to pieces that left us wondering, “Hey, how do we pull that off in real life?” Here, five such moments that nudge us to think past the big trends and shop a little more creatively.

headline: Fancy Optician Dom Vetro Is the Anti-Warby Parker
abstract: “My head is fat,” Alec Baldwin, a client, said of his loyalty. “I literally can’t find frames that are wide enough.”
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — On a recent morning, in a warehouse sandwiched by auto repair shops, Ashley Bezamat, the 37-year-old founder of the eyewear company Dom Vetro, was hunching over a thin bar of white acetate.

headline: Williamsburg Gets a Trinidadian Cocktail Bar With Indie Flavor
abstract: Clyde’s, which is partly owned by Major Lazer’s Christopher Leacock, spins modern mixes of reggae, calypso and soca.
lead_paragraph: Just when the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn seems to be overrun with corporate retailers — Whole Foods, Citibank and Apple, to name a few — comes a lively Trinidadian cocktail bar that harks back to the neighborhood’s alternative, indie spirit.

headline: Treasury Official Charged With Leaking Bank Reports to Journalist
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Prosecutors said Natalie Mayflower Sours Edwards had illegally shared department reports on suspicious banking activity.
lead_paragraph: The federal authorities arrested a Treasury Department official on Wednesday and charged her with illegally showing a journalist secret reports about suspicious wire transfers by President Trump’s former campaign chairman Paul Manafort and others.

headline: Indigenous Stories for Young Readers
abstract: Young adult and middle grade fiction to educate children in the vast terrain of Native American history.

headline: A Train Ride Back to the Old Israel
abstract: It takes four times as long as the new high-speed rail. I take it anyway.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Last month, the first section of a new high-speed rail line opened in Israel. When it’s fully operational a few months from now, passengers will board fire-engine-red carriages in Tel Aviv and be whisked on electrified track over the country’s longest bridge, then over its highest, and through the longest tunnel, and finally into a new station 260 feet under Jerusalem. The trip, about 35 miles, will take less than 30 minutes, making it, by a wide margin, the fastest way to get between the country’s two most important cities.

headline: A Tale of Three Presidents
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Nicolás Maduro and Donald Trump have an authoritarian bent, as did Hugo Chávez, but the Chávez I knew also believed in social justice, equality and fundamental freedoms.
lead_paragraph: Speaking to reporters at the United Nations last month, President Trump said he would be willing to meet with Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, if he were here. Despite Mr. Maduro’s constant diatribes against the American Empire, even a tenuous offer to meet with an autocrat-friendly American president was one Mr. Maduro couldn’t refuse.

headline: Elizabeth Warren and the Folly of Genetic Ancestry Tests
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: DNA can’t tell us about identity.
lead_paragraph: This week, Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts announced that geneticists had analyzed her DNA and proved her longstanding claim that she has Native American ancestry. Senator Warren had caved in to months of ridicule by President Trump, who mocked her using a racist term and ultimately refused to believe her “useless” DNA test.

headline: In Afghanistan’s Season of Crisis, ‘Words Do Not Have the Strength’
abstract: Seventeen years into the war, Afghans cannot remember a time quite like this, with peril and hopelessness at every turn, and no clear way out.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the past 17 years of war and crisis in Afghanistan, no one remembers a season quite like this one, with peril and hopelessness at every turn. People here struggle for words to explain how it feels.

headline: Vagabond Lives: Happier Memories From Kathryn Harrison’s Childhood
abstract: Her previous memoirs delved into her parents’ traumatic influence. Now, in “On Sunset,” she introduces the beloved Old World grandparents who raised her.
lead_paragraph: ON SUNSET A Memoir By Kathryn Harrison Illustrated. 266 pp. Doubleday. $27.

headline: Making ‘Making a Murderer,’ Again
abstract: The creators Moira Demos and Laura Ricciardi discussed what it was like returning to the series that launched their careers.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, few had heard of Steven Avery.

headline: ‘They Aren’t Coming Home’: Mourning 4 Daughters Lost in Limo Crash
abstract: Tom and Linda King’s four youngest daughters and three sons-in-law perished in the limousine crash that killed 20 people earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM, N.Y. — It was 6:28 p.m. when the phone rang that Saturday, shattering the nervous quiet that had cloaked Tom and Linda King’s home in upstate New York after word of a terrible crash hit Facebook.

headline: Netflix’s Cash-Fueled Road to Streaming Dominance
abstract: The streaming service surprised Wall Street with huge gains in subscribers in the third quarter. The results showed why AT&T and Disney spent big on their latest acquisitions.

headline: Do You Have What It Takes to Be an N.B.A. Agent?
abstract: To become a certified agent, you must pass a grueling three-hour test that evaluates your knowledge of the collective bargaining agreement and the regulations governing agents. With the help of the N.B.A. players union, we have put together a sample quiz.
lead_paragraph: To become a certified agent, you must pass a grueling three-hour test that evaluates your knowledge of the collective bargaining agreement and the regulations governing agents. With the help of the N.B.A. players union, we have put together a sample quiz.

headline: ‘Terrace House’ Has Never Been So Heartwarming and Humiliating
abstract: As the “Opening New Doors” season continues, we unpack our affection (mostly) for Japan’s greatest gift to American reality television.
lead_paragraph: American reality television has, in recent years, become so ubiquitous and hypertrophied as to be staid. All the moves are telegraphed, all the story lines exhausted. Which is why the Japanese reality show “Terrace House” — the first iteration of which dates back to 2012 — feels so refreshing. It moves at a leisurely pace. It asks little of its participants. It soothes rather than rankles.

headline: Why Southeast Asia and Australia’s Coral Reefs Became So Rich in Species
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Coral', 'Biodiversity', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: Biodiversity is a long game.
lead_paragraph: Dive into the coral reefs of Southeast Asia or Australia and you’ll likely spot a wrasse. But which of the hundreds of kinds of wrasses will you see?

headline: ‘The Conners’ Killed Roseanne. Here’s the Reaction So Far.
abstract: Months after ABC cancelled the “Roseanne” reboot, the Conners are back, this time without Roseanne Barr. What are people saying? We’ve rounded up the must-reads.
lead_paragraph: What’s the verdict on ABC’s “Roseanne” spinoff, “The Conners”?

headline: Skeptical of Saudis’ Story, Unlike Trump
abstract: Readers criticize the Trump administration’s acceptance of the Saudi regime’s denials of murdering Jamal Khashoggi and are dubious of any Saudi investigation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: These Are the Best and Worst (Actually New) Sitcoms This Fall
abstract: While everyone was talking about the revived “Murphy Brown” and “The Conners,” there were seven brand-new comedies this fall. We catch up with them.
lead_paragraph: Seven entirely new situation comedies were added to the schedules of the major broadcast television networks this fall, and The New York Times did not review any of them.

headline: We Asked for Epic Love in 100 Words. 3,000 Responded.
abstract: For the first Modern Love in miniature, we’re sharing your stories about life-changing burritos, unconventional arrangements, and other romantic gains and losses.
lead_paragraph: From Austin, we headed west. For two weeks, my best friend and I were on a journey of self-exploration, an adventure through the vast American landscape that would find us in a multicolored haze, and an event that would bond us for life. All of this came about because of one thing: a burrito so good we had to drive to California to get it. If it weren’t for that burrito we wouldn’t have found ourselves in a purple sunset, sitting on the edge of the Grand Canyon with a question that would change our lives forever. She said yes. — Jared Owenby

headline: U.N. Syria Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, Announces Resignation
abstract: Mr. de Mistura, the United Nations chief negotiator for Syria, will be the third diplomat to leave the job since Syria’s grinding civil war began 7 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ chief mediator for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, said Wednesday that he would step down at the end of November, becoming the third diplomat to leave the job since Syria’s civil war began in 2011.

headline: Bruce Springsteen Shared His Memories of the Stone Pony. Now It’s Your Turn.
abstract: The Times wants to hear from readers who have visited the music venue. What made the Stone Pony such a thrill?
lead_paragraph: The Stone Pony, the celebrated rock club in Asbury Park, N.J., is a beacon for music lovers, a place to see local bands and legends alike. And if you’re lucky, Bruce Springsteen might hop onstage for an impromptu performance.

headline: ‘I Could Have Killed You,’ Ohio Officer Warns Two Boys With BB Gun
abstract: The Columbus police released body-camera video of the encounter as a “life lesson” for young people, setting off a discussion about policing, race and gun control.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio police officer, his weapon drawn, approached two boys in a Columbus neighborhood over the weekend and told them to kneel before picking up what turned out to be a BB gun lying on the sidewalk.

headline: Liz Gerring: Of Fields and Freedom
abstract: Ms. Gerring’s new dance, “Field,” has an earthiness to its movement. “As much as we’re soaring and jumping,” the dancer Brandon Collwes said, “I always feel that I’m coming back to the ground.”
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a weekly visual exploration of dance on Instagram. Watch the video from our most recent post below, and follow us at @nytimes.

headline: Trump Embarks on Bilateral Trade Talks to Pressure China
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Customs (Tariff)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh off securing trade agreements with South Korea, Canada and Mexico, President Trump is embarking on a new plan: refashioning the Trans-Pacific Partnership to his liking through a flurry of bilateral trade deals.

headline: John C. Reilly Reads ‘As a Father, I Was Hardly a Perfect Fit’
abstract: On this week’s podcast, “The Sisters Brothers” star tells the story of a divorced dad’s desperate quest for a Yankees cap.
lead_paragraph: For six months, a divorced dad asked his 10-year-old son one simple question: “How big is your head?” On this week’s Modern Love podcast, John C. Reilly reads “As a Father, I Was Hardly a Perfect Fit,” an essay about parental guilt and the desperate search for a Yankees cap.

headline: Liberal Upper West Siders Get Their Revenge: Trump Place Sign Comes Down
keywords: ['Buildings (Structures)', 'Names, Organizational', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Condominiums', 'United States Politics and Government', 'your-feed-onlyinnewyork']
abstract: Tenants at 200 Riverside Boulevard voted to remove the Trump brand from their building’s signage. A judge sided with their decision.
lead_paragraph: Few places in the United States are more staunchly liberal than the Upper West Side of Manhattan. And so few things are more galling to many residents of a residential complex there than the big letters that greet them at their building: T-R-U-M-P P-L-A-C-E.

abstract: Coke is still producing the diet cola, but a major bottler has stopped distribution in its 14-state territory.

headline: Congratulations, You’re a Certified N.B.A. Agent. Good Luck Finding a Client.
abstract: Salaries have never been higher and the glamour of the N.B.A. is at a fever pitch, which means representing players is brutally competitive.
lead_paragraph: At 10:02 a.m. on a sunny day last winter in the gym at the National Basketball Players Association’s Midtown Manhattan headquarters, dozens of nervous prospective N.B.A. agents sat at folding tables, hunched over the first test many had taken in years.

headline: Ebola Outbreak in Congo Not a Global Emergency, W.H.O. Says
abstract: Health officials expressed serious concern about the disease, which has a high risk of spreading to neighbors, but were optimistic it would be controlled.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — World health officials on Wednesday expressed deep concern over the spread of the Ebola virus in the Democratic Republic of Congo, but concluded that it did not yet qualify as an international health emergency.

headline: Exposed by Michael: Climate Threat to Warplanes at Coastal Bases
keywords: ['Hurricane Michael (2018)', 'F-22 Airplane', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Coastal Areas', 'Global Warming', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The devastation of Tyndall Air Force Base, where 17 grounded F-22 stealth fighters were damaged in the storm, points to American air power’s vulnerability in major hurricanes.
lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Michael wrecked much of Tyndall Air Force Base near Panama City, Fla., last week, the storm exposed a significant military vulnerability. The base’s F-22 stealth fighter jets may be unmatched in the skies, but they were all but defenseless on the ground, as the powerful storm ripped apart hangars, flooded buildings and scattered debris.

headline: The Skywhale Returns to Australia’s Skies, and Its Creator Braces for Impact
abstract: The buxom hot-air balloon was widely condemned when it first appeared five years ago. The artist who created it is hoping for a warmer reception this time.

headline: David Fizdale’s Candor Sets Tone for Knicks in Opener
abstract: They won’t all come as easy as the Knicks’ 126-107 win on opening night, but their new coach could be the breath of fresh air they need to endure it.
lead_paragraph: Standing in a scrum of reporters eagerly holding up recording devices to capture the words of David Fizdale, it was striking how something interestingly unfamiliar was occurring. An honest-to-goodness news conference had broken out with Fizdale, the newest member of the ever-expanding Knicks coaching fraternity.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is eagerly embracing a trade war with China, but on Wednesday, it opted once again not to label that nation a currency manipulator despite President Trump’s repeated complaint that Beijing is weakening the renminbi.

abstract: With less than three weeks before Election Day, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has still not agreed to debate his Republican challenger, Marcus J. Molinaro.
lead_paragraph: He leads in every poll by double-digit margins. He is a two-term Democrat seeking re-election in a divisive midterm year, in a state filled with blue-wave voters. And his Republican opponent is running out of money.

abstract: A two-term Democrat from Kentucky, he was narrowly defeated by Mr. McConnell, then a county judge and executive, in a Republican campaign engineered by Roger Ailes.
lead_paragraph: Walter D. Huddleston, a two-term Democratic senator from Kentucky whose hairsbreadth loss in a rancorous re-election campaign put Mitch McConnell on the road to becoming a Republican power in the Senate, died on Tuesday in Warsaw, Ky. He was 92.

headline: Omega-3s in Fish Oils Tied to Healthy Aging
abstract: Older adults with the highest blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids were more likely to be living without chronic diseases or mental or physical deterioration.
lead_paragraph: Higher blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids, the fats found in fish, are linked to a healthier old age, according to a new study.

headline: High Blood Pressure of Pregnancy Tied to Dementia Later in Life
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Women and Girls', 'Preeclampsia', 'Dementia', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Blood Pressure', 'Hypertension']
abstract: Up to 5 percent of pregnant women develop pre-eclampsia, which is tied to an increased risk of dementia in later years.
lead_paragraph: Having pre-eclampsia — dangerously high blood pressure during pregnancy — is linked to an increased risk for dementia later in life, according to a new study.

headline: A Devastated Tyndall Air Force Base

headline: ‘Halloween’ Review: Jamie Lee Curtis, Look Out!
abstract: David Gordon Green’s sequel to the horror classic brings Michael Myers back for blood.
lead_paragraph: It’s been four decades since Michael Myers and his fright mask first gave us the willies in John Carpenter’s “Halloween,” which makes him 61 — and, if David Gordon Green’s same-name sequel is to be believed, still in possession of a ramrod spine, pile-driver fists and non-arthritic knees. The meals at Smith’s Grove Sanitarium, where he’s been cooling his heels all these years, must be unusually nutritious.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Master Class in Distraction
abstract: Democrats need to be focused on the midterms.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has been on a bit of a media tear the past few weeks, holding forth on both the personal and the political — and making clear that someone needs to perform an intervention before she further complicates life for her fellow Democrats.

headline: Documenting the Rise of White Nationalism
keywords: ['Photography', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Charlottesville, Va, Violence (August, 2017)']
abstract: Mark Peterson was awarded the W. Eugene Smith Grant for his work chronicling the rise of white nationalism in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Mark Peterson has received this year’s W. Eugene Smith Grant for Humanistic Photography for his long-term work on the rise of white nationalism and how the American confederacy manifests itself today. He will receive $35,000 to complete his work, “The Past Is Never Dead.”

headline: The Enduring Appeal of Oscar the Grouch
abstract: Big Bird’s nice, but Oscar, who loves trash and shuns his neighbors, is a lovable curmudgeon.
lead_paragraph: Everyone loves kind, sweet Big Bird, but Caroll Spinney’s other character — the famously grumpy, trash can-dwelling Oscar the Grouch — has an ardent fan club, too.

headline: Senate Truce Collapses as G.O.P. Rush to Confirm More Judges Begins Anew
abstract: Last week, senators agreed to confirm one last slate of President Trump’s nominees, then recess for the midterm campaign. But on Wednesday, Republicans recommenced the judicial rush.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats struck a deal last week with Republicans that saw the quick confirmation of 15 more conservative judges in exchange for a rapid flight to the campaign trail. Liberal activists were infuriated, but after the brutally divisive fight to confirm Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, the agreement held out a promise of peace.

headline: A President Kowtowing to a Mad Prince
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Trump is providing cover for Saudi barbarism.
lead_paragraph: American presidents have periodically engaged in cover-ups of their own corruption or licentiousness, but President Trump is breaking new ground. He is using the United States government to cover up a foreign despot’s barbarism.

headline: As Other Republican Candidates Struggle Financially, Trump Stockpiles Cash
abstract: The president has raised $106 million for his re-election, leading some Republicans to grumble that he is siphoning money from endangered congressional candidates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump’s first campaign finance report in July 2015 revealed a shoestring operation run by a handful of loyalists working from a two-room suite in Trump Tower and funded almost entirely by $1.8 million in loans from the candidate.

headline: Uncomplicated Technology, and Why It’s Always Worth Your Money
abstract: If you believe the marketing, you’d think every new gadget will change your life — but many are confusing to use or doomed to obsolescence. Here’s how to determine whether your purchase will stand the test of time.
lead_paragraph: My daughter Liz loves gadgets. She even recently reviewed one: the WobbleWorks 3Doodler Create+, a device that’s part pen, part 3-D printer. (Here she is giving a demo of it.) What struck me most is because it’s designed as a toy, it slips past our notice as a “gadget.” Yet it most certainly is, letting you create objects in the same manner (and using many of the same materials) as a regular, complicated 3-D printer.

headline: McGahn, Soldier for Trump and Witness Against Him, Leaves White House
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: As White House counsel, Mr. McGahn spearheaded President Trump’s most significant political accomplishments but also became a witness against him in the special counsel inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald F. McGahn II departed as White House counsel on Wednesday, ending a tumultuous 21-month tenure during which he spearheaded some of President Trump’s most significant political accomplishments, including two appointments to the Supreme Court, but also became a chief witness against him in the special counsel investigation.

headline: Theresa May Plays for Time on Brexit, Amid Talk of an Extension
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: At a summit Mrs. May asked for help in reviving stalled exit talks, but offered little new. Negotiations now look likely to go down to the wire.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — British Prime Minister Theresa May tried Wednesday to salvage talks on her country’s withdrawal from the European Union, appealing for time to avert a messy and economically damaging departure without an agreement and hinting that it might take longer than expected to fully pull away from the bloc.

headline: Elitist or Egalitarian: Competing Views of Harvard Emerge in Bias Trial
abstract: Starkly different portrayals of the university emerged in testimony on the third day of a lawsuit examining whether Harvard discriminates.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Two starkly different pictures of Harvard — an elitist country club or an egalitarian engine for social change — emerged on Wednesday in a federal trial examining whether the university discriminates against Asian-Americans.

headline: 50 Years After Tet Offensive, a Marine Receives the Medal of Honor
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Medal of Honor (US)', 'Vietnam War']
abstract: Sgt. Maj. John L. Canley, now 80, repeatedly charged into enemy fire and carried wounded Americans to safety during one of the bloodiest battles of the Vietnam War.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump awarded the Medal of Honor on Wednesday to a Marine who saved the lives of numerous fellow soldiers during one of the bloodiest battles of the Vietnam War, when he repeatedly charged into enemy fire and carried wounded Americans to safety during fighting that went on for a week.

headline: Powerful Executives Have Stepped Away From the Saudis. Not SoftBank’s.
abstract: The chief executive of SoftBank, Masayoshi Son, and his ambitious Vision Fund, are deeply enmeshed with the oil-rich kingdom, which has promised to invest $45 billion.
lead_paragraph: Since the disappearance and apparent killing of a dissident journalist in a Saudi Arabian consulate, some of the most powerful figures in business are distancing themselves from the kingdom. There is one prominent exception: Masayoshi Son, chief executive of the SoftBank Group.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Gleefully or Warily, Canadians Usher In Era of Legalized Marijuana
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 18, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “Canada is once again a progressive global leader. We have gay rights, feminism, abortion rights, and now we can smoke pot without worrying police are going to arrest us.”

headline: In the Majors, the Postseason Is Paranoia Season
abstract: Why did the Astros send an employee to surveil the Red Sox’s dugout? Because it’s October, and with high stakes come high suspicions.
lead_paragraph: Alex Cora was still a teenager when his brother, Joey, played with Randy Johnson in Seattle in 1995. Even then, Alex could tell what pitch Johnson would throw before he threw it. If Johnson’s glove was narrow when he gripped the ball inside it, he was about to throw a fastball. If the glove was spread wider, a slider was coming.

headline: The Horseface Chronicles
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'ADULTERY', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Try to think of something worse than Trump’s “unexpressed thoughts.”
lead_paragraph: So, Donald Trump called Stormy Daniels “Horseface.” Truly, I thought that after the first two or three or 12 incidents of comparing women to animals, he’d have figured out it was a bad plan.

headline: Review: Glenn Close Raises a Saint in ‘Mother of the Maid’
abstract: In Jane Anderson’s satisfyingly old-fashioned play about Joan of Arc’s mom, Ms. Close shows the stuff of which great stage stars are made.
lead_paragraph: Gliding into her 70s, Glenn Close is in her prime. Her performance in Jane Anderson’s four-handkerchief “Mother of the Maid,” at the Public Theater, is a triumphant blend of sharp sense and passionate sensibility, of an old pro’s expertise and a newcomer’s enthusiasm.

headline: Clayton Kershaw Carries the Dodgers to the Brink of a World Series Berth
abstract: Kershaw battled through seven innings, allowing one run and escaping a bases-loaded jam, to give the Dodgers the advantage in the N.L.C.S.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was early Wednesday afternoon, just the third inning, but the capacity crowd at Dodger Stadium had sensed the moment — perhaps because it looked so familiar: Clayton Kershaw on the mound in a ritual case of October peril.

headline: Said Something in Response
abstract: Erik Agard gives us something to sing about.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — If you don’t know Erik Agard except for his crossword bylines, let’s start by saying that he’s kind of a big deal in the puzzle community right now.

keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Torture', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The Washington Post received the prominent Saudi dissident journalist’s latest piece from his translator the day after he was reported missing in Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: The dissident Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi disappeared after he walked into the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul just over two weeks ago, and evidence increasingly suggests he was brutally murdered.

headline: The Season of Peak Sneaker Silliness
abstract: Sneakers increasingly seem like the Dutch tulips of today. Which means the bubble may be about to burst.
lead_paragraph: Way back in the wild days of fashion yore, in January, 2014, Karl Lagerfeld held a couture show set in a fictional Cambon Club (like the Cotton Club, but not), complete with a full orchestra and grand, sweeping staircase, down which his models tripped in gossamer, bejeweled creations, each one complete with its very own bespoke sneakers.

headline: New York to Settle Inquiry of Rent-to-Own Trailer Park Firms
keywords: ['Mobile Homes and Trailers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: The agreement, which the attorney general’s office could announce Thursday, would give people who signed leases the right to recoup their deposits.
lead_paragraph: Regulators have been cracking down on abusive rent-to-own deals in which people shell out thousands of dollars for run-down homes that they never actually get to buy.

headline: The Graduates
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Fashion Shows', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The designers of Vaquera have press, buzz and talent. Can they quit their day jobs now?
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday afternoon in September at Public School 42 on Hester Street, there were drinks spilled on the floor of the cafeteria and wadded-up notebook paper littered here and there. Tiny chairs for tiny students were arranged in loose lines, barely at knee height, but P.S. 42’s students weren’t coming.

lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: I Didn’t Hate the English — Until Now
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: In which an Irish woman discovers how little the people who shaped her country’s fate know or care.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last month, some video footage went viral in Ireland of a group of English men verbally abusing young women at a Dublin housing crisis protest. The men, it turned out, were part of a bachelor party who had come from Bristol and seemed to be dressed intentionally to look like a cartoon of landed gentry, in tweeds and the loudly colored trousers widely beloved by braying men of a certain kind.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Puffs’ and ‘Star Trek Into Darkness’
abstract: An Off Broadway riff on Harry Potter streams on BroadwayHD. And “Star Trek Into Darkness” airs on FXM.
lead_paragraph: An Off Broadway riff on Harry Potter streams on BroadwayHD. And “Star Trek Into Darkness” airs on FXM.

headline: LeBron James Once ‘Hated’ Southern California. How He Came to Embrace It.
abstract: His first trip to Los Angeles was for a basketball tournament as a teenager. Friends say it planted a seed that reached full bloom when he joined the Los Angeles Lakers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The sun had already set when LeBron James and his high school teammates pulled up to the beach in a limousine-length Cadillac Escalade. They had come straight from the airport, with 50 Cent blaring from the speakers.

abstract: How did Spinney come to be on the show? How did he help shape the characters he played and the organization?

headline: Steve Penny, Former U.S.A. Gymnastics Chief, Arrested on Evidence Tampering Charge
abstract: Penny is accused of interfering in an investigation of Lawrence G. Nassar, the national gymnastics team doctor who is serving 40 to 175 years in prison for sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: Steve Penny, the former president and chief executive of U.S.A. Gymnastics, was arrested Wednesday on a felony charge of evidence tampering in a Texas investigation into sexual abuse by Lawrence G. Nassar, the imprisoned former doctor for the national gymnastics team.

headline: Red Sox Emerge From a Chaotic Day With Commanding Lead in A.L.C.S.
abstract: Wednesday started with talk of sign-stealing and news of Chris Sale’s illness, and it ended with a spectacular catch that sealed Boston’s win over Houston.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — On a day riddled with controversies and accusations over spying and illicit cameras, one notable illness and loads of offense, it was somehow fitting that four and a half hours of thrilling baseball would come down to one final, nerve-racking defensive play.

headline: Chalk Outline
abstract: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to and comment on current events and our society? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Can Hasan Minhaj Make Topical Comedy Work on Netflix?
abstract: With “Patriot Act,” the former “Daily Show” correspondent plans to cover news most late-night hosts ignore, and looks to defy Netflix’s spotty talk show track record.
lead_paragraph: Standing on the set of his new Netflix series, “Patriot Act,” one evening earlier this month, Hasan Minhaj asked his studio audience if they had any questions about what they were about to see. He knew that his stage, an immense digital screen encircling the diamond-shape platform he was standing on, was a bit of a technological monstrosity — “it’s like if Michael Bay directed a PowerPoint presentation,” he joked to the crowd — and so some clarification might be required.

headline: Pull Up a Seat. Two Plays, Dinner and Western History Are Served.
abstract: A downtown theater has cleared the house to make room for Samuel D. Hunter’s pairing “Lewiston/Clarkston.”
lead_paragraph: For the first time in more than a dozen plays, Samuel D. Hunter has left Idaho altogether.

headline: Stephen Colbert Pillories Trump for Rejecting Climate Change Science
abstract: President Trump told The Associated Press on Tuesday that the science regarding climate change is still unsettled.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: Flat Out: Rejecting Breast Reconstruction
abstract: After a double mastectomy, Catherine Guthrie wanted to retain her strength and challenge the idea of feminine norms.
lead_paragraph: In the recently published memoir “Flat: Reclaiming My Body From Breast Cancer,” Catherine Guthrie tells the story of grievous medical mistakes that she managed to record without sugarcoating their consequences or flailing against the injustice of it all. A women’s health reporter, Ms. Guthrie approached the cancer experience guided and guarded by her previous investigations. She nevertheless found herself stunned by the retrograde assumptions and defective practices of the physicians she consulted.

headline: Lisa Borders Is Ready for the Next Phase of Gender Parity
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', '#MeToo Movement']
abstract: The head of Time’s Up — an organization behind #metoo awareness campaigns — on celebrity activism and bringing women to the table.
lead_paragraph: You’re the first C.E.O. of Time’s Up, a self-described political movement toward eradicating sexual harassment in the workplace. Why does a political movement need a C.E.O.? Why make it sound like a company? Just because the term “C.E.O.” has been used for companies doesn’t mean it’s not a fungible term that can’t be used in other arenas. It doesn’t bother me at all.

headline: How to Rewire Your Traumatized Brain
abstract: “Rationalization was much easier than recognizing the gravity of what was lost: an innocent, healthy childhood and an introduction to sexuality on my terms.”
lead_paragraph: I hear some people have trouble with therapy, that it can take years for them to open up to their doctors, let alone cry or break down. Not me. Day one, I told my therapist, Amy Bernstein, “I’ll just tell you everything, and we’ll go from there.”

headline: How I Quit the Bottle (the Hair Dye Bottle)
abstract: Would going gray require me to listen to folk music, host potlucks and wear caftans? Or could it be another way of being a woman in the world?
lead_paragraph: As I sat in the colorist’s chair in a high-end salon, I could not help but admire how young I looked. My gray roots had just been obliterated with a $300 Chernobyl of Deep Chocolate Mocha and Buttery Caramel lowlights.

headline: Should Marijuana Be Legal?
abstract: Canada just legalized marijuana. Should the United States follow suit? Or do you think Canada is making a mistake?
lead_paragraph: Canada just legalized marijuana. Should the United States follow suit? Or do you think Canada is making a mistake?

headline: 36 Hours in Chicago
abstract: Culture, comedy and culinary outings in the ever-evolving Loop district and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Chicago’s 77 neighborhoods — including Lincoln Park, home to the new Wrightwood 659 gallery — offer myriad reasons to stray from the beaten path. But lately the Loop, as the downtown district is called for the elevated train tracks that encircle it, is fighting for your attention with a new architecture center, writers’ museum, river walk, design-centric hotels, destination restaurants and Art on the Mart, a digital art installation broadcast across a 2.5-acre building facade on the river. All of the city’s train lines fan out from downtown, making it a great base from which to explore beyond, particularly for those in search of vibrant storefront theaters, design shops and breweries. Late fall and winter are bargain times to appreciate them, when rates for everything from airfare to hotel rooms drop. But the best reasons to visit Chicago now largely defy climate.

headline: The Culture Wars of Car Racing
abstract: Grimy, daring and deadly, dirt-track racing has become a magnet for fans — and a threat to the Nascar status quo.
lead_paragraph: The air was heavy with exhaust and motor oil at Charlotte Motor Speedway in North Carolina as I waited for Tony Stewart to arrive. Charlotte was hosting the 2017 championship weekend for the World of Outlaws, the premier dirt-racing series in the country, and all 60,000 tickets had sold out well in advance. Stewart, the ex-Nascar star, was late — running on “Tony time,” a handler told me — so I went for a walk along the dusty pit road to look at the scores of racecars lined up. “You’ll probably have to run at some point,” I was warned. “And remember: The cars can’t turn right.” Their larger right-side tires help them around a loop that only bends left and, indeed, make it nearly impossible to turn right.

headline: Tina Turner: By the Book
abstract: The singer, whose memoir “My Love Story” has just been published, wishes Mick Jagger would write an autobiography: “He can outtalk anyone on the planet. That’s the book I want to read, and so will everybody else. Mick?”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your nightstand?

headline: Bigger Seats, Better Service? Nope. But Airlines Are Offering Cool Pretzels.
abstract: To up their hip quotient, companies are offering snacks from small, local producers as an inexpensive way of breeding loyalty with passengers.
lead_paragraph: Pretzel Perfection was a little-known company producing 100,000 bags of gluten-free pretzels a month when it made its debut on Delta flights in 2017. Now, the brand, which Amy Holyk, then a stay-at-home mother, started out of her garage in Vancouver, Wa., turns out more than 8 million bags of pretzels and snack mixes a month and had $16 million in revenues last year.

headline: Stone Mountain: The Largest Confederate Monument Problem in the World
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)']
abstract: Stone Mountain has been called “a blight” upon the state of Georgia. But to others it is a key part of Southern heritage.
lead_paragraph: STONE MOUNTAIN, Ga. — The Rev. Ferrell Brown, a white pastor at a suburban Atlanta megachurch, stood on the big bald top of Stone Mountain on a warm Saturday morning, sharing a stage with two relatives of those murdered at a black church in Charleston, S.C., three years ago.

headline: Were the Founders Against Slavery All Along?
abstract: Sean Wilentz’s “No Property in Man” argues that despite some expedient compromises, the Constitution’s writers were careful to plant the seeds of abolition.
lead_paragraph: NO PROPERTY IN MAN Slavery and Antislavery at the Nation’s Founding By Sean Wilentz 350 pp. Harvard University Press. $26.95.

headline: Trump’s Focus on a Washington Building Project Draws Scrutiny
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: President Trump has taken an interest in the F.B.I. headquarters, which had been set for redevelopment. Democrats wonder if he is trying to protect his hotel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly two years before he would begin his presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump arrived in Washington to show off his plans for a luxury hotel on Pennsylvania Avenue under a deal he had reached to lease the site from the General Services Administration.

headline: Aloft in Downtown Brooklyn
abstract: For a buyer looking to upgrade a tiny Greenwich Village one-bedroom, crossing the East River beat heading uptown.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, after living in a few rentals in the East Village and SoHo, Kris Chen bought a starter one-bedroom in Greenwich Village. His little co-op unit, in a 1955 building, had originally been an alcove studio.

headline: Computer Stories: A.I. Is Beginning to Assist Novelists
abstract: Robin Sloan is using a homemade software program to supply phrases and images for his new book.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Robin Sloan has a collaborator on his new novel: a computer.

headline: Who’s Winning the Social Media Midterms?
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Democrats appear to be winning on social media, except in some key races.

headline: Andrew Gillum, a Florida Insider Running as a Progressive Outsider
abstract: Mr. Gillum, the Democratic nominee for governor, supports higher corporate taxes and Medicare for all. He also has a lobbyist as a top adviser and, as mayor of Tallahassee, was on the payroll of a consultant.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — City Hall never did seem big enough for Andrew Gillum.

headline: Watch Out Workers, Algorithms Are Coming to Replace You — Maybe
abstract: The Israeli author Yuval Noah Harari says no industry is truly immune to the effects of A.I.
lead_paragraph: Over the past five years, the Israeli author and historian Yuval Noah Harari has quietly emerged as a bona fide pop-intellectual. His 2014 book “Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind” is a sprawling account of human history from the Stone Age to the 21st century; Ridley Scott, who directed “Alien,” is co-leading its screen adaptation. Mr. Harari’s latest book, “21 Lessons for the 21st Century,” is an equally ambitious look at key issues shaping contemporary global conversations — from immigration to nationalism, climate change to artificial intelligence. Mr. Harari recently spoke about the benefits and dangers of A.I. and its potential to upend the ways we live, learn and work. The conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: Who Has the Best Shots in Women’s Tennis?
abstract: A poll of 20 coaches, players, former players and analysts narrow down the field. Ashleigh Barty’s name keeps coming up.
lead_paragraph: Much has changed in four years in women’s tennis. In August 2014, when The New York Times last tried to determine the best strokes in the game, Li Na, Maria Sharapova, Petra Kvitova and Serena Williams were all reigning Grand Slam champions.

headline: A Black Motorists’ Guide to Jim Crow America, Newly Relevant
abstract: The “Green Book,” a travel manual published between 1936 and 1967 — and now the premise of a film by the same name — feels as necessary as ever.
lead_paragraph: Next month, the actor Viggo Mortensen, one of the six cover subjects of T’s 2018 Greats issue, will star alongside Mahershala Ali in “Green Book,” a movie based on the true story of the jazz pianist Don Shirley’s road trip through the American South in 1962. Here, the author Kaitlyn Greenidge discusses “The Negro Motorist Green Book,” which served as a guide for black travelers across North America and inspired the film.

headline: Is Trump Destroying the World Order?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']

headline: The World of A.I.
abstract: From Singapore to Israel, countries besides the United States and China are striving to play a role in the field of artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Judging by the breathless coverage, it can seem as if the only countries developing A.I. are the United States and China. But while companies in those two countries are leading the way in cutting-edge research and products, it’s still early for the industry and other nations are working hard to become major A.I. players. Here are six that could challenge the two juggernauts.

headline: An A.I. Glossary
abstract: Artificial intelligence has its own insider jargon. Here are some crucial concepts and terms, defined and digested for the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: The term “artificial intelligence” may sound new and futuristic, but it was actually coined back in 1956 for a tech conference at Dartmouth College. Since then, the A.I. field has progressed in fits and starts as new hardware, software and ideas slowly propelled it forward.

headline: Afghan Leader Blindsided by U.S. Meeting With Taliban, Officials Say
abstract: An American envoy who met the Taliban reportedly tried to evade the topic during a meeting with an already concerned Afghan president, several officials say.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the White House ordered American diplomats this summer to engage the Taliban directly in the hopes of jump-starting an Afghan peace process, many in Afghanistan welcomed it as a vital first step in trying to break the stalemate that dominates the 17-year war here.

headline: Khashoggi’s Killing Isn’t a Blunder. It’s a Crime.
abstract: A wink and a nod from Washington is the worst possible response to Riyadh’s butchery.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s apparent torture, murder and dismemberment of Jamal Khashoggi has been met in some quarters with more lamentation than outrage. Here — so the argument goes — was the most reformist government in the kingdom’s history; and then it did this stupid, awful thing; and now the U.S. runs the risk of making matters worse “in a fit of righteousness,” as one observer recently put it.

headline: Canada’s New Marijuana Economy: Meet the Winners and Losers
abstract: After 95 years of prohibition, Canada has legalized marijuana. We met with buyers, sellers, growers and students to hear what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: After 95 years of prohibition, Canada has legalized marijuana. We met with buyers, sellers, growers and students to hear what they had to say.

headline: New York Today: Staying Safe in Car Services
abstract: Thursday: What to do if you feel you’re in danger, and Tennis for Two.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:28 a.m.

headline: The Blind Man’s French Dog Problem
abstract: It’s not really about the dog. Or being French. Or blind.
lead_paragraph: Last summer my wife, Juju, was invited to attend a conference in Paris, and she asked me to come along. I’d always wanted to visit Paris, so of course I said yes. But before I could book my ticket, I needed to do some research. I’m blind, and I use a Seeing Eye dog — a German shepherd named Nadia — to help me get around.

headline: The Democrats’ Left Turn Is Not an Illusion
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Whites', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Like many overnight sensations, it has been years in the making.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 18 years, the Democratic electorate has moved steadily to the left, as liberals have displaced moderates. Self-identified liberals of all races and ethnicities now command a majority in the party, raising the possibility that views once confined mainly to the party elite have spread into the rank and file.

headline: Japan’s Cherry Blossoms (Some of Them) Appear Months Early
abstract: An unusually strong typhoon season may have caused the famously picturesque flowers to bloom long before April, when they typically emerge.
lead_paragraph: An unusually strong typhoon season may have caused some of Japan’s famous cherry blossom trees to bloom several months early.

headline: Letting Louis C.K. Back Onstage
abstract: Who gets second chances in the #MeToo era, and who gets to decide?
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: DealBook Briefing: SoftBank’s Big Saudi Problem
abstract: The Japanese company became the most powerful tech investor with $45 billion from Saudi Arabia. Now that money is causing it some headaches.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday. Want this by email? Sign up here.

headline: Review: In ‘What They Had,’ a Family Bickers While a Mother Drifts Away
abstract: A stellar cast barely rescues Elizabeth Chomko’s predictable first feature about a family matriarch’s slow slide into dementia.
lead_paragraph: Programmatic and groaningly trite, “What They Had,” the debut feature from Elizabeth Chomko, would be impossible to swallow without its star-studded cast. Even so, it requires all their considerable skills to stop this soapy family drama from sliding into complete banality.

headline: Review: In ‘Wildlife,’ Passions Run Rampant
abstract: The film, directed by Paul Dano and starring Carey Mulligan and Jake Gyllenhaal, is a domestic drama both sad and terrifying.
lead_paragraph: In the very first scenes of “Wildlife,” the smoke coming off the tops of the mountains north of Great Falls, Mont., is easy to take for fog, or for cloud cover. After all, the sky above that smoke is so blue, and the town below seems so tidy. The impression doesn’t last long.

headline: Review: ‘The Guilty’ Places a Troubled Police Officer on Hold
abstract: Gustav Moller’s ingeniously lean thriller builds tension from little more than one police officer, two rooms and a frantic telephone call from a kidnapped woman.
lead_paragraph: Like the best podcasts and radio plays, the stripped-down Danish thriller “The Guilty” paints such vivid pictures with words that, afterward, we’re not exactly sure what we saw and what was merely imagined.

headline: Review: ‘On Her Shoulders’ Follows Nobel Peace Prize Winner Nadia Murad
abstract: The documentary spotlights the hope and weariness of Murad, who was held captive by the Islamic State in Northern Iraq.
lead_paragraph: The opening scene echoes throughout “On Her Shoulders.” In it, Nadia Murad is nearly besieged by a mob of admirers, scores of whom have their cellphone cameras held high to capture her image. Again and again they take her photo. Again and again she presses on to speak for her cause.

headline: Review: In ‘Caniba,’ a Killer Tries to Make His Case
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Cannibalism']
abstract: Issei Sagawa, who killed and cannibalized a woman in 1981, is the subject of a new documentary by Véréna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor.
lead_paragraph: The Roman playwright Terence wrote, “I am human; nothing human is alien to me.” Filmgoers interested in putting this idea to the test will find powerful material in “Caniba,” a new documentary directed by Véréna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor.

headline: Review: Bright Young Men Stoop to Scam in ‘Nigerian Prince’
abstract: This engaging debut feature film by Faraday Okoro asks if there is an honest way for young people to thrive in a country like today’s Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: It’s not enough anymore to be mere Nigerian royalty, so Pius (Chinaza Uche), the central con man in “Nigerian Prince,” doesn’t confine himself to phishing. He’s always on the lookout for new ways to cheat poverty. Pius sees both a potential mark and something of himself in his teenage cousin Eze (Antonio J. Bell), who arrives unexpectedly — and unhappily — from America.

headline: Review: In ‘The Waldheim Waltz,’ a Nation Reckons With Its Nazi Past
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The Austrian documentarian Ruth Beckermann focuses on Kurt Waldheim, and she is clear on where she stands: She participated in protests against Waldheim.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to make a nation reconsider its self-image? That’s the question lying at the heart of the Austrian documentarian Ruth Beckermann’s informative and unnerving “The Waldheim Waltz.” Using mostly contemporaneous material — TV reports and news conferences, as well as documentary video footage she shot herself — the filmmaker follows the controversial 1986 presidential campaign of the Austrian politician Kurt Waldheim, whose candidacy was plunged into chaos by new revelations regarding his Nazi past.

headline: Review: In ‘Galveston,’ on the Run With Nowhere to Go
abstract: Ben Foster and Elle Fanning star in this on-the-lam scenario that goes past film noir and lands at film murk.
lead_paragraph: With shadowy imagery that pushes the boundaries of visibility and a mumbly lead performance from Ben Foster that strains the limits of intelligibility, “Galveston” goes past film noir and lands at film murk.

headline: Banksy’s Shredding Prank Misfired, He Says: ‘In Rehearsals It Worked Every Time’
abstract: The mechanism that cut apart the $1.4 million “Girl With Balloon” jammed, the artist revealed in a video. The work was meant to be completely destroyed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the $1.4 million artwork began passing through a shredder hidden in its frame, gasps were heard in the auction room. About halfway through, the shredding suddenly stopped, and the top portion of “Girl With Balloon” seemed to have been saved.

headline: Jim Mattis, Meeting His Chinese Counterpart, Tries to Ease Tensions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

headline: Titian and Gerhard Richter: Keeping Faith With Painting, 5 Centuries Apart
abstract: An idiosyncratic exhibition in northern Italy pairs the leading artist of Renaissance Venice with contemporary Germany’s master of the blur.
lead_paragraph: MANTUA, Italy — In 1972, Gerhard Richter represented West Germany at the Venice Biennale and presented one of his most renowned series of paintings: “48 Portraits,” which depict famous and forgotten white men in blurry, pallid black and white. While in Venice that summer, he went to the Scuola Grande di San Rocco, where he came upon a painting by Titian from around 1539. It was a small, foamy scene of the Annunciation, hiding in plain sight amid the Scuola’s dozens of more dramatic works by Tintoretto. Titian paints Mary crouched to the right of the composition, her eyes cast down and her hand clasped over her breast. The archangel wafts in from the left on a cloud of smoke, wearing a tunic of lustrous magenta, spreading his wings of steely gray as he delivers the big news.

headline: New York’s Worst Bedbug Neighborhoods
abstract: A decline in bedbug violations in recent years doesn’t mean that there are fewer bedbugs in the city.
lead_paragraph: As some of us know from personal experience, finding bedbugs in your apartment is jarring. While they don’t carry diseases to humans (that we know of), their bites are itchy and can get infected.

headline: Italy’s Oldest Instrument Hints at Sounds of Prehistoric Rome
abstract: The music of the ancient world is largely lost, but recent findings and recreations of antique instruments can give a taste.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When the archaeologist Giovanni Carboni first came upon the oddly shaped ceramic object during an excavation in a Roman suburb in 2006, he was baffled.

headline: After Brewers’ Misdirection, Wade Miley Will Pitch Game 6. For Real, This Time.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The next time Wade Miley steps on the mound for the Brewers, on Friday at Miller Park in Milwaukee, with the season on the line, he promises it will be for real.

headline: ‘Ray Donovan’: New Coast, Same Wounds
abstract: For its sixth season, the Showtime drama has moved its Hollywood fixer, played by Liev Schreiber, to New York.
lead_paragraph: When Liev Schreiber arrived on set last month to shoot a late-season episode of “Ray Donovan,” his shirt was a blazing white, his jeans were neatly creased and his face was just a mess. There was blood on his hairline, bruises wreathed his nose. This is a familiar “Ray Donovan” look. The makeup team lives for contusions.

headline: A New Culprit Is Identified in China’s Choking Smog
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Air Pollution', 'Formaldehyde', 'Sulfur and Sulfur Compounds']
abstract: Researchers say that emissions of formaldehyde from autos and chemical and oil refineries play a larger role in China’s smog than previously known.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Scientists have found a new culprit contributing to China’s notorious wintertime smog, and controlling it could help sustain the significant improvements in air quality that Beijing and other northeastern cities experienced last winter, according to research published on Thursday.

headline: Interference or Not? One Fan Changes the Course of a Game
abstract: Fan interference on Jose Altuve’s potential home run for the Astros in the first inning of Game 4 kept the score, 2-0, in the Red Sox’ favor.
lead_paragraph: It was a wild American League Championship Series game with memorable moments, great batting, fielding and pitching, and a diving catch to end it. But what most people wanted to talk about Thursday morning was a controversy in the first inning.

headline: Viggo Mortensen Captures Fall Flowers and a Film Festival, in Polaroids
abstract: We sent the actor a camera and asked him to document his travels ahead of the release of his new film, “Green Book.”
lead_paragraph: Viggo Mortensen, one of the six cover subjects of this year’s Greats issue, is a veritable Renaissance man. He is, of course, best known for his acting, but Mortensen (alongside his son, Henry, and their business partner Michele Perez) also runs the independent publishing house Perceval Press, through which the movie star has put out collections of his own poetry, painting and photography, in addition to other artists’ works. Last month, we sent him a Polaroid camera and asked him to document his travels ahead of the release of his new film, “Green Book.” In turn, he provided us with a vibrant study of the local flora in New York — where the paparazzi caught him snapping pictures in the rain — Madrid, Barcelona and Zurich, and cheekily aimed his lens at a press pool.

headline: Remembering the Moon Landing, Nearly 50 Years Later: ‘We Were All Completely Silent’
abstract: A new film, “First Man,” tells the story of Neil Armstrong’s stepping onto the moon in the summer of 1969. We asked readers to tell us what they remembered about that historic day.
lead_paragraph: There was no such thing as YouTube in 1969. If you missed watching an important event on TV, you couldn’t Google it to catch up. For the most part, you just had to be there.

headline: Frogs Are Disappearing. What Does That Mean?
abstract: For ages, they have been symbols in human culture — of fertility, gastronomy and now the alt-right movement. But these noble amphibians are declining in numbers.
lead_paragraph: THE DUSKY GOPHER FROG, once endemic to the longleaf pine savannas of Mississippi, Alabama and Louisiana — and now listed among the 100 most endangered species on earth — is tiny, dark and warty. The creature is often described as both secretive and shockingly loud, with a rumbling, back-of-the-throat mating call that is uncannily close to the human snore. It hides from the sun almost its whole life, finding shelter in burned-out tree stumps. And although it’s armed against danger (its glands secrete poison), in the presence of a predator, the three-inch-long frog lifts its front legs to cover its eyes, like a child pretending to be invisible: You can’t see it if it can’t see you.

headline: Musks for Men Who Appreciate Subtlety
keywords: ['Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Smells and Odors', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Lush without being overpowering, these new fragrances celebrate the scent’s multitudes.
lead_paragraph: Musk: One can almost smell the word. In the past, musk has been associated with fragrances that are both dank and overpowering, but that’s becoming less and less true. Because the harvesting of the substance — which comes from the gland of the endangered male musk deer — has been illegal since 1975, all commercial musk is a synthetic interpretation of the actual, animal thing. First synthesized by the chemist Albert Bauer in 1888, artificial musk now encompasses a wide variety of olfactory compounds. Gone are the louche scents of yesteryear. Modern musks can be filthy, dainty, weighty, wispy; in short, they’re unpredictable. But the distinctive quality all musks share is a certain lushness, a tendency to smell as opulent as cashmere feels. Frédéric Malle, the founder of his eponymous French fragrance house, says, “Musk conveys different ideas based on what it is paired with.” Yet a commonality exists: “Very often it makes a perfume more addictive.”

headline: Searching for Water Across Borders
keywords: ['Water', 'Shortages', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Irrigation', 'Deserts', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Saudi Arabia and China are among the countries that have turned to the United States and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: As climate change begins to make water scarcity a critical security issue globally, wealthier countries have begun to look outside their borders to meet their water needs. In moves that have important trade and geopolitical implications, Saudi Arabia and China have come to America to help solve their water problems and feed their people.

headline: With Piranha-Like Teeth, This Prehistoric Predator Never Bit Off More Than It Could Chew
abstract: A fossil discovered in southern Germany is the earliest known flesh-eating bony fish.
lead_paragraph: Some 150 million years ago, prehistoric fish swimming in the sponge and coral reefs of what is now southern Germany might not have suspected there was a piranha-like predator prowling among them. But by the time they realized the danger — CHOMP! — the sneaky creature would have bitten off one of their fins.

headline: A Conservative Group’s Closed-Door ‘Training’ of Judicial Clerks Draws Concern
keywords: ['Federal Courts (US)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The conservative legal movement has long cultivated law students and young lawyers, partly to ensure a deep bench of potential judicial nominees
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The closed-door “training academy” was aimed at a select group: recent law school graduates who had secured prestigious clerkships with federal judges. It was organized by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative group that has played a leading role in moving the courts to the right, and it had some unusual requirements.

headline: Takehisa Kosugi, Composer for Merce Cunningham, Dies at 80
abstract: In a long career on the cutting edge, Mr. Kosugi found music everywhere — in bicycle parts, in crumpled paper, even in silence.
lead_paragraph: Takehisa Kosugi, an avant-garde composer who was an accomplished violinist but who was just as likely to play bicycle spokes or inflatable balls in his innovative explorations of the sonic landscape, died on Oct. 12 in Ashiya City, Japan. He was 80.

headline: Will Trump Make New York Democrats the New Lords of Capitol Hill?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If the president’s unpopularity leads to Democrats taking back the House, New York stands to play a larger role in Washington than it has in decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump may well be one of the few New York leaders liked by the heartland of America. Yet his growing unpopularity elsewhere may not only fuel a Democratic resurgence in November — it may be the very thing that propels more New Yorkers into power.

headline: Suzanne Collins Talks About ‘The Hunger Games,’ the Books and the Movies
abstract: To celebrate the 10th anniversary of the first book in the trilogy, here is an excerpt from an interview between the publisher and the author.
lead_paragraph: “The Hunger Games,” by Suzanne Collins, came out in 2008. It is the first in a trilogy by the same name that includes “Catching Fire” (2009) and “Mockingjay” (2010). The series has more than 100 million copies in print worldwide, and spent more than 260 consecutive weeks on The Times best-seller list. The books have spawned four record-breaking films and many Katniss Halloween costumes. In a 10th anniversary edition of the book, which hits stores this month, David Levithan, a vice president and publisher at Scholastic Press, interviewed Collins. An excerpt from that interview, including potential spoilers, is below, condensed and edited for clarity and length.

headline: Katniss Everdeen Is My Hero
abstract: Suzanne Collins’s lead character in The Hunger Games trilogy is a timely reminder to all who care to heed it: Teenage girls are powerful and courageous and capable of great rage.
lead_paragraph: Katniss Everdeen and I met on a rainy Virginia day in 2010. I’d seen “The Hunger Games” and its sequels at nearly every bookshop I visited. On that particular day, feeling glum about my own failed attempts to write, I decided to pick up this book everyone was talking about.

headline: This Is the Most Lucrative Moment in History to Catch Bass
abstract: A rivalry between two tournament fishing circuits has slapped the industry like a 10-pound largemouth to the face.
lead_paragraph: One Friday morning in August, even before the sun had risen over the St. Lawrence River, the docks in Waddington, N.Y., were aglow. Some of the artificial light came from a flotilla of sleek boats that drifted around the marina, kitted out with luminous fish-finder devices. The rest emanated from smartphones and video cameras, as dozens of professional anglers recorded social-media clips ahead of the last competition of the regular season.

headline: You’re Not ‘Flu Shot People’? Then You’re Not Touching My Baby
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Influenza', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: What to do about in-laws who don’t do vaccines.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are expecting our first child in January. We’re very excited! We want to protect him during the height of flu season, so I asked our parents and siblings to get flu shots. My family is onboard. But my in-laws keep saying, “We’re not flu shot people.” My husband and I agree that no one can see the baby without getting a flu shot. Still, I worry that my in-laws will see this as an empty threat or claim to have gotten shots when they haven’t. I’ve sent them many articles and videos, which they’ve ignored. How do we convince them?

headline: Religion and Women’s Rights Clash, Violently, at a Shrine in India
abstract: A New York Times journalist was met with rock-throwing and threats when she tried to visit a Hindu temple after justices ruled that women should be allowed access.
lead_paragraph: NEAR SABARIMALA TEMPLE, India — As a woman and a man climbed a steep trail on Thursday leading to one of Hinduism’s holiest temples, a mob multiplied with frightening speed.

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Character matters, in literature as much as life. This week’s recommended titles delve deep into the stories of complicated individuals, whether through biography (Gandhi, Lorraine Hansberry) or memoir (Sally Field, Marwan Hisham) or fiction (the heroine of John Wray’s novel, derived from a real-life figure, is an American fighting for the Taliban). For readers who prefer a wide-angle lens, we offer a manifesto about female rage, a simmering thriller from Tana French about the ways that privilege protects and blinds its recipients, and a celebration of libraries that opens with the harrowing tale of a fire tearing through the stacks. It will make you feel even more protective of your books than you do already.

headline: William Shearer, Doctor (‘Like Another Dad’) to Boy in Bubble, Dies at 81
abstract: “What he gave us was a powerful lesson in many areas of medicine,” Dr. Shearer said of his young patient, who lived in a sterile plastic cocoon.
lead_paragraph: Dr. William Shearer, who treated the so-called bubble boy — a youngster isolated from birth in sterile plastic cocoons because he lacked a functioning immune system — through the last years of his short life, died on Oct. 9 at his home in Houston. He was 81.

headline: Review: Jonas Kaufmann, Back at the Met, Is Good, Not Great
abstract: The superstar tenor brought richness and nuance to Puccini’s “La Fanciulla del West,” but his singing seemed underpowered.
lead_paragraph: You could feel trepidation at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday as the audience took its seats for Puccini’s “La Fanciulla del West.” The superstar tenor Jonas Kaufmann was finally returning after an absence of four and a half years, including withdrawals from two new productions conceived with him in mind. Would he actually show?

headline: N.B.A. G League to Offer Prospects $125,000 as Alternative to ‘One and Done’
abstract: Eighteen-year-olds who previously played for Duke or Arizona may now be suiting up for the Fort Wayne Mad Ants.
lead_paragraph: Elite 18-year-old basketball players will soon have another alternative to playing a “one and done” year at college. The N.B.A. announced Thursday that, beginning next year, select players would be able to earn $125,000 to play in its development league, the G League, for a year before entering the N.B.A. draft.

headline: Vatican Mum on North Korea’s Invitation to Pope Francis

lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis received an invitation on Thursday to visit North Korea, a message relayed to him in a private audience at the Vatican with President Moon Jae-in of South Korea.

headline: These Food ‘Museums’ Want to Tease Your Palate and Dominate Your Instagram
abstract: Pop-up food experiences are growing in popularity around the globe, and these destinations encourage you to enjoy free samples and take plenty of photos.

headline: Sears’s Edward Lampert Was a Wizard. Now He’s Coming to Terms With Failure.
abstract: Sears went bankrupt under the financier’s leadership. For the first time since the bankruptcy, Mr. Lampert speaks publicly about how he got it wrong.

Tisch were among the prominent backers who gave him more than $200 million in start-up capital.

headline: Researchers Explore a Cancer Paradox
abstract: Healthy cells carry a surprising number of cancer-linked mutations, but they don’t turn into tumors. What’s holding them back?
lead_paragraph: Cancer is a disease of mutations. Tumor cells are riddled with genetic mutations not found in healthy cells. Scientists estimate that it takes five to 10 key mutations for a healthy cell to become cancerous.

headline: Amazon HQ2 Watch: Northern Virginia Checks the Most Boxes
abstract: Amazon won’t say a word about where it plans to put its much-hyped second headquarters. But there is a growing consensus that it will go across the river from Washington.

headline: Saudis May Blame Intelligence Official for Killing Jamal Khashoggi

headline: Women Get Feet in the Door of the Car Design Boys’ Club
abstract: Their numbers remain small, but more women are being trained for the jobs that determine how our cars look and feel.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years ago, Sharon Gauci became the first woman asked to join the judges’ panel for her native country’s Australian Design Awards. The annual laurels had been handed out since the 1950s, so Ms. Gauci may be forgiven if she viewed the invitation — a career highlight — as a smidge overdue.

headline: Review: At Ballet Theater, a Gala Stage for Women’s Work
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s fall gala featured dances by Lauren Lovette and Michelle Dorrance, and Twyla Tharp’s “In the Upper Room.”
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater, while in some ways the most conservative institution in American dance, keeps reinventing itself. The company announced its initiative Women’s Movement in May, to support the work of 21st-century female choreographers. This cause takes further steps forward in the company’s two-week season at the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: Met and Brooklyn Museums Will Not Use Saudi Money for Programs on the Middle East
abstract: As more details emerged about the fate of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi, the museums said they would use their own money for events originally supported by Saudi funds.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum said on Thursday that they would not use Saudi money for programs on Middle Eastern art that had originally been supported by groups tied to the Saudi government.
