abstract: An employee reluctantly invited her immediate manager to her wedding. Now the boss has blabbed about the occasion to a higher-up manager — whom the employee really dislikes.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: This Playwright Has Been Listening to Her Mother
abstract: Jaclyn Backhaus’s new play sounds like the story of a Punjabi-American of her generation, and it is. But it also draws on her mother’s fraught family.
lead_paragraph: Scrunched up against a counter at the Punjabi Grocery & Deli, an East Village hole-in-the-wall, Jaclyn Backhaus tucked into a vegetarian lunch she had handpicked for two: saag curry, chana paneer, pakoras and daal.

headline: Review: Netflix’s ‘Wanderlust’ Is an Experiment in Fidelity
abstract: Toni Collette plays a therapist who tries to save her marriage by talking her husband into an open marriage. (He doesn’t take much convincing.)
lead_paragraph: “Wanderlust” begins with Joy, the British therapist played by Toni Collette, getting back on the bike, literally and figuratively. Out of commission after an accident that left her with a broken hip, she straps on an industrial-grade helmet and pedals slowly down the street, even though she’s still having trouble walking.

headline: What Does He Do, Work in a Cave? Why, Yes
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Computer Security', 'Restaurants', 'Baseball', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: A software company operates underground to keep data secure. Its chief seeks a Middle-earth effect in décor.
lead_paragraph: Gene Peters is chief executive of Rosnet, a restaurant software company in Parkville, Mo.

headline: Charge of Treason Escalates Tensions in Close Arizona Senate Race
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Martha McSally drew national attention this week when she accused her Democratic opponent, Kyrsten Sinema, of treason.
lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — Martha McSally was speaking to a veterans group on Thursday about aggressive liberal politics when she suddenly shifted the conversation to Kyrsten Sinema, her Democratic opponent in the race for an open Senate seat here. “Speaking of treason,” she said, referring to Ms. Sinema, “her extreme views are out of step.”

headline: At MoMA, Judson Dance Looks Back With Anger and Toughness
abstract: Remarkable revivals of pieces by Deborah Hay and David Gordon show that Judson Dance Theater’s works remain radical still.
lead_paragraph: The Judson Dance Theater exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art honors a generation of genre-changing dance-makers who first came into their element in the 1960s. When you look at the objects, pictures and photographs on the walls, you can understand that yes, they were once radical.

headline: Not Just for Grown-Ups: The Broadway Audience Is Getting Younger
abstract: The average age of the Broadway theatergoer last season was 40.6 — the lowest since 2000, the Broadway League says, and 15 percent of theatergoers were under 18.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway audience is getting younger.

headline: Bella Thorne’s Cats, Big Bird and More: Your Week in Pop Culture
abstract: What you need to know from this week’s TV, music and movie news.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

headline: Homeless in San Francisco
abstract: A resident calls the situation a state of emergency.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Barbara Kingsolver’s New Book, a Family Teeters on the Brink
abstract: “Unsheltered,” a big, gripping, emotionally complex novel on the same scale as “The Poisonwood Bible,” explores what it means to have a safe place in the world.
lead_paragraph: UNSHELTEREDBy Barbara Kingsolver480 pp. HarperCollins Publishers. $29.99.

headline: Is This ‘A Star Is Born’ Pop Song Supposed to Be Bad or Glorious?
abstract: “Why Did You Do That?” is the film’s most debated song, and co-writer Diane Warren explains its intention.
lead_paragraph: Reader, I have a question. Why do you look so good in those jeans?

headline: Three Internet Trolls Convicted of Systematic Defamation Against Journalist in Finland
abstract: Jessika Aro, a Finnish journalist investigating Russian disinformation campaigns, had been called a spy, a drug dealer and unhinged.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — For more than three years, a Finnish journalist who investigated Russia’s army of vicious internet trolls faced a barrage of false accusations online that she was an American intelligence operative, a drug dealer and an unhinged bimbo driven by Russophobia.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Nonspooky Halloween Decor
abstract: How scary must it all be?
lead_paragraph: Carrie writes: I am 35 and live in the in-law apartment of my mother’s house. Every Halloween my mother dresses as a witch, fills a pot with dry ice and invites kids to help her with her witches brew. It’s great. But sometimes she gets cartoony decorations. I seek an injunction preventing my mother from purchasing nonspooky Halloween decorations.

headline: Founder of Proud Boys Says He’s Arranging Surrender of Men in Brawl
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Assaults']
abstract: Two members have been arrested. Gavin McInnes, the group’s founder, said other members would soon be in custody.
lead_paragraph: The founder of the far-right group the Proud Boys said on Friday that he was arranging the surrender of several members whom the police are seeking in connection with a violent brawl outside a Republican club in Manhattan last weekend.

headline: Georgia Voting Begins Amid Accusations of Voter Suppression
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Questions about the fairness of voting rules and procedures have continued to grow as early voting began in the governor’s race between Stacey Abrams and Brian Kemp.
lead_paragraph: MARIETTA, Ga. — Wim Laven arrived to his polling location in Atlanta’s northern suburbs this week unsure what to make of recent allegations of voter difficulties at the ballot box. Then he waited two hours in the Georgia sun; saw one person in the line treated for heat exhaustion; and watched a second collapse, receive help from paramedics, yet refuse to be taken to the hospital — so he could remain in line and cast his ballot.

headline: Trudeau Has It All Over Trump
abstract: A reader lists the forward-looking qualities of Canada’s prime minister.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Romanov Is Not Too Happy With ‘The Romanoffs’
abstract: The self-declared Grand Duchess Maria, a descendant of Russian royalty, took it upon herself to issue a bitter critique of the fictional Amazon series.
lead_paragraph: “The Romanoffs,” Amazon’s new drama series in which characters are descendants of Russia’s royal family, has not received the best reviews.

headline: The Playlist: Esperanza Spalding’s Intoxicating Groove, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Empress Of, Khalid, Brandi Carlile, Madame Gandhi and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Spinning a Tale to Protect a Saudi Prince
abstract: Readers discuss the murder of Jamal Khashoggi: how the Saudis are trying to explain it and how the American media are covering it.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Saving Afghanistan: It’s Futile. Let’s Leave.
abstract: Our relationship with Afghanistan is like a bad marriage, a former defense official says. It’s time for a divorce.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Susan Orlean on a Great Library Fire
abstract: Orlean discusses “The Library Book,” about a 1986 blaze in Los Angeles that damaged or destroyed more than a million books.
lead_paragraph: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

headline: University of Southern California to Pay $215 Million Over Sex Abuse Scandal
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: The settlement, which still needs to be approved by the court, is among the largest settlements from a university facing accusations of sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The University of Southern California has agreed to pay $215 million to settle a federal lawsuit filed by hundreds of women who say that they were sexually abused by the former head gynecologist at the student health center and that school officials did not address their complaints.

headline: Should Hillary Clinton Be Mum Before the Midterms?
abstract: Readers react to an opinion piece urging her to keep a low profile before she “complicates life for her fellow Democrats.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Liberal San Francisco, Tech Leaders Brawl Over Tax Proposal to Aid Homeless
abstract: Jack Dorsey of Twitter and Marc Benioff of Salesforce, among others, are sparring over a Nov. 6 ballot initiative that would impose new corporate taxes.
lead_paragraph: For months, technology companies in San Francisco have fought a local ballot proposition that would impose taxes on corporations to fund initiatives to help the homeless.

headline: Carrie Mae Weems Captures Her Life in 10 Unconventional ‘Polaroids’
abstract: When T sent the artist a Polaroid camera and asked her to send back photos, she took a characteristically unexpected approach.
lead_paragraph: In a career spanning nearly half a century, Carrie Mae Weems, one of the cover subjects of this year’s Greats issue, has completely rethought the rules of image-making. “Her photographs and short films, as gimlet-eyed and gutsy as they are visually compelling, have gone a long way toward resetting our expectations of pictures and challenging our assumptions about her largely African-American subjects,” writes Megan O’Grady in her profile of the artist. Weems was an obvious candidate to participate in our recurring 10 Polaroids feature, in which we send someone a Polaroid camera and ask them to capture scenes from their life. But what Weems then submitted was unexpected. Among her photographs, below, are some traditional Polaroids; however, to create other images, Weems digitally added a white border to a selection of photographs that she had taken previously — either in the past month, as she rehearsed for a coming performance at Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater, or in the past few years — using it as a framing device. Weems, after all, has built her practice around upending our expectations of photography.

headline: Justice Dept. Accuses Russians of Interfering in Midterm Elections
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Social Media', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Russians working for a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin created social media accounts to pose as Americans and write posts on divisive issues including race and gender, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russians working for a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin are engaging in an elaborate campaign of “information warfare” to interfere with the American midterm elections next month, federal prosecutors said on Friday in unsealing charges against a woman whom they labeled the project’s “chief accountant.”

headline: U.S. to Tell Russia It Is Leaving Landmark I.N.F. Treaty
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Treaties', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: President Trump has been moving toward leaving the treaty because Russia has been violating it and because it is constraining American efforts to counter China in the Western Pacific.
lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is preparing to tell Russian leaders next week that it is planning to exit the landmark Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, in part to enable the United States to counter a Chinese arms buildup in the Pacific, according to American officials and foreign diplomats.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Suspend Military Drills
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The decision was made as part of an effort to give the continuing nuclear negotiations with North Korea an opportunity to work, Pentagon officials said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The United States and South Korea have suspended another military exercise this year as part of an effort to give the continuing nuclear negotiations with North Korea an opportunity to work, Pentagon officials said on Friday.

headline: Powerball and Mega Millions Jackpots Are Up to $2 Billion. Here’s What to Do if You Win Both.
abstract: Your odds are 1 in 88 quadrillion, but it’s best to be prepared. If you do win: Don’t sign the winning ticket. Tell no one. Hire a lawyer, a financial adviser and an accountant.
lead_paragraph: The Mega Millions jackpot climbed to an astounding $1.6 billion on Saturday, the largest lottery prize in United States history, just hours after a drawing failed to produce a winning ticket. The Powerball jackpot isn’t too shabby either: $470 million.

headline: The Halloween Movie Franchise: How We Have Covered It
abstract: Check out these reviews, video features and an oral history.
lead_paragraph: The new “Halloween” sequel is in theaters. In the four decades since the mute Michael Myers spawned a franchise by stalking babysitters (including Jamie Lee Curtis’s Laurie Strode), we’ve amassed considerable coverage. Here’s a rundown.

headline: A Harvest That Requires Flooding, Floating and Pumping
keywords: ['Irrigation', 'Cranberries', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Water', 'Careers and Professions', 'Family Business']
abstract: Growing cranberries involves techniques that aren’t common on other American farms. In Wisconsin, the year-round work culminates in waterlogged weeks of autumn.
lead_paragraph: John Moss, 33, is a grower at Elm Lake Cranberry in Cranmoor, Wis.

headline: BepiColombo Launches on Long Journey to Mercury
abstract: The European-Japanese spacecraft will be the third mission to the rocky planet closest to the sun.
lead_paragraph: Earth is going back to Mercury.

headline: What if the Republicans Win Everything Again?
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Total victory for the G.O.P. would mean Trump unleashed.
lead_paragraph: The end of Robert Mueller’s investigation. The loss of health insurance for several million people. New laws that make it harder to vote. More tax cuts for the rich. More damage to the environment. A Republican Party molded even more in the image of President Trump.

headline: Some Plants Thrive in the Shadows
abstract: They don’t need sunlight because they are busy feeding on other organisms.
lead_paragraph: A. Plants do need sunlight or other light sources to power the chemical reactions of photosynthesis and make food for themselves. But some plants rely on others to make food for them and can survive without sunlight.

headline: A Lemon Cake That Cuts to the Pith
abstract: This recipe, using the whole fruit, is full of deep citrus flavor and may just be worth baking right away.
lead_paragraph: I can shrug off chocolate and ignore caramel, but when it comes to lemon, I can never resist. If there’s a lemon dessert on the menu, I order it. If I see a lemon cake recipe I’ve never tried, I’ll bake it as soon as is humanly possible.

headline: Anthea Bell, Translator of Freud, Kafka and Comics, Dies at 82
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Translating is “like acting,” said Ms. Bell, the rare practitioner who became a well-known name in her own right.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anthea Bell, the rare translator who, despite her best efforts to stay hidden, became a name herself in bringing works by Franz Kafka, Sigmund Freud and other major writers to English audiences, died on Thursday in Cambridge, England. She was 82.

headline: Bruce Nauman Reappears: Pay Attention
abstract: “Disappearing Acts” lets us see with clarity where the artist stands and why he is pertinent to our wrenching moment.
lead_paragraph: If art isn’t about life and death, and the emotions and ethics that surround them, what is it about? Style? Taste? Auction results? Some artists focus on those, but the most interesting head for the uncool existential bottom line, which is what Bruce Nauman does. He’s approached this line by many paths: history, humor, shock, politics and formal variety. And he’s merged those paths into a bumpy superhighway of a career, which we’re invited to travel in “Bruce Nauman: Disappearing Acts,” a half-century retrospective that fills the sixth floor of the Museum of Modern Art and nearly the entire premises of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: ‘Gold Mine’: Why New Jersey Is Suddenly Challenging Nevada as a Sports Betting Hub
abstract: A total of $336.6 million has been wagered on sports in New Jersey since sports betting became legal in June. Could the Garden State challenge Nevada for sports betting supremacy?
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At first, the sports book in northern New Jersey appeared to have everything ready when sports betting became legal in the state: 52 high-definition TVs, a fully stocked bar, a revamped menu, a plush V.I.P. section and 20 tellers spread out in a cavernous room.

headline: Jamal Khashoggi’s Killing: Here’s What We Know
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The killing of the journalist has strained relations between Turkey and Saudi Arabia, and put the United States at the center of a dispute between two critical allies.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of leaking snippets of information, the Turkish president laid out his first detailed account of the killing of the dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi inside the Saudi Consulate. And a Saudi investment conference opened in Riyadh despite a widespread international boycott over the writer’s death.

headline: What to Do and Where to See Alpacas in Peru’s Sacred Valley
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Textiles', 'Local Food', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Machu Picchu is the area’s most popular tourist stop, but the land beyond is home to lesser-known ruins, artisanal crafts and an innovative food scene.
lead_paragraph: Beneath the snowcapped Andean peaks outside of Cusco lies Peru’s Sacred Valley, a fertile and archaeologically rich expanse covering nearly 60 miles from east to west. On one end, you’ll find the ruins of Písac, complete with an ancient sun temple carved from pink granite; on the other, the famed 15th-century citadel of Machu Picchu.

headline: Manafort to Be Sentenced in February in Financial Fraud Case
keywords: ['Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: President Trump’s former campaign chairman, who is now cooperating with the special counsel’s Russia inquiry, appeared in court in a wheelchair.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — A federal judge ordered on Friday that Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, be sentenced in February for the financial fraud crimes he was convicted of in August.

headline: Dozens Watching Fireworks in India Are Mowed Down by Speeding Train
abstract: A Hindu religious holiday signifying the victory of good over evil ends in tragedy, as people sitting on railway tracks are killed by a speeding train.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — They were watching the bad guy go down.

headline: Disinformation Spreads on WhatsApp Ahead of Brazilian Election
abstract: Facebook, which owns WhatsApp, is trying to prove it can curb the spread of false news. But the app’s design makes it difficult.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over the past few months, the 120 million Brazilians who use WhatsApp, the smartphone messaging application that is owned by Facebook, have been deluged with political messages.

headline: The Best and Worst of the Week’s Trailers: Actress Showcases
abstract: The strongest clips (“Destroyer,” “Mary, Queen of Scots”) offer performances that may figure in the Oscar race. The weakest is a dog. Literally.
lead_paragraph: Oscar season is afoot, and the best actress race looks to be very competitive. This week’s new trailers bring us several hopefuls, led by Nicole Kidman, Saoirse Ronan and Margot Robbie (unless she’s entered as a supporting actress), who star in the most promising of the new promotional clips.

headline: Four Knockout Group Shows to See Now
abstract: From eight centuries of the art now called Surrealist to startling new takes on assemblage from Port-au-Prince, our critic finds a heady mix of old and modern, sex and politics in these powerhouse gallery shows.
lead_paragraph: Among New York’s many commercial galleries, there are group shows and then there are group shows, veritable extravaganzas that give the genre all they’ve got. These exhibitions are immersive and often densely packed; they can require of viewers the same stamina as museum shows (and often as much effort on the part of their organizers). They reach into the past or focus on other cultures. They show us the art of our era in new thematic arrangements, or the art of this-very-instant, from  unfamiliar creators. Here are four of the city’s most energizing and eye-opening group shows, with subjects stretching  from  fantastic art of the sixteenth century to contemporary assemblage  from Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Each creates its own world, full of surprises and multiple rewards.

headline: Three Florida Police Officers Are Sent to Prison for False Arrests
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The arrests came at the behest of the police chief of Biscayne Park, who the authorities said wanted to clear unsolved cases.
lead_paragraph: Three former Florida police officers were sentenced to prison this week for conspiring to falsely arrest people to improve the department’s crime statistics — at the instruction of their police chief.

headline: Finding a Better Bratwurst
abstract: Good brats may not be easy to come by, but sausages, paired with sizzled apples and onions, are a perfect way to welcome the crisp days.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever noticed how a brisk walk on a crisp, sunny fall day can make a person hungry? Something about falling leaves and cool breezes arouses certain cravings. Some are satisfied with hot chocolate or a cappuccino; others crave a beer and a burger. For me, it’s sausages sizzling in a cast-iron pan with apples and onions.

headline: C.E.O.s May Avoid Riyadh Conference but Not Saudi Money
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Arms Trade', 'Foreign Investments', 'Private Equity', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Even though American and European executives are staying away, companies are unlikely to sever ties or avert future deals after the killing of Jamal Khashoggi.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Saudi Arabia is pouring $20 billion into a new investment fund run by Wall Street’s Blackstone Group. The French oil giant Total just inked a nine-billion-euro petrochemical deal with the kingdom. The British defense company BAE Systems is selling 48 Typhoon combat jets to Riyadh for an estimated five billion British pounds.

headline: The ‘Sugar Dater’
abstract: How one man used SeekingArrangement to deceive a number of women in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In an article published earlier this week, Chandler Fowles, 25, told of being scammed last spring by a man she met on SeekingArrangement.com, a dating website dedicated to connecting “sugar daddies” and “sugar babies.” He had promised her and a female friend $2,500 for sex and to cover the cost of a hotel room, pretended to pay them through a phony PayPal transaction and then fled after he got what he wanted.

headline: New Sentences: From John Ashbery’s ‘They Knew What They Wanted’
abstract: A list is a powerful thing.
lead_paragraph: — From “They Knew What They Wanted: Poems & Collages” (Rizzoli Electa, 2018, Page 43), a collection of work by John Ashbery. The piece in which this sentence appears, “Hoboken,” was written in the 1950s but widely disseminated only recently.

headline: Climate Change Is No Joking Matter. Except, This Week, It Was.
abstract: Global warming made the rounds on the late-night comedy shows this week. It was funny, but do jokes blunt the message that climate change is a threat? Hardly, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Late night is heating up. That is, shows like “Saturday Night Live,” “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” and “The Daily Show With Trevor Noah” have been focusing on global warming in the past week.

headline: Your Neighbor in an Adjacent ZIP Code May Pay Less for Car Insurance
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Personal Finances', 'Consumer Protection', 'Income', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A consumer group says insurers sometimes charge more to people living in less affluent ZIP codes — even if they have good driving records.
lead_paragraph: Living in the wrong ZIP code — even a short distance from a boundary — may mean a difference of hundreds of dollars in your automobile insurance rates, a new analysis finds.

headline: Julian Assange Says He’s Suing Ecuador for ‘Violating His Fundamental Rights’
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Extradition', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The WikiLeaks founder claimed that his longtime hosts at the country’s embassy in London are limiting his contact with the outside world and censoring his speech.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange announced on Friday that he was suing the Ecuadorean government for “violating his fundamental rights,” claiming that his longtime hosts at the country’s embassy in London are limiting his contact with the outside world and censoring his speech.

headline: Democrats, Looking Ahead to 2020, See a Future That Is Female
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: In the On Politics newsletter, a record midterms for women sets the stage for a record presidential campaign; plus, a barrier-breaking candidate in Texas and a new poll in California.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: T Suggests: Furniture for Doomsday, Riot Grrrl T-Shirts and More
keywords: ['Furniture', 'Art', 'Chairs', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A roundup of things T editors — and a few contributors — are excited about in a given week.
lead_paragraph: Twelve different variations of gingham appear across the 71 rooms of the Hotel Peter & Paul, which had its soft opening earlier this month in the Marigny district of New Orleans. The custom fabrics, created by the 100-year-old Swiss textile manufacturer Filtex, come in dusty pine green, Venetian red, sunflower yellow and cornflower blue. Checks range in size from postage stamp to cocktail napkin, and cover billowing window drapes, upholstered scroll-leg chairs and the curtains around oversize wrought-iron four-poster beds. The effect is surprisingly calming. For the overall aesthetic of many of the rooms, “we embraced a Swedish, Gustavian austerity,” says Ari Heckman, the co-founder and C.E.O. of the design firm ASH NYC, which is a partner in the project. The gingham is offset by white lime-wash walls, pale-wood floors and antique furniture sourced from both Europe and local New Orleans estate sales.

headline: Cuomo, Called a Chicken, Says ‘I Will Be Here’ for Debate. He Has Caveats.
abstract: After days of being mocked, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo agreed to debate Marcus Molinaro, but only if it took place within 24 hours, at 8 a.m.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is totally, completely, absolutely willing to debate his Republican opponent, Marcus J. Molinaro. Just as long as it takes place within 24 hours, on the radio, at 8 a.m., on Saturday.

headline: Poem: Exiliados
abstract: Selected by Rita Dove.
lead_paragraph: Romeo and Juliet in 21st-century America is no simple narrative. While Javier Zamora’s lovers may not have to contend with feuding families nor navigate the ethnic minefields of “West Side Story,” their destinies are star-crossed nevertheless. As they embark on their first date, the shadow of exile — to lose a homeland and not feel quite welcome in the new one — sweeps over them. No hands are held yet, no kisses dared; yet they dream of love, what might grow from borrowed ground. Selected by Rita Dove

headline: The Challenge With Prosecuting Newsweek’s Former Owner for Fraud: There Were No Losses
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: The charges filed by the Manhattan district attorney’s office against two media companies raise a question: Can there be fraud if no money is lost?
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Harvard’s Admissions Process, Once Secret, Is Unveiled in Affirmative Action Trial
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Asian-Americans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION']
abstract: A lawsuit accusing one of the country’s most selective universities of discriminating against Asian-Americans is providing a glimpse into how admissions officers decide “yea” or “nay.”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The deliberations that take place inside 86 Brattle Street, a red brick building where Harvard University’s admissions committee convenes, have very much stayed inside 86 Brattle Street.

headline: Macedonia Moves Ahead With Name Change, Helping Its NATO Bid
abstract: In a tenuous victory for Prime Minister Zoran Zaev and his Western allies, Parliament voted to proceed with renaming the country the Republic of North Macedonia.
lead_paragraph: The government of Macedonia secured just enough support from Parliament late Friday to keep alive a deal to change the country’s name, a move that could end a bitter, decades-old dispute with Greece and set the Balkan nation on a path to joining NATO.

headline: Shirin Aliabadi, Iranian Artist With a Focus on Women, Dies at 45
abstract: Her work depicted young women negotiating their modern, slightly rebellious impulses within the strictures of the Islamic Republic.
lead_paragraph: Shirin Aliabadi, an Iranian artist who gave expression to Iranian women navigating between their youthful, rebellious energy and the strictures of the Islamic Republic, died on Oct. 1 in Tehran. She was 45.

headline: Saudi Arabia Says Jamal Khashoggi Was Killed in Consulate Fight
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The kingdom’s public prosecutor said Mr. Khashoggi died after an argument and fistfight inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After two weeks of shifting stories, Saudi Arabia said Saturday that its agents strangled Jamal Khashoggi, a dissident journalist, during a fistfight inside the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul and that 18 men had been arrested in the case.

headline: As Trump Assails Caravan, a Clash Between Migrants and Mexico Police
abstract: A tense hour-long standoff near the Guatemala-Mexico border left at least six Mexico police officers wounded.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD TECÚN UMÁN, Guatemala — Members of a caravan of migrants that have been traveling from Honduras toward the United States, infuriating President Trump, overran a border gate in northern Guatemala on Friday and broke through another gate leading to Mexico before coming to a halt in the face of a large phalanx of Mexican riot police.

headline: Right to Know Is Now the Law. Here’s What That Means.
abstract: Police officers in New York City must provide more information to members of the public they interact with, and get consent for many searches.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department ordered 10 million business cards that officers must hand out to people they stop on the street. The cards will include the officers’ names and ranks, and are required under the new Right to Know Act.

headline: Khashoggi, Female Candidates, Mega Millions: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Evelyn Anthony, Writer of Spy Thrillers, Dies at 92
abstract: Ms. Anthony was one of the few women to explore the espionage genre. “I am basically an entertainer, and I’m very proud of it,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn Anthony, a best-selling British novelist who transitioned from historical fiction to espionage thrillers, becoming one of the first female writers to explore the spy genre, died on Sept. 25 at her home in Essex, northeast of London. She was 92.

headline: Facebook Ads From Unknown Backer Take Aim at Brexit Plan
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Advertising', 'Online Advertising', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The anonymous group’s campaign highlights Facebook’s continuing trouble with political advertising.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Theresa May has struggled to build support for her plan for Britain’s exit from the European Union. Now, it turns out, some of the opposition has come from an unknown organization posting ads to millions of people on Facebook.

headline: A Month of Robert Glasper’s Experiments at the Blue Note
abstract: The pianist’s October residency showcases how one of the most prominent jazz musicians of his generation has grown into an ambassador and a connector.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere close to midnight last Sunday, the rapper Yasiin Bey tossed his hoodie over a mic stand and hunkered down into a shimmy, tilting forward and leaping back across the tight Blue Note stage, his eyes locked on Chris Dave’s snare drum.

headline: Lisbeth Palme, Witness to an Assassination, Dies at 87
abstract: A noted advocate for children, she was also a key part of long-running efforts to find the killer of her husband, Sweden’s prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Lisbeth Palme, a crucial witness in one of the biggest unsolved crimes in modern European history, the 1986 murder of her husband, Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden, has died at 87.

headline: Stalking the Elusive Central Park Squirrel
abstract: I thought volunteering for New York’s squirrel census would be a walk in the park. I was wrong, kind of.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: The Poison on Facebook and Twitter Is Still Spreading
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Censorship', 'Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Social platforms have a responsibility to address misinformation as a systemic problem, instead of reacting to case after case.
lead_paragraph: A network of Facebook troll accounts operated by the Myanmar military parrots hateful rhetoric against Rohingya Muslims. Viral misinformation runs rampant on WhatsApp in Brazil, even as marketing firms there buy databases of phone numbers in order to spam voters with right-wing messaging. Homegrown campaigns spread partisan lies in the United States.

headline: Saturday Night Bikes
abstract: Meadowlands Racetrack is usually home to thoroughbreds or harness racers. But on a recent Saturday, a different kind of horsepower was on display.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Almost any other Saturday night of the year, the loudest noise heard in this expanse of former wetlands would come from horse-loving crowds cheering thoroughbreds or harness racers. On a recent Saturday, though, a far more raucous form of horsepower was in the air: scores of motorcycles tearing around the one-mile oval of the Meadowlands Racetrack in the final meet of the American Flat Track season.

headline: Bill Walker, Governor of Alaska, Suspends Campaign Amid Sinking Polls
abstract: Governor Walker, an independent, said he could not win the three-way race next month. He threw his support to former Senator Mark Begich, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Bill Walker of Alaska, a political independent who has been fighting an uphill battle for a second term, suspended his campaign on Friday and announced he was throwing his support behind his Democratic challenger. With only a few weeks before the election, the announcement upended the race, which until now had three candidates.

headline: ‘The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill’ Kids, 20 Years Later
abstract: A room full of children, one teacher and a conversation about love. Lauryn Hill’s debut solo album was filled with memorable interludes. Here’s what six of those voices have to say now.
lead_paragraph: A room full of children, one teacher and a conversation about love. Lauryn Hill’s debut solo album was filled with memorable interludes. Here’s what six of those voices have to say now.

headline: Something New May Be Rising Off California Coast: Wind Farms
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Windmills', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The Interior Department is moving to lease parcels in the deep Pacific waters for development, which could help the state meet its clean-energy goals.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — California’s aggressive pursuit of an electric grid fully powered by renewable energy sources is heading in a new direction: offshore.

headline: America’s Elections Could Be Hacked. Go Vote Anyway.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The system’s vulnerabilities are real, but please do not stay home.
lead_paragraph: Will November’s election be hacked? A quick sampling of news stories over the past couple of years offers little comfort.

headline: A Whole Lot of Babbling Going On
abstract: Did Donald Trump ever mention he got elected president?
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump goes on the road, things get peculiar.

headline: Uproar Over Dissident Rattles Saudi Royal Family
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Royal Families', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Members of the House of Saud are increasingly alarmed by the kingdom’s crown prince but can do little about it.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As international outrage grew at Saudi Arabia over the apparent killing of the Saudi dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul, an alarmed King Salman dispatched a senior royal to address the matter with Turkey’s president.

headline: Trump and Women: Another Writer Looks for Answers
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: “Golden Handcuffs: The Secret History of Trump’s Women” traces how the president’s consequence-free (so far) comments about women continue a running theme that started early in his life.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Should Americans be shocked that President Trump called a woman “Horseface” this week?

headline: The Issues That Russian Operatives Used to Divide Americans, in Their Own Words
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A criminal complaint offered a rare view into how Russian operatives tried to disrupt the American political process, including the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a criminal complaint unsealed Friday, federal prosecutors described a Russian operation to sow political discord in the United States that began in 2014 and was now aimed at disrupting the midterm elections. The covert campaign was designed to inflame passions about hot-button issues and controversial figures, including the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, whose team has been investigating Moscow’s interference in the 2016 presidential race.

headline: Man Charged With Threatening to Murder 2 Senators Who Supported Kavanaugh
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ronald DeRisi, 74, was arrested on Friday after the police recovered voice mail messages threatening violence against senators who had voted to confirm Justice Brett Kavanaugh.
lead_paragraph: A 74-year-old Long Island man was arrested Friday on charges that he made death threats against two United States senators in retaliation for their support of Brett M. Kavanaugh’s nomination to the Supreme Court.

headline: What Will It Take for the Knicks and Nets to Have a Real Rivalry?
abstract: “They have to be good at the same time. Being bad at the same time doesn’t help,” Jeff Van Gundy, the former Knicks coach, said before the Nets won a thriller between the New York teams on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Nets Coach Kenny Atkinson grew up on Long Island, and he knows the history of sports rivalries across the bridges and through the tunnels. He knows about the great Rangers-Islanders playoff battles of his childhood, about baseball’s Subway Series, and about the fits and starts of manufacturing an interborough N.B.A. rivalry.

headline: Fox Network Is Replacing Chief With Charlie Collier of AMC
abstract: Gary Newman, a co-chief executive of the Fox Television Group, had been expected to stay in charge, but wanted to leave in the spring. So the network acted now.
lead_paragraph: In a surprise move, Fox will turn to AMC’s president, Charlie Collier, to take over its broadcast network in several months, the company announced Friday.

headline: Italy’s Debt Rating Is Cut to One Level Above Junk
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: Moody’s downgrade followed the government’s decision to accept higher budget deficits, a move that prompted a sell-off in Italian 10-year bonds.
lead_paragraph: The rating on Italy’s debt was slashed on Friday by Moody’s Investors Service to one level above junk in a reaction to the Italian government’s decision to accept higher budget deficits in coming years.

headline: More Insulting Lies From Saudi Arabia
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'International Relations']
abstract: What we face now is a test for President Trump and America itself.
lead_paragraph: After lying for more than two weeks about the death of Jamal Khashoggi, the Saudi government has now announced a series of new lies about his murder in ways that insult both Jamal’s memory and our intelligence.

headline: The Curse of Affirmative Action
keywords: ['AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Asian-Americans']
abstract: A lawsuit challenges Harvard’s betrayal of “Veritas.”
lead_paragraph: Of all the names I’ve been called in life, including the usual anti-Semitic slurs, none has more sting than “affirmative action hire.”

headline: The End of a Once Mighty, Still Deadly Industry: the Canada Letter
abstract: Until recently, Canada fought efforts to ban asbestos. This week it joined much of the world in doing so. But the deadly legacy remains.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s positions on issues like same-sex marriage, immigration and, most recently, recreational marijuana have given it a reputation for progressiveness. But the government’s announcement this week that it was banning asbestos, a potent cause of cancer, came decades after many other nations took the step.

headline: Quotation of the Day: $2.5 Billion in Storm Losses, but Don’t Ask Georgia Farmers About Climate Change
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 20, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve always had bad weather. Is it getting worse? Have we had three bad years in a row? Yeah. But I’m worried about the weather, not about climate change.”

headline: Corrections: October 20, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, October 20, 2018.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Relatives of Tails
abstract: Ben Gross and James Somers throw something for everyone into their debut puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — How often do we get a pairs debut? I couldn’t find this statistic. It’s nice to take on a new venture with a trusty companion, like knowing that you have someone to talk to at a holiday party (not that this sort of thing is on my mind these days).

headline: In Break With U.S. Intelligence, Trump Says Saudi Explanation of Journalist’s Death Is Credible
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The president’s response sets up a clash with Congress, where Republicans and Democrats both tarred the Saudi explanation as lacking credibility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump broke with his own intelligence agencies on Friday, appearing to accept Saudi Arabia’s explanation that the journalist Jamal Khashoggi was killed by accident during a fistfight, while the United States’ spy agencies are increasingly convinced that he was assassinated on high-level orders from the Saudi royal court.

headline: Brewers Come Alive at the Plate, Forcing the Dodgers to Game 7
abstract: Milwaukee took a big early lead in front of a raucous home crowd, which will root Saturday for the Brewers to advance to the World Series for the first time since 1982.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Jesus Aguilar violently slammed his arms against his legs. Mike Moustakas waved his hands toward the dugout. Erik Kratz signaled toward the crowd. Ryan Braun screamed as he held his arms in the air, as if thanking the heavens.

headline: Remains of 63 Fetuses and Infants Found at Second Detroit Funeral Home
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The discovery came amid a widening investigation one week after similar remains were discovered at another funeral home in the city.
lead_paragraph: The remains of 63 infants or fetuses were found at a funeral home in Detroit on Friday, the Detroit Police Department said.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘My Dinner with Hervé’ and ‘The Illusionist’
abstract: Peter Dinklage stars in the new HBO drama “My Dinner with Hervé.” And “The Illusionist” arrives on Amazon Prime.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dinklage stars in the new HBO drama “My Dinner with Hervé.” And “The Illusionist” arrives on Amazon Prime.

headline: Playing Up Support Among Hispanic Voters, Trump Takes Aim at Immigration Laws
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The president toggled between distortions of the existing immigration system and the inflammatory language of his 2016 campaign at a rally on Friday in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — President Trump blasted immigration laws and border security at a boisterous rally here on Friday, all while playing up his support among Hispanic voters.

headline: Mount Athos, a Male-Only Holy Retreat, Is Ruffled by Tourists and Russia
keywords: ['Monasteries and Monks', 'Russian Orthodox Church', 'Byzantine Civilization', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The monks on an isolated peninsula in Greece have followed the same way of life for more than 1,000 years, but an Athens vs. Moscow diplomatic spat and a tourism onslaught are unsettling its habits.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT ATHOS, Greece — The skulls, lined up five deep on wooden shelves, date back hundreds of years, with the names of the more recently deceased scratched onto their foreheads — Monk Theolothelis, 91, 26-6-1986, or Monk Kyprianos, 100, 14-8-87.

headline: Afghanistan Votes for Parliament Under Shadow of Taliban Violence
abstract: The parliamentary vote was delayed for three years by political and security troubles. Both continued on Saturday, with logistical problems and many Taliban attacks.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Voting under threat of Taliban violence, Afghans across the country cast ballots in parliamentary elections held during one of the most fragile moments in 17 years of the war.

headline: Wentworth Defeat Pushes Australia’s Prime Minister Into Minority Government
abstract: Voters in a Sydney district chose an independent candidate over contenders from the major parties for the seat former Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull had held.
lead_paragraph: [Sign up for the Australia Letter to get news, conversation starters and local recommendations in your inbox each week.]

headline: Advice From Health Care’s Power Users
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Doctors']
abstract: When you’re sick, the health care system can be scary and confusing. But in a recent survey, seriously ill Americans shared some hard-won wisdom.
lead_paragraph: If the health care system seems confusing to you, you are not alone. In a large recent survey of the most seriously ill people in America, we learned that they, too, find it difficult to navigate. But they have developed a few strategies for getting through. Here are some tips and pitfalls about how to be sick from a group with lived experience.

headline: How the Blockchain Could Break Big Tech’s Hold on A.I.
abstract: Several start-ups hope to use the technology introduced by Bitcoin to give broader access to the data and algorithms behind artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Pairing artificial intelligence and the blockchain might be what you would expect from a scammer looking to make a quick buck in 2018.

headline: Gillibrand’s (Lack of) Spending in 2018 Offers Hints of 2020
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Senator Kristen Gillibrand, a Democrat from New York, maintains that she is solely focused on her re-election. But her trips and campaign spending suggest otherwise.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — The last time that Senator Kirsten Gillibrand was on the ballot for re-election, she poured $8 million into a summer television-advertising spree en route to a landslide victory.

headline: This is the front line of Saudi Arabia’s invisible war
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Hospitals', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The Khashoggi crisis has called attention to a largely overlooked Saudi-led war in Yemen. On a rare trip to the front line, we found Yemenis fighting and dying in a war that has gone nowhere.
lead_paragraph: The Khashoggi crisis has called attention to a largely overlooked Saudi-led war in Yemen. On a rare trip to the front line, we found Yemenis fighting and dying in a war that has gone nowhere.

headline: If My Co-Op Neighbor Has Basil on Our Common Roof, Then I Want Some
abstract: The roof belongs to all the shareholders, but there are limits to how you can use a common area.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a 120-unit, prewar co-op building on the Upper West Side with a roof deck shared by all residents. Someone has a very large basil plant, which has been there for years. It now has a sign on it stating, “Do not cut, plant belongs to …,” with the apartment number listed. If the roof space is shared, shouldn’t the basil plant be shared, too?

headline: Republicans Find a Facebook Workaround: Their Own Apps
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Conservative political apps deliver curated partisan messages, free from the strictures and content guidelines imposed by Silicon Valley giants.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a society in which everyone more or less agrees with you.

headline: Election 2018 Digital Misinformation Roundup
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections']
abstract: The midterm elections are 17 days away. Here is a collection of coverage from The New York Times and elsewhere on efforts to mislead voters on social media and the wider internet.
lead_paragraph: As Election Day draws near, a growing amount of disinformation is getting published online to confuse, inflame or distract potential voters.

headline: Hotel Review: In Washington, a Design-Driven Newcomer Spices Things Up
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The Line DC, in a repurposed 110-year-old church, has all-day cafes, happening bars and even its own radio station.
lead_paragraph: From $268 a night including Wi-Fi.

headline: Dance Like Everybody’s Dancing Like No One’s Watching
abstract: A judgment-free look back at Mister Sunday, a generous, open-air party (with nonstop house music) on the border of Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: For hundreds of hipsters, and mothers and fathers and toddlers and grandparents, the trek to Nowadays has been almost a weekly migration on the L train to Halsey Street, where they packed the outdoor space all summer for the Mister Sunday party.

headline: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
abstract: The man behind the news: Jamal Khashoggi. Let Melissa McCarthy and Tiffany Haddish cheer you up. Read some tiny love stories. Spend 24 hours in America. And more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the weekend. It’s finally fallish (at least in New York). With the chill comes one more cup of coffee, one more layer of clothing and maybe a bit more time to read some great journalism.

headline: O.M.G. Look at That Dog!
abstract: At the Groom Expo, the world’s largest creative grooming industry event, held in Hershey, Pa., dogs are every color of the rainbow. But the practice is not without its critics.
lead_paragraph: At the Groom Expo there are poodles everywhere: poodles dyed a kaleidoscope of colors, poodles with tribal designs shaved into their fur, a poodle that is shaved and dyed to look like a reindeer with a fawn carved into its side, a poodle whose hair is dyed in the shape of Tweety of “Looney Tunes,” a “Seasons Greetings” poodle dyed to look like a jack-o’-lantern on one leg and Santa on another.

headline: Venture Capitalist: A.I. Hype Still “Has a Ways to Go Up”
abstract: Anna Patterson, a former senior engineer at Google, has looked at all sorts of start-ups working on A.I. Some have great ideas, and some go too far.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Google has likened artificial intelligence to fire — a powerful breakthrough that is full of risks.

headline: On Politics: The Biggest Stories of the Week
abstract: Here are the stories that dominated the news in American politics.
lead_paragraph: From the killing of a Washington Post columnist to developments in the midterm elections, it’s been a busy week in American politics. Here are some of the biggest stories you might have missed (and some links if you want to read further).

headline: The Sound of ‘Housewives’ Everywhere
abstract: Behind the scenes with the men who make America’s favorite “ladies” into drama queens.
lead_paragraph: On the wall of Russell Howard’s home studio in Marina del Rey, Calif., hangs a plaque from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers commending him for having altered the bedrock of the entertainment landscape by planting, through his company Signature Tracks, more music on American television than almost anybody else in 2016.

headline: Remembering the Marvelous, Maddening Mario Buatta
abstract: Under all that colorful chintz there were some serious dust bunnies, but also a lot of laughs.
lead_paragraph: When Mario Buatta drew his last breath at 9:12 p.m. on Oct. 15 at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, the celebrated interior designer, 82, known for his exuberantly colorful work, riotous persona and matching sobriquet, the Prince of Chintz, seemed at peace.

headline: Kiernan Shipka Gets a Tarot Card Reading. It’s Mostly Good News.
abstract: The former “Mad Men” child actor plays a teenage witch in Netflix’s “The Chilling Adventures of Sabrina.”
lead_paragraph: “I worry a lot,” said the actress Kiernan Shipka, with a nervous laugh. “I’m a catastrophizer by nature.”

headline: Notes on Global Convergence (Wonkish and Off-Point)
abstract: Why rich countries stay different and middle-income countries surge.
lead_paragraph: For readers obsessed with the Trumpification of America and the looming election, I’m with you — I try not to check FiveThirtyEight more than five times a day, but it’s hard. If you can’t bear to think about anything else, don’t read this; rest assured that this blog post isn’t coming at the expense of writing about the core issue of the moment, it’s a rest break, a bit of vacation in the head.

headline: Back When Sears Made Black Customers a Priority
abstract: In this week’s Race/Related, an interview about Jim Crow capitalism and Sears.
lead_paragraph: Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.

headline: Differences Aside, Bipartisan Love in Washington
abstract: The couple met during a congressional delegation to Bahrain. Then they were unexpectedly seated next to each other on the flight home.
lead_paragraph: Katherina Dimenstein and Michael Timothy Berman were married Oct. 20 at Succotash, a restaurant in Washington. Adam Reny, a Universal Life minister, officiated, with Kelsey Spooner assisting. Both are friends of the couple.

headline: A Celebration Uniting Past, Present and Future (Mom Predicted It)
abstract: Theirs was the first Jewish wedding celebration since the Holocaust at Mad Synagogue in the Tokaj region of Hungary.
lead_paragraph: Viktoria Bedö and Jonah Chaim Fisher were married Oct. 18 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member of the New York City Clerk’s Office, officiated.

headline: When Jackie Married Ari: How We Reported the Wedding of the Decade
abstract: 50 years ago, the queen of Camelot wed a Greek tycoon. The Times had an inside source at a ceremony that was off limits to the press. But that wasn’t our only scoop.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: What Big Pharma Fears Most: A Trump Alliance With Democrats to Cut Drug Prices
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With Democrats seen as likely to retake the House, drug makers are quietly making contingency plans to fend off proposals that would squeeze their profits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The pharmaceutical industry, pilloried by President Trump for the last two years, is war-gaming for the possibility that its worst fear is realized: that Democrats, if they flip control of the House, find common ground with the president to rein in drug prices.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Ohio’s 1st District, Chabot vs. Pureval
abstract: This gerrymandered district includes most of the city of Cincinnati, and stretches out to conservative exurbs to ensure a Republican-lean.
lead_paragraph: This gerrymandered district includes most of the city of Cincinnati, and stretches out to conservative exurbs to ensure a Republican-lean.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Illinois’s 6th District, Roskam vs. Casten
abstract: Illinois’s Sixth is emblematic of a type of district that could decide control of the House: a well-educated suburb that voted for Hillary Clinton but that usually votes Republican and has a strong incumbent against a political newcomer.
lead_paragraph: Illinois’s Sixth is emblematic of a type of district that could decide control of the House: a well-educated suburb that voted for Hillary Clinton but that usually votes Republican and has a strong incumbent against a political newcomer.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: New Mexico’s 2nd District, Herrell vs. Torres Small
abstract: This district covers the entire southern half of the state, and has voted Republican in the last three presidential elections. Unlike many rural districts, this one is majority Hispanic. The winner will be the first woman to represent the district since its creation in 1969.
lead_paragraph: This district covers the entire southern half of the state, and has voted Republican in the last three presidential elections. Unlike many rural districts, this one is majority Hispanic. The winner will be the first woman to represent the district since its creation in 1969.

headline: Saudi Journalist Jamal Khashoggi Was Killed While in Exile. These Books Explain the Country He Left.
abstract: Books on Saudi Arabian history and politics shed light on the Saud family’s reign.
lead_paragraph: As the world waits for answers about Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi’s disappearance, we asked our international correspondent David Kirkpatrick, who wrote “Into the Hands of the Soldiers: Freedom and Chaos in Egypt and the Middle East,” to suggest three books to help us understand Saudi Arabia and United States relations with that country. Here are his recommendations.

headline: ‘People’s Vote’ March on Brexit Draws Thousands to Streets of London
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Demonstrators are demanding a new referendum on Britain’s exit from the European Union, though Prime Minister Theresa May has rejected the idea.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thousands of Britons took to the streets of Central London on Saturday for a “People’s Vote” march, demanding that the government call a new referendum on Britain’s exit from the European Union.

headline: 10 Recipes Readers Love
abstract: Make farro with mushrooms, beef barley soup, and more.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, make roasted cauliflower with feta (above), Melissa Clark’s beef barley soup with lemon, Sam Sifton’s apple pie or any of the top dishes of the week. Click the “10 Most Popular Recipes” collection below for more recipes.

headline: Immune-Based Treatment Helps Fight Aggressive Breast Cancer, Study Finds
abstract: Combining immunotherapy and chemotherapy can help women with an aggressive type of breast cancer and should become their new standard of care.
lead_paragraph: Women with an aggressive type of breast cancer lived longer if they received immunotherapy plus chemotherapy, rather than chemo alone, a major study has found.

headline: Mega Millions Results: No Winning Numbers and a Record $1.6 Billion Jackpot
abstract: If you didn’t win on Friday, you are in good company. Nobody else won either. Now the jackpot is the largest ever.
lead_paragraph: Did you end up with a losing Mega Millions ticket on Friday? If so, take heart: Nobody else won the jackpot either. That means the top prize has now risen to an estimated $1.6 billion.

headline: For Those About to Rock, an Uncertain Fate
abstract: Is rock music in 2018 a sound, a mood or a retail category? Where do Twenty One Pilots, the 1975 and Greta Van Fleet fit in?
lead_paragraph: Rock music is far from the center of the pop music zeitgeist in 2018, but it’s possible that the state of pop music — or at least, the industry of pop music — demands rock stars, and even rock “bands,” while not worrying much about whether the music slotted into those categories would be recognizable as rock to fans of one or two generations ago.

headline: How Sears Helped Oppose Jim Crow
abstract: For black Southerners in 1900, shopping locally meant enduring indignities and implicit threats. Enter the catalog.
lead_paragraph: Every year I give a lecture on the history of retail in which Sears, central to American shopping for a century, plays a starring role. On Monday, when Sears filed for bankruptcy protection, I got a little wistful — not because I was particularly attached to the company, but because of the largely unsung role of its iconic catalog in helping African-Americans evade the injustices and humiliations of the Jim Crow era.

headline: Has the N.C.A.A.’s ‘Student-Athlete’ Fiction Reached Its Logical End?
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)', 'Basketball', 'Draft and Recruitment (Sports)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A federal trial is telling an important story about the buying and selling of young basketball prospects.
lead_paragraph: When I was a young reporter in Philadelphia, I covered the trial of a mobster by the name of Harry (The Hunchback) Riccobene, a tiny man who was then in the twilight of his long criminal career and facing new charges that could send him back to prison, where he had already spent much of his adult life. Early in the proceedings, I approached him in a corridor during a break and asked if he was nervous. He wasn’t. “What’s the expression?” he said to me. “My record speaks for itself.”

headline: Stacey Abrams Hopes Medicaid Expansion Can Be a Winning Issue in Rural Georgia
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Politics and Government', 'Medicaid', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Rural Areas', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: By framing expansion as a pragmatic business move, Ms. Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor, is hoping to siphon some traditionally Republican rural votes.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For the upscale urban audience at a campaign town hall here, it would have been enough for Stacey Abrams to pitch Medicaid expansion as a moral issue — the health-care-as-human-right argument that appeals to progressives everywhere.

headline: Sweden Indicts Woman Who Tried to Block Afghan Man’s Deportation on Flight
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Deportation']
abstract: Prosecutors said Elin Ersson had violated the Swedish aviation act by remaining standing on takeoff. But she vowed to continue her campaign.
lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Swedish prosecutors have indicted a woman who in July staged a standoff to prevent the deportation of a rejected asylum seeker to Afghanistan by refusing to take her seat on the flight.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Richard Silvestri tries to feed us some wisdom in today’s cryptic.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The cryptic crossword is Eurocentric and highbrow. I found an interesting article about the mental approach a solver must take, and it’s really impressive. So take a crack at it. If you’re completely new to the genre, Deb recommends this guide.

headline: Brewers’ Ryan Braun Still Holds a Special Place in Milwaukee’s Heart
abstract: Braun’s career hit rock bottom in 2013, and at 34, he is no longer the superstar. But Milwaukee has been forgiving, and the longtime favorite has found his hitting stroke.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Ryan Braun woke up energized before the opener of the Milwaukee Brewers’ final road series in the regular season. He was in St. Louis, home of the Cardinals, the team that always seems to block the Brewers from glory. The Brewers, at the time, held the top wild-card spot in the National League. But the Cardinals could overtake them with a sweep.

headline: Tuning Out Critics, the Red Sox Sing Their Own Praises
abstract: The most criticized and doubted 108-win team in baseball history has gotten it together ahead of the World Series, which begins on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As the Red Sox sprayed Champagne and beer across the visitors’ clubhouse here Thursday night, they also began showering one another with praise.

headline: Mexico’s President-Elect Rethinks His Campaign Promises
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Missing Persons']
abstract: Faced with the reality of a limited budget and soaring crime, Andrés Manuel López Obrador is scaling back campaign commitments — even before taking office.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Winning Mexico’s presidency this summer did not slow down Andrés Manuel López Obrador: Three months into his transition, he is traveling across the country to thank voters, replay his campaign promises and pledge, “I will not fail you.”

headline: Saudis’ Image Makers: A Troll Army and a Twitter Insider
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Social Media', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy']
abstract: The kingdom silences dissent online by sending operatives to swarm critics. It also recruited a Twitter employee suspected of spying on users, interviews show.
lead_paragraph: Each morning, Jamal Khashoggi would check his phone to discover what fresh hell had been unleashed while he was sleeping.

headline: Saudi Explanation of Jamal Khashoggi’s Killing Fails to Squelch Skepticism
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States International Relations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: As doubts swirled about the Saudi account that the dissident journalist was strangled during a fight, an explanation emerged about the presence of a doctor of forensic medicine at the killing.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia’s explanation on Saturday only added to the international uproar over the killing of the dissident Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul. President Trump appeared to step back from an earlier expression of confidence in this new description of events that Mr. Khashoggi was strangled after a fistfight — skeptics focused on apparent gaps in the narrative and Turkey threatened to undermine the already shaky Saudi account with its own rival investigation.

headline: A Saudi Prince’s Fairy Tale
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, issues another incredible explanation for the death of Jamal Khashoggi.
lead_paragraph: The question now is not whether the Saudis’ latest explanation for Jamal Khashoggi’s death is credible, but whom do they think they’re fooling. In the autocratic world of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, what common people think is irrelevant; what matters is whether throwing his hit men under the bus is enough to satisfy President Trump.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Struggling in Key Battlegrounds, With House at Stake
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, Governors', 'States (US)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Party leaders worry that candidates for governor and Senate are in trouble in Michigan, Illinois, Minnesota, Pennsylvania and possibly Wisconsin, and that difficulties could spill into House races.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Republican leaders are increasingly worried that their candidates for governor and Senate are in political trouble across Michigan, Pennsylvania, Minnesota and other states that the party prizes, and that the difficulties could spill into House races that the G.O.P. needs to win in November to keep control of the chamber.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Moscow officials have abruptly withdrawn permission for the annual commemoration of the victims of Stalinist repression that has been held at a memorial stone near the headquarters of the Russian intelligence services since 2007.

headline: Misery ‘Every Day, Every Hour’ in Syrian Camp. And Now, It’s Grown Critical.
abstract: The humanitarian situation for some 50,000 Syrians at a camp for the displaced near the Jordanian border has deteriorated, and aid agencies warn it has reached a critical level.
lead_paragraph: In a stretch of desert in southern Syria on the border with Jordan, a sandstorm battered the shelters of some 50,000 displaced people in a makeshift camp already running low on food, clean water and medical care.
