headline: Tapping Into the Feminine Wild (With Help From Simone de Beauvoir)
abstract: The contemporary choreographer Carrie Ahern uses “The Second Sex” as a jumping-off point for her “Sex Status 2.0.”
lead_paragraph: Carrie Ahern isn’t one of those contemporary choreographers who makes a dance and moves on. She really digs her heels into a piece and before you know it, she’s created a multiyear project — like her investigation into modern death, for which she learned how to hunt and butcher and slaughter animals. She performed the first part in a butcher shop.

headline: Intersex, and Erased Again
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Intersex', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'ANATOMY AND PHYSIOLOGY', 'Gender', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Where does the Trump administration’s broadside against transgender rights leave people like me?
lead_paragraph: Imagine knowing that every aspect of your physiology, from your height to your cup size, was chosen off a menu — not by nature but by doctors and family members.

headline: How an Abandoned Hotel Became a Witches’ Lair for ‘Suspiria’
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Nineteen Hundred Seventies', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Luca Guadagnino’s latest film takes place in a fictional dance academy in 1970s Berlin, constructed within the dilapidated interiors of a 1912 Italian retreat.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, the last paying guests of the 200-room Grand Hotel Campo dei Fiori in Varese, Italy, checked out. Since then, the property — a once-glamorous Art Nouveau retreat perched atop a hard-to-reach wooded Alpine foothill — has remained largely vacant, home only to caretakers and their families. The brightly painted walls have faded and peeled; sections of the ceiling have collapsed; the furniture, much of it left in place, has gathered dust. It was for exactly these reasons that the director Luca Guadagnino was determined to film “Suspiria,” his reimagining of Dario Argento’s 1977 horror classic, on the property.

headline: Southern Barbecue With a Fiery Dip and a Deep History
abstract: In a narrow swath of Kentucky and Tennessee, the specialty is a pork-shoulder steak, grilled and dunked in a tongue-torturing hot sauce.

headline: Review: ‘Bodyguard’ on Netflix, Britain’s Biggest TV Hit in Years
abstract: A complicated thriller about a policeman assigned to protect a politician was the highest-rated British drama since the second season of “Downton Abbey.”
lead_paragraph: The British writer Jed Mercurio builds television shows the way the Cenobites build puzzle boxes in the “Hellraiser” movies. Get too close to one, and its intricate mechanism shoots its hooks into you, pulling you through a portal into a gyre of suspense from which there’s no escape.

headline: At 95, Ned Rorem Is Done Composing. But He’s Not Done Living.
abstract: As the composer, writer and gay icon lives quietly on the Upper West Side, his music and books warrant reconsideration.
lead_paragraph: “I know everything,” the composer Ned Rorem said on a recent afternoon, “but I remember nothing.”

headline: How The New York Times Covered the 1916 World Series
abstract: “The Superbas, pride of Brooklyn and of the National League, and the carmine-hosed Boston warriors scrambled for the petals of the first blossom.”
lead_paragraph: The only other time the Red Sox and Dodgers franchises faced off in the World Series, things were a little different. The Red Sox opted to play their home games at Braves Field rather than the smaller Fenway to make some extra admission money. The Dodgers were known as the Robins, or sometimes the Superbas. And they played in Brooklyn. The event was lowercase and had an apostrophe: “world’s series.”

headline: How the Illinois Governor’s Race Turned Into One of the Most Expensive in the Country
abstract: J.B. Pritzker, the billionaire Hyatt Hotel heir, has put in about $162 million of his own money to take on the incumbent, Bruce Rauner, a Republican multimillionaire.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In a political climate in which invective and vitriol have become the norm, the race to become governor of Illinois still sticks out for its rancor. But the bitter tenor and record-shattering money being spent here by two ultra-wealthy men have little to do with the political turbulence in Washington.

headline: Trump Is Not Going to Cut Middle-Class Taxes This Year, Despite What He Says

headline: Pomona Opens, Serving Inventive American Fare
abstract: A modern cocktail and wine bar in Harlem, a Milanese bakery in Midtown, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Michael Vignola, who was the original executive chef at Henry at Life Hotel, and Rachid Abdelouahad, who was director of operations at Strip House and Blue Water Grill, among others, have joined forces to move into the underground space that was the clubby Beautique for a few years. The Midtown location was also at one point Shezan, a chic Indian restaurant designed by the architect Charles Gwathmey. There’s no trace of it in Jason Henning’s design, which includes butterscotch leather banquettes, polished wood in amber tones, lanternlike lights and several archways. This time around, there will be a tiny lounge area on the street level. Downstairs, there’s a bar, main dining room, a smaller room with tile flooring, and an even smaller private room. To the rear, past the bar and through the kitchen, is a lounge. Mr. Vignola is serving inventive American fare like foie gras sliders, potato and mackerel terrine, slow-cooked halibut, rib-eye for two cooked two ways, and a duck burger. The restaurant is named for a Roman goddess of abundance. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Florida Governor, DeSantis vs. Gillum
abstract: The day after Mr. DeSantis won the Republican primary, he said voters should not “monkey this up” by electing Mr. Gillum. Mr. Gillum, who is black, said, “In the handbook of Donald Trump, they no longer do whistle calls — they’re now using full bullhorns.”

headline: In ‘A Star Is Born,’ Equality Is Deadly
abstract: Bradley Cooper, in the third remake of the movie, tells a story of men, women and male sacrifice that has been portrayed over and over.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Oct. 5, after a bitter national debate about men, women and sexual assault, the Senate voted to advance the nomination of Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. That day was also the one-year anniversary of the New York Times article that helped topple Harvey Weinstein, igniting a sustained, worldwide storm over men, women and abuse. Here’s what else happened that day: The latest version of “A Star Is Born” opened, wowing critics and audiences with yet another, more palatable story about men, women, the power of a woman’s voice and the drama of a man’s sacrifice.

headline: Coming of Age on Horseback
abstract: In the sport of equestrian vaulting, even a 12-year-old girl can be “too big.”
lead_paragraph: As filmmakers, we have always been interested in the theme of maturation and have long sought to portray the process authentically through film. Coming-of-age is a highly visual subject: You can tell a story about it without unnecessary words, focusing instead on image and sound. In this film, we found a story line where we could bring our assumptions onto the screen while also connecting to our childhood experiences.

headline: Read These 3 Books on Trans Rights and Gender Identity

lead_paragraph: A proposal by the Department of Health and Human Services argues for a more narrow definition of gender that would threaten protections of the transgender community under federal civil rights law. These three books by trans writers explore the historical precedent for nonbinary gender expression and the personal experience of being transgender.

headline: Gertrude Mokotoff, Ex-Mayor and a Bride at 98, Is Dead at 100
abstract: A Vows article in The Times about her wedding to Alvin Mann, then 94, drew a wide readership. They had met at the gym.
lead_paragraph: Gertrude Mokotoff, who was 71 when she became the first female mayor of Middletown, N.Y., and then drew even wider attention more than a quarter of a century later by marrying a 94-year-old man when she was 98, died on Oct. 17 at a hospital in that city. She was 100.

keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Italian Language', 'News and News Media', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']

lead_paragraph: In the weeks after the murder of Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in Istanbul, a question has been repeatedly asked: How could the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, be so reckless as to sanction this horrifying murder carried out in such a clumsy and shameless fashion?

headline: In New Volume of Sylvia Plath’s Letters, a Marriage Falters and Masks Fall Away
abstract: In this correspondence, written between 1956 and 1963, ending a week before Plath’s death, at 30, we see goals triumphantly and tragically fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, a plaque was mounted outside a lavender-painted house in northwest London, commemorating the time when Sylvia Plath had lived and worked there. Plath’s daughter, Frieda Hughes, presided over the unveiling at the home she had only briefly known (she was born in the bedroom). She was stunned by its size. The kitchen was two paces long. The bedroom was so small, she said, “It wasn’t possible to swing a gerbil.”

headline: Museum of Bible Removes Dead Sea Scrolls It Suspects Are Fake
abstract: Five fragments once associated with the famous scrolls were shown to have “characteristics inconsistent with ancient origin” according to a statement from the museum in Washington this week.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of the Bible in Washington has removed five Dead Sea Scroll fragments from its exhibit this week after testing raised suspicions about their authenticity.

headline: Two Weeks Before Midterms, Transgender People Feel Like ‘Pawns’
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: With elections near, many transgender people were unsurprised to come under attack by the Trump administration, which has rolled back L.B.G.T. rights.
lead_paragraph: When the news broke on Sunday morning, many transgender people, world-weary, saw it as grimly predictable: With two weeks to go until the midterm elections, the Trump administration was considering a new move that would undermine federal civil rights protections for the transgender community. This time, they thought, it was the nuclear option.

headline: Some Viewers Think Netflix Is Targeting Them by Race. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The users say that the site’s promotional images can look like racial targeting. Netflix says it doesn’t know its users’ demographic information.
lead_paragraph: It’s not exactly news that different Netflix users see different images when they scroll through the streaming service’s titles. In a June article from New York magazine, Todd Yellin, Netflix’s vice president of product, described how the company offered over a dozen posters — or “row art” — for its women’s wrestling series “GLOW.” One poster shows a picture of two cats fighting; another features an image of the show’s principal male lead, Marc Maron; another depicts Alison Brie and Betty Gilpin, duking it out in the ring.

headline: Todd Bol, Creator of Little Free Library Movement, Dies at 62
abstract: He built a wooden box, filled it with books and stuck it in his front yard; today there are more than 75,000 like it in 88 countries, run under the honor system.

headline: ‘Use That Word!’: Trump Embraces the ‘Nationalist’ Label
abstract: The term is often freighted with the whiff of extremism when used domestically, but President Trump has enthusiastically doubled down on words and ideas that his predecessors shied away from.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a general rule, presidents do not refer to themselves as a “nationalist” given the freighted history of the word. But as President Trump tries to galvanize his conservative base to turn out in the midterm elections, he has adopted the label as a badge of honor.

abstract: President Trump described himself as a nationalist twice this week — a loaded term past presidents had avoided.
lead_paragraph: President Trump described himself as a nationalist twice this week — a loaded term past presidents had avoided.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Get Up. It’s O.K. I’m Right Here With You.’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring five reader-submitted stories of 100 words or fewer.
lead_paragraph: After five rounds of in vitro fertilization, my wife and I didn’t have the funds to be parents anymore. We cried all the time. Avoided Facebook. Held our dogs too tight. Watched baby elephant videos. To escape the wormhole of grief, we bought tickets to Prague we could barely afford. Our sadness flickered like a ghost. In Old Town, we smiled. Licked the rain from each other's lips. Kissed on Charles Bridge. Wrote graffiti declaring our love. Held hands on the tram. Ate soup that warmed our bones. We were not done with the world. — Jackson Bliss

Molinaro, devolved into a shouting match in which discussions about New York’s challenges were largely eclipsed by name-calling and aspersions about the other’s record.

headline: This Thermometer Tells Your Temperature, Then Tells Firms Where to Advertise
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Thermometers', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Home Appliances', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps', 'Consumer Protection', 'Privacy']
abstract: Clorox is using data from so-called smart thermometers to target ads to areas where people are sick. It’s the latest example of internet-connected devices being used for advertising.
lead_paragraph: Most of what we do — the websites we visit, the places we go, the TV shows we watch, the products we buy — has become fair game for advertisers. Now, thanks to internet-connected devices in the home like smart thermometers, ads we see may be determined by something even more personal: our health.

headline: Stephen Hawking’s Final Paper: How to Escape From a Black Hole
abstract: In a study from beyond the grave, the theoretical physicist sings (mathematically) of memory, loss and the possibility of data redemption.
lead_paragraph: The cosmologist and pop-science icon Stephen Hawking, who died last March on Einstein’s birthday, spoke out from the grave recently in the form of his last scientific paper. Appropriately for a man on the Other Side, the paper is about how to escape from a black hole.

headline: Eugene H. Peterson, 85, Scholar Turned Homespun Pastor, Dies
abstract: Mr. Peterson produced 30 books, including a wildly popular colloquial version of the Bible, and eschewed megachurches and televised preaching.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Eugene H. Peterson, a Presbyterian minister who challenged the mass marketing of Christian evangelism and wrote a shelf of books on religion — notably “The Message,” a series that recast the Bible into everyday English — died on Monday at his home in Lakeside, Mont. He was 85.

headline: Millions Have Voted Early in the Midterms. Here’s What That Means — and What It Doesn’t.

headline: When Sears Flourished, So Did Workers. At Amazon, It’s More Complicated.
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Executive Compensation', 'Personal Finances', 'Corporations', 'Income Inequality', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Profit-sharing plans for rank-and-file employees are vanishing as corporate America has adopted a new approach toward who reaps a healthy company’s gains.

headline: Tom Jago Dies at 93; in the Spirits Industry, a Maker of Best Sellers
abstract: His hand could be found in Baileys Irish Cream, Malibu Rum and Johnnie Walker Blue. He was so revered, Scotch lovers named him a Master of the Quaich.
lead_paragraph: Tom Jago, an inventive British liquor executive who was part of the team that developed Baileys Irish Cream and made it the world’s best-selling liqueur, and who later helped establish the Malibu Rum and Johnnie Walker Blue brands, died on Oct. 12 in London. He was 93.

headline: Hack of Saudi Petrochemical Plant Was Coordinated From Russian Institute
abstract: A major cybersecurity firm identified a government-run technical research institute in Moscow as the culprit, but left unanswered why Russians would target the plant.
lead_paragraph: A new study of the malicious computer code used in a botched attack on a Saudi petrochemical plant concludes that much of the effort was coordinated from inside a state-owned Russian scientific institute, one of the most direct links between official Russian hackers and a hostile intrusion on a major piece of infrastructure.

headline: Megyn Kelly Apologizes to NBC Colleagues Amid Storm Over ‘Blackface’ Remarks
abstract: While discussing how “the costume police are cracking down” this Halloween, the NBC morning host defended ways of dressing up that offend others.

headline: Getting Beyond Balls and Strikes
abstract: What do umpires and judges have in common? Not as much as some people think.
lead_paragraph: Three umpires walk into a bar. The World Series is on TV — Red Sox vs. Dodgers. The three umps have a few beers as they watch the game and discuss their philosophies of umpiring.

headline: The Best Way to Keep Democrats From Blowing This Election
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: The two biggest political thrusts of the Party of Trump — a tax cut for the rich that opened a tsunami of debt, and trying to take away health care from millions — are widely unpopular. It’s as simple as that.
lead_paragraph: We know that outrage has a minimal shelf life in the Trump era. Our president can give despots a license to kill, claim that climate change is going to magically reverse itself, make up nonexistent riots — and it all passes in a blur.

headline: Battling Dementia, Sandra Day O’Connor Leaves Public Life With Plea for Bipartisanship
abstract: Justice O’Connor, 88, was the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court. She wielded immense power and often found ways to bridge divides in a less polarized era.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first woman to serve on the Supreme Court was just 75, young by its standards, and still sharp and vigorous when she left. But she gave up the job she loved, along with extraordinary power, to guide and comfort her husband, who was struggling with Alzheimer’s disease.

It was directly in his path, close enough to reach out and touch, as he walked over to celebrate with the jubilant Juventus fans.

It entails moving defenders around like chess pieces, player evaluations based on launch angles and spin rates, and versatile rosters designed to provide a minute edge.

headline: 1918: Italian Workmen Jump Into American Shellhole
abstract: An escape from German capture led the two Italians to seek shelter in a forest, before braving shellfire to find refuge with U.S. soldiers.
lead_paragraph: (SPECIAL TELEGRAM TO THE HERALD.) From BURR PRICE. WITH THE AMERICAN ARMIES — Two Italians dropped into a shellhole in which several Americans were sleeping at daybreak yesterday and cried to the startled occupants in perfectly good Chicago steelworkers’ English: “Don’t shoot! We’ve just escaped from the German lines!”

headline: The Unreality of Racial Justice Cinema
keywords: ['Movies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: From “Black Panther” to “The Hate U Give,” new movies about the fight for black lives deliver powerful fantasies. But can they be truthful?
lead_paragraph: There never was an Officer Andy Landers, but, as conceived by Spike Lee, he’s crudely functional, a villain with a destiny as awful as it is seductive. In “BlacKkKlansman,” Lee’s summer hit based loosely on the true story of Ron Stallworth, a black police officer who infiltrated the Ku Klux Klan in Colorado in the 1970s, Landers is the cretin within, an unreformed racist among Stallworth’s own ranks.

headline: The Beastie Boys Put Down the Mic and Pick Up the Pen
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: After the death of Adam Yauch, Michael Diamond and Adam Horovitz worked to capture the groundbreaking group’s aesthetic and legacy on the page. Here’s how they did it.
lead_paragraph: The story begins — or maybe ends — with three guys in their early 50s hanging out on a beautiful late summer afternoon, drinking iced coffee and talking about how much they love the Clash, and how weird it is that the celebrity-clogged hotel where they’re sitting is just up the block from where CBGB was way back when. Dad stuff. Two of the dads, though, are the surviving members of the Beastie Boys: Adam Horovitz, with upswept gray hair and a white T-shirt with a faint graffito on the front; and Michael Diamond, wearing a bright red button-up, his hair still dark, his face creased and tan from years living in Southern California. Ad-Rock and Mike D, in other words.

headline: Living Beneath the Ground in an Australian Desert
abstract: For about a century, residents of Coober Pedy have escaped the searing heat by building their homes underground. Tamara Merino captured life beneath the earth.
lead_paragraph: The sandy red hills dotting the mining community of Coober Pedy stretch uninterrupted toward the horizon. “Ghost town” was what the Chilean photographer Tamara Merino first thought when she and her partner stopped in town to fix their van’s flat tire while crossing the vast Simpson Desert in South Australia.

headline: The Story of Amsterdam, Told Through Its Trash
abstract: During the construction of a new subway line, archaeologists discovered thousands of objects that reflect life in the city, from the Paleolithic era to the present day.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — The objects come as a surprise. In two display cases wedged between escalators in the Rokin metro station here, they emerge into view only as you travel up and down. Suddenly, thousands of fragments of the city’s past appear: vases, pipes, anchors, shards of china, buttons, human bones.

lead_paragraph: Kacey Musgraves took an LSD trip and returned with the concept for “Slow Burn,” a song that set the tone for her genre-bending country album. Using FaceTime interviews, demos and doodles, we show you how the track came together.

keywords: ['Men and Boys', '#MeToo Movement', 'Emotions', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Mentors', 'Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: Some pioneering programs are teaching boys to question gender roles, both for their own well-being and as a way to prevent sexual violence.
lead_paragraph: “In here, we get to say stuff we wouldn’t normally say in front of other people. And we don’t judge each other,” said a seventh grader with dark curls. “Boys should have a safe space to talk about things that matter to us,” said another seventh grader with a hint of a Canadian accent.

headline: Even a 10-Minute Walk May Be Good for the Brain
abstract: Ten minutes of mild exercise can immediately alter how certain parts of the brain communicate and coordinate with one another and improve memory function.
lead_paragraph: Ten minutes of mild, almost languorous exercise can immediately alter how certain parts of the brain communicate and coordinate with one another and improve memory function, according to an encouraging new neurological study. The findings suggest that exercise does not need to be prolonged or intense to benefit the brain and that the effects can begin far more quickly than many of us might expect.

headline: Five Places to Shop in Arusha, Tanzania
abstract: For in-the-know locals and travelers alike, the downtown area is a place to linger and shop in a city known as a quick layover to safari destinations.
lead_paragraph: This sprawling city in the northern tourist region of Tanzania is the gateway to popular safari destinations and Africa’s highest peak, Mt. Kilimanjaro. But even if your stay is a brief stopover, you shouldn’t miss some of the stores that locals enjoy in Arusha’s downtown, an area of mostly low-slung concrete buildings where street vendors hawk everything from local crafts and fruit to children’s toys. These establishments sell goods made exclusively in this East African country and show off a side of Tanzania that’s beyond its prime game viewing.

headline: Here’s Why a 50-Degree Day Feels Colder in Fall Than in Spring
abstract: Why might nippy temperatures now feel much more comfortable in just a few months? The body takes time to adapt to the cold.
lead_paragraph: That first cold spell of the season always feels especially harsh.

headline: I Defended the Pentagon in 1967, but I Was Torn Between Duty and Conscience
abstract: A veteran remembers the Vietnam War demonstrations at the Pentagon, where he stood guard with his unit but felt himself siding with the protesters.
lead_paragraph: October 1967 was a time of simmering hostilities in the United States on two momentous sociopolitical fronts: liberal civil rights activists were battling conservative segregationists, while at the same time antiwar protesters were mounting street demonstrations calling on President Lyndon B. Johnson’s administration to end the Vietnam War. From coast to coast, college-age demonstrators picked up the year’s most memorable chant: “Hey, hey, L.B.J., how many kids did you kill today?”

headline: In a Florida Swing District, an ‘Inconvenient’ Republican Holds On
abstract: Representative Carlos Curbelo is a perennial target for Democrats. His political fate might be an indicator of national trends in the 2018 midterms.
lead_paragraph: MARATHON, Fla. — If Representative Carlos Curbelo clings to his seat in Congress come November, defying the political odds for a moderate Republican in one of the nation’s most competitive districts, it will be in part because of people like Gary Graves, the owner of a Florida Keys seafood business. His spiny lobster catch has been hit with costly tariffs as part of the White House’s trade war with China, yet he supports President Trump, and Mr. Curbelo, anyway.

abstract: An unpretentious place with a vibrant downtown and miles of coastline, the village is also surprisingly diverse, thanks to a wide range of housing.

On Friday, they toured the property and made an offer. Over the weekend, knowing the market was competitive, they increased their bid twice. By Monday afternoon, despite 11 rival offers, the house was theirs.

headline: The Problem With Fixing WhatsApp? Human Nature Might Get in the Way
keywords: ['Instant Messaging', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections']

headline: Paradise Threatened: Fiji’s War Against Climate Change
abstract: The South Pacific nation faces major environmental challenges, from the destruction of coral reefs to rising sea levels. At least one resort is asking tourists to help.

It’s a route I took several times this spring when I visited friends in Suva, a bustling port city where cruise ships drop anchor year-round and deposit thousands of tourists.

headline: Cuomo-Molinaro Debate: 5 Takeaways

lead_paragraph: It finally happened: After days of back-and-forth over who was too afraid to face whom, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his Republican challenger, Marcus J. Molinaro, squared off on Tuesday in their first and likely only debate.

headline: The ‘Doctor Zhivago’ Nobel Dust-up
abstract: Sixty years ago, the Swedish Academy awarded the Russian author Boris Pasternak the Nobel Prize for Literature, but less than a week later, under pressure from the Soviet government, Pasternak rejected the award. The story, which had more twists and turns than a Cold War-era spy novel, played out in The New York Times with one front-page story after another.
lead_paragraph: The drumbeats started on Nov. 21, 1957, when the paper noted that Boris Pasternak’s epic novel, “Dr. Zhivago,” was about to hit stores in Italy over the protests of the Soviet government. The Soviets, who had allowed Pasternak to approach foreign publishers in a short-lived show of benevolence, quickly regretted their decision and tried to force the book’s Italian publisher into returning the manuscript for “revisions.” They demurred.

headline: ‘Zero Tolerance’ Immigration Policy Surprised Agencies, Report Finds
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Family Separation Policy (US Immigration)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The Homeland Security and Health and Human Services Departments were not given advance notice, leaving them unprepared for the thousands of family separations that followed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration did not tell key government agencies about its “zero tolerance” immigration policy before publicly announcing it in April, leaving the officials responsible for carrying it out unprepared to handle the resulting separations of thousands of children from their families, according to a government report released on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Bodyguard’ Was a Sensation in Britain. But Can It Conquer America?
abstract: The steamy thriller, the most popular television show in Britain in years, arrives on Netflix on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s been pretty grim in Britain over the last few months. Brexit, Brexit, Brexit. Newspaper headlines and social media keep telling us that the country has never been more divided. “Brexit preppers” are stockpiling food and medication. Half the cabinet is in a perennial state of officially outraged fury and imminent resignation. The beleaguered prime minister, Theresa May, keeps insisting there is a way forward.

headline: Do Not Double-Major
abstract: Having two college majors has become a fad. It’s not a good one.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: California Today: Dodgers Pursuing Their First Championship Since 1988
abstract: Wednesday: The Dodgers are down one game in the World Series, California loses more jobs to China than any other state, and the Neptune Pool at Hearst Castle reopens.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and CNN Offices Are Sent Pipe Bombs
abstract: The similar devices set off an intense investigation into whether a bomber is going after people who have often faced barbed right-wing criticism.

headline: A Bird’s-Eye View of the Bahamas
abstract: This property on the coast of Nassau, which has a two-story home and a private lighthouse, is on the market for $3.5 million.
lead_paragraph: This property on the coast of Nassau, which has a two-story home and a private lighthouse, is on the market for $3.5 million.

headline: House Hunting in … the Bahamas
abstract: Luxury prices are inching up in Nassau, thanks in part to foreign investors who see the island nation as a safe investment.
lead_paragraph: Solomon’s Lighthouse, a waterfront estate on the northeast shore of Nassau, in the Bahamas, takes its name from the private lighthouse on the property that offers panoramic views of Montagu Bay, the island of New Providence and the Atlantic Ocean. The estate also includes a 7,000-square-foot British Colonial-style house, a swimming pool and a recently renovated backyard area.

headline: A Rejuvenated Blake Griffin Scores 50 Points in Pistons’ Win
abstract: Griffin tied career highs in 3-pointers made (five) and attempted (10), and looked more like a point guard than a power forward at times in a victory over the Sixers.
lead_paragraph: Blake Griffin came tearing into the N.B.A. in 2010 after being the No. 1 overall draft pick in 2009 for the Clippers, earning five consecutive All-Star selections. In later years, he continued to score around 20 points a game, but began to be hampered by injuries, and the Clippers finally traded him to the Pistons last January. His days as an elite player seemed to be over.

headline: German Artists Who Blazed a Path Cut Short by War
abstract: Before their deaths on World War I battlefields, the painters Franz Marc and August Macke helped open the door to abstraction.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard not to leave “Franz Marc and August Macke: 1909-1914,” an alternately thrilling and dizzying exhibition on the artistic friendship of two important German painters, saddened by the tragic end of both men’s careers.

headline: Kerry Washington Has Something to Fear
abstract: Returning to Broadway after “Scandal,” the actress takes a role in “American Son” that’s a far cry from Olivia Pope, but that may be closer to who she is.
lead_paragraph: Kerry Washington shifted a bit on the cozy couch we were sharing in her dressing room at the Booth Theater, her eyes trained inquisitively on mine.

headline: Spinal Cord Repaired in the Womb, in First Surgery of its Kind in U.K.
keywords: ['Birth Defects', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Spina Bifida', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: A team of surgeons this summer successfully repaired the spinal cords to treat spina bifida in two babies before birth.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A team of surgeons has repaired the spinal cords of two babies while they were still in their mothers’ wombs, the first surgery of its kind in Britain.

headline: Private Equity’s Broadband Rush Is Riskier Than It Looks
abstract: It might take longer to recoup investments in fiber infrastructure than investors like Goldman Sachs and KKR hope.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Unite sweet and salty with a no-recipe recipe for French toast hash.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Steven Raichlen gave us a great story from Monroe County, Ky., this week, all about the pork-shoulder steaks they cook there over hickory embers, and dip in hot-pepper sauce. It’s barbecue that’s not really barbecue, and of course we have a recipe (above) that you can try out this weekend if you’re game. (We also got a good one for pickled eggs, using roughly the same sauce.) A grilled pork-shoulder steak dipped in hot-pepper sauce is one of life’s great pleasures. (Pickled eggs, same deal.)

headline: Goods Mart: A 7-Eleven for All You Organic People
abstract: Rachel Krupa, a publicist, wants to hit pause on the Amazon Dash button.
lead_paragraph: You’ve heard of conscious uncoupling. But a conscious convenience store?

headline: The Pope Doesn’t Understand China
abstract: Francis’s natural optimism about Communists is being encouraged by cynics around him who know better.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Last month the Vatican announced that it had come to a provisional agreement with the government of China over the appointment of Catholic bishops. Supporters of the deal say that it finally brings unity after longstanding division — between an underground Church loyal to the pope and an official church approved by the Chinese authorities — and that with it, the Chinese government has for the first time recognized the authority of the pope. In fact, the deal is a major step toward the annihilation of the real Church in China.

headline: XXXTentacion Discusses Abuse and Stabbings on Tape Released by Prosecutors
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Domestic Violence', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The rapper and singer, who was killed in June, had been facing charges of domestic battery and false imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: Before the popular rapper and singer XXXTentacion was shot and killed in Florida this summer, the 20-year-old musician had been on an accelerated track to mainstream success, with hit songs and albums that earned him a $10 million record deal for his next release.

headline: Cold, Windy, Gray Day? Heart Attack Risk Is High
abstract: People are more likely to have heart attacks when the weather is bad, Swedish researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: When the weather is bad, more people have heart attacks, Swedish researchers have found.

headline: ‘There’s a Black Man in the Children’s Area’ and Other Baseless Accusations
abstract: Readers share stories of themselves or friends and relatives deemed suspicious for simply walking around in their own skin.
lead_paragraph: In “To the Next ‘BBQ Becky’: Don’t Call 911. Call 1-844-WYT-FEAR,” Niecy Nash, the actress and comedian, uses a satirical infomercial to call attention to society’s “fear of the other,” specifically when white people call the police on black people who are just going about their business.

headline: For Two Architects, the Art They Own Is Entwined With Their Lives
abstract: The collection of Hilary Sample and Michael Meredith is like a visual autobiography. It’s also the first thing they see when they leave their office.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Sample and Michael Meredith, a married couple and the founders of MOS Architects, don’t think of the art on their walls as a collection, per se.

headline: How to Make Friends
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Friendship', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: If you’re in college, at work or somewhere in between, we’re here to help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Edit. Each week in our newsletter, you’ll hear from college students and recent graduates about issues going on in their lives. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Riverbank’s Cultural Center Renamed After $1 Million Gift
abstract: Robert F. Smith, Carnegie Hall’s chairman and the biggest donor to the National Museum of African American History and Culture, donated the money a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Smith initially preferred to keep this quiet. About a year ago, the businessman and philanthropist — who is chairman of Carnegie Hall and the largest donor to the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture — donated $1 million to the Cultural Performance Center at the Denny Farrell Riverbank State Park in Harlem.

headline: Alexander Soros: The Hate That Is Consuming Us
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: Bombs sent to my father, George Soros, and to former President Obama and Hillary Clinton are a result of our politics of demonizing opponents.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon an explosive device was delivered to my father’s home north of New York City. An alert member of our staff recognized the threat and called the police. Fortunately, the authorities were able to detonate the device safely. On Wednesday, the Secret Service said it had intercepted similar devices sent to the offices of former President Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.

headline: Even for Trump, There Is Such a Thing as Too Far
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: When children are being locked away, Republican attacks on immigrants will backfire.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, on the campaign trail and at home in the White House, President Trump has made it clear that attacking immigrants is the main thrust of his midterm message. In 2016, his anti-immigrant campaign resonated with his core supporters and it may well again in 2018, but this year more people have been turned off by the reality of his anti-immigrant politics. As a result, Mr. Trump’s vile strategy is more likely to backfire this time.

headline: Saudi Crown Prince Calls Khashoggi’s Death ‘Heinous’
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: It was the crown prince’s most public comment since the backlash over the Oct. 2 killing of the Saudi critic Jamal Khashoggi began roiling the kingdom.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The crown prince of Saudi Arabia on Wednesday denounced the “heinous crime” committed against Jamal Khashoggi, the dissident writer killed in Turkey. It was his most public attempt yet to separate himself from Saudi operatives suspected of the killing, who include some of the crown prince’s own aides.

headline: Brazil Prepares to Elect a Hypocrite
abstract: Some Brazilian conservatives see the presidential candidate Jair Bolsonaro as representative of everything they value. They should look closer.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — For a liberal woman like me, it’s hard to understand why anyone would vote for a presidential candidate who has been described by international publications as “racist, homophobic and sexist” (Libération), “a threat to democracy” (The Economist), a “Trump of the tropics” (The Guardian), “a xenophobe” (Clarín) and a sympathizer with “military dictatorships and torturers” who has “openly expressed fascist ideas” (Zeit).

headline: F.B.I. Arrests White Nationalist Leader Who Fled the Country for Central America
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Gangs', 'Charlottesville, Va, Violence (August, 2017)', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Robert Rundo is the founder of the Rise Above Movement, a violent California neo-Nazi gang. He and three other gang members were accused of inciting riots.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. arrested the leader of a violent California neo-Nazi gang on a federal conspiracy charge after he fled the country earlier this month.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Noah Purifoy’s first solo on the East Coast; Henning Christiansen’s first survey in America; Charles White’s “Truth and Beauty”; and Storm King’s climate-change show.
lead_paragraph: Through Nov. 3. Tilton Gallery, 8 East 76th Street, Manhattan; 212-737-221, jacktiltongallery.com.

headline: Review: Hilary Hahn Plays an Unabashedly Romantic Bach
abstract: The star violinist played her first-ever solo recital in New York on Tuesday, as part of Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival.
lead_paragraph: Encores have never been an afterthought for Hilary Hahn. In recent years, this brilliant violinist has commissioned 27 short solo pieces from as many composers to expand her stash of end-of-concert treats.

headline: Outrage Over a Handshake Between Khashoggi Son and the Crown Prince
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Saudi images of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman shaking the hand of a stone-faced Salah Khashoggi, whose father was killed in a Saudi consulate, stirred anger.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The image of the Saudi crown prince shaking the hand of a son of the slain journalist Jamal Khashoggi stoked outrage on social media on Wednesday as suspicions continue that the crown prince had a role in the killing.

headline: In the Studio With Farshad Farzankia
abstract: The Copenhagen-based artist, who was born in Tehran, makes bright figurative canvases that explore otherness and cultural identity.
lead_paragraph: The Copenhagen-based artist, who was born in Tehran, makes bright figurative canvases that explore otherness and cultural identity.

headline: The Artist Who Is Selling Out Shows Just Two Years After He Started Painting
abstract: Farshad Farzankia left his day job in 2016. Now, he’s putting the finishing touches on his first major U.S. solo show, which will open later this month.
lead_paragraph: At just past 10 on a late summer morning, the artist Farshad Farzankia is sitting at a desk in his sun-seeped studio on the outskirts of Copenhagen, wearing paint-splattered Vans and old track pants, like a ’90s skater kid now fully grown. Nursing a can of Coke and occasionally puffing on a hand-rolled cigarette, he doodles on a sheet of printer paper. Stacked against the walls are the large hypersaturated canvases that consume his days (and often nights, hence the early soda fix).

headline: Review: ‘Deutschland 86,’ an East-West Thriller, Looks South
abstract: In the pulpy follow-up to “Deutschland 83,” the Cold War comes to Africa, but spying remains a family affair.
lead_paragraph: You may find the scheme at the center of “Deutschland 86” a bit confusing. That’s all right; so does Martin Rauch (Jonas Nay), the reluctant East German spy roped into carrying it out.

headline: Dean Skelos, Ex-New York Senate Leader, Gets 4 Years and 3 Months in Prison
abstract: Mr. Skelos and his son, Adam, had been retried after their earlier convictions for corruption were overturned on appeal.
lead_paragraph: Dean G. Skelos, the former New York State Senate majority leader who wielded sweeping power in the Legislature for nearly a decade, was sentenced to four years and three months in prison on Wednesday for a corruption scheme involving his son.

headline: In Two New Books, Unhappy Conservatives Ask: What Now?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: In “The Corrosion of Conservatism,” lifelong Republican Max Boot says the party needs to be “burned to the ground.” In “Them,” Sen. Ben Sasse says the country’s problems go “deeper” than politics.
lead_paragraph: To hear Max Boot tell it, he feels as forlorn as the despondent, battered elephant on the cover of his new book, “The Corrosion of Conservatism: Why I Left the Right.” Boot minutely describes a disillusionment that wasn’t only “painful and prolonged” but “existential.” Here he is — a lifelong Republican with sterling neoconservative credentials (an enthusiastic supporter of the Iraq War and a champion of “American empire”) — explaining why he’s eager for the day when “the G.O.P. as currently constituted is burned to the ground.”

headline: 6 Attention-Getting Off Broadway Shows Are Back for Encores
abstract: Return engagements mean second chances to see acclaimed productions, like “School Girls” and “Happy Birthday, Wanda June,” that got away.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks and done is often the run for an Off Broadway play. Every now and then, though, intrepid producers — following the lead of enthusiastic audiences — bring shows back for second editions, often longer and sometimes in spiffier theaters. Here are six shows, now playing or soon to reopen, that New York Times critics enjoyed the first time around. Don’t count on a third chance.

headline: A Changing Tennessee Weighs a Moderate or Conservative for Senate
abstract: Phil Bredesen, the Democrat, has a centrist approach in a state that traditionally embraced moderates. His campaign is testing whether that is still viable in Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — As Phil Bredesen, the former Democratic governor of Tennessee now running for Senate, was wrapping up a voter forum at Rhodes College recently, the liberal-leaning mix of students, faculty and local residents began to grow restless from his unapologetically moderate brand of politics.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: New York’s 27th District, Collins vs. McMurray
abstract: This race wasn’t supposed to be close; President Trump won the district by 25 points. But in August, Mr. Collins was charged with insider trading (he has maintained his innocence), and a recent poll showed him ahead by just three points.
lead_paragraph: This race wasn’t supposed to be close; President Trump won the district by 25 points. But in August, Mr. Collins was charged with insider trading (he has maintained his innocence), and a recent poll showed him ahead by just three points.

headline: The Wildebeest Is One Highly Toned Machine
abstract: New research shows the animal’s muscles are incredibly efficient for its size, more so than other large animals.
lead_paragraph: This time of year, the temperature routinely reaches 104 degrees in northern Botswana. The grasses recede, forcing herds of wildebeest to walk farther and farther from their only water source to graze. Humidity falls to about 10 to 15 percent.

headline: The Battle for Congress Is Close. Here’s the State of the Race.

headline: New York Sues Exxon Mobil, Saying It Deceived Shareholders on Climate Change
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Global Warming', 'Attorneys General', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']

lead_paragraph: New York’s attorney general sued Exxon Mobil on Wednesday, claiming the company defrauded shareholders by downplaying the expected risks of climate change to its business.

headline: We Answer Your ‘Internetting’ Questions About Drag Queens and Cat Pranks
abstract: It’s the stunning season finale of “Internetting After Dark,” the show about the show.
lead_paragraph: Season 2 of “Internetting” has come to an end. On the final leg of our dystopian internet tour, babies failed, celebs were subdued, drag queens were commodified and girlfriends were terrorized via marriage proposal. And yet, we still have more questions than answers.

headline: Tony Hoagland, Poet With a Wry Outlook, Is Dead at 64
abstract: Though he took poetry seriously, he wasn’t afraid to go for a laugh.
lead_paragraph: Tony Hoagland, a widely admired poet who could be both humorous and heartfelt, often in the same poem, died on Tuesday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 64.

headline: Adam Sandler’s Netflix Special: His Most Satisfying Comedy in Years
abstract: The new show, “100% Fresh,” leans heavily on funny songs but also sentimentality, a combination that worked for our critic.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of his easygoing hang of a new special, “100% Fresh,” Adam Sandler, one of the biggest movie stars in the world, walks into a Times Square subway station and, disguised in a hoodie and sunglasses, tries his hand at busking.

abstract: What you need to know from today’s TV, music and movie news.

headline: Just Embed a Phone Into This Editor’s Mind, Already
abstract: Choire Sicha, who runs The New York Times’s Styles desk, has such a close relationship with his smartphone, he says, it may be time to “punch the circuitry into the back of our skull.”
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Choire Sicha, the editor of the Styles desk at The Times, which reports on everything from weddings and fashion to social change and self-care, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline: Craving Some Americana? The Saturday Evening Post Archive Is Online
abstract: The nearly 200-year-old magazine has a new website with a digital archive of its pages and more than 3,500 covers.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 200 years after its inception, The Saturday Evening Post has unveiled a new website with a digital archive of its issues dating back to 1821, as well as a gallery of its signature covers.

headline: Review: ‘Suspiria’ Is a Gaudy Freakout of Female Violence
abstract: Luca Guadagnino’s remake of the 1970s Dario Argento freakout is a bloated fantasy of consuming power.
lead_paragraph: Smeared in red and wrapped in woo-woo mystery, “Suspiria” is a fable of demonic possession. In storybook terms, its bad, bad trouble involves a young, outwardly naïve American dancer, Susie (Dakota Johnson), whose tenure at an all-female school in Germany turns progressively strange. The other less interesting possession involves the Italian director Luca Guadagnino, who has taken a 1970s freakout from Dario Argento and turned it into a bloated fantasy of violently consuming female power. It’s the old vagina dentata scare show, this time fancied up with art-house pretensions.

headline: Fracking Returns to Britain, and So Do Seismic Tremors Near Drilling Site
abstract: Minor earth tremors were reported in an area where an energy company resumed hydraulic fracturing less than two weeks ago, reinforcing fears of opponents.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks after an energy company won a court battle over opponents who feared hydraulic fracturing would cause seismic tremors in northwest England, the drilling work appears to be doing just that.

headline: Danny Leiner, Director Known for Stoner Films, Is Dead at 57

lead_paragraph: Danny Leiner, a director who turned the wanderings of the wasted into two successful movies, “Dude, Where’s My Car?” and “Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle,” died on Oct. 18 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 57.

lead_paragraph: At a crucial moment in late-night television, a new showrunner is taking over “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon,” a onetime ratings winner that lost its lead in total viewers soon after the inauguration of President Trump.

headline: Fashion or Costume? You Decide
abstract: If the industry didn’t get a little weird on occasion, it wouldn’t be fashion. It would be just clothes.
lead_paragraph: Halloween is the one night a year when you can step out in your most outlandish gear without feeling ridiculous. But for many in the fashion flock, such dressing up is a year-round event. Indeed, it’s getting harder to distinguish between the makings of a Halloween costume and the accessory of the moment.

abstract: Mr. Rato, also a former head of the International Monetary Fund, was set to turn himself in on Thursday after his appeal was denied in a case of credit card fraud.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Rodrigo Rato, a former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, was set to enter a Spanish prison on Thursday after failing to win an appeal of his 2017 conviction for credit card fraud while running Bankia, a giant Spanish lender that nearly collapsed  in 2012.

headline: Annapurna Devi, Acclaimed but Reclusive Indian Musician, Dies at 91
abstract: Her performances with her husband at the time, Ravi Shankar, were acclaimed, but there were only a few of them.
lead_paragraph: Annapurna Devi, a noted Indian musician and teacher whose decision to stop performing relatively early in her career made her something of an enigma, died on Oct. 13 in Mumbai. She was 91.

headline: After Bomb Scares, Trump Tries Bipartisanship, Then Blames the Media
abstract: The president tried to soften his rallying cry after law enforcement authorities said bombs were sent to prominent Democratic Party figures.
lead_paragraph: MOSINEE, Wis. — A day after a national call for unity in the wake of the bomb scares targeting several prominent Democrats, President Trump blamed the “Mainstream Media” and “Fake News” for the anger and division thriving in the United States.

headline: Still Clubbing at 82

headline: Subway Fare That Stinks: Nachos, Meat ... Crab Legs?
abstract: Andy Byford, who oversees the New York City subway, said snacks were fine. But don’t discard chicken bones or other messy foods on the floor.
lead_paragraph: It is an unspoken compact among subway riders in New York City: If you are going to eat on the train, keep it simple. But sometimes, there are messy scofflaws.

abstract: Scientists are increasingly warning that cutting emissions isn't enough. We'll also have to take billions of tons of carbon out of the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With time running out to avoid dangerous global warming, the nation’s leading scientific body on Wednesday urged the federal government to begin a research program focused on developing technologies that can remove vast quantities of carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere in order to help slow climate change.

headline: Who Needs a Border Wall When You Have DS-5535?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Visas', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: A new, quietly introduced visa form reminds us that mind-numbing bureaucracy can be an effective family-separation tool if that’s your game.
lead_paragraph: On May 16, I accompanied my fiancée to the United States Consulate in Casablanca, Morocco, for her visa interview. We had waited eight months for the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services to approve our application and the National Visa Center to issue an appointment. I booked her a return flight, hopeful that we would be flying back together to continue our lives in New York.

headline: If I Win My District, I’ll Get Rid of It
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment']
abstract: New York’s 101st State Assembly District is a gerrymandered monstrosity.
lead_paragraph: I am working hard to win the race for the 101st Assembly District in New York — and if I succeed, I will work just as hard to get rid of it. The 101st is a monstrosity of gerrymandering that disenfranchises voters and weakens representative democracy in upstate New York.

headline: Three Found Guilty in N.C.A.A. Basketball Recruiting Scheme
abstract: Two Adidas executives and an aspiring agent funneled $100,000 to a top high school prospect, who ended up losing his college basketball eligibility.
lead_paragraph: A jury returned unanimous guilty verdicts against two former Adidas employees and an aspiring sports agent in Manhattan federal court Wednesday after more than two days’ deliberation, concluding that it constituted fraud for the defendants to funnel money to the families of college basketball recruits in exchange for the prospects’ commitment to teams sponsored by Adidas.

headline: The Social Responsibility of Business
abstract: By supporting a modest tax increase, companies in San Francisco can help end the city’s homelessness crisis.
lead_paragraph: Back when I was in business school in the 1980s, I was taught — as were generations of aspiring entrepreneurs and executives — that the business of business is business. “There is one and only one social responsibility of business,” the economist Milton Friedman famously wrote in “Capitalism and Freedom”: “to increase its profits.” In an essay for this newspaper in 1970, Dr. Friedman went further, arguing that executives who claim that companies have “responsibilities for providing employment, eliminating discrimination, avoiding pollution and whatever else may be the catchwords” of the day are guilty of “undermining the basis of a free society.”

headline: How Scientists Cracked the Climate Change Case
abstract: The biggest crime scene on the planet is the planet. We know the earth is warming, but who or what is causing it?
lead_paragraph: The latest report from the world’s climate scientists has made clear the size of the challenge if the world is to stay below the global warming limit hoped for in the Paris climate agreement. Unfortunately, with current trends we are likely to cross this threshold within the next two decades because we are already two-thirds of the way there.

keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Biographical Information']

headline: What 9 Art Buyers Wore to a Hamptons Art Fair
abstract: Contemporary art and vintage cars were on display at the September Art Fair in Bridgehampton, N.Y., as were plenty of early-fall looks.
lead_paragraph: Jay-Z and Beyoncé didn’t show up this time. But the September Art Fair — an invitation-only open-air event held last month at a private golf resort in the Hamptons — still drew plenty of deep pockets. Along with works from blue-chip galleries including David Zwirner and Marlborough Contemporary, the second annual fair featured classic cars by Porsche, Ferrari and Maserati. It may have been after Labor Day, but these elite automobile fanatics and art aficionados weren’t afraid of wearing white.

headline: Osamu Shimomura, 90, Dies; Won Nobel for Finding a Glowing Protein
abstract: Dr. Shimomura isolated a green-glowing protein from jellyfish. It became a major element of biological research, lighting up the inner workings of cells.
lead_paragraph: Osamu Shimomura, who shared the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2008 for his discovery of a glowing jellyfish protein that is now ubiquitous in biomedical research, died on Friday in Nagasaki, Japan. He was 90.

headline: Albert K. Smiley III, 74, Keeper of Mohonk Mountain House, Dies
abstract: He nudged the hotel, which had been in the family for generations, into the modern world while maintaining its Victorian traditions and its commitment to conservation.
lead_paragraph: Albert K. Smiley III, a hotelier who preserved Mohonk Mountain House in upstate New York as a 19th-century Victorian retreat that could have been inspired jointly by Rip Van Winkle and Charles Addams, while also nudging it gently into the next century, died on Oct. 16 in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 74.

headline: When Trump Phones Friends, the Chinese and the Russians Listen and Learn
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Smartphones']
abstract: President Trump has been repeatedly told by aides that his cellphone calls are not secure from foreign spies. But he has refused to heed the warnings to stop talking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump calls old friends on one of his iPhones to gossip, gripe or solicit their latest take on how he is doing, American intelligence reports indicate that Chinese spies are often listening — and putting to use invaluable insights into how to best work the president and affect administration policy, current and former American officials said.

It’s because in the span of four days, she not only gave birth to her first child, but also saved her husband’s life.

headline: Frankenstein at 200

headline: ‘We Feel a Kinship With the Creature’
abstract: How and why has that hunk of inhumanity been reanimated so often? Mel Brooks, Kenneth Branagh and others put the pieces together.
