abstract: Ms. Jenner, the transgender rights activist, said that President Trump was relentlessly attacking the transgender community and she no longer supports him.
lead_paragraph: Caitlyn Jenner, the transgender rights activist who has long drawn criticism from members of the L.G.B.T.Q. community for her Republican leanings, unambiguously denounced President Trump on Thursday for his stance on transgender issues.

headline: George Shultz: We Must Preserve This Nuclear Treaty
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Treaties', 'Cold War Era', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: This is the time to expand, not abandon, an important nuclear weapons agreement with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Nuclear weapons are a threat to the world. Any large-scale nuclear exchange would have globally catastrophic consequences. Conscious of this reality, President Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev, the leader of the Soviet Union, worked in the 1980s to reduce the number of nuclear weapons, with the ultimate goal of getting rid of them.

headline: Blistered Feet, Sleepless Nights. The Caravan Presses On.
abstract: They know President Trump has vowed to block them yet they press on. “We prefer to die on the American border than die in Honduras from hunger,” one said.
lead_paragraph: PIJIJIAPAN, Mexico — María has been traveling with her two daughters from Honduras in the company of thousands of strangers, most of whom are young, single men. So it follows that she has some concerns about safety as they travel north as part of the migrant caravan.

headline: Caroline Wozniacki Reveals That She Has Rheumatoid Arthritis
abstract: Wozniacki, 28, said that symptoms like fatigue and joint soreness began appearing this summer. She did not receive a diagnosis until after the United States Open.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Wozniacki, her tennis season over after a loss at the WTA Finals on Thursday, revealed that she had recently received a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis, an autoimmune disease that can cause joint pain and stiffness and problems with mobility.

headline: Busy Philipps Has Flourished by Being Herself

headline: How a Democratic House Could Work With Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: If he remembers his campaign promises. And cares enough to stick with them.
lead_paragraph: In his frenetic campaigning for the midterms, President Trump has gone all in with racially charged, ethnonationalist demagogy — spinning out dystopian visions of “unknown Middle Easterners” storming the southern border, MS-13 members terrorizing the countryside and anxious Californians rioting over sanctuary cities.

headline: F-Bombs and Real Bombs
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Terrorism', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Firearms']
abstract: Our problem isn’t “incivility.” It’s right-wing violence.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, after bombs were sent to a number of Donald Trump’s most prominent enemies, he held a rally in Mosinee, Wis. A president with even a pretense to statesmanship would have canceled it — the country was in the middle of what can reasonably be described as a terrorist attack, with someone attempting mass murder against leading Democrats. Trump, needless to say, is not such a president.

headline: When City Center Was Balanchine’s House
abstract: Jacques d’Amboise, Patricia Wilde, Allegra Kent and Edward Villella talk about the roles they danced at the theater, which is celebrating George Balanchine and its 75th anniversary as a palace of the arts.
lead_paragraph: When Lincoln Kirstein and the choreographer George Balanchine were attempting to get a company off the ground in the 1930s and ’40s, they had little more than a pickup troupe, with meager seasons and slender prospects. That began to change in 1948, when the company, the newly named New York City Ballet, found an institution willing to take it in: New York City Center.

headline: Is an Extroverted Applicant Better Suited for Harvard Than an Introvert?
abstract: Facing a lawsuit accusing it of rejecting Asian-American applicants because of supposed low personality scores, the university clarified that quieter students ought to be accepted too.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Days before the opening of a trial accusing Harvard of discriminating against Asian-American applicants, the college issued new guidance to its admissions officers earlier this month on what personalities it is seeking in its incoming freshmen, a question at the heart of the case.

headline: A Toddler Who Appeared in Immigration Court Goes Home to Honduras. ‘Mi Amor,’ Her Mother Cries.
keywords: ['Family Separation Policy (US Immigration)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Children and Childhood', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: Fernanda came to the United States at the age of 2 but was separated from her grandmother. On Friday, after months in foster care, she flew home.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — The passengers from American Airlines Flight 941 trickled out, alone, in couples and in groups — all but the small girl whose family was nervously awaiting her in the arrivals area. It had been three months since 2-year-old Fernanda Jacqueline Davila had been whisked away with her grandmother on a journey to the United States that had gone badly wrong.

headline: Can a Billboard-Size ‘Baby, Please’ Bring Kevin Durant to the Knicks?
abstract: Many fans have their hearts set on snagging Kevin Durant to be their latest savior. One fan is betting on a billboard to seal the deal.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the morning rush hour, the billboard appeared across from the main entrance of Madison Square Garden, just in time for Friday’s game between the New York Knicks and the Golden State Warriors. Underneath a plea — “Can You Make NY Sports Great Again?” — Kevin Durant and Kristaps Porzingis, in matching blue jerseys, held the Larry O’Brien Trophy.

headline: Trump, Will Money or Morals Prevail With the Saudis?
abstract: For the United States, doing nothing about the premeditated killing of Jamal Khashoggi is not an option.
lead_paragraph: For the United States, doing nothing about the premeditated killing of Jamal Khashoggi is not an option.

headline: Trump, Will Money or Morals Prevail With the Saudis?
abstract: For the United States, doing nothing about the premeditated killing of Jamal Khashoggi is not an option.
lead_paragraph: The horrific killing of Jamal Khashoggi, a United States-based journalist for The Washington Post, has galvanized American and international outrage against Saudi Arabia to an extent unheard-of since Sept. 11. In the video above, we suggest some ways the United States can make clear its extreme revulsion at the crime and pressure the kingdom’s leaders into telling the whole truth and ensuring accountability for the perpetrators. All signs point to the powerful crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, as the main man behind the murder; only 18 security and intelligence underlings have been arrested.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Pipe Bombs Investigation Turns Toward Florida as More Trump Critics Are Targeted
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 26, 2018.
lead_paragraph: “There is somebody, by definition, who is a serial bomber, yes, and a terrorist.”

headline: Corrections: October 26, 2018
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, October 26, 2018.
lead_paragraph: SPORTS

headline: Review: At This Professor’s Office Hour, No Time for ‘The Niceties’
abstract: A white liberal historian and a frustrated African-American student make a combustible combination in Eleanor Burgess’s play.
lead_paragraph: Zoe Reed, the heroine of Eleanor Burgess’s “The Niceties,” is an overachieving undergraduate uncertain about her post-collegiate path. A political science major who spends her free time protesting, she is rebellious by nature. But if her affluent parents had their way, she would make a life much like theirs, building on the opportunities they’ve given her.

headline: Review: In ‘Lewiston/Clarkston,’ America at a Crossroads (Plus Dinner)
abstract: Samuel D. Hunter’s golden diptych, set in twin cities in Idaho and Washington, gets a riveting production, with barbecue, at the reconfigured Rattlestick.
lead_paragraph: It’s only fitting that Rattlestick Playwrights Theater would gut its Greenwich Village home to accommodate the unconventional production of “Lewiston/Clarkston” that opened there on Thursday. The 24-year-old company merely did for Samuel D. Hunter’s new play what the play will do to you.

headline: Review: Elaine May Might Break Your Heart in ‘Waverly Gallery’
abstract: This impeccably acted revival presents Kenneth Lonergan’s poignant comic drama about dementia as a memory play in more ways than one.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Gladys Green opens her mouth — which is the moment that the curtain rises on Kenneth Lonergan’s wonderful play “The Waverly Gallery” at the Golden Theater — it’s clear that for this garrulous woman, idle conversation isn’t a time killer. It is a lifeline.

headline: Go to the Dogs
abstract: The return of Evan Kalish.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Evan Kalish, he was making his New York Times Crossword debut by spilling secrets on a Monday. Today, he returns with a fresh and crunchy themeless grid that is a fun start to our solving weekend.

headline: Former Sheriff’s Deputy in Houston Indicted in Killing of Unarmed Man
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The deputy, Cameron Brewer, shot and killed Danny Ray Thomas in March. On Thursday, he was indicted by a grand jury on one count of aggravated assault.
lead_paragraph: A former sheriff’s deputy in Houston who shot and killed an unarmed black man who was acting erratically was indicted Thursday on a felony charge.

headline: Monsters That Live On You
abstract: Good news: You’re never home alone. Meet your microscopic roommates and hairy houseguests up close and personal in bug-tastic augmented reality.
lead_paragraph: Good news: You’re never home alone. Meet your microscopic roommates and hairy houseguests up close and personal in bug-tastic augmented reality.

keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Chess', 'Careers and Professions', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'ALIMONY', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Stung by divorce, a high-earning professional tries to recast herself in the dating world as a woman in need of male protection.
lead_paragraph: My new guy and I were lying next to each other, half-covered by bedsheets, the afternoon sun warming my feet. We had been dating for about a month.

headline: In ‘Shell,’ Kristina Olsson Captures a City That’s Reaching for Greatness
abstract: The building of the Sydney Opera House provides a backdrop for this novel about Australia in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — From Kristina Olsson’s balcony the view is of the tropical flora of the Australian north. In the distance — beyond a canopy of jacaranda and poinciana — the towers of Brisbane hover in the haze.

abstract: The party should be embracing the challenge of economic inequality. Instead, it’s shrinking away.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — What does it take to make a major political party so frustrated with itself that it prefers therapy over governing?

headline: China Kindergarten Stabbing Injures 14 Children
abstract: Mass shootings are rare in China, which has strict gun control. But attackers with knives sometimes carry out mass stabbings, and children are often the targets.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A woman with a knife attacked students at a kindergarten in southwestern China on Friday, injuring 14 children before she was stopped by teachers and guards, the police said.

abstract: This word has appeared in 68 articles on nytimes.com in the past year.

headline: A British Tradition Is Challenged by a Soccer Insurgent
abstract: A streaming service wants to bring an end to the longstanding rule against showing soccer games on Saturday between 2:45 and 5 p.m. in England. Smaller clubs, who rely on attendance to their games during that window, could suffer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As far as Derry City was concerned, it was a big game. A cup quarterfinal, on home turf, against one of its fiercest rivals from the League of Ireland should have been the sort of night to draw a raucous crowd, the gate receipts swelling the club’s coffers.

headline: On Politics: As More Bombs Surface, Investigators Look to Florida
abstract: Officials investigating pipe bombs sent this week to several critics of President Trump have turned their attention toward Florida, believing some were sent from there.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. Here are some of the stories making news in Washington and politics today.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Latest Campaign Finance Reports
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: National Democratic Party committees and super PACs outraised their Republican counterparts this month, but the Republican committees had more money in the bank as of last week.
lead_paragraph: The 2018 midterm elections are expected to shatter spending records, and campaign finance reports filed on Thursday provided a glimpse inside frenzied final fund-raising pushes, while revealing how much money each side has left to spend in the final weeks before Election Day.

headline: New York Knew Some Schools in Its $773 Million Plan Were Likely to Fail. It Kept Children in Them Anyway.
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio is poised to end a program that sent children to poorly performing schools even as officials knew they had little hope of improving.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio promised to “shake the foundations of New York City education” in 2014 with a new program called Renewal, a signature effort to improve the city’s 94 poorest-performing schools by showering them with millions of dollars in social services and teacher training.

headline: Why Are Antiques So Cheap? Because Everyone Lives in the Kitchen
abstract: Changes in the way we live in our homes have created a serious problem for the art and collectible industry.
lead_paragraph: LEWES, England — The 18th-century oak bureau was expected to sell for at least 50 pounds, or about $65. The auctioneer asked for an opening bid of £30. No takers. What about £20? Again nothing. Unsold. The auction moved on.

headline: Learning With: ‘Young People Are Suing the Trump Administration Over Climate Change. She’s Their Lawyer.’
abstract: This case could test whether there is a constitutional right to a stable and safe climate. What do you think? Do these young people have strong arguments in their favor?
lead_paragraph: Before reading the article:

headline: Intimate and Glamorous Portraits of Parisian Transgender Women
keywords: ['Photography', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties']
abstract: Christer Strömholm’s photos of the women he lived with make up an intimate and sensitive portrayal of transgender women decades before such depictions were widely seen.
lead_paragraph: In 1959, Christer Strömholm, then a little-known Swedish photographer, found his way to Paris and to a group of people who would transform his life, and he theirs.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld on Louis C.K., Roseanne and Tense Times in Comedy
abstract: Analytical as ever, the comic has strong opinions about disgraced peers like Cosby. He says the audience is always right (even about his #MeToo joke).
lead_paragraph: In some ways, the world of Jerry Seinfeld is the same as it ever was. He’s still the singularly recognizable stand-up, the star and co-creator of his eponymous TV sitcom and the host of a Netflix talk show, “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.” At 64, he is still playing dozens of live dates a year and, on Friday, announced the return of his residency at the Beacon Theater with 20 new shows in 2019.

headline: Allison Janae Hamilton’s Spirit Sources
abstract: Pine tar and turpentine, climate change and hurricanes affect her fantastical art of the rural South, in a show at Mass MoCA.
lead_paragraph: Indoors, for Allison Janae Hamilton, is always a kind of compromise. She grew up in Florida — first in Miami, attuned to the ocean and the Everglades, then in Tallahassee, with its exuberant tree cover, and where she enjoys kayaking in the haunting cypress swamps. Childhood summers were spent in western Tennessee, returning for planting and picking time on her maternal family’s farm. Her multimedia art never strays far from her concern with the land, especially the Southern land, and its occupants, especially its black occupants.

headline: News Quiz: Test Your Knowledge of the Week’s Headlines
abstract: Did you stay up to date this week?
lead_paragraph: Did you stay up to date this week?

headline: Kimmel Wouldn’t Want to Be the Spy Who Has to Listen to Trump’s Calls
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel and other late-night hosts criticized President Trump after a report revealed his phone calls were sometimes intercepted by foreign spies.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. If you’re interested in hearing from The Times regularly about great TV, sign up for our Watching newsletter and get recommendations straight to your inbox.

headline: The Changing Jersey Waterfront
abstract: As new residential towers fill the Jersey coastline, the population is shifting from singles and young couples to more young families.
lead_paragraph: As new residential towers fill the Jersey coastline, the population is shifting from singles and young couples to more young families.

headline: Notes From the Book Review Archives
abstract: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Shirley Jackson’s “The Haunting of Hill House.”
lead_paragraph: Happy Halloween! This week’s issue is filled with ghosts and horror, both real and fictional. In 1959, Edmund Fuller reviewed Shirley Jackson’s “The Haunting of Hill House,” which, nearly 60 years later, is still considered the best of its genre. Read an excerpt below:

headline: The Season’s Standout Crossover Y.A. Novels

lead_paragraph: A WINTER’S PROMISEBy Christelle DabosTranslated by Hildegard Serle 492 pp. Europa. $19.95.

headline: What Our Extremist Politics Owe to Batman and Captain America
abstract: “The Sky Is Falling,” by the pop culture historian Peter Biskind, traces the roots of our polarized political climates to Hollywood, television and Marvel Comics.
lead_paragraph: THE SKY IS FALLINGHow Vampires, Zombies, Androids, and Superheroes Made America Great for ExtremismBy Peter Biskind252 pp. The New Press. $26.99.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Dark Cavalcade of New Horror Fiction
abstract: In these novels, a phantom walks the earth, families at a campground descend into a terrifying alternative universe and the Devil roams a bleak English landscape.
lead_paragraph: The strongest emotion we feel is fear, and the strongest kind of fear is fear of the unknown. I am paraphrasing H. P. Lovecraft, a founding father of American horror, who died in 1937, but this sentiment is very much relevant today. Fear. The gasp as your plane hits turbulence and drops; the creeping sensation as the front door squeaks open in the middle of the night; the shudder when you hear the dentist’s drill buzz — we all know fear in some form or another. Fear drives us to do things we might never have considered doing, or to become someone we didn’t plan to be. Fear forces us to choose between safety and risk. And this, of course, is the stuff of great fiction.

headline: Graphic Novels to Give Kids Chills and Thrills
abstract: In "Fake Blood,” a sixth grader morphs into a vampire. “Scarlett Hart: Monster Hunter” has a retro-modern teenage heroine who slays all kinds of evil creatures.
lead_paragraph: All adolescents face two monsters: insecurity about where they are now, and the stress of impending adulthood. Fantasy writers have long asked us to imagine how tough that would be if supernatural forces were also in the mix. Two new graphic novels spin enthralling tales of young heroes slaying those inner beasts — right along with the kind that suck your blood and try to kill you.

headline: Misfits, Stalkers and Kiddie Sociopaths: The Latest Thrillers
abstract: On the 30th anniversary of “The Silence of the Lambs,” Mark Harris assesses the state of the psychological thriller — and weighs in on five new ones.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 30 years since the publication of Thomas Harris’s “The Silence of the Lambs,” the suspense novel that pitted the F.B.I. trainee Clarice Starling against the serial killer Hannibal Lecter, showcased them as they bored into each other’s psyches and did more to change the genre than any novel until Gillian Flynn’s “Gone Girl” a generation later. To revisit “The Silence of the Lambs” today is to encounter a story that shows its age — not just because of the of-its-era language in which transgender issues are discussed, but because it is something that too few thrillers dare to be in 2018: strictly linear.

headline: From Stephen King, Master of Darkness, a Light New Tale
abstract: King’s slim new novel, “Elevation,” returns us to Castle Rock, where prejudice drives a plot that blends the fantastical with the mundane.
lead_paragraph: ELEVATIONBy Stephen King146 pp. Scribner. $19.95.

headline: Hunting Down the Best True-Crime Tales
abstract: Marilyn Stasio discovers books that document the history of serial killing and the poisons of past and present, as well as some scandalous murder cases.
lead_paragraph: Put a pile of anything in front of me — shoes, seashells, books — and I’ll robotically start organizing them into categories. It soothes my mind to separate, say, con artists from gangsters, and it makes a jumble of true-crime books on a variety of topics easier to tackle. But since the ones right in front of me are about serial killers, let’s start with those.

headline: New in Paperback: ‘To Siri With Love,’ ‘The Relive Box’
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

headline: Susan Orlean Burned a Book. It Was ‘Excruciating.’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: While researching “The Library Book,” about the 1986 fire that decimated the Los Angeles Central Library, the author took a paperback and some matches into the yard.
lead_paragraph: PLAYING WITH FIRE Early in “The Library Book” — about the suspicious fire that roared through the Los Angeles Central Library in 1986 — Susan Orlean decided she needed to see what it felt like to burn a book.

headline: Should Tech Giants Like Google Be in the Business of Teaching Children How to Be Good Digital Citizens?
abstract: Who is best positioned to teach young people these critical 21st-century skills?
lead_paragraph: Should internet companies like Google be in the business of teaching children how to be good digital citizens? Or is Google not the most trustworthy source when it comes to giving advice on how to navigate the internet safely?

headline: How ‘Gardening While Black’ Almost Landed This Detroit Man in Jail
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: A black man started an urban farm in his old neighborhood. Three white women called the police repeatedly, accusing him of threatening them. The case went to court.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For nearly two years, a man tilled an overgrown park in a half-abandoned Detroit neighborhood into a tiny urban farm, filling the earth with the seeds of kale and spinach and radishes. He was black.

headline: Family History in Her Bones
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Bones', 'Skeletons', 'Tumors', 'Halloween', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: I don’t need to see the X-ray to recognize this bump on my daughter’s leg as the first sign of the genetic condition I inherited from my mother.
lead_paragraph: I hold my 4-year-old daughter’s hand as she lies on the cold surface of the X-ray table, watching her brow furrow as she concentrates on holding her left ankle at the awkward angle in which the technician placed it. This is, for her, an exciting experience, something about which she feels only curiosity.

headline: Should I Get the High-Dose Flu Vaccine?
abstract: People younger than 65 can receive the high-dose vaccine, but there are caveats.
lead_paragraph: Q. If the high-dose flu vaccine is more potent, why do I have to wait until I’m 65 to get it?

headline: A Family Reunion, Centuries Later
abstract: Cut into pieces in the late 18th century, a Dutch Golden Age painting has been reassembled at the Toledo Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Family reunions can be touching or tense, joyous or fractious. But they are almost always complicated.

headline: Looking at Songs That No Longer Seem Quite So Romantic
abstract: A marathon musical performance in San Francisco will feature songs “written with good intentions,” but that are “utterly revealing.”
lead_paragraph: Pay close attention to the lyrics of familiar pop songs, and the ingrained cultural attitudes toward women become all too clear.

headline: A.I. Is Helping Scientists Predict When and Where the Next Big Earthquake Will Be
abstract: Scientists have a miserable record of predicting where and when earthquakes will strike. Some are now turning to artificial intelligence for answers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Countless dollars and entire scientific careers have been dedicated to predicting where and when the next big earthquake will strike. But unlike weather forecasting, which has significantly improved with the use of better satellites and more powerful mathematical models, earthquake prediction has been marred by repeated failure.

headline: Just in Time for Halloween, a Graphic Homage to a Classic Work of Gothic Horror Literature
abstract: Sergio García Sánchez illustrates Edgar Allan Poe’s short story “The Fall of the House of Usher.”

abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Rebuilding After a Hurricane: Why Does It Take So Long?
abstract: It’s not just the repairs, it’s navigating a ‘patchwork’ storm recovery system, applying for federal money and finding a reliable contractor.
lead_paragraph: Six years after Hurricane Sandy, there are still about 2,000 households mired in the rebuilding process.

headline: Out of the Gallery, Into the Street
abstract: From Manhattan to Miami, artists are showing their work in real estate developments, some of which even have galleries and cultural programs.
lead_paragraph: A massive Anish Kapoor sculpture integrated into the base of a TriBeCa building. Custom works by Robert Indiana and Olafur Eliasson featured at a condominium opening next year in Miami. And three artistic takes on the traditional scale model by the kinetic sculptor Es Devlin, which take up prime space in the sales gallery for the XI, a residential tower south of Hudson Yards in New York.

headline: Restoring the House the Ringling Circus Built
abstract: Ron McCarty spent his career refurbishing and refurnishing the 56-room palazzo owned by John and Mable Ringling, bringing back an array of memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: Sarasota, Fla. — In the 1920s, John Ringling and his wife, Mable, built their dream house in Sarasota, Fla.: a 56-room Venetian Gothic palazzo named Ca’ d’Zan, or House of John.

headline: Pérez Art Museum Miami Recalls Pink Islands
abstract: A new exhibition looks back at “Surrounded Islands,” Christo and Jeanne-Claude’s popular but controversial 1983 project, which draped 11 uninhabited islands in fabric.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It might have been the first time a traffic jam in South Florida ended in smiles. On the afternoon of May 7, 1983, cars began to slow down on the causeways that sail over Biscayne Bay and connect Miami Beach with the mainland. Many motorists stopped altogether, hopping out onto the road for a better look at the surreal sight in the bay: 11 small, uninhabited islands were newly surrounded by 6.5 million square feet of pink woven polypropylene fabric, each looking like a 200-foot-wide, pastel-colored lily pad, shimmering in the tropical sunlight.

headline: New Sentences: From ‘Dungeons & Dragons Art & Arcana’
abstract: Sometimes it takes a while for a thing to catch up to its name.
lead_paragraph: — From “Dungeons & Dragons Art & Arcana: A Visual History” (Ten Speed Press, 2018, Page 173), by Michael Witwer, Kyle Newman, Jon Peterson and Sam Witwer.

headline: Breast-Feeding Is Good for the Mother, and Not Just the Baby
keywords: ['Breast Cancer', 'Breastfeeding', 'Women and Girls', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Diabetes', 'Babies and Infants', 'Parenting', 'Infant Formulas']
abstract: Women who breast-feed are less likely to develop breast cancer, ovarian cancer, Type 2 diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis and may have improved cardiovascular health.
lead_paragraph: Most women know breast-feeding is good for their babies’ health. But doctors and midwives rarely tell moms-to-be that it’s also good for nursing mothers.

headline: Readers Respond to the 10.14.2018 Issue
abstract: Here’s what readers had to say about our stories on a Philadelphia neighborhood known as the “Walmart of Heroin” and doctors burning out on the job.

headline: Jersey City Grows Up
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Condominiums']
abstract: More singles who moved to the area are choosing to stay when they start families, and are pushing into nearby waterfront towns like West New York and Weehawken.
lead_paragraph: When Zacheus and Ratri Chan showed up at an open house for a townhouse in the Bergen-Lafayette neighborhood of Jersey City last fall, there was a line down the street.

headline: Japan’s Leader Goes to Beijing. Here’s What’s at Stake.
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations']
abstract: After a bitter and bloody history dating back to World War II, Japan and China are mending ties, and there’s one big reason: Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan is in Beijing for a three-day visit, the first Japanese leader to make an official trip to China in nearly seven years. The visit represents a chance to move beyond the tense relations between the two countries in recent years and their history of hostilities. Mr. Abe reached trade deals with China and committed to stable relations in a day of meetings Friday with President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang.

headline: How a Hugely Popular Pretzel Bun Became a Political Minefield
abstract: For months, immigration activists have been protesting restaurants that rely on breads from Tom Cat, a baker targeted by ICE. Has activism run amok?
lead_paragraph: By virtue of its near constant appearance on Instagram, the pretzel bun on the burger at the Emily restaurants, as they are known, stands as a celebrity carbohydrate, and like all celebrities, it is both worshiped and detested.

headline: CBS Inquiry Into What Went Wrong in Les Moonves Era Hits Snags as It Advances
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Television', '#MeToo Movement', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Investigators have interviewed more than 250 people as they examine allegations of misconduct. But not every accuser has been contacted, and some are hesitant to cooperate.
lead_paragraph: The #MeToo movement may have affected the CBS Corporation more than any other mass media company over the past year. After The New Yorker and The Washington Post published articles detailing accusations against high-ranking men at the network, CBS parted ways with Leslie Moonves, its chief executive; Jeff Fager, the longtime executive producer of “60 Minutes”; and Charlie Rose, one of its best known anchors.

headline: Exhibitions in Qatar Celebrate Syria Before the War
abstract: Before Syria’s government and its people embarked on a brutal, destructive conflict, there was another Syria — one that museums will honor this fall.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — A thousand miles southeast of what remains of Syria’s civil war, “Syria Matters,” a major exhibition at the Museum of Islamic Art here, is focused on the history and the soul of the country rather than the images of conflict that have been reflected in headlines and splashed across television screens for the past seven years.

headline: House and Senate Latest, Good News for Beto: 11 Days to Go
abstract: Super PACs for both parties are devoting late money to vulnerable seats, and two major newspapers in Texas endorsed Beto O’Rourke, Ted Cruz’s opponent.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Tip Sheet, a daily political analysis of the 2018 elections, based on interviews with Republican and Democratic officials, pollsters, strategists and voters.

headline: U.S. Economy Charged Ahead in the Third Quarter
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Interest Rates', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After six months of strong growth, the economy is on track for its best annual performance since 2005. But there were signs of a slowdown ahead.
lead_paragraph: The American economy barreled ahead in the third quarter as consumers stepped up and spent more, keeping it on track for the best annual performance since 2005.

headline: The Auction Season’s Real Gems
abstract: Colored diamonds and more contemporary designs are among the trends as Christie’s prepares for Magnificent Jewels, a much-anticipated sale.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere on a Gulf of Panama beach in the early 16th century, someone found a perfectly formed, pear-shaped 50-plus-carat pearl. Someone else named it la Peregrina (the Wanderer), and Mary Tudor of England received it as an engagement gift in 1554. (She was 38 and died four years later.)

headline: Hungary Turned Far Right. That’s Meant Millions for Its Opera.
abstract: Viktor Orban’s government has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the Hungarian State Opera. Now the company is coming to Trump’s America.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — The grand, gilded Hungarian State Opera House here is where Brahms once heard Mahler conduct Mozart. It’s where Bartok’s still-shocking “Bluebeard’s Castle” had its premiere a century ago. It’s where the artist Matthew Barney shot part of his “Cremaster” cycle, and Jennifer Lawrence filmed scenes for her violent thriller “Red Sparrow,” in which she played a ballerina-turned-spy.

headline: How Julia Jordan, Champion of Female Playwrights, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: She manages to find time for everything but writing plays. But on her Brooklyn porch, with neighbors, that can wait.
lead_paragraph: Julia Jordan writes plays, runs a non-profit organization, plays Sudoku obsessively, walks her dog and raises two kids in a Brooklyn house in mid-renovation. You could say she’s earned a Sunday off.

headline: After the Hurricane Came the Con
abstract: Six years after Sandy devastated Long Island, homeowners are still dealing with the wreckage of a sweet-talking contractor who took their money and left their houses unfinished.
lead_paragraph: It was the giant whiteboard that did it, they said.

headline: Rafael Lozano-Hemmer Is a Crowd Pleaser. He’s Also Obsessed With Death.
abstract: This Canadian artist with Mexican roots is opening a show at the Hirshhorn that showcases his sometimes eerie melding of technology and human biology.
lead_paragraph: Can an artist be a creator of entertaining, technologically inspired, interactive creations that people line up to try, and be, at the same time, a somewhat macabre intellectual with a penchant for social criticism?

headline: Will One State Go It Alone to Make Polluters Pay?
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Referendums', 'Global Warming', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Taxation', 'Coal', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Washington State voters will consider carbon fees aimed at curbing climate change. If they approve, the state will be the first in the nation to impose the fees.
lead_paragraph: CENTRALIA, Wash. — The last coal mine in Washington State closed down about a decade ago in Centralia, about 65 miles south of Seattle, leaving scars on the land and the local economy. Now, a solar electricity project — perhaps the largest in the state — is planned for the same location, by the same company that once ran the mine.

headline: New-York Historical Society Goes All Harry Potter
abstract: To help draw millennials, the society is presenting the exhibition “Harry Potter: A History of Magic,” along with Potter trivia contests.
lead_paragraph: With its 38-foot-high ceiling, bookcases stuffed with faded, leather-bound volumes and walls festooned with oil portraits that seem to wink, the second floor reading room of the New-York Historical Society bears a striking resemblance to a certain fictional school for wizards.

headline: The Ivy League Becomes the Future of Football
abstract: Can football be made safer? The Ancient Eight are at the forefront of efforts to keep football from going the way of boxing.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.H. — The earliest football game between two eventual members of the Ivy League took place when Columbia played Yale in 1872. Dartmouth’s football team had its first intercollegiate game in 1881, several years before the sport was formally introduced at Ohio State and Alabama.

headline: The Return of the Vampire King of New York
abstract: The wild goth subculture of the 1990s may be gone, but as long as there are people who want fangs, Father Sebastiaan will supply them.
lead_paragraph: In the dim corner of Halloween Adventure, a two-story costume store in Manhattan, a man called Father Sebastiaan sculpts vampire fangs by hand. A Ouija board hangs crooked on the wall, near a purple crystal and an uneven pile of occult books. His work stall, no larger than a broom closet, is barely visible behind pirate and cowboy masks.

headline: A Day on the Road With the Migrant Caravan
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The political frenzy is heightening over a so-called migrant caravan heading toward the United States, but who are the people making the grueling journey? We spent 24 hours with a family as they trekked through Mexico for an up-close view of what’s at stake.
lead_paragraph: The political frenzy is heightening over a so-called migrant caravan heading toward the United States, but who are the people making the grueling journey? We spent 24 hours with a family as they trekked through Mexico for an up-close view of what’s at stake.

headline: The Tragedy of Saudi Arabia’s War in Yemen
keywords: ['Famine', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Malnutrition', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The Khashoggi killing has cast light on Saudi tactics in Yemen, where an economic war has pushed millions to the brink of starvation.
lead_paragraph: The Khashoggi killing has cast light on Saudi tactics in Yemen, where an economic war has pushed millions to the brink of starvation.

headline: Why We Are Publishing Haunting Photos of Emaciated Yemeni Children
abstract: The images we have published out of Yemen may be as grueling as anything we have used before. Here’s why we made the decision to publish them.
lead_paragraph: Amal Hussain is a 7-year-old Yemeni girl with a haunting gaze whose image sits atop our latest report from Yemen, a country plunged into war and on the brink of a catastrophic famine.

headline: Pipe Bombs, Google, Megyn Kelly: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Falling Stars Challenge’ Takes the Humble Out of Humblebragging
abstract: The meme began as an unusual way to show off one’s wealth, but it’s taken on new meaning while spreading across Asia.
lead_paragraph: Flaunting your wealth on social media usually looks a tad more subtle than this.

headline: As China Rattles Its Sword, Taiwanese Push a Separate Identity
abstract: Faced with growing threats from China, Taiwanese are trying to use referendums to change the island’s name and establish a separate identity from China.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — With greater frequency, China is using its growing air and sea power to try to intimidate Taiwan, the self-ruled island that it hopes to annex. China has also weaponized its economic prowess to induce foreign companies and even governments to erase Taiwan’s international presence.

headline: Loss Across and Love Down
abstract: For Maria Janelli, solving crossword puzzles made loss bearable and love possible.
lead_paragraph: Crossword puzzles are opportunities for collaboration and friendly competition. Conquering a crossword puzzle with a friend creates a sticky fiber that binds two people together.

headline: They Saw a Sign and Didn’t Shake It Off
abstract: Mariano Rivera III, a relief pitcher like his famous Yankees father, traded one true love for another after retiring from professional baseball.
lead_paragraph: For much of the last three years, Mariano Rivera III and Alyssa Picinich were kept apart by Mr. Rivera’s first love.

headline: New York Today: A Bomb-Carrying Truck
abstract: Friday: Where the pipe bombs go and strange tasting water.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this nebulous Friday.

headline: The Voters Both Parties Are Ignoring
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Democrats and Republicans share a blind spot for the diversity of the Latino electorate.
lead_paragraph: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

headline: Can Colorado Save America?
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: It’s impossible to drive across the state and not be reminded of the first boundlessness of American potential.
lead_paragraph: NUCLA, Colo. — Richard Craig, gun lover, Trump hater, is the man behind the local ordinance here that made gun ownership obligatory for the head of every household. The unusual rule, approved overwhelmingly by the town board in 2013, has gained this small community in southwestern Colorado some notoriety. “I believe in our Constitution,” Craig told me. “Having our guns is just part of American freedom.” As for President Trump, “I think he’s an idiot. He should quit tweeting and keep his mouth shut.”

headline: Erdogan Demands that Saudis Tell Turkey Who Ordered Khashoggi Killing
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said that Turkey had new evidence, while Russia said it had no reason to doubt Saudi accounts of the killing.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said Friday that Turkey had uncovered further evidence in the killing of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, pressing Saudi Arabia to reveal who gave the orders and demanding that its leaders explain what happened to Mr. Khashoggi’s body.

headline: DealBook Briefing: Google’s #MeToo Moment
abstract: The company protected a number of male executives accused of sexual misconduct, and even gave some big payoffs when they left.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday. Want this by email? Sign up here.

headline: Vatican Faces Modern-Day Suffragists, Demanding Right to Vote
abstract: Women want the Vatican to ease rules about who has a say on major policy decisions. Male religious brothers have the right to vote, so why can’t nuns?
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Two modern-day American suffragists had a plan.

headline: Baseball’s Defensive Dance: How the Dodgers and Red Sox Use the Shift
abstract: The infield defensive shifts have become a mainstay in baseball. But the Dodgers and the Red Sox use them very differently.
lead_paragraph: The infield defensive shifts have become a mainstay in baseball. But the Dodgers and the Red Sox use them very differently.

headline: Horror, Horror, Read All About It
keywords: ['Movies', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Posters', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The newspaper ads for 1980s horror movies could be as fun to scrutinize as the films themselves. A fan who collected the ads shares highlights.
lead_paragraph: For scary-movie lovers, the 1980s were a golden decade. The horror scene exploded so much after the original “Halloween” (1978) proved so popular that titles like “The Dorm That Dripped Blood,” “The Mutilator” and “Deadtime Stories” were being advertised in the mainstream pages of The Times, The Daily News and The New York Post.

headline: The Week in Arts: Pistol Annies’ New Album; Return of ‘House of Cards’
abstract: Miranda Lambert leads the female trio, whose third album, “Interstate Gospel,” is timeless and harmony-laden.
lead_paragraph: Nov. 2; itunes.apple.com.

headline: What Debra Messing Can’t Travel Without
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Luggage and Packing']
abstract: The “Will and Grace” actress always packs a compact camera, a “super cozy” pajama-like onesie and a hat that needs its own suitcase.
lead_paragraph: Debra Messing has starred in television shows and movies for decades, but the actress is best known for playing Grace Adler in “Will and Grace,” which ran on NBC from 1998 to 2006 and which the network brought back to TV screens last year. The sitcom’s new season had its premiere on Oct. 4.

headline: In London, a Restaurant Specializes in Indian Home Cooking
abstract: The owner and chef at Darjeeling Express uses recipes handed down by her mother and grandmother from the Kolkata region, with an all-female cast in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: When she moved from India to England in 1991, Asma Khan studied British constitutional law — but she could barely boil an egg. “I struggled a lot because I didn’t know how to cook,” she said. “England was a foreign land. Nothing was in my control. But I realized I could infuse my house with the aromas of home.” For two summers she returned to India to learn the recipes of her mother and grandmother. And with her new skill, came a vision: “Every time I slept at night, I dreamed I was feeding people,” she said.

headline: Afghan War Casualty Report: Oct. 19-25
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ninety-three civilians and 65 security force members were killed during the past week as fighting spread to 19 provinces.
lead_paragraph: The following reports compile all significant security incidents confirmed by New York Times reporters and stringers throughout Afghanistan. It is necessarily incomplete as many local officials refuse to confirm casualty information.

headline: Republicans for Democrats
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Conservative readers explain how and why they will vote against Trump this year.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline: Shinzo Abe Says Japan Is China’s ‘Partner,’ and No Longer Its Aid Donor
abstract: For 40 years, Japan has quietly given foreign aid to China. Visiting Beijing, its leader said that would end, announcing a “new phase” in the relationship.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It has been eight years since China overtook Japan as the world’s second-largest economy. Yet the Japanese government continued to provide China with development assistance usually reserved for poorer countries. Until now.

headline: There’s Much Talk About Latino Voters, but Are Campaigns Talking to Them?
abstract: Friday: How Hispanic voters are being courted, and a special New York Times crossword to test your knowledge of California sports.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Behind the Clash Over Italy’s Budget, a Fear of Populism
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Politics and Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Euro (Currency)']
abstract: The European Union fended off the challenge of Greek debt, but doing so with the Italian budget crisis could be much harder.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Just a few years ago, the European Union faced down a populist Greek government whose debts threatened the common currency, the euro, and the very integrity of the bloc.

headline: So Much for the Starter House
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Mortgages', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: With inventory tight, home prices high and interest rates rising, many homeowners are giving up on the idea of trading up from the first home they bought.
lead_paragraph: Johanna Lasser had lived in a dozen apartments before she bought her first house two years ago, a rundown Victorian in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn. Ms. Lasser and her husband, Jimm, figured they would fix it up, stay a few years and then move on to a house in the suburbs, or one in a better school district, as many people do.

headline: The Week in Tech: Apple Goes on the Attack
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media', 'Smartphones', 'Privacy', 'Quantum Computing', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Apple’s C.E.O. slammed his Silicon Valley peers for building a “data industrial complex” but his speech requires context.
lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline: ‘Suspiria’ Then and Now: Finding Darkness in an All-Female World
abstract: Tilda Swinton and Dakota Johnson were drawn to the complex depiction of feminism and violence in Luca Guadagnino’s remake of the Dario Argento original.
lead_paragraph: When Dario Argento’s German-set horror movie “Suspiria” came out in 1977, Berlin was on edge. Demonstrators angry at the West German government and what were seen as the depredations of capitalism hit the streets. The far-left guerrilla group the Red Army Faction terrorized the city in what would become known as the German Autumn, leaving several dead. It was also a key period for the assertion of feminist power and female liberation. The Red Army counted women among its leaders, and one of the first feminist magazines in Germany, Emma, published its inaugural issue that year.

headline: Outspoken Trump Supporter in Florida Charged in Attempted Bombing Spree
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The suspect was identified as Cesar Sayoc Jr., 56, of Aventura, Fla. Attorney General Jeff Sessions said he “appears to be a partisan.”
lead_paragraph: An outspoken supporter of President Trump from South Florida was charged on Friday with sending explosive packages to at least a dozen of the president’s critics, apparently bringing to a close an attempted bombing spree that has gripped the country just ahead of the midterm elections.

headline: Behind LeBron James, Lakers Push the Pace to Victories
abstract: Back-to-back wins, including their first at home with James, come as the team ramps up running and scoring. “Speed kills,” James says.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Lakers are off and running. No, really. They are running. And running. And running some more.

headline: A Cabaret in Hungary Asks a Horrific Question: What if Jews Vanished?
abstract: “The Chosen Ones,” a theater production in Budapest, raises the chilling prospect to investigate anti-Semitism and other prejudices.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — What would happen if Jewish people suddenly disappeared?

headline: For Transgender Americans, the Political Gets Even More Personal
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'States (US)']
abstract: The Trump administration delivered a one-two punch to transgender people just weeks before a midterm election in which a record number of L.G.B.T.Q. candidates are seeking office.
lead_paragraph: Gender Letter helps you keep up with the world — and the women and issues shaping it. Tell me what you think at dearmaya@nytimes.com.

headline: Trump’s Trade War May Create New Auto Jobs. In China.
keywords: ['Customs (Tariff)', 'Automobiles', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Caught in a crossfire of tariffs, BMW and other foreign carmakers are gauging whether to relocate some manufacturing to China. Jobs could follow.
lead_paragraph: President Trump has said he started a trade war to create jobs in America. But foreign carmakers that employ thousands of workers in the United States are gauging whether tariffs, the main weapon in that war, may compel them to shift jobs to, of all places, China.

headline: Jamie Lee Curtis: I’m Waving the Banner for Generations of Women
abstract: The “Halloween” actress on being a box-office smash at 59, on celebrating that on Twitter and on what she was thinking while filming with a cracked rib.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Lee Curtis has many reasons to be grateful this year. She turns 60 on Thanksgiving, and she’s currently celebrating the monster success of “Halloween.” The new sequel to John Carpenter’s 1978 original earned $76.2 million in its first weekend — the biggest opening for a horror movie with a female lead and for any film starring a woman over 55.

headline: Silicon Valley Nannies Are Phone Police for Kids
abstract: Child care contracts now demand that nannies hide phones, tablets, computers and TVs from their charges.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley parents are increasingly obsessed with keeping their children away from screens. Even a little screen time can be so deeply addictive, some parents believe, that it’s best if a child neither touches nor sees any of these glittering rectangles. These particular parents, after all, deeply understand their allure.

headline: In ‘The Black Cat,’ the Titans of Terror, Karloff and Lugosi, Face Off
abstract: Classic Hollywood’s star monsters appeared together in half a dozen films — some, like “The Black Cat” and “The Body Snatcher” are surprisingly good.
lead_paragraph: Now considered a classic, “The Black Cat” (1934) was the first movie to feature Universal’s two prized assets, Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi, and the studio’s excitement was palpable. It’s “the monster of ‘Frankenstein’ plus the monster of ‘Dracula,’ plus the ‘monstrousness’ of Edgar Allan Poe,” the ads boasted, “all combined by the master makers of screen mysteries to give you the absolute apex in super-shivery.”

headline: Hugh Jackman Breaks the Movie Star Rules and Doesn’t Care
abstract: Jackman talks about portraying Gary Hart in “The Front Runner,” the next incarnation of “The Greatest Showman,” and why life is better than ever at 50.
lead_paragraph: Some celebrities revel in the spotlight; others, not so much. Hugh Jackman falls into the first category, as witnessed when he recently settled into a well-positioned banquette in a West Village restaurant and faced his dining audience, the better to disarm and dazzle.

headline: In ‘Homecoming,’ a Sound Experiment Becomes Something to See
abstract: A hit podcast is reimagined with creepy sets, unsettling visuals — and Julia Roberts.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — What do you see? If you’re listening to “Homecoming,” the cult hit podcast from Gimlet Media, the answer is nothing. A psychological thriller set largely inside a mysterious corporate facility somewhere in Florida, the podcast’s story is relayed strictly through sound, even more so than other fictional podcasts of late, or the cliffhanger-loving radio dramas that preceded them. Seemingly cobbled together from found recordings of phone calls and therapy sessions, there’s not even a narrator to tell you where you are, or when.

headline: The Digital Gap Between Rich and Poor Kids Is Not What We Expected
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Income Inequality', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting']
abstract: America’s public schools are still promoting devices with screens — even offering digital-only preschools. The rich are banning screens from class altogether.
lead_paragraph: The parents in Overland Park, Kan., were fed up. They wanted their children off screens, but they needed strength in numbers. First, because no one wants their kid to be the lone weird one without a phone. And second, because taking the phone away from a middle schooler is actually very, very tough.

headline: A Dark Consensus About Screens and Kids Begins to Emerge in Silicon Valley
abstract: “I am convinced the devil lives in our phones.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The people who are closest to a thing are often the most wary of it. Technologists know how phones really work, and many have decided they don’t want their own children anywhere near them.

headline: Stacey Abrams, a Daughter of the South, Asks Georgia to Change
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Politics and Government', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: In an election steeped in issues of race, voting rights and the South’s past, present and future, Ms. Abrams is trying to become the first black woman elected governor of any state.
lead_paragraph: THOMASVILLE, Ga. — Let’s say you were making a TV movie about Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor in the reliably Republican state of Georgia. Where would you begin?

headline: How to Work a Night Shift
abstract: Avoid eating candy to stay awake. Cut off the caffeine five hours before you plan to sleep.
lead_paragraph: “Beware of the deep dark,” says Teresa Wren, who has worked the night shift for 30 years as a labor-and-delivery nurse at the University of Washington Medical Center in Seattle. With sufficient sleep during the day, you can stay alert, but you’ll have to get through a wave of fatigue between 2 a.m. and 4 a.m. Take a short nap if you can. Wren warns against eating unhealthful snacks or candy to stay awake; her go-to weapons against the darkness are one caffeinated diet soda per night and a walk up and down the external stairwell in the cool air.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Leftover Bagel Ownership
abstract: Asiago bagels, you’re on notice.
lead_paragraph: Jessica writes: Recently, I brought home three bagels from an office gathering. My boyfriend, Kelly, was going to take one for his lunch, but our dog stole it. So Kelly took the remaining two bagels (one plain, one Asiago) and is still annoyed at having “lost a bagel.” I pointed out that it had been a net gain, as technically all three were mine. Who’s right?

headline: Thanksgiving Is Coming
abstract: It’s less than a month away. Maybe it’s time to start planning.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The emails are starting to come in now from friends, the texts, the direct messages, the phone messages left in consideration and in haste: Just checking in about Thanksgiving. Had a couple questions.

headline: U.K. Apologizes for Visa Letters Demanding Immigrants Submit a DNA Test
abstract: Hundreds received illegal requests for genetic evidence of their relationship to British citizens. The home secretary, Sajid Javid, called the practice “unacceptable.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s home secretary has apologized to hundreds of immigrants who were illegally forced to provide DNA samples as part of a visa application process to settle in the country.

headline: I’m a Child of Immigrants. And I Have a Plan to Fix Immigration.
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Neither Democrats nor Republicans will like it. But it would be humane, it would adhere to the rule of law, and it would work.
lead_paragraph: An immigration lawyer once told me bluntly: Immigration is a wedge issue.

headline: Abroad in America: What Is Firing Up Female Candidates?
abstract: Welcome to the ‘Year of the Woman.’ More than 250 women are running for House and Senate seats alone.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The New York Times’s international election newsletter, where Sarah Lyall tries to explain the U.S. midterm elections to readers outside the United States (and perhaps to herself). Eleven days to go.

headline: Silicon Valley Can’t Escape the Business of War
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Cloud Computing']
abstract: Many in the tech industry don’t want to be part of the military-industrial complex. But defense work is already part of Silicon Valley’s DNA.
lead_paragraph: The sunny precincts of Silicon Valley have been wrestling for months with the question of whether technology companies should stay out of work related to the military. Google recently announced that it would no longer compete for a $10 billion Pentagon cloud computing contract. Microsoft employees have pressured its chief executive to do the same.

headline: BTS Conquered America. What’s Next for K-Pop?
abstract: Now that K-pop is successful on its own terms, the questions it faces are changing.
lead_paragraph: This year, BTS became the first K-pop act to debut atop the Billboard album chart, and recently concluded its American tour with its first sold-out stadium show in the United States, at Citi Field in Queens. The group’s rise has been rapid, and obliterated all previous notions of how far a Korean-speaking act can go in the U.S. It also reflects a K-pop audience that is widening and maturing, here and around the world.

headline: White Briton Filmed Hurling Racist Abuse on Ryanair Flight Says He’s Not Racist
abstract: David Mesher apologized to Delsie Gayle, saying he had lost his temper; and Ryanair addressed the controversy for the first time.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A white British man who was filmed shouting racist abuse at a black woman in a Ryanair plane in Spain apologized in a TV interview on Friday and said that he had lost his temper, a bit, and that he was “not a racist person by any means.”

headline: New ‘Daily Show’ Correspondent Graduated From Twitter
abstract: Jaboukie Young-White laces his comedy with sharp social commentary, often drawn from his life as a queer person of color.
lead_paragraph: Age: 24

headline: Trump’s Complaint: Bomb Plot Coverage Overtakes His Campaign Rhetoric
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: President Trump said it was “very unfortunate” that news organizations were not talking about politics and instead were focused on pipe bombs mailed to his critics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took the podium in the East Room on Friday, he opened with a solemn expression of gratitude to the F.B.I. and other law enforcement agencies for arresting a suspect in a bomb plot against prominent Democrats and other critics of him.

headline: Death Toll in Jordan Flood Reaches 21, but Grief Quickly Turns to Anger
abstract: The victims were mostly middle-school children on a trip near the Dead Sea. Officials said the school may not have had the proper permits.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Grief at the death of 21 people, mostly schoolchildren, in a flash flood near the Dead Sea in Jordan turned to anger on Friday as the Jordanian government said that the school that organized the trip may not have had the proper permits.

headline: Stocks Resume Slide, Pulling S.&P. 500 Briefly Into a Correction
abstract: The benchmark index fell to 10 percent off its most recent peak in early trading on Friday but recovered some of those losses. It is down more than 9 percent from its high in September.
lead_paragraph: Disappointing earnings reports from the tech giants Amazon and Alphabet set off another turbulent day on Wall Street on Friday, and the benchmark stock-market index briefly dipped into a correction.

headline: Mild Cauliflower Makes for an Easygoing Dinner Partner
abstract: The classic mixture of anchovies, capers and olives add deep flavors to this cauliflower salad.
lead_paragraph: I love the versatility of the unassuming cauliflower. In vegetable terms, it’s a blank canvas. That’s not to say it’s flavorless, but cauliflower’s relatively mild personality is ready to be transformed in combination with a vast number of other flavorful ingredients. Its nature is to absorb and comply.

headline: After the Royal Wedding, a Gospel Choir Hits the Big Time
abstract: Before singing for Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, the London-based Kingdom Choir was largely unknown. Now the ensemble has an album out and is set to travel the world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Karen Gibson wanted some silence. She was standing before the Kingdom Choir, the gospel ensemble she founded and has led for more than 20 years, during a recent rehearsal at a church in the London neighborhood of Pimlico. The group had just been working on a version of “All of Me,” made famous by John Legend, and a couple of dozen singers were enjoying a rambunctious moment of downtime.

headline: New Type of Credit Score Aims to Widen Pool of Borrowers
abstract: The creator of the FICO score says it will test a supplement that considers a borrower’s bank account balances and cash management.
lead_paragraph: Consumers with less-than-stellar or borderline credit scores may soon have a new option to help them qualify for loans and credit cards.

headline: He Almost Couldn’t Walk His Daughter Down the Aisle. What Is Causing His Leaden Feet?
abstract: It started as a feeling of pins and needles in his feet. Now he’s struggling to walk. Can you help?
lead_paragraph: It started as a feeling of pins and needles in his feet. Now he’s struggling to walk. Can you help?

headline: FIFA Averts ‘Institutional Crisis’ by Delaying Major Vote
abstract: The organization’s president backed down from plans to hold a vote on the creation of two new competitions that would have meant profound changes for global soccer.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — Gianni Infantino, the president of FIFA, backed down on Friday from plans to hold a vote on the creation of two new competitions that would have meant profound changes for global soccer after he was told that they would lead to an “institutional crisis” for the sport.

headline: Libraries, Writ Small
abstract: Todd Bol’s Little Free Library boxes, which blend the form of folk art with the function of a community water cooler, have popped up in all 50 states and in 88 countries.
lead_paragraph: Todd Bol was simply paying homage to his mother, a schoolteacher and lover of books. He built a doll-size schoolhouse, filled it with his mother’s books and put it out for his neighbors in Hudson, Wis., as a book exchange.

headline: From ‘Walking Dead’ Casualty to South Korean Cinema Star
abstract: Steven Yeun, who played Glenn Rhee on the TV series, rejected the Asian stereotypes Hollywood was offering. Now he’s working with world-class auteurs.
lead_paragraph: When Glenn Rhee, the scrappy pizza deliveryman turned warrior on “The Walking Dead,” became another casualty of that AMC series, Steven Yeun, the actor who played him, already felt he had outgrown his character. But like Donnie Yen, Joan Chen and other Asian-American performers before him, he had to look outside Hollywood to find three-dimensional roles that defied stereotypes and caricatures.

headline: A Stir-Fry That Brings Out the Best in Green Beans
abstract: Fresh and crisp, they’re a lean counterpart to rich, brawny pork in this garlicky, gingery, spicy dish.
lead_paragraph: Green bean season is shorter than my list of ways to prepare them. Before I can cycle through the dozen or so dishes, it’s time to move on to wintry brussels sprouts and cabbage.

headline: Netflix’s Audience Is Multiplying. But So Is Its Debt.
keywords: ['Television', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Netflix has enchanted subscribers and investors, and disrupted global media. But its dependence on debt raises questions about its real value.
lead_paragraph: Netflix, the streaming-video juggernaut, is growing with astonishing speed. And if you ignore the fact that it borrows billions to finance that growth, the company is a classic success story.

headline: Why The Times Is Covering the Caravan
abstract: Yes, President Trump is a big part of the equation. But his response to the caravan does not make this any less of a story, writes our deputy International editor.
lead_paragraph: Several readers have written to The Times asking why news organizations like ours are covering the caravan of migrants from Central America making their way toward the United States. These readers argue that President Trump is focusing national attention on the caravan as a political tactic ahead of the midterms, and that The Times should not be helping such efforts by devoting coverage to it.

headline: The Playlist: Cardi B Hits Pay Dirt, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks from Maggie Rogers, Julia Holter, Tyler, the Creator and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Last-Minute Meals
abstract: Salt-and-pepper roast chicken, broiled fish tacos, a grain frittata: Dinner doesn’t have to be a production. It can just taste like one.
lead_paragraph: Hi and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes, delicious recipes you can make on a Tuesday — but actually I also make them on Saturdays. Last weekend, a group of my closest friends came over for dinner, one of those things that miraculously comes together sort of at the last minute. I got to the store that afternoon and put a sheet pan full of chicken thighs in the oven just after my daughter went to bed. (I did chicken thighs rather than a whole chicken because they’re fast, everyone likes them and I barely have to think about them, since they cook evenly and are so forgiving.)

headline: Review: A New Conductor Inspires the Orchestra of St. Luke’s
abstract: Bernard Labadie, an early-music specialist, made his debut as the versatile ensemble’s principal conductor in a program of Haydn and Mozart.
lead_paragraph: Connoisseurs love to talk about the distinct sounds of different orchestras. But there’s art in versatility, too — in the ability of a group of players to adapt, chameleon-like, to the demands of the given music and conductor.

headline: Living in a Van Plastered With Hate, Bombing Suspect Was Filled With Right-Wing Rage
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Cesar Sayoc Jr., 56, accused of mailing 13 improvised explosive devices, had a lengthy criminal history in Florida that included felony theft, drug and fraud charges.
lead_paragraph: AVENTURA, Fla. — On Twitter, Cesar Sayoc Jr. lashed out at immigrants, gun control advocates, and prominent Democratic politicians. On Facebook, he misspelled a racial epithet, directing it at the likes of Oprah Winfrey and former President Barack Obama.

headline: Man Arrested in Britain on Suspicion of Trying to Damage Magna Carta
abstract: The document, which is more than 800 years old, has been temporarily removed from display in Salisbury, England.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A man was arrested on Thursday in connection with the vandalism of a glass display case at the cathedral in Salisbury, England, housing an original Magna Carta, one of the world’s most revered legal documents.

headline: 50 Years Later, a Victim of Ireland’s ‘Laundries’ Fights for Answers
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Nuns', 'Torture', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Elizabeth Coppin spent her youth in abusive schools and workhouses. Now, a U.N. committee on torture has agreed to hear her allegations of systematic human rights violations.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — For 30 years, she struggled with secret memories of beatings and other abuses, as well as most of the classic symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder: chronic anxiety, social isolation, compulsive behavior, depression, flashbacks, nightmares and suicidal thoughts.

headline: You’ve Become Rich. That Doesn’t Mean You’re Great at Everything.
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Wealth generated in one arena is frequently used to buy influence and control in others. That’s bad for the economy and society, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: In allowing the best competitors to rise to the top in our market economy, we allow enormous wealth to concentrate in relatively few hands. The competition that produced Apple, Tesla and Google has also produced billionaires.

headline: Review: In ‘Ordinary Days,’ a Sweet Escape to the Recent Past
abstract: Adam Gwon’s chamber musical about four New Yorkers is being revived Off Broadway in a production by Keen Company.
lead_paragraph: Every time I think about “Ordinary Days,” Adam Gwon’s chamber musical about four New Yorkers longing for meaningful connection, Stephen Sondheim’s song “Another Hundred People” starts playing in my head.

headline: Brett Howden Stands Out in the Rangers’ Youth Movement
abstract: The rebuilding Rangers see a potential star in Howden, a rookie center acquired from Tampa Bay last season.
lead_paragraph: In a rebuilding season in which they have struggled to score and win in regulation time, the Rangers are a work in progress, with a shifting lineup from game to game.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Pennsylvania’s 1st District, Fitzpatrick vs. Wallace
abstract: After the redrawing of the Pennsylvania congressional map in February, the new First District preserves the core of Pennsylvania’s Eighth and keeps Bucks County intact. But it now adds more Democratic territory from central Montgomery County, so going by 2016 results, it’s now a Clinton-leaning district instead of a Trump-leaning one.
lead_paragraph: After the redrawing of the Pennsylvania congressional map in February, the new First District preserves the core of Pennsylvania’s Eighth and keeps Bucks County intact. But it now adds more Democratic territory from central Montgomery County, so going by 2016 results, it’s now a Clinton-leaning district instead of a Trump-leaning one.

headline: Cicely Berry, Who Taught Actors Shakespeare’s Sound, Is Dead at 92
abstract: Using unorthodox methods (walk around a room, speak it together), she helped actors find their voices by feeling the weight and rhythms of the words.
lead_paragraph: Cicely Berry, whose unorthodox exercises released actors’ minds to feel the sound and muscularity of Shakespeare’s verse for nearly a half-century as the Royal Shakespeare Company’s voice director, died on Oct. 15 in Cornwall, England. She was 92.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: North Carolina’s 9th District, Harris vs. McCready
abstract: This Republican-leaning district stretches from central Charlotte to rural, traditionally Democratic and majority black areas of eastern North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: This Republican-leaning district stretches from central Charlotte to rural, traditionally Democratic and majority black areas of eastern North Carolina.

headline: Why Private Equity Is Furious Over a Paper in a Dermatology Journal
abstract: The sudden, unexplained removal of a research paper on private equity firms buying dermatology practices has raised questions about corporate influence.
lead_paragraph: Early this month, a respected medical journal published a research paper on its website that analyzed the effects of a business trend roiling the field of dermatology: the rapid entrance of private equity firms into the specialty by buying and running practices around the country.

headline: Surprise Mahler: The Week in Classical Music
abstract: A new album, the Richard Tucker Foundation gala and Bruce Nauman were among the highlights.

headline: Crazy Tender Chicken in Only an Hour
abstract: You don’t need any special equipment to get falling-off-the-bone meat. Here’s how Alison Roman does it.
lead_paragraph: Many people assume, based on what I do for a living, that I must have an extraordinary kitchen full of the latest tools and appliances. The reality here is that I have cooked with the same beat-up Dutch ovens for years, have a stove that is basically an Easy-Bake Oven, and only last year decided it was time to buy a blender (that honestly I have used only once).

headline: Facebook Removes Iranian Network That Was Spreading Disinformation
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Social Media', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
