headline: Trump’s Visit to Pittsburgh Divides a City Mourning Victims of Hate
keywords: ['Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hundreds came together in anguish to mourn those killed in an anti-Semitic attack on a synagogue. Others marched in protest as President Trump paid his respects.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — One of Pittsburgh’s most solemn days began with hundreds coming together in anguish and grief in synagogues and at gravesides, to start the services for those killed as they prayed on the Sabbath. In the afternoon, they came together again, in shivas to honor the dead and comfort the living, and, later by the thousands, in solemn marches of protest around the Squirrel Hill neighborhood where the attack took place on Saturday.

headline: The Evolution of a Restaurant Dish, From Vision to Revision
abstract: Adding a new item to the menu takes lots of trial, error and time. We followed the California chef Jeremy Fox as he created, and recreated, an elaborate chicken dish.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Standing beside a table of four at Rustic Canyon, a casual but ambitious restaurant here, a server described an elaborate new special for two or more to share: an entire spatchcocked chicken, cut into parts, with blueberries and chicken jus, and grilled chicken hearts on rosemary skewers. He detailed the three sides: housemade toast with chicken-liver mousse and poached gizzards; polenta that used corn six ways; and an okra confit with gribenes, crispy bits of chicken skin.

headline: ‘Deutschland 83’ Was a Hit Abroad but a Flop at Home. What About ‘Deutschland 86’?
abstract: The second series of the spy drama has gone down better in Germany than the first.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When the spy series “Deutschland 83” had its premiere in 2015, it was portrayed as a breakthrough moment for German television. At that point, the country had yet to produce any prestige shows with an international following, unlike France and Denmark. The series, which followed a young East German soldier corralled into working as an undercover agent on the other side of the Iron Curtain, was the first German show to air on an American network, SundanceTV. In Britain it became the most-watched foreign-language drama ever.

headline: Abroad in America: It’s Been an Awful Few Days
abstract: After two terrible events, the finger-pointing keeps getting worse.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The New York Times’s international election newsletter, where Sarah Lyall tries to explain the U.S. midterm elections to readers outside the United States (and perhaps to herself). Only a week to go.

headline: Trump’s Birthright Citizenship Proposal Is at Odds With Legal Consensus
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Constitution (US)', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Supreme Court decisions and a scholarly consensus reject Mr. Trump’s claimed power to end birthright citizenship by executive order.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The words of the 14th Amendment are plain, and the scholarly and judicial consensus about what they mean is nearly uniform: Children born in the United States automatically become citizens of the United States.

headline: Disgust vs. Delight: Why Do Certain Foods Turn You Off?
abstract: “I want people to question what they find disgusting,” said the lead curator and chief financier of the Disgusting Food Museum, a touring pop-up exhibition in Malmo, Sweden.
lead_paragraph: MALMO, Sweden — The idea that anything labeled “food” can be described as “disgusting” is a minefield, running up against cultural tastes and personal preferences, not to mention the shrinking ability of some countries to feed all their people.

headline: A Chef Draws a Map of the World, With Africa at the Center
abstract: At Henry, a hotel restaurant in Midtown, the chef JJ Johnson’s cooking has a global vision.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year Henry, a new restaurant in the lobby of the Life Hotel on West 31st Street, quietly died. You wouldn’t know it to look around the place on any recent night at 8, when a seamless playlist of hip-hop and R&B unspools as servers carry stacked beef ribs to what seems like every third table.

headline: On ‘More Blood, More Tracks,’ Familiar Bob Dylan Songs Cut Closer to the Bone
abstract: The 14th Bootleg Series release gives the songs on Dylan’s 1975 album “Blood on the Tracks” a revealing close-up, illuminating the spare versions that might have been.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan had crucial second thoughts just as he was about to release “Blood on the Tracks,” the indelible 1975 album filled with songs of separation, heartache, sorrow, rage and regret. Now it’s getting a revealing close-up. “More Blood, More Tracks: The Bootleg Series Vol. 14,” due Friday, unveils all of the initial sessions: the solo, duo and small-group versions of songs that Dylan replaced, for half of the album, with more extroverted full-band recordings. There are an exhaustive deluxe six-CD version with every surviving take and a one-CD compilation of alternate versions of the album’s 10 songs plus one that was omitted, “Up to Me.”

headline: A Discreet Jubilee for a Groundbreaking Chelsea Gallery
abstract: Paula Cooper, a model of integrity in a market gone crackers, celebrates 50 years of art and activism with an exhibition featuring artists from its very first show.
lead_paragraph: Many dealers have influenced art history through the works they’ve bought and sold, but only a very few have done something more profound: reshape how we see art and transform what we value. In New York that dealer is Paula Cooper, whose namesake gallery — the first to open south of Houston Street — has led the charge for Minimalist and Conceptual art for 50 years now. The Paula Cooper Gallery has also been defined by an embrace of music, dance and poetry, and by a political activism uncommon in galleries of its prominence. (Ms. Cooper and her husband, the editor Jack Macrae, also own the excellent bookshop 192 Books, on 10th Avenue nearby.)

headline: Claire McCaskill, a Democrat, Slams ‘Crazy Democrats’ on Fox News
abstract: Senator McCaskill, whose opponent calls her too liberal for Missouri, sought distance from liberals like Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: Senator Claire McCaskill, the Missouri Democrat facing one of the country’s toughest re-election races, raised eyebrows on Monday when she distanced herself from leading members of her own party, including two possible presidential hopefuls, Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders, in a Fox News interview about “crazy Democrats.”

headline: Tiny Love Stories: Dog Parades, Rowing-Machine Romance and a Hurricane
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring five reader-submitted love stories of 100 words or fewer.
lead_paragraph: It was a typical New York City love story: We met playing kickball, bonded over jazz and fantasy football and dog runs. We were together for a year, but Astoria is far from the Upper West Side. Weeknights became weekends became every other weekend. We split up after the Halloween dog parade, both agreeing that it just fizzled. Yet, three years later, we still talk every day. But only trading cute dog photos on Instagram. Pugs, Brussels Griffons and Frenchies exclusively. It’s one of my most cherished friendships. — Ricardo Screpka

headline: A Blind, One-Armed Piano Man From Baghdad
keywords: ['Blindness', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Music', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Disabilities', 'your-feed-onlyinnewyork']
abstract: In Staten Island, there is a bar full of middle-aged white guys who like their classic rock. And that’s exactly what Ahmed Shareef, a disabled Iraqi refugee, plays.
lead_paragraph: At Liedy’s Shore Inn, many of the guitar aficionados and ex-roadies play the Rolling Stones by night and collect Social Security checks by day. Their nostalgic, tight-knit culture is maintained by Liedy’s geographic remoteness — it is sandwiched between empty lots on the North Shore of Staten Island — and the bar’s detachment from the rest of the city. Only members of Liedy’s inner circle seem to know the correct phone number, as opposed to the obsolete one outsiders find on Google.

headline: Tally of the Dolls
abstract: How Barbie, G.I. Joe and their wee friends became powerful Instagram influencers.
lead_paragraph: It began at the breakfast buffet. He was impossible to miss: ruggedly handsome, his chiseled cheek marred only by a single, stretching scar hinting at a rough-and-ready past. I sensed a military background, his clothing-optional approach allowing me the full scope of his 16-pack abs.

headline: Whitey Bulger Is Dead in Prison at 89; Long-Hunted Boston Mob Boss
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Racketeering and Racketeers', 'Informers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: One of America’s most wanted gangsters for 16 years, he was beaten to death by fellow inmates in West Virginia. His murderous life inspired books and films.
lead_paragraph: James (Whitey) Bulger, the South Boston mobster and F.B.I. informer who was captured after 16 years on the run and finally brought to justice in 2013 for a murderous reign of terror that inspired books, films and a saga of Irish-American brotherhood and brutality, was found beaten to death on Tuesday in a West Virginia prison. He was 89.

headline: George Washington for President
abstract: Patriots put love of their own people first, while nationalists put hate for other people first.
lead_paragraph: Dear Reader. I think you know, after 23 years of my writing this column, that I’m not lazy. I always try to come up with fresh ideas. Today, though, I am fresh out of fresh ideas. More than any time in my career, I think our country is in danger. It has a disturbed man as president, whose job description — to be a healer of the country in times of great national hurt and to pull us together to do big hard things that can be done only together — conflicts with his political strategy, which is to divide us and mobilize his base with anger and fear. And time and again he has chosen the latter.

headline: As World’s Air Gets Worse, India Struggles to Breathe
abstract: Though India’s government has taken a few steps to curb pollution, data from across the country shows hazardous air pollution continues to rise.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A toxic fog is creeping over New Delhi. Children trudge to school with plastic masks strapped to their faces. Sports events are canceled. Eyes burn. Throats itch. Chests heave.

headline: A Vault of Glass and the Deepest Volcanic Eruption Ever Detected
abstract: Close to the Mariana Trench and nearly three miles below sea level, scientists found evidence of an underwater eruption that was only months old.

keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The midterms are coming, then the holidays. They don’t have to be awkward.

headline: Trump’s Wish List: No More Birthright, More Troops
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)']

headline: Eurozone Growth Slips to Four-Year Low, Fueling Crisis Fears
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Growth in Italy fell to zero, raising further questions about a government spending plan that was based on rosier projections for growth.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Economic growth in the eurozone has fallen to its slowest pace in more than four years, and Italy is not growing at all, according to figures released Tuesday. The snapshot is likely to sharpen political divisions in the European Union and make the region more vulnerable to the forces rattling financial markets.

headline: Hachibei, Specializing in Eel, Opens in Midtown East
abstract: Adam Leonti’s latest in the former Dovetail space, a rooftop bar atop an RH store, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Freshwater eel is basically all that’s served in an intimate townhouse dining room, up a flight of stairs from the street. Here, grilled eel is seared on both sides as it is brushed with a sauce developed in Kyushu, the island in southwestern Japan where it is a specialty. It comes on a bed of rice with soup, salad, seasoned tofu and pickles, $55 for the regular size and $75 for the large ($25 and $45 without tofu or salad at lunch, with only 100 orders available). The name refers to several unagi places, both stands and restaurants, on Kyushu. Okuno Hachibei, related to the family, is the consultant for the New York restaurant, which is owned by a group of eel-loving investors who prefer to be in the background. As to the décor, the restaurant has black walls, red curtains and a light wood counter and tables; it seats only 40. (Opens Friday)

headline: Review: In ‘When We Went Electronic,’ Hell Is Available in Spandex
abstract: Caitlin Saylor Stephens’s play, directed by Meghan Finn for the Tank, is like a fun house ride that’s just a pile of distorting mirrors.
lead_paragraph: Bethany and Brittany — creatures of nylon, texturizer and vocal fry — are sales associates at the flagship branch of American Apparel. Their tights are ripped. Their bruises are covered by Ray-Bans. They can’t remember what happened last night, and they can’t seem to leave this stockroom. Think “No Exit,” with Lycra.

headline: How a ‘Jews for Jesus’ Moment Backfired for Mike Pence
abstract: A look at the contentious history of Messianic Judaism, and why a campaign event prayer provoked controversy after the synagogue attack.
lead_paragraph: At a campaign stop in Michigan this week, Vice President Mike Pence condemned anti-Semitism and the deadly massacre at Pittsburgh synagogue, and asked “a leader in the Jewish community” to offer a prayer for the victims and the country.

headline: FIFA, Hacked Again, Braces for New Revelations
abstract: Embarrassed by earlier leaks, officials from soccer’s world governing body and their counterparts at UEFA are preparing for the release of more private information.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — FIFA acknowledged this week that its computer systems were hacked earlier this year for the second time, and officials from European soccer’s governing body fear they also might have suffered a data breach.

headline: I Thought the Web Would Stop Hate, Not Spread It
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: This is what the internet has come to: thugs like Mohammed bin Salman funding tech companies to host the vitriol of thugs like Cesar Sayoc and Robert Bowers.
lead_paragraph: When I was a reporter at The Washington Post back in the pre-Internet days, there was a man who would write me a letter every time I had a story that had a name in it that he perceived to be Jewish.

headline: Edward Gorey Was Eerily Prescient
abstract: A new biography celebrates his mysterious life and art.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the Order of the Good Death, a group of academics, artists and death professionals, held its annual Death Salon, which this year took place at Mount Auburn cemetery in Boston. Among the events was a tribute to Edward Gorey, the artist and author of such illustrated books — fiercely beloved by certain dark-hearted children, and adults too — as “The Gashlycrumb Tinies” and “The Doubtful Guest.”

headline: After Maryland Player’s Death, Coach and Athletic Director Keep Their Jobs
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: D.J. Durkin will keep his job as Maryland head coach, but President Wallace Loh announced he would retire in June in the wake of Jordan McNair’s death last summer.
lead_paragraph: At modern American universities, it is not unusual that the head football coach is the most powerful, and the highest-paid, individual.

headline: A Mobster of Many Enemies, Whitey Bulger May Have Been Killed in a Hit
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Informers', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: The notorious South Boston mobster and F.B.I. informant was found dead in a federal prison in West Virginia on Tuesday after what was described as an attack by other inmates.
lead_paragraph: James (Whitey) Bulger had amassed enemy after enemy over a lifetime of murder, extortion, double-crossing and — in a breach of the cardinal rule of his ilk — snitching on rival mobsters.

headline: You’re Disillusioned. That’s Fine. Vote Anyway.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Governors', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: Very pragmatic advice for anyone thinking about not casting a ballot.
lead_paragraph: A young woman in Milwaukee recently asked me if I had any advice for disillusioned young voters. She said that in a representative democracy it was hard to want to vote for, in her words, “yet another 40,000-year-old white man” who didn’t look like her or have familiarity with her experiences.

headline: After Pittsburgh Shooting, Rabbis Talk to Children About Responding to Hate
abstract: Rabbis across North America told us how they are comforting their congregations and securing their synagogues in the wake of the Pittsburgh shooting.
lead_paragraph: In the days since a gunman killed 11 people inside the Tree of Life synagogue in Pittsburgh on Saturday, rabbis have been forced to answer difficult questions from their grieving congregations as they help their communities grapple with the news of such a horrific attack. Some of the questions from children and young people have included an element of disbelief at what happened. College students have been asking Rabbi Shlomo Agishtein from Stony Brook, N.Y., how people could hate Jews this much.

headline: ‘Listen Now Again’ Is a Tasting Menu of Seamus Heaney’s Poetry
abstract: An exhibit in Dublin of the Nobel laureate’s body of work offers an archive of a productive literary life.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — On a December day seven years ago, the poet Seamus Heaney drove up to the back door of the National Library of Ireland, his car packed with 12 boxes of attic.

headline: Kepler, the Little NASA Spacecraft That Could, No Longer Can
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Kepler Space Telescope', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Planets', 'Extraterrestrial Life']
abstract: After nine and a half years in orbit, 530,506 stars observed and 2,662 planets around other stars discovered, the telescope will be left to drift forever around the sun.
lead_paragraph: Kepler, NASA’s vaunted planet-hunting space telescope, has run out of maneuvering fuel and is being retired, the space agency announced on Tuesday.

headline: Senior Saudi Prince Returns to Kingdom as Royals Confront Khashoggi Crisis
abstract: The return of King Salman’s brother, who had feared arrest if he went back to Saudi Arabia, may be a sign the royal family is seeking a unified response to the furor over the death of Jamal Khashoggi.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A senior member of the Saudi royal family, who had feared returning to the kingdom, flew back to Riyadh from London on Tuesday in the most significant move in the royal family since the killing of the dissident Jamal Khashoggi.

headline: Facebook’s Vision for the Future: Less News Feed, More Stories
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Company Reports']
abstract: The social network, which reported slowing growth on Tuesday, has plans to reduce its dependence on News Feed.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Facebook told Wall Street in July that its business would slow down, it had few answers for how it planned to change that trajectory.

headline: Dionisio Lind, Whose Voice Was a Mighty Carillon, Dies at 87
abstract: For decades, Mr. Lind played at the Riverside Church and at St. Martin’s Episcopal in Harlem, sounding their bells far and wide.
lead_paragraph: Dionisio Lind, whose bell ringing was heard but not seen by generations of New Yorkers who harkened to the pealing from carillons at two majestic Manhattan churches, died on Oct. 10 in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: A Source for Global Pantry Staples
abstract: Snuk, a new online retailer, sells harder-to-find ingredients like almonds from Afghanistan and preserves from Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: An online merchant for harder-to-find ingredients has just gotten off the ground. Snuk Foods, based in Industry City, Brooklyn, sells Afghan almonds, Spanish tinned seafood, Korean fig vinegar, Pakistani mango pickles and much more. Recipes and background information for the ingredients are also included on the website.

abstract: Melissa Clark’s sweet potatoes are brought to life by butter — and maybe a little more than a splash of bourbon.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark’s sweet potatoes are brought to life by butter — and maybe a little more than a splash of bourbon.

headline: Inquiry Into Ryan Zinke Land Deal Is Said to Escalate
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: The move, if confirmed, is a sign that the federal government is considering a criminal investigation of the interior secretary’s conduct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Interior Department’s top watchdog has referred an investigation into a possible conflict of interest by Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke to the Justice Department, according to a person familiar with the matter, a sign that the federal government is considering a criminal investigation of Mr. Zinke’s actions.

headline: Brioche Chestnut Stuffing
abstract: Melissa Clark’s mother, Rita Clark, loves chestnut stuffing but likes to use frozen leftover bagels. Melissa prefers to break out the brioche. Here’s the compromise.

abstract: The shipping company said it was ending a discount program with the gun group, after a routine review that began months ago.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Text Messaging', 'Absentee Voting']

If you see a suspicious post or text, please take a screenshot and share it with us.]

headline: Synagogue Suspect’s Guns Were All Purchased Legally, Inquiry Finds
abstract: Robert Bowers, accused of killing 11, legally bought and possessed the assault weapon and three handguns he used in the massacre, the A.T.F. said.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of the Pittsburgh synagogue shooting, Robert Bowers, legally purchased the guns he used to kill 11 people in what is believed to be the deadliest attack against the Jewish community in the United States, according to the federal authorities.

headline: Roast Turkey With Garlic and Anchovies
abstract: Melissa Clark is roasting her Thanksgiving turkey with garlic and anchovies — a tribute to her late father, who loved cooking the turkey.

headline: Potential Midterm Upsets We’re Watching
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Previewing some possible midterm surprises; plus, a trip off the grid in North Dakota, and new polls in California and Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Parts of America Are Still Struggling Economically. They Don’t Matter Much in the Midterms.
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The most competitive districts in the race for control of the House are disproportionately prosperous — and their economies aren’t doing much to lift Republicans.
lead_paragraph: With just days to go before the midterm elections, President Trump is making an economic appeal to well-off suburban voters: Elect Republicans, the president warns in tweets and a new national ad, or kiss the good economic times goodbye.

headline: In Echo of Flint, Mich., Water Crisis Now Hits Newark
abstract: For months, Newark officials said on the city’s website that its tap water was “ABSOLUTELY SAFE TO DRINK,” despite parallels to what happened with lead in Flint.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — For nearly a year and a half, top officials in Newark denied that their water system had a widespread lead problem, despite ample evidence that the city was facing a public health crisis that had echoes of the one in Flint, Mich.

headline: Hawaiian Supreme Court Approves Giant Telescope on Mauna Kea
abstract: The court granted a building permit for a roughly $2 billion observatory, which activists had protested would further degrade the site of an ancient volcano.
lead_paragraph: After years of hearings and litigation, the Supreme Court of Hawaii on Tuesday approved a building permit for a giant telescope on the ancient, contested site of the volcano Mauna Kea.

headline: Pittsburgh, Midterms, Whitey Bulger: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: #MeToo Ripples Reach the Suzuki Violin World
abstract: William Preucil, the violinist fired by the Cleveland Orchestra amid sexual misconduct accusations, plays on Suzuki lesson recordings. He will be replaced.
lead_paragraph: When the Cleveland Orchestra fired its longtime concertmaster, William Preucil, last week amid accusations of sexual misconduct, the news soon resonated beyond the orchestra world to music teachers and the parents of violin students.

headline: As Merkel Eyes Exit, Nervous E.U. Wonders Who’ll Take the Stage
abstract: News that Chancellor Angela Merkel, who is synonymous with the European Union, plans to step down has created anxiety over who can fill her shoes.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European stage Angela Merkel commanded for so long and so effectively may be cracking, if not collapsing. She has been the poster woman for Europe’s democratic center, but the center is imploding. She and Germany have been a symbol of stability, but now even Germany is seen as politically unstable.

headline: Standing ‘Against White Supremacy,’ G.O.P. Campaign Chief Rebukes Steve King
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Neo Nazi Groups']
abstract: The head of the House Republican campaign arm all but jettisoned Representative Steve King of Iowa, declaring “we must stand up against white supremacy.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Pittsburgh began burying the victims of Saturday’s synagogue massacre, the head of the House Republican campaign arm all but jettisoned Representative Steve King of Iowa from the House Republican Conference, declaring, “We must stand up against white supremacy and hate in all forms.”

headline: Defense Contractor Accused of Slighting Reservists in Hiring
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Discrimination', 'Reserves (Military)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Defense Contracts', 'Pilots']

lead_paragraph: In October 2014, Nathan Kay applied for a job as a pilot at L3 Technologies, a Pentagon contractor that helps conduct surveillance and reconnaissance missions around the world.

headline: Brazil Lurches to the Right
abstract: Jair Bolsonaro joins the club of reactionary populists rising to power.
lead_paragraph: The script has become familiar in this global season of far-right politics: A fringe politician peddling vitriol and promising order catches the mood of a nation yearning for change, any change, and rides it to the presidential palace.

headline: Ghosts, Goblins and Ghouls? The New York Times Was on It
abstract: During the 19th and early 20th centuries, ghost stories were a common feature in newspapers across the country. The Times was no different.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

keywords: ['Hurricane Florence (2018)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Floods']

headline: Amid Calls for Hate Crime Charges in Kroger Killings, Prosecutors Say It’s Complicated
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Under Kentucky law, a crime is not labeled a hate crime until sentencing. But federal prosecutors could bring separate hate crime charges.
lead_paragraph: One of the two black grandparents killed by a white gunman on Oct. 24 at a Kroger supermarket in a suburb of Louisville, Ky., was buried on Tuesday. A funeral for the other is scheduled for Saturday. In the meantime, calls continue to grow for hate-crime charges to be filed in their deaths.

headline: Horacio Cardo, Illustrator With a Political Edge, Is Dead at 74
abstract: Mr. Cardo’s phantasmagorical paintings and collages offered compelling commentary on war, social issues and Freudian psychoanalysis.
lead_paragraph: Horacio Cardo, an Argentine artist whose phantasmagorical paintings and collages were known for their compelling commentary about politics, war, social issues and Freudian psychoanalysis, died on Oct. 22 in Pinamar, a resort city on the eastern coast of Buenos Aires Province. He was 74.

abstract: It casts rogue grievances as legitimate obsessions and gives prejudices the shimmer of ideals.

headline: Giants Quarterback Kyle Lauletta Accused of Almost Hitting Officer With Car

headline: Trump Administration to Revise Birth Control Exemptions in Hopes of Saving Them
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Women and Girls', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Having lost in two federal courts and fearing more setbacks, the Trump administration is revising rules that allow employers to deny women insurance coverage for contraceptives based on religious or moral objections.

headline: The Internet of Things (That Go Bump in the Night)
abstract: What happens when the devices that promise to improve our lives turn bad?

headline: They’re Trained for War. Now American Troops Are Headed to the U.S. Border.
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Posse Comitatus Act (1878)']
abstract: President Trump’s pledge to send soldiers to the border likely will be costly, will divert military resources from other conflicts and threats and has echoes of a 2014 scare over Ebola.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Already, President Trump has sent 1,000 military forces to the southwest border in a decision he said will protect Americans from a caravan of migrants coming from Central America. He has pledged to deploy at least 4,000 more troops by week’s end, as part of a last-ditch effort to galvanize the Republican base before the midterm elections on Tuesday.

headline: Inside Gen Z
abstract: Winners of a Learning Network contest share their take on what previous generations should know about them.
lead_paragraph: The Learning Network, a site about teaching and learning with content from The New York Times, runs contests for students all year long. In September, we challenged teenagers to analyze media and adult stereotypes about their generation — then take photos to counter them. “What can you show us from your own life, or the lives of those around you, that might help make the portrait of ‘Gen Z’ more interesting, nuanced, complete or real?” we asked. Nearly 2,200 students answered. Here are 11 of our winners, with excerpts from their accompanying artists’ statements. You can see many more at learning.nytimes.com.  —Katherine Schulten

headline: For Many American Families, Abolishing Birthright Citizenship Is ‘Unthinkable’
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: America has long conferred citizenship on those born within its borders, a principle which has led to crucial opportunities for immigrant families.
lead_paragraph: Cipriano and Josefa moved to the United States in the early 1990s from Guerrero, Mexico, and settled in North Carolina. They got jobs on chicken farms, hoping to secure a chance at the American dream for their growing family.

headline: Plot to Smear Mueller Unravels as F.B.I. Is Asked to Investigate
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates', 'Sexual Harassment', 'News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The office of the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, has asked the F.B.I. to investigate what appears to be an effort to smear him, stemming from suspicious emails offering women money in exchange for fabricating sexual misconduct claims against him.

headline: Do You Live in an Area Where Voting Has Become Tougher?

headline: Port Authority Bomber Was Trying to Commit Suicide, Defense Argues
abstract: As the terror trial of Akayed Ullah opened, his lawyer said he had nothing to do with the Islamic State, but had tried to kill himself with a pipe bomb.
lead_paragraph: After a Bangladeshi immigrant detonated a homemade pipe bomb last December in a crowded subway corridor near the Port Authority Bus Terminal, he admitted his role in the attack, the government said, telling investigators, “I did it for the Islamic State.”

headline: Mets Introduce Brodie Van Wagenen, Their New G.M. (and a Recovering Agent)
abstract: Van Wagenen, 44, has represented stars like Jacob deGrom and Yoenis Cespedes, and he has never worked in a team’s front office.
lead_paragraph: For many years, Brodie Van Wagenen has been part of Mets’ news conferences, sitting in the audience as a new contract for one of his clients, such as Yoenis Cespedes or Todd Frazier, was announced. On Tuesday afternoon, Van Wagenen stepped in front of the audience to complete an unorthodox transition — from working as an agent, who frequently negotiated against the Mets, to being their general manager and the voice of the team in negotiations.

headline: First College Football Playoff Rankings: No Surprises but a Few Conundrums
abstract: Top-ranked Alabama leads the way, and three conferences may be facing battles to put teams in the final four-team field.
lead_paragraph: The College Football Playoff committee has certainly faced tougher tasks than determining which team to slot first in its initial rankings this season.

headline: Chinese Intelligence Officers Accused of Stealing Aerospace Secrets
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: China’s intelligence service has used espionage and computer hackings to steal secrets from American companies to help its own government-run industries, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Intelligence officers in a small office in China’s vast intelligence-gathering network for years stole secrets from aerospace companies in the United States and abroad, Justice Department officials said on Tuesday in unsealing the third indictment in recent weeks that detailed China’s elaborate efforts to steal corporate secrets through espionage and hacking.

headline: Political Mailer Prompts Charges of Anti-Semitism

headline: Deer Antlers Couldn’t Grow So Fast Without These Genes

headline: In Campaign’s Homestretch, Trump Tosses Out Ideas to See What Sticks

headline: Samsung Reaps Record Profit, but Tougher Times Could Come
abstract: The South Korean giant’s smartphone business is stagnant, and a yearslong run-up in the price of memory chips seems to be cooling down.

headline: In California, the Search for a Missing 800-Pound Hammer Continues
abstract: The hammer heist, in Healdsburg, Calif., has befuddled the city and its officials. At one point, a large nail appeared where the hammer had once been.
lead_paragraph: As residents of Kansas City, Mo., revel in the recovery of a sorely missed “stolen colon,” locals in Healdsburg, Calif., are still holding out hope for their own oversize oddity.

headline: Review: Remembering What Was and Wasn’t in ‘Good Grief’
abstract: Ngozi Anyanwu’s tender new play, directed by Awoye Timpo at the Vineyard Theater, considers the nature of memory in the aftermath of a tragedy.
lead_paragraph: This is the way they were. Maybe.

headline: Review: In ‘Days of Rage,’ the Revolution Will Be Trivialized

(The design house dressed models up as tarot cards for an ad campaign last year, and this year, cast Tippi Hedren of “The Birds” fame as a soothsaying crystal ball gazer in a short video.) Sephora, too, recently planned to stock a Starter Witch Kit from Pinrose in stores, but it was pulled after some protested that it was culturally appropriative.

A prominent governor who spoke out in her defense was killed by his own bodyguard, and mobs have rallied against the suggestion that leniency might be in order.

Instead, Lopez, the multihyphenate performer, producer and branding maven, held a half-dozen business meetings in her home here, from early morning until sundown, on ambitious ventures ranging from real estate to fitness.

headline: Once at Guantánamo, 5 Senior Taliban Members Now Join Political Office in Qatar
abstract: The insurgent group said the five leaders who were traded for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in 2014 have been shifting to active roles just as peace talks are being pushed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Five senior Taliban members who spent years in the American prison camp at Guantánamo Bay have joined the insurgency’s political office in Qatar at a time when that delegation has been at the center of American efforts to start a peace process, Taliban officials said Wednesday.

headline: New York Attorney General Debate: 5 Takeaways From James vs. Wofford

lead_paragraph: Seven days before Election Day, Letitia James and Keith H. Wofford finally faced off on Tuesday night in their only debate for New York attorney general, mixing fireworks with substantive disagreements on policy issues.

headline: How to Write a Condolence Letter
abstract: Include a specific memory. Avoid platitudes and religious language.
lead_paragraph: “It doesn’t have to be in flowery language on fancy stationery,” says Barbara Bouton, who worked with bereaved families for more than two decades at a hospice in Louisville, Ky., before joining the National Hospice and Palliative Care Organization. People often avoid those who have experienced death — they literally look away. Don’t do that. Your loved ones will die, too. Death is part of the connective tissue that binds humans across time and culture and place. Sit down and write the person a letter; doing so will make it easier when you see that person to look her in the eye and acknowledge the loss.

headline: How to Cook All the Mushrooms
abstract: Roast them brown and sweet, then pickle them through and through.
lead_paragraph: I think about cooking mushrooms as soon as there’s a chill in the air and I catch the scent of rain-soaked earth. But why? I was never attuned to mushroom seasons. I’ve never come home from a brisk walk in the woods like some 20th-century food writer, rain boots caked with mud, baskets full of wild varieties that I identified on sight. When I was growing up, my family bought pints and pints of brown- and white-button mushrooms all year round from the supermarket. I remember how they were squashed together and sealed tight, their graying, velveteen caps pressing obscenely against the plastic. But these mushrooms, these cheap, seasonless mushrooms, they taught me almost everything I needed to know — namely, that I loved mushrooms.

headline: How the Far Right Is Shaking Germany’s Political Order
abstract: Germany’s role as the defender of a liberal and tolerant Europe is in jeopardy in part because of a far-right political party that is gaining strength. We went to Chemnitz, where weekly protests take place against immigration, to see why the far right feels emboldened.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday in Chemnitz, Germany, a crowd of far-right activists gather to denounce immigrants.

headline: Her Allergies Were Getting Better, So Why Were Her Sinus Headaches Getting Worse?
abstract: Her doctors couldn’t figure out why the pain in her head was becoming excruciating. They’d need to rethink their assumptions.
lead_paragraph: It was the pain that woke her that night — the worst pain the 60-year-old woman had ever felt. It was as if a C-clamp were tightened around her head and face, punctuated with pulsations of what seemed like an electrical current.

headline: Being Fit May Be as Good for You as Not Smoking
abstract: A new study found a strong correlation between endurance and living a long life.
lead_paragraph: Being in shape may be as important to a long life as not smoking, according to an interesting new study of the links between fitness and mortality.

headline: Elena Ferrante Stays Out of the Picture
abstract: For two years, the pseudonymous literary sensation corresponded regularly with the director adapting “My Brilliant Friend” for HBO. But the resulting show is a testament to her elusiveness.
lead_paragraph: Saverio Costanzo, the 43-year-old director of the HBO limited series “My Brilliant Friend,” is a haunted man. For over a decade, he has corresponded with a woman whose face he cannot see, whose voice he cannot hear, whose existence is confirmed only by the many thousands of words she has written dissecting his artistic choices. When he speaks of her, his black eyes turn upward, as if seeking a trace of her in the cracks of the ceiling or in some metaphysical plane high above the penthouse suite of the Beverly Hilton Hotel, where Costanzo and the cast of “My Brilliant Friend” have arrived for HBO’s summer press tour. “Sometimes she was so strong,” he said, gruffly. “I don’t know. I’m still trying to put everything together. It’s very hard. It was like working with a ghost.”

headline: The Particular Horror of Long Commutes for Young Families
keywords: ['Work-Life Balance', 'Working Hours', 'Commuting', 'Parenting', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Traffic jams and delayed trains are infuriating for everyone, but they’re especially painful when they make you miss your baby’s bedtime yet again.
lead_paragraph: When Elizabeth Yura returned to the office after maternity leave, her work-life balance got more complicated. So did her commute. Before she had a baby, she was willing to put up with an hour and 45 minutes on an Amtrak commute from her home in Emeryville, Calif., to her office in Sacramento. But as a new mom, she started driving to work to save a little time: a one-way trip of an hour and 20 minutes, or longer in traffic.

headline: Training the Next Generation of Doctors and Nurses
abstract: Bed-bound mannequins that can bleed, blink and give birth (there’s even a realistic placenta); VR goggles to see what a polyp actually looks like.
lead_paragraph: For decades, medical education has followed a timeworn path — heaps of book learning and lectures, then clinical rotations exposing students to patients.

headline: Disney World? Not Again. Four Surprising Alternatives for Your Next Family Trip.
abstract: From the French Riviera to the Croatian island where “Mamma Mia II” was filmed, here are vacation spots that will appeal to multigenerational travelers.
lead_paragraph: When my husband, Daniel, and I first moved to London, we were young, child-free and eager to travel. But mere days before we left for our first long adventure — a 10-day train ride from London to Lisbon, with stops in France and Spain — I discovered I was pregnant. Needless to say, Daniel enjoyed the trip far more than I did, with a glass of wine never far from his lips and a plastic bag never far from mine.

headline: A Mandarin Duck Mysteriously Appears in Central Park, to Birders’ Delight

headline: What Isaac Asimov Taught Us About Predicting the Future
abstract: Alec Nevala-Lee considers the science fiction writer’s concept of “psychohistory,” a fictional method for predicting the future dreamed up during turbulent times.
lead_paragraph: In February, the spaceflight company founded by Elon Musk conducted a test launch of its Falcon Heavy rocket, which successfully sent its payload into orbit around the sun. Its cargo included a Tesla Roadster — which now looks like a sign of Musk’s midlife crisis — and a digital copy of the Foundation trilogy by Isaac Asimov. Two months later, Apple announced that it was developing a television version of the classic science-fiction saga for its new streaming service. Previous attempts to adapt the series have failed, which might not have surprised Asimov, who, after rereading it, confessed, “I couldn’t help noticing, of course, that there was not very much action in it.”

headline: Morningside Heights: More Space for the Money

lead_paragraph: Video games hit their 60th birthday in October, if you start counting (as many do) with Tennis for Two, a rudimentary Pong ancestor cobbled together by the physicist William A. Higinbotham at Long Island’s Brookhaven National Laboratory. Games have evolved a lot since then, of course, becoming far more complicated and visual, as well as multiplayer.

headline: Lil Peep Died Before Becoming Pop Royalty. His New Music May Change That.
abstract: The rapper and singer’s death at 21 left questions about the future of his songs. Now his closest collaborators are preparing his first full posthumous statement.
lead_paragraph: Starting in his teenage years, Lil Peep made music in his bedroom. His mother helped him pay for equipment, and he began to build an identity on his laptop, a boy singing and rapping his heart out into a machine. As he got older, the bedrooms changed but his habits didn’t: Almost all of his recording started and finished there.

headline: Trump Plays His Greatest Hits
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Elections (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The president closes the 2018 campaign with a return to his 2016 strategy.
lead_paragraph: Every good politician knows that you need a closing argument for your campaign, a way to seal the deal with wavering voters or goose turnout among the already committed. So in the last two weeks, with the midterms looming, Donald Trump has offered a set of closing arguments that might be summarized as follows: The fake news media is the enemy and reporters deserve to be roughed up a little, I’m going to help the middle class with tax cuts and cheaper prescription drugs, and nobody will be tougher on illegal immigration — whether that means sending thousands of troops to the southern border or ending birthright citizenship by fiat.

abstract: People in the U.S. House and Senate have wildly inaccurate perceptions of our opinions and preferences.

headline: $1.2 Million Homes in California, Georgia and New York

The house is currently being considered for historic designation. It is about three miles from the town center.

headline: Review: The Revelatory Early Works of Lucinda Childs at MoMA
abstract: In “Early Works (1963-1978),” Ms. Childs and her dancers beautifully show the geometries, meters and harmonies of her idiom.
lead_paragraph: The most marvelous revelations of the Museum of Modern Art’s “Judson Dance Theater: The Work Is Never Done” have come in the shape of live performances of works from 1961 to 1978. But the pleasure has been double-edged; an era is ending.

headline: The Great Center-Right Delusion
abstract: Politicians and pundits get America wrong.
lead_paragraph: What’s driving American politics off a cliff? Racial hatred and the cynicism of politicians willing to exploit it play a central role. But there are other factors. And an opinion piece by Hertel-Fernandez, Mildenberger, and Stokes in today’s Times (which is actually social science, not opinion!) seems to confirm something I already suspected: misunderstanding of what voters want is distorting both political positioning and public policy.

headline: 10 Bucolic Acres in Northern France
