headline: House Hunting in … France
abstract: Low mortgage interest rates, affordable homes and a large inventory are drawing more international buyers to rural Normandy.
lead_paragraph: This 10-acre property is in Cléville, a small area in the region of Normandy, near the English Channel, on the northwest coast of France. Surrounded by farmland and anchored by a four-story manor house built in the 17th century, it has several additional buildings, including a three-bedroom caretaker’s lodge, two four-bedroom guesthouses, renovated stables and a chapel, as well as a small airplane hangar and a garage.

headline: Protesters Rally Against Trump’s Visit to Pittsburgh
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: People gathered in Pittsburgh on Tuesday to mourn those killed in an anti-Semitic attack at a synagogue and to protest President Trump’s visit.
lead_paragraph: People gathered in Pittsburgh on Tuesday to mourn those killed in an anti-Semitic attack at a synagogue and to protest President Trump’s visit.

headline: Two Decades Filled With Laughter and Pastry
abstract: The couple met in 1997 when both lived in Los Angeles. “It was one of those lightning bolts, love-at-first-sight moments,” Gesine Bullock-Prado said.
lead_paragraph: Because marriage is an ever-evolving experience, we constantly shift, change and, in some cases, start over. In It’s No Secret, couples share thoughts about commitment and tell us what they have learned along the way.

headline: Yes, in Your Backyard
abstract: Are accessory dwelling units the answer to the housing shortage? The designer Yves Béhar thinks so, and he has a new prototype to prove it.
lead_paragraph: In the San Francisco Bay Area, a region filled with technology companies interested in design, Yves Béhar is a designer interested in technology. Among other things, Mr. Béhar and his company, Fuseproject, have helped create August smart door locks, PayPal’s brand identity, an app-connected height-adjusting desk for Herman Miller, the Snoo smart bassinet and Ori robotic furniture.

headline: A Store Had to Move Thousands of Books. So a Human Chain Was Formed.
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Moving and Moving Industry']
abstract: Volunteers passed more than 2,000 books down a street in Southampton, England, after a rent increase forced October Books to give up its old location.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The plea went out a few weeks ago from the bookstore in a port city in southern England: “Care to lend a hand?”

headline: N.F.L. at the Half: Who’s Better, Who’s Worse?
abstract: With eight weeks in the books, it’s good to be a Packers fan. The Bills? Maybe not so much.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. season is eight weeks old. A glance at the standings tells us that some teams have improved: Can you believe the Redskins are 5-2? And that others haven’t: The Eagles, the 13-3 Super Bowl winners last year, are 4-4.

headline: The Problems With Britain’s New Digital Tax
abstract: The levy is a first step toward tackling how big tech companies move revenue and costs between jurisdictions, but it may not be aggressive enough.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: Petra Laszlo, Hungarian Camerawoman Who Kicked Migrants, Has Conviction Overturned
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The country’s highest court said she should have faced a lesser charge. Video of her kicking two people in 2015 made her a symbol of hostility to refugees.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Hungary’s highest court on Tuesday overturned the conviction of a camerawoman who was filmed kicking refugees at the height of the migrant crisis in 2015, briefly becoming a symbol of the country’s hostility to people fleeing the war in Syria.

headline: What to Cook Tonight
abstract: It’s Halloween, and that may call for something simple, or you could aim higher with new recipes from Alison Roman, Melissa Clark and David Tanis.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. What a joy it is to sleep through these autumn nights, the windows cracked to chill the room, the curtains drawn against the sun that comes later each morning. I wake refreshed, eager to bring warmth into the lives of those around me. But first: Coffee, breakfast, chores. (Pity the northern suburbanites and those on rural roads, for the leaves are falling now, fast and piling deep.)

headline: What if the Powerful (and Paranoid) Started Using Official Tasters Again?
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Royals and politicians once relied on attendants to sample their meals for them, lest they contain poison. In our new age of espionage, might that practice be poised for a revival?
lead_paragraph: THE GREEN TEA was poured from a porcelain pot in a wood-paneled piano bar at the Millennium Hotel in London. It had been laced with lemon, honey and a radioactive isotope of polonium, a highly unstable element first identified in 1898 by the chemist Marie Curie. She named polonium after her homeland, Poland, which at the time did not exist as a nation-state, its territory having been parsed out and claimed by Russia, the Kingdom of Prussia and the Austro-Hungarian Empire. The name was an intentionally political act, as was the isotope’s appearance in that poisoned cup more than a century later, in 2006, presented by a former K.G.B. agent to Alexander Litvinenko, a Russian dissident and defector, who drank it and died.

headline: The Witch Continues to Enchant as a Feminist Symbol
abstract: In film and art, the figure has moved from the edges of the action to become the very plot.
lead_paragraph: “THIS WITCH,” BEGINS the recently released documentary on Ruth Bader Ginsburg. It’s a recording of the conservative talk-radio host Michael Savage, who often characterizes the justice this way. He’s hardly alone in his fondness for the word, which has only grown in popularity in the 300-plus years since the infamous Salem witch trials of 1692. These days, though, it’s often women — Lana Del Rey and Björk among them — deploying “witch” (or related terminology) to describe themselves, not as a pejorative but as a badge of honor. They may not all recite spells or worship a moon goddess, but at a time when misogyny is rampant and women’s rights are on shaky ground, they relate to the witch as a feminist symbol. A witch, after all, is a woman with power. She has the ability to heal, satisfying wellness types who like to gift potions of hyssop and mugwort, anise seed and bladder wrack from Enchantments, a decades-old occult-themed shop in Manhattan’s East Village. More than that, as the prophetic “weird sisters” of “Macbeth” make clear, she has the power to drive the plot.

headline: Turkish Prosecutor Says Saudis Strangled Khashoggi
abstract: After a campaign of leaks intended to keep pressure on the Saudis over the Saudi dissident’s death, Turkey appeared to be changing its strategy.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi was strangled almost as soon as he stepped into the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul a month ago, and his body was then dismembered and destroyed, the chief prosecutor for Istanbul said on Wednesday, giving the first official explanation from Turkey of how Mr. Khashoggi died.

headline: With $30 Million, Obscure Democratic Group Floods the Zone in House Races
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The Hub Project, a Democratic group that does not disclose its donors, has spent nearly $30 million on the midterms through an array of state-level groups.
lead_paragraph: BRADENTON BEACH, Fla. — The billboard flickered from the side of a truck, displaying an image of Representative Vern Buchanan, Republican of Florida, wearing a yachtsman’s cap. Keith Fitzgerald, a local dignitary invited by the group Floridians for a Fair Shake, stood before it as he tore into the lawmaker’s record.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Paul Mogensen’s spiraling abstractions, reconsidering the banana in a two-woman show and Franz Gertsch’s photorealist paintings.
lead_paragraph: It would be too simple to say that Paul Mogensen is doing the best work of his life right now. Over his 50-year career he has made many excellent paintings, all adamantly abstract. He has extracted an impressive variety from the possibilities of proportion and geometry, and of paint as both material and color (straight from the tube). His pursuit of the figure-ground relationship of abstraction — geometric shapes on monochromatic backgrounds — initiated by Kazimir Malevich and Piet Mondrian in the early 1900s — has led him at times to shaped canvases and also to multipanel installations that use the white wall as canvas.

headline: When Nightmares Are Real
abstract: Donald Trump has harmed me more than any specter ever could.
lead_paragraph: I have been afraid of a lot of things, over the course of a long life. But what I feel now is new.

headline: How to Punish Voters
abstract: The prosecution of individual voters for fraud is a trend that seems intended to intimidate.
lead_paragraph: Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp, the chief elections official in the state, is a pioneer of present-day voter suppression. Mr. Kemp has a record of making it harder for people to register to vote, and more difficult for those voters to remain on the rolls. Since 2012, his office has canceled more than 1.4 million voter registrations. In July 2017, over half a million people — 8 percent of the state’s registered voters — were purged in a single day. As of earlier this month, over 50,000 people’s registrations, filed before the deadline to vote in the coming midterm election, were listed as on hold. Seventy percent had been filed by black applicants.

headline: William Wheeler, New York Mass Transit Visionary, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Wheeler oversaw the strategic planning that led to, among other things, the MetroCard and countdown clocks for subways and buses.
lead_paragraph: William M. Wheeler, who as a New York mass transit official oversaw the strategic planning that inaugurated the MetroCard, belatedly spawned the first phase of the Second Avenue subway and dared, by recommending countdown clocks, to introduce the presumption that subways and buses would arrive punctually, died on Saturday at his home in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 69.

headline: Who’s the Greatest Star of ‘The Prom’? Me. Me. Me. Me.
abstract: The four musical comedy leads of this production insist that they’re not as narcissistic as their characters. Even if they’re playing versions of themselves.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of vain actors. But there are those who are way worse: vain, past-their-prime actors who want to recapture their former glory. And what better way to get attention than (big smiles, the cameras are snapping) charity work?

headline: Rosanne Cash Takes the Long View on ‘She Remembers Everything’
abstract: The singer and songwriter contemplates the present as the result of a lifetime of choices on an album that welcomes new collaborators and moodier realms.
lead_paragraph: The passage of time, tenacious love, a life on the road and inevitable mortality suffuse “She Remembers Everything,” Rosanne Cash’s new album. “From this point on there’s nothing certain/except there’s not many miles to go,” she sings in one of the album’s most upbeat songs, the country-rocker “Not Many Miles to Go.” And in “Everyone But Me,” a solemn piano hymn, she counsels, “Our strange and beautiful lies/Fade and turn to dust.” Cash is 63, and she is neither pretending otherwise nor regretting where she stands right now.

headline: Bones Are Found in Rome, Renewing Speculation in 1983 Disappearance
abstract: News reports suggested that bones discovered in a Vatican-owned building could be tied to one of Italy’s most enduring cold cases.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In June 1983, Emanuela Orlandi, the 15-year-old daughter of a Vatican employee, vanished on her way home from a music lesson. In the intervening 35 years, Emanuela’s disappearance has been one of Italy’s most intriguing cold cases.

headline: For Beto O’Rourke, a Road to Victory Winds Through Rural East Texas
abstract: If Beto O’Rourke stands any chance of winning a Senate seat in Texas, it is in the small towns of East Texas, which years ago voted for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: TYLER, Tex. — Barely a week from Election Day, Beto O’Rourke is still down in the polls. President Trump just increased his Republican opponent’s momentum at a hot-blooded rally in Houston. And despite Mr. O’Rourke’s national star power and record-breaking fund-raising, his quest seems as daunting and as unlikely as ever — winning a Senate seat in Texas, something no Democrat has done since 1988.

headline: Divers Zero In on Black Boxes From Indonesia Plane Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots', 'Recording Equipment']
abstract: Locator beacon signals allowed investigators to narrow down the location of the data recorders, but recovering them could be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Enticed by faint pings from the seafloor, Indonesian investigators have determined the general location of the data recorders that will be crucial in discovering what caused the crash of Lion Air Flight 610, one of the deadliest commercial air disasters in years, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Gayle King Has the Spotlight All to Herself
abstract: Known for decades as Oprah’s best friend, the CBS anchor has become a celebrity in her own right. Even — especially — with the network’s men imploding all around her.
lead_paragraph: Gayle King doesn’t so much enter a room as envelop it. The day we meet, in early October, the co-host of “CBS This Morning” is wearing pumps in a plaid felt material, like a Scottish kilt, that match her tricycle-red sheath dress. She is 5 foot 10 and carrying an iridescent bucket of a handbag that she periodically digs through, excavating her iPhone to show me photos of Tina Turner, whom she’d just interviewed in Zurich, and of the disappointing eyelash extensions for which she’d just paid $189.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Illinois’s 14th District, Hultgren vs. Underwood
abstract: This district, in the exurbs west of Chicago,  has long had a Republican bent. Dennis Hastert, the longest-serving Republican Speaker of the House in history, represented it from 1987 to 2007.
lead_paragraph: This district, in the exurbs west of Chicago,  has long had a Republican bent. Dennis Hastert, the longest-serving Republican Speaker of the House in history, represented it from 1987 to 2007.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Michigan’s 8th District, Bishop vs. Slotkin
abstract: This district includes Democratic-leaning areas near the state capital and Michigan State University, and  extends to the Republican-leaning outer suburbs of Detroit.
lead_paragraph: This district includes Democratic-leaning areas near the state capital and Michigan State University, and  extends to the Republican-leaning outer suburbs of Detroit.

headline: Midterm Election Poll: Iowa’s 4th District, King vs. Scholten
A Family Recovered Most of What the Nazis Stole. But Not This.
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Despite decades of effort and government intervention, the family of the Paris art dealer Paul Rosenberg has been unable to reclaim a Degas portrait.
lead_paragraph: The family of Paul Rosenberg, a renowned Paris art dealer whose gallery had exclusive arrangements with Braque, Matisse and Picasso, has worked tirelessly, with tremendous success, to recover the 400 works the Nazis looted from him.

headline: The Bay’s Final Battle
abstract: A pair of teams going nowhere in the standings will play one last time in the Bay Area before the Raiders leave for greener pastures (again).
lead_paragraph: It’s a rivalry that never was.

headline: As New Sanctions Loom, U.S. Push Against Iran Faces Steep Obstacles
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: Efforts to tighten the screws on Tehran could further alienate European allies and bruise relationships with China and India, which continue to buy large amounts of Iranian oil.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump called on world leaders in September to slash their purchases of Iran’s oil before the imposition on Nov. 5 of major sanctions, the last major pieces of the administration’s blockade of the Iranian economy.

headline: María Irene Fornés, Writer of Spare, Poetic Plays, Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Fornés won acclaim and awards for her experimental works. But her fellow playwrights often said her achievements far outstripped her fame.
lead_paragraph: María Irene Fornés, a Cuban-born American playwright whose spare, poetic and emotionally forceful works were hallmarks of experimental theater for four decades, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 88.

headline: Review: ‘Tosca’ Is Sondra Radvanovsky’s Show at the Met Opera
abstract: The star soprano brings strong singing and fervent dramatic purpose to Puccini’s classic opera.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera’s “Tosca” was plagued by drama when it was new last season. The lead singers canceled; the conductor, Met music director James Levine, was suspended amid accusations of sexual misconduct (and later fired by the company). The director, David McVicar, said he considered quitting.

headline: New York Bishop Is Accused of Sexual Abuse
abstract: John Jenik, an auxiliary bishop, has been removed from his public ministry after an allegation involving a relationship with a teenage boy in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: An auxiliary Catholic bishop in New York, John Jenik, has been accused of sexual abuse and removed from his public ministry, Catholic officials said, the latest scandal to hit an institution already reeling from revelations of inappropriate behavior by its clergy around the globe.

headline: In Congo’s Ebola Outbreak, Experimental Treatments Are Proving Effective
abstract: More than half of the patients who received treatment survived, scientists reported.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Experimental new treatments for Ebola appear to be working effectively in the most recent outbreak in Central Africa, an expert reported at a medical conference here on Wednesday.

headline: An Early Guide to the Nickel Subway Rides Is on Sale for $12,000
abstract: A gallery in Manhattan will exhibit some of New York’s historical maps, from 1548 to 1964, including transit maps and a 1904 subway guide.
lead_paragraph: Getting on the New York City subway when it opened in 1904 cost only a nickel, but one of only two known examples of a first guide to the Interborough Rapid Transit system is on sale for $12,000.

headline: For the Singer Ingrid Michaelson, Home Is Where the Art Is
abstract: Her chosen field is music, but she finds comfort in objects and images from the home where she grew up, and works by her mother and grandmother.
lead_paragraph: Clues to the essence of the singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelson are all over her quaint walk-up in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn. Brownies under a glass dome (she loves to bake). Photos of her boyfriend, the actor and singer Will Chase. A fake tree in a bag ready to be unpacked for the holidays — she’s very into Christmas.

headline: ‘The Front Runner’: When Sex in Politics Had the Power to Shock
abstract: As the drama chronicles, Gary Hart’s presidential campaign was dogged by questions about his personal life. Would we care today?
lead_paragraph: Depending on your cynicism about politics, “The Front Runner” — a film that chronicles the rise and rapid fall of Gary Hart’s quest to become the Democratic nominee for president in 1988 — seems perfectly timed as a reminder of a period when character seemed to matter a great deal more.

headline: New at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Parade: A Sunny Little Cloud
abstract: The art duo FriendsWithYou aims high with a 30-foot-wide balloon for this year’s event.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Smiley clouds have floated through the art of Samuel Borkson and Arturo Sandoval III ever since they started working together, in 2002, under the peppy name FriendsWithYou.

headline: Oxford Roiled by Invitation to Far-Right German Politician
abstract: The Oxford Union, the famed debating society, has been taken to task for giving a platform to the leader of the anti-immigrant Alternative for Germany.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — As right-wing leaders continue to rise globally, so too has the question of whether they should be heard on prestigious Western platforms.

headline: Whoa, Whoa, Whoa. Leggings That Cost $300?
abstract: A startling new industry standard.
lead_paragraph: First there were the impossible-to-get-into $40 exercise classes. Then came $365 foam rollers and $1,000 yoga mats. And now: $320 workout tights you basically have to pass a background check to be allowed to buy. Of course, they’re sold out.

headline: Satanists Might Sue ‘Sabrina’: 6 Things to Know in Pop Culture Today
abstract: What we’re talking about in TV, music and movie news this Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: What would you like to see here? Email us at popculture@nytimes.com.

headline: U.S. and Britain Seek Yemen Cease-Fire as Relations With Saudis Cool
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Pressure from Saudi Arabia’s biggest arms suppliers intensified to halt a conflict that has created what the United Nations has called the world’s worst humanitarian crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Britain, Saudi Arabia’s biggest arms suppliers, are stepping up their pressure for a cease-fire in the Yemen war, the world’s worst man-made humanitarian disaster.

headline: The View From Flooded Venice
abstract: Venice experienced its highest flooding in a decade, leaving much of the city underwater.
lead_paragraph: Venice experienced its highest flooding in a decade, leaving much of the city underwater.

headline: Country’s Fierce Supergroup Pistol Annies Returns, Humor Intact (and Baby on the Way)
abstract: Miranda Lambert, Ashley Monroe and Angaleena Presley’s “Interstate Gospel” is dropping into a Nashville landscape that’s still far from their own aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Standing onstage at the Ryman Auditorium last week between her Pistol Annies’ bandmates Ashley Monroe and Miranda Lambert, Angaleena Presley set up the gleeful divorce tune “Got My Name Changed Back” by announcing, “This next song is not about anyone in this band.” Lambert, who has endured more than a few tabloid headlines, quickly disagreed. “She’s full of it,” she said in stronger language.

headline: What You Need to Know About the Strike Against Marriott Hotels
abstract: When hotel workers go on strike, as more than 7,500 are at brands managed by the world’s largest hotel chain, it can be difficult territory for guests to navigate.
lead_paragraph: Edna Garcia saved for two years to afford her Hawaiian holiday, an 18-day splurge with two cousins. They all needed to recharge. There had been caregiving, and the loss of their mothers, and one cousin’s bout with advanced breast cancer.

headline: Blake Griffin Isn’t Bitter. Detroit Has Made Him Better.
abstract: Broken promises made him a Piston, but a fresh start and a 50-point stunner have the former Clippers superstar looking forward.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was around this time a year ago that Blake Griffin was the undisputed centerpiece of the post-Chris Paul Los Angeles Clippers. A lengthy article on his evolving game and changing stature lauded him under a headline that read: “The Clippers Are All-In on Blake Griffin.”

headline: Subscribe to ‘With Interest,’ a Weekly Newsletter About Business News That Matters
abstract: It’ll be concise, informative and entertaining, with three essential items from the past week and three for the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Scratching your head about what business headlines you need to follow, and why?

headline: Fight Fire With Fire, or Be Civil With Trump? The Obama Coalition Is Unsure
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2020', 'Youth']
abstract: The former president’s star power among Democrats is unmatched, but some supporters are skeptical that his leadership style is suited to the sharp-elbowed political moment.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — John Toles-Bey wants to be clear: He loves Barack Obama.

headline: In Fit of Pique, Trump Attacks Ryan Just Days Before Midterm Elections
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The attack, after the speaker criticized President Trump’s birthright citizenship plan, suggested that Mr. Trump was preparing to cast blame elsewhere for Republicans’ possible loss of the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump attacked the Republican speaker of the House on Wednesday for criticizing his position on birthright citizenship and said he should focus instead on safeguarding the party’s majority in Congress, a remarkable display of intraparty fighting six days before midterm elections in which the Republican majority is at risk.

headline: In ‘Heavy,’ Kiese Laymon Recalls the Weight of Where He’s Been
abstract: An American memoir full of devotion and betrayal, euphoria and anguish, tender embraces and rough abuse.
lead_paragraph: Kiese Laymon started his new memoir, “Heavy,” with every intention of writing what his mother would have wanted — something profoundly uplifting and profoundly dishonest, something that did “that old black work of pandering” to American myths and white people’s expectations. His mother, a professor of political science, taught him that you need to lie as a matter of course and, ultimately, to survive; honesty could get a black boy growing up in Jackson, Miss., not just hurt but killed. He wanted to do what she wanted. But then he didn’t.

headline: The Great Speckled Dinosaur Egg
abstract: Eggs of different colors evolved in dinosaurs before the appearance of birds.
lead_paragraph: As any child can tell you, dinosaurs, not birds, invented feathers. According to a new scientific report, dinosaurs also invented — or, if you want to get technical, first evolved — eggs of different colors. Birds did not evolve their egg colors on their own, but inherited the ability from non-avian dinosaurs.

headline: Thinking Clearly About Immigration
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Reihan Salam’s “Melting Pot or Civil War?” tries to lower the temperature of our heated immigration debate.
lead_paragraph: MELTING POT OR CIVIL WAR? A Son of Immigrants Makes the Case Against Open Borders By Reihan Salam 213 pp. Sentinel. $27.

headline: Scientists Warn That World’s Wilderness Areas Are Disappearing
abstract: “Wild areas provide a lot of life support systems for the planet,” said the author of a study that found 77 percent of earth’s land had been modified by humans.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Scientists are warning that if human beings continue to mine the world’s wildernesses for resources and convert them into cities and farms at the pace of the previous century, the planet’s few remaining wild places could disappear in decades.

headline: Tech Drove Stocks Skyward. It Was a Different Story on the Way Down.
keywords: ["Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Company Reports', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Large technology companies, and the big profits they produce, lifted the markets earlier this year. But during October’s tumble they were only part of a broad-based downturn.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest technology companies drove the stock market to record highs earlier this year. As stocks have tumbled, though, it’s more like they’re just along for the ride.

headline: Climate Change Is on the Ballot
abstract: Global warming is an issue in midterm races in the United States — not to mention Brazil’s recent election, and Canada’s next one.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Unpublished Black History
abstract: Revealing moments in black history, with unpublished photos from The New York Times archives.
lead_paragraph: Revealing moments in black history, with unpublished photos from The New York Times archives.

headline: 4 Spooky Short Stories Inspired by Haunting Images
abstract: In the spirit of Halloween, we asked writers to respond to photographs by Francesca Woodman, Gregory Crewdson and more.
lead_paragraph: In the spirit of Halloween, we asked writers to respond to photographs by Francesca Woodman, Gregory Crewdson and more, as part of our #TMicronovel series on Instagram.

headline: Once Paralyzed, Three Men Take Steps Again With Spinal Implant
abstract: An experimental, pacemaker-like device offers hope for treating spinal injuries.
lead_paragraph: David Mzee broke his neck in 2010. He was a college student in Zurich at the time, an athlete who enjoyed risk and contact, and he flipped off a trampoline and onto a foam pad. “The foam pad, it didn’t do its job,” he said.

headline: War in Yemen: New York Times Reports Driving the Conversation
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Politics and Government', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: New York Times journalists traveled to Yemen in October to provide a deeper look at the war, the latest in a series of in-depth reports.
lead_paragraph: The conflict between Saudi-backed forces and Houthi rebels in Yemen, which has led to the world’s worst humanitarian crisis, has captured growing international attention.

headline: Review: ‘Homecoming’ Is Military, Industrial and Complex
abstract: In Amazon’s thriller, Julia Roberts plays a counselor for war veterans who starts to question who her research is really meant to help.
lead_paragraph: Sam Esmail’s “Mr. Robot” is one of the most audacious, inventive TV dramas of this decade. It is also, well, a lot. It’s narratively and creatively maximalist, full of subplots, conspiracies, directorial triple back flips and twist upon baffling twist.

headline: In Lyric McHenry’s Death, a Bronx Man Is Arrested
abstract: Two months after Ms. McHenry, a budding film producer, died of an overdose, a man has been charged with dumping her body on a desolate Bronx sidewalk.
lead_paragraph: Lyric McHenry, a Stanford University graduate with a budding film career, slipped away from her 26th birthday party at a Manhattan hotel two months ago without saying goodbye. A few hours later, her lifeless body was discovered on a desolate street in the Bronx. She had scraped knees and a glassine envelope of cocaine in her pocket.

headline: Pittsburgh Grieves, With Back-to-Back Funerals and Mourners 50 Deep
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The public rituals of mourning those killed in the synagogue shooting are accumulating day by day.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Beth Markovic, an owner of the last kosher grocery store in Pittsburgh, was up to her elbows on Wednesday, making yet another order of sherry mushroom chicken. She has lost track, she said, of how many orders she has made since the devastating massacre here last weekend.

headline: On a Tiny Finnish Island, a Helipad, 9 Piers — and the Russian Military?
abstract: Finnish police and soldiers recently raided a mysterious island. Why? Many suspect that Russia was buying land in Finland for secret military bases.
lead_paragraph: SAKKILUOTO, Finland — Retired to a tiny island in an archipelago between Finland and Sweden, Leo Gastgivar awoke early one morning to visit the outhouse in his bathrobe, only to notice two black speedboats packed with Finnish commandos in camouflage fatigues waiting in the bay near his front door.

headline: Geneticists, Step Up
abstract: In a time of racial tension, an ethicist sees an urgent need to educate the public.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Swizz Beatz Has a Closet Full of Black Calvin Klein T-shirts
abstract: The producer and musician also has a thing for Saint Laurent jeans, Zara suits and anything vintage.
lead_paragraph: Swizz Beatz, who recently released his second studio album, “Poison,” grew up in the Bronx and lives in Manhattan, but he considers his style to be global. Whether he’s in London, Tokyo or Cape Town, he is always shopping for clothes. That may explain why his closet is in need of pruning. Just ask his wife, Alicia Keys, who keeps her side of the closet tidy.

headline: Disenfranchising Native American Voters
abstract: A reader discerns a new low in Republican cynicism.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mel Ramos, Painter of Female Nudes and Comic Heroes, Dies at 83
keywords: ['Art', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Women and Girls', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: In his precisely painted portraits of unclothed women, Mr. Ramos tiptoed on the line between Pop Art and smut.
lead_paragraph: Mel Ramos, whose many paintings featuring realistically depicted nude or underdressed women often left critics divided over whether they were clever Pop Art or something more akin to smut, died on Oct. 14 in Oakland, Calif. He was 83.

headline: What if He Falls?
abstract: Alex Honnold took a huge risk when he made his free solo climb of El Capitan. Did making a film about it make it even riskier?
lead_paragraph: Alex Honnold took a huge risk when he made his free solo climb of El Capitan. Did making a film about it make it even riskier?

headline: How Does the Urban Prairie Girl Do Winter?
abstract: With some styling tricks and a cold-weather purchase or two, you can translate the aesthetic of the moment into 40-degree attire.
lead_paragraph: We already know that the Urban Prairie Girl ruled summer, in her high necks, apron details and ruffles, making “Amish dowdiness seem a provocative fashion choice,” as noted by another writer in The New York Times. But with temperatures already dipping to 40, how will the U.P.G., whose look centers on calico and gingham, acclimate?

headline: What if He Falls?
abstract: Alex Honnold took a huge risk when he made his free solo climb of El Capitan. Did making a film about it make it even riskier?
lead_paragraph: What happens if the person you are making a documentary film about is attempting one of the most dangerous feats imaginable?

headline: What Frankenstein’s Monster Really Looks Like
abstract: Mary Shelley’s great novel is about the failure to recognize the humanity of those who don’t resemble us.
lead_paragraph: This Halloween I’m hoping to see at least a few trick-or-treaters dressed as Frankenstein’s monster. After all, this year is the 200th since the publication of Mary Shelley’s great novel, which perhaps more than any other book has become the model of modern literary horror.

headline: Yemen, Pakistan, Indonesia: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bust Magazine Is on a Mission
abstract: Jane is gone. Teen Vogue (the print version) is gone. The Village Voice, gone. How has this feminist lifestyle publication survived for 25 years?
lead_paragraph: “The blood’s not real,” said a staffer at the Brooklyn headquarters of Bust, the independent, feminist lifestyle magazine and website. Her tattooed and bare arms were streaked with red, as were those of an intern, who quipped, “Just another day at the office.” They had been working on a photo shoot for a Halloween-themed haunted house feature.

headline: Spotting Disinformation Online Before the Midterm Elections
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Censorship', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: Rumors. Inflammatory and divisive messages. Doctored photos. Kevin Roose, technology columnist, explains how he has waded into that shadowy world to write about it.
lead_paragraph: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Kevin Roose, a technology columnist in New York who has been writing about disinformation online, discussed the tech he’s using.

headline: The Fear of Losing Your Health Insurance
abstract: Readers express concern that the Affordable Care Act may be overturned.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: In ‘Boy Erased,’ a Young Man Struggles With Faith and Sexuality
abstract: Lucas Hedges, Nicole Kidman and Russell Crowe star in a true story about a discredited (but still practiced) “treatment” for homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: Jared Eamons, an Arkansas college student who is an avid runner and an aspiring writer, is also gay. Or rather, he is in the midst of figuring that out about himself — what it means, how he might act on it — when his panicked parents enroll him in a conversion therapy program designed to change, or at least suppress, his sexuality.

headline: Neighbor Arrested in Fatal Slashing of 70-Year-Old on Upper West Side
abstract: The police detained a 24-year-old woman on charges that she killed her downstairs neighbor, Susan Trott, inside the older woman’s apartment.
lead_paragraph: A trail of blood led from one apartment to another. That was the first clue that led the police to suspect a 24-year-old woman in the fatal stabbing of her neighbor in an Upper West Side co-op.

headline: An Unlikely Duck Spotting in Central Park
abstract: Bird watchers were delighted to see a Mandarin duck, native to East Asia, unexpectedly appear in Central Park in October.
lead_paragraph: Bird watchers were delighted to see a Mandarin duck, native to East Asia, unexpectedly appear in Central Park in October.

headline: Whitey Bulger’s Fatal Prison Beating: ‘He Was Unrecognizable’
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: Everyone knew Whitey Bulger had enemies. Some question how they got to him so quickly, right after he was transferred to a West Virginia prison.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The inmates who killed James (Whitey) Bulger, Boston’s notorious crime boss, deliberately moved out of view of surveillance cameras in a West Virginia prison before pummeling him with a padlock that was stuffed inside a sock, law enforcement officials said on Wednesday, as investigations began into how such a murder could have taken place in a supposedly secure facility.

headline: Inside What Even an Ally Calls Trump’s ‘Reality Distortion Field’
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: From nonexistent riots to conspiracy theories about migrants to false claims about his popularity and job-creating record, the president has offered a litany of falsehoods in the midterm campaign.
lead_paragraph: As he barnstorms the country trying to help Republican allies, President Trump has offered voters this fall a litany of misleading statements and falsehoods that exaggerate even legitimate accomplishments and distort opponents’ views beyond the typical bounds of political spin.

headline: Trump’s Visit to Pittsburgh
keywords: ['Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: One reader is shocked that the president needs advice from family members about how to respond to a tragedy. Another criticizes those who protested his visit.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Final Debate in Georgia Governor’s Race Canceled as Republican Breaks Schedule
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Elections, Governors', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Midterm Elections (2018)']
abstract: The candidates for governor had long planned to debate on Sunday evening. But that was before President Trump announced a campaign rally.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Plans for the final debate of Georgia’s raucous race for governor collapsed on Wednesday after the Republican nominee, Brian Kemp, abandoned the forum’s long-scheduled timing so he could campaign alongside President Trump this weekend.

headline: 5 Harvard Friends, and a Frank Talk About How They Got In
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Asian-Americans', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: As a lawsuit challenging the use of affirmative action in admissions plays out, five freshmen reflect on why they beat the competition.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Two freshman friends sat across from each other in a common room, comparing notes on how exactly they got into Harvard. In some ways, their situations were opposites: One was a “double legacy,” with two parents who had received Harvard degrees. The other was the son of a police officer and on full financial aid.

headline: Trump vs. the Media: Is the President Winning?
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “Mr. Trump is no master of the actual duties of the presidency, but he is a master of using the media for his own ends,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Democrats in an All-Hands-on-Deck Scramble to Save Menendez in New Jersey
abstract: In the deeply blue state, the race between Senator Robert Menendez and Bob Hugin is tight. Party leaders are pulling out the stops to defend the seat.
lead_paragraph: UNION BEACH, N.J. — It was a rare convergence of New Jersey’s governor and its two senators for an official event meant to be about policy, not politics.

headline: How the War in Yemen Became a Bloody Stalemate — and the Worst Humanitarian Crisis in the World
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: Saudi Arabia thought a bombing campaign would quickly crush its enemies in Yemen. But three years later, the Houthis refuse to give up, even as 14 million people face starvation.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia thought a bombing campaign would quickly crush its enemies in Yemen. But three years later, the Houthis refuse to give up, even as 14 million people face starvation.

headline: Studies Warn Against Minimally Invasive Surgery for Cervical Cancer
abstract: Compared to open surgery for cervical cancer, the less invasive approach was more likely to result in cancer recurrence and death, new studies found.
lead_paragraph: Two new studies revealed bad news about minimally invasive surgery for cervical cancer, a widely used procedure performed through small slits in the abdomen instead of a big incision.

headline: Amy Landecker Reads ‘An Ancient Coda to My 21st-Century Divorce’
abstract: The “Transparent” star tells a story of unexpected closure years after a divorce.
lead_paragraph: Planning her second wedding, Cindy Chupack thought her first marriage was long behind her. Then her rabbi told her that the divorce would not be final without a “get,” a Jewish divorce certificate. On this week’s Modern Love podcast, the actress Amy Landecker reads “An Ancient Coda to My 21st-Century Divorce,” an essay about new beginnings made possible by an old ritual.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Google Settlement That Paid Class Members Nothing
abstract: In a lively argument, the justices considered internet privacy and whether payments to charities are a good way to settle class actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a lively and freewheeling argument on Wednesday, the Supreme Court considered whether it should place limits on class-action settlements in which the plaintiffs’ lawyers receive millions and their clients get nothing. In the process, several justices mused about the nature of privacy in the digital age.

headline: Phylis Bamberger, Who Challenged Brutality at Attica, Dies at 79
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: As a Legal Aid lawyer, she won a suit to protect inmates who faced reprisals from guards after the deadly 1971 prison uprising. She later became a judge.
lead_paragraph: Phylis Skloot Bamberger, a lawyer who successfully sued to protect inmates from what a federal judge described as “barbarous abuse” by guards in the wake of the 1971 Attica prison uprising, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79.

headline: The Fed Is Relaxing Banking Rules. What Goodies Are the Banks Getting?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In May, Congress required the Federal Reserve to cut regulations for some well-known lenders. Not everyone is happy.
lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline: How to Clean All of Your Halloween Messes
abstract: The year’s spookiest holiday can also be its messiest.
lead_paragraph: Halloween has come and gone, what with its ghosts and goblins and Grittys, and here comes the scariest part: The cleanup. Because not only is Halloween the best holiday of them all (this is canon, don't @ us), it's also the messiest. Whether a costume mishap has befallen a favorite item of clothing, your enthusiasm for fun-sized Snickers bars has left the couch smeared with chocolate, or a gourd has gone gooey on the dining room table, this guide will help you tackle even the most terrifying Halloween messes.

headline: Overlooked No More: Miki Gorman, the Unlikely Marathon Winner
keywords: ['Marathon Running', 'Running', 'New York City Marathon', 'Boston Marathon', 'Records and Achievements', 'Women and Girls', 'Biographical Information']
abstract: Gorman at 40, was self-conscious about her body and had recently given birth when she entered the New York City Marathon. Her win made her that much more of a pioneer for women in the sport.
lead_paragraph: Since 1851, obituaries in The New York Times have been dominated by white men. With Overlooked, we’re adding the stories of remarkable people whose deaths went unreported in The Times.

headline: On the Ballot This Year: A Lot to Think About
abstract: In On Politics: Voters will decide on complex issues put on the ballot by fellow citizens; plus, a banner year for diversity, and a new poll in Steve King’s district.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Midterms, Markets, Pittsburgh: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: A Guide to the Ryan Zinke Investigations
keywords: ['Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Inspectors General', 'Casinos', 'Hatch Act (1939)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ryan Zinke has faced more than 15 ethics inquiries since taking over the Interior Department. At least six are ongoing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ryan Zinke, who intends to resign as interior secretary at year’s end, faces a number of ethics inquiries related to his leadership at the Interior Department.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things to Help You Sleep Better
abstract: First fix your habits and schedule. Then see about some gadgets.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! S.L. editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: A New Orson Welles Movie Is Coming to Netflix. These Are His Films Streaming Right Now.
abstract: “The Other Side of the Wind” stopped production in the 1970s, and its fate was long in limbo. But trouble was the norm for Welles: Here’s a brief look back.
lead_paragraph: This Friday, Netflix will debut “The Other Side of the Wind,” the long-delayed final feature from the legendary filmmaker Orson Welles. “Wind” was shot in bits and pieces between 1970 and 1976, and according to Josh Karp’s excellent history “Orson Welles’s Last Movie,” Welles spent the remaining nine years of his life attempting to complete it — an endeavor complicated by funding shortages and a bizarre battle for ownership of the footage (which has, since his death, been claimed by parties including his surviving loved ones, Showtime and the Iranian government).

headline: Voters, You’re Being Manipulated
keywords: ['Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Voting and Voters', 'Synagogues', 'Terrorism', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Trump and Fox News are trying to scare white voters into supporting Republican candidates.
lead_paragraph: When the bigot who shot up a Pittsburgh synagogue arrived at the local hospital emergency room to be treated for his injuries, he was shouting, “Kill all the Jews.” He was then promptly treated, very professionally, by three Jews.

headline: A Voter’s Guide to Health Care
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Get the facts before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: “I support forcing insurance companies to cover all pre-existing conditions,” Josh Hawley, the Republican attorney general of Missouri who’s running for the Senate against Claire McCaskill, assured voters in an emotional ad featuring his son, a kindergartner who suffers from such a condition.

headline: Victor Marchetti, 88, Dies; Book Was First to Be Censored by C.I.A.
abstract: A former employee of the agency, he ran afoul of it as co-author of a book about its inner workings. It led to a landmark First Amendment fight.
lead_paragraph: Victor Marchetti, a former C.I.A. employee and co-author of the first book, about the agency’s inner workings, that the federal government sought to censor before its publication, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Ashburn, Va. He was 88.

headline: D.J. Durkin Is Fired by Maryland a Day After Being Reinstated
abstract: On Tuesday Durkin was reinstated and the president announced he would resign, but the university reversed course and fired the coach.
lead_paragraph: The University of Maryland fired its football coach, D.J. Durkin, the university president announced Wednesday night. The news came one day after the school had said Mr. Durkin would be reinstated following an investigation into the death of a player last spring.

headline: Acclaimed French Director Is Accused of Sexual Assault
abstract: The authorities in Paris have opened a preliminary investigation into Abdellatif Kechiche, the director of “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” after an actress filed a complaint.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Abdellatif Kechiche, an acclaimed French director whose film “Blue Is the Warmest Color” won the top prize at Cannes in 2013, is under investigation for sexual assault, the authorities in Paris said on Wednesday.

headline: Once Fringe, George Soros Conspiracies Now Saturate the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: George Soros, a billionaire Democratic fund-raiser, has long been villainized in certain right-wing circles. Now conspiracy theories about him have gone mainstream, to nearly every corner of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: George Soros, a billionaire Democratic fund-raiser, has long been villainized in certain right-wing circles. Now conspiracy theories about him have gone mainstream, to nearly every corner of the Republican Party.

headline: New Migrant Caravans Trek North, Ignoring Political Repercussions
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'United States International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Inspired by an earlier caravan’s success at crossing borders, other migrants are banding together. But this is feeding anti-immigrant sentiment in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: TAPACHULA, Mexico — It was only last week that a caravan with thousands of Central American migrants hunkered down for the night here in Tapachula, in southern Mexico.

headline: How Vilification of George Soros Moved From the Fringes to the Mainstream
keywords: ['Midterm Elections (2018)', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Philanthropy', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: On both sides of the Atlantic, a loose network of nationalists has used anti-Semitic imagery to portray Mr. Soros as the shadowy leader of a globalist cabal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after he was informed last week that an explosive device had been delivered to his suburban New York home, George Soros, the billionaire investor and Democratic donor, got on a call with colleagues to discuss yet another threat: the authoritarian Hungarian government’s crackdown on a university he had founded.

headline: Google Faces Internal Backlash Over Handling of Sexual Harassment
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', '#MeToo Movement', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Workers are up in arms over how the company treated accused executives, another sign of growing employee activism at the Silicon Valley behemoth.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google is struggling to contain a growing internal backlash over its handling of sexual harassment and its workplace culture.

headline: The Neuroscience of Hate Speech
keywords: ['ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Empathy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Humans are social creatures who are easily influenced by the anger and rage that are everywhere these days.
lead_paragraph: Do politicians’ words, the president’s especially, matter?

headline: Jewish Leaders, in Call for Unity After Shooting, Welcome Outsiders to Shabbat
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Synagogues', 'Pittsburgh, Pa, Shooting (2018)', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A campaign to #ShowUpForShabbat a week after the massacre at a Pittsburgh synagogue is meant to send a message of solidarity with the Jewish community.
lead_paragraph: In preparation for the first Sabbath following the synagogue shooting in Pittsburgh, Jewish leaders are signaling that they do not plan to close off their communities out of fear.
